PROCTEXT.PARA: Madam SPEAKER (Hon. Joan Child) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to inform the House that Question Time this afternoon will be videotaped with sound for archival purposes. Edited highlights will also be available for use on news and current affairs programs by both the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and commercial television networks. I also wish to inform the House that before Question Time today I will suspend proceedings briefly to allow a panoramic photograph of members of the House to be taken.

INTERJECT.PARA: Mr Peacock-It is not the last day. We are coming back next week.

TALK.START.PARA: —The television cameras will be in the House today; so it is convenient.
—Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:

PETITION.TITLE: National Day of Prayer
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker, House of Representatives, and Parliament assembled.
`Righteousness exalts a nation,
but sin is a disgrace to any people'. Proverbs 14:34
Considering:
1. the loss of hope among the youth of the nation.
2. the breakdown of the family unit.
3. the increase of corruption in our society.
4. the increasing weight of our national debt.
5. the emerging divisions in our community.
we petition you to:
1. encourage every Australian to see his/her responsibility to live uprightly before God and others;
2. encourage commitment in marriage and encourage fathers and mothers to love and cherish their children;
3. encourage the Members of Parliament to live and legislate according to Biblical principles;
4. encourage business in Australia to pursue their transactions in generosity-without greed;
5. support the Christian Church in expressing the friendship of God, and in carrying out its practical responsibilities to the poor, needy and dispossessed,
by calling a National Day of Prayer for Australia, to seek God's help to heal our land.
We as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Aldred (from 103 citizens), Mr Fife (from 28 citizens), Mrs Harvey (from 27 citizens), Mr Rocher (from 11 citizens) and Mr Webster (from 33 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Release of Confidential Medical Information
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. We, the undersigned citizens, respectfully showeth:

That we express grave concern about the public release of confidential medical information by the Government, sufficient to enable the public identification of doctors and their patients and call upon the Parliament to censure all those involved in this gross abuse of the privacy of all Australians.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Connolly (from 64 citizens), Dr Harry Edwards (from eight citizens), Mr Shipton (from 99 citizens) and Mrs Sullivan (from 77 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Reform of Pathology Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of these pathology laboratory staff, residents of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth:
that the performance of pathology tests and the reporting of the results of pathology tests clearly constitute a scientific activity, and not a medical service;
that all Sections of the Health Insurance Act which require or presuppose the ``supervision'' of Medical Scientists in the provision of pathology services by medical practitioners should be repealed;
that Medicare provider numbers should be vested in public institutions or issued to Medical Scientists with appropriate qualifications and experience for the purpose of providing pathology services;
that the outcome of such reform would be a considerable reduction in the outlay of public money for the provision of such services;
that mechanisms should be put in place to provide the means for full consultation with the Scientific profession in all matters pertinent to the provision of pathology services.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House will support a reform of the pathology legislation in the interest of fair, equitable and rational public administration.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Dr Harry Edwards (from three citizens), Mr Jenkins (from 305 citizens) and Mr Scott (from 417 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, your humble petitioners showeth:
1. The proposed Australia Card will have a dramatic impact on the lives of all Australians.
2. Therefore your petitioners request a national referendum on the Australia Card bill before the proposal is re-submitted to Parliament.
As in duty bound your petitioners will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Ewen Cameron (from 158 citizens) and Mr Rocher (from 482 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Road Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth that:

Australians living in rural and non-urban areas rely extensively on the local road network for all facets of their lives. Funding for roads is an essential part of the Commonwealth's responsibilities for the maintenance of the transport infra-structure. Road funding under the Hawke Government has decreased significantly in real terms and local government is particularly disadvantaged by this decline.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled:

Oppose any proposal to absorb road funds into General Revenue Assistance to either Local or State Governments; and Immediately address the serious problem of a rapidly deteriorating road network which is confronting local government by allocating more resources to local road funding.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Prosser (from 435 citizens) and Mr Tuckey (from 128 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Road Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the electorate of Murray respectfully showeth that:
Australians living in rural and non-urban areas rely to a great degree on the local road network for all facets of their lives.
Funding for roads is an essential part of the Commonwealth's responsibilities for the maintenance of the transport infrastructure.
Road funding under the Hawke Government has decreased significantly in real terms and local government is particularly disadvantaged by this decline.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Immediately address the serious problem of a rapidly deteriorating road network which is confronting local government by allocating more resources to local road funding.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Crime and Violence: Television
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:

There is too much crime and violence on television and this is breaking down the standards and codes of behaviour in our society. We therefore request the House to urge television stations to improve the standards of shows, news and current affairs programmes by reducing the incidence of crime and violence broadcast every day into people's homes.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Smith (from 1,793 citizens), Mrs Sullivan (from 341 citizens), Mr Ian Cameron (from 10 citizens) and Mr Cowan (from 179 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Brisbane Airport: Flight Paths
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Canberra:

The petition of certain electors draws to the attention of the House the increase in noise pollution and the subsequent effect on the quality of life of residents in certain southern suburbs of Brisbane caused by the opening of the new Brisbane Domestic Airport.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to take steps to minimise noise levels and alter aircraft flight paths to enable a return to the lifestyle previously enjoyed by the affected residents.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Road Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain electors of the division of Indi. Draws to the attention of the House the current inadequate level of funding for road construction and maintenance and express concern that the House may have placed before it, as part of the government economic strategy, options to further reduce such expenditure, and in so doing placing an increased financial burden upon local government ratepayers.

Your petitioners therefore respectfully call upon the House to ensure an increase over current road funding levels through a clear dedication of a proportion of fuel excise collected, indexed for inflation, towards roadworks and that such funding arrangements provide for a clear and reliable method of distribution to local government.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

This humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that they are totally opposed to any change in the present Australian National Flag as declared in the Flags Act (1953).
Your petitioners humbly pray that Parliament in its wisdom will take no action to change in any way the Australian National Flag.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of The House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that whereas:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location on this planet Earth;
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. They know the Flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have became united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the Flag will produce divisions in the Australian community.

Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will propose and pass a motion that ``the existing Australian National Flag be changed only with the approval of the Nation as expressed in a Referendum.''
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectively showeth that they are totally opposed to any change in the present Australian National Flag as declared in the Flags Act (1953).
Your petitioners humbly pray that Parliament in its wisdom will take no action nor permit any action to be taken to make any change without the approval of the Australian people by referendum.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Identity Card
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth that:

The Hawke Labor Government's ID Card proposal is the most far reaching and intrusive piece of Australian legislation yet introduced, and that on all the evidence available, it will not tackle in the most cost-efficient and effective manner tax and social security fraud.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Reject Labor's ID Card proposal to prevent a gross waste of taxpayer's money and a significant infringement of civil liberties.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Identity Card
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the proposed introduction of compulsory identification cards should be reconsidered and rejected because the proposal;
Is not a cost-effective method of reducing tax evasion and social security fraud, and to the contrary, in the form proposed will facilitate such evasion and fraud,
Will constitute an unwarranted infringement of individual privacy by the aggregation of a wide variety of personal information of a private matter,
Will cause a further large and costly growth in the bureaucracy and burden on the tax payer, and
Cannot be guaranteed against misuse for purposes other than for which their introduction is stated to be intended:
And your petitioners humbly pray that the problems which identification cards are intended to reduce should be attacked by other, more effective methods.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Advertising of Alcohol
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows: We oppose the advertising of alcohol in any form.

Alcohol is recognised as Australia's number one drug problem which is responsible for at least 50% of all road fatalities; a high percentage of serious crime and vandalism. Hospital beds are filled with sufferers of the many alcohol related diseases including: cirrhosis of the liver; heart disease; stomach ulcers; various forms of cancer and mental illness. Alcohol also causes much family unhappiness and marriage breakdown, as well as being involved in some cases of child abuse and molestation.

Your petitioners request that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should ban all advertising of alcohol on television and radio because of its persuasive effects on children and young people.

PETITION.TITLE: Treatment of Sun Damaged Skin and Warts
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows that the petitioners are concerned that the Minister for Health proposes to delete from the Medical Benefits Schedule those item numbers covering the treatment of sun-damaged skin and warts by specialists. They fear that those patients suffering chronically from these problems cannot always be treated successfully by a general practitioner. They protest that they will be financially disadvantaged. They also realise that their problems require early detection and expert treatment, if the petitioners are not to be exposed to increased risk of skin and other cancers.
Your petitioners request that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should recognise our concern and permit the abovementioned items in the medical schedule to be reinstated.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament: The petition of certain citizens of Australia points out to the House-

That we welcome the Government's move in increasing the tax free threshold for pensions from $5914 to $6142 and also increasing the pension free area for married pensioners from $50 to $70 and for single pensioners from $30 to $40 per week; but we point out that-

(1) The $250 pensioner rebate which cuts out completely if a pensioner earns more than $8142 in a year, does not provide complete tax relief to those pensioners who earn above the $6142 tax free threshold, and
(2) Those pensioners in receipt of income earnings which take them above the tax threshold are therefore not enjoying the benefits of their full income.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to adjust the pensioner tax free threshold by increasing the $250 ``pensioner-rebate'' as a matter of urgency.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensioners: Provisional Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable The Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in parliament:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia points out to the House-
The hardship that provisional tax is imposing on pensioners who are assessed by the Australian Taxation Office and must pay provisional tax.
Your petitioners therefore request that the House exempt all pensioners from paying provisional tax.

PETITION.TITLE: Gymea Bay Post Office, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable The Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we strenuously object to the proposal that the Post Office at Gymea Bay be closed. The Post Office serves a community need and we would be seriously inconvenienced by having to travel to another centre for our postal requirements, or even to collect registered letters and parcels, cash Pension cheques and transact banking. Many of us are Pensioners and the cost of such travel would be an unnecessary imposition. The nearest Post Office is 2.3 kms away with no convenient transport.

We maintain that the purpose of the Post Offices should be to serve the public for the variety of services they offer, and that they should not be closed merely to save money or help Australia Post make a profit.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House should take all possible steps to prevent the closure of Gymea Bay Post Office.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable The Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in parliament:

The petition of certain Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders, who are residents of the State of Queensland, draws to the attention of the House the objections of Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders to the proposed Arrangements for the Assistance of Aboriginal Students in 1989, by the Department of Employment, Education and Training. These proposed changes, as of April 13, 1988, are outlined below.
1. Under 16 year old at-home students

No Living Allowance payments will be made under ABSEC or ABSTUDY for these students. For Aboriginal students only, the Department of Social Security (DSS) will pay an Education Allowance of $10.00 pw to the Family Allowance Supplement (FAS).
2. Under 16 year old away-from-home students
These students may apply for AIC which will be income-tested and indexed. Students who do not qualify under AIC will be paid under ABSEC, but the 1988 rate will not be indexed.
3. Students 16 years and over
New applicants will be required to apply for AUSTUDY and be subject to the AUSTUDY income test. There will be special provisions in AUSTUDY for Aboriginal students, including
* wider range of courses approved for assistance
* $30 pw supplement for students 21 years and over in Category A courses
Continuing students may apply for AUSTUDY (with the special provisions) or remain with ABSEC or ABSTUDY which will not be income tested or endorsed.
4. ABSEC and ABSTUDY in 1989

In 1989 ABSEC and ABSTUDY will not be income tested but also will not be indexed and thus will be paid at the 1988 rates. The only students who can receive Living Allowance from ABSEC or ABSTUDY in 1989 will be continuing students 16 and over and students living away from home who are under 16. However, even these students may choose to apply for AUSTUDY which will be income tested, but will have higher rates because of indexation.
5. Direct Education Assistance

All secondary and post secondary Aboriginal students will continue to be eligible for Direct Education Assistance (tutorial, excursions, orientation visits, etc.). This includes students who are supported by AUSTUDY, AIC or the DSS Education Supplement and those who may be income tested out of AUSTUDY, AIC or the DSS Education Supplement.
6. Continuing Students
Some continuing students will not retain their 1988 rate of Living Allowance, namely-
* 18-20 AH and 21-24 AH Category B course students receive $75 pw in 1988, but will receive the AUSTUDY rate of $60 pw in 1989.

* 21 year old and over Category A course students will receive a supplement of $30 pw above AUSTUDY rates in 1988 but in 1989 this will only be paid as a supplement to AUSTUDY for students who meet the income test.
The reasons for our strong objection being the possible consequences:
1. Means testing:

A] will disadvantage Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander families, in that it will create confusion, disillusionment and misunderstanding, as a majority of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders are not familiar with the administrative procedures of the various government departments which they will have to deal with.

B] will only take up unnecessary time and cost, as according to the 1986 Census of Population and Housing, conducted by the Bureau of Statistics, approximately 46% of Queensland Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders earn between $14,976 and $21,892 per annum, not to mention the 17% who are `not started', and the 3% who have spouse(s) that are temporarily absent, whom means testing may not even effect; as AUSTUDY means testing begins at $16,000 per annum, for one student.

2. Enrolment attendance and retention rates of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander students will fall, as a consequence of the above mentioned misunderstandings. Particularly when parents find they may have to pay for their children's educational needs, up-front in some cases, before being reimbursed. Especially families with more than one child, and those who live on isolated communities with children attending boarding schools in various parts of Queensland.

3. Families who choose to send their children to Catholic Education Institutions will be disadvantaged due to their higher school costs. Therefore may have to withdraw their children from their preferred schools.

4. Problems of racial conflict be created amongst all those eligible for AUSTUDY, as the extra benefits which will be given to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander students will be seen as `special treatment', by the wider community.
5. The changes to ABSEC and AUSTUDY can only serve as a hindrance, and contradiction to the Aboriginal Employment Development Policy of 1987, which states:

``The Government's specific long-term objective concerning education and formal training is to increase the participation in primary, secondary and tertiary education, and in formal training courses, until comparability with the rest of the Australian population is reached.''
Your petitioners therefore request the House to not allow the abovementioned changes, and the move towards AUSTUDY.

PETITION.TITLE: Nursing Homes
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned electors showeth:

That any proposed redistribution of funds for Nursing and Personal Care staff costs in Nursing Homes will detrimentally affect the quality of care given in Nursing Homes in South Australia and the quality of life of the residents in those Nursing Homes. The Outcome Standards for Nursing Homes, so recently established, will not be achieved and elderly people will not receive the standards of care or quality of life that they need.

Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will raise the funding level for Nursing and Personal Care staff hours for all States to enable at least the number of hours of care for Nursing Home residents in South Australia to be achieved by all States.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: War Veterans Benefits
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned members of the War Veterans' community and concerned citizens respectfully showeth:

That there has been continuous, substantial and damaging erosion of war veterans' benefits and services since May of 1985 in the areas of: the deletion of the dependants' pension; the removal from the Department of Veterans' Affairs repatriation schedule pharmaceuticals of war widows, their dependants and service pensioners; a reduction in dental benefits; the deletion of the ten per cent disability pension assessment previously allowed when glasses were prescribed; the restriction on the issue of glasses and other associated losses in benefits to partially blind veterans; the lack of protection in the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 for intermediate or special rate pension rates disability pensions; the loss of benefits in respect of reimbursement of substantial costs incurred in obtaining medical opinion in support of a claim or an application; the means testing of the war veterans' children education scheme; the deletion of the intellectually handicapped dependants' allowance; the termination of the defence re-establishment agricultural and loans schemes; the loss of the automatic right of admission to private hospitals without prior approval of a DMO; the imposition of a nursing home patient contribution rate for war veterans who are resident in nursing homes or who are receiving psychiatric treatment for war related disabilities; the abolition of the defence service home loan scheme; reductions in the allowances of skin care, podiatry and physiotherapy treatments; and abuses in the use of information supplied by war veterans in responses to life-style questionnaires; vicious cuts in pharmaceuticals and denial of repeat prescriptions.

That it is cruel and cynical of the Government to treat war veterans, many of whom are now advanced in age, in declining health and vulnerable, as expendable and unworthy of optimum care and benefits, when they and their comrades gave of their utmost to this country in its times of greatest need;

Now, therefore your petitioners request that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled pass appropriate legislation to reverse the decisions of the Government which have brought about the erosion of war veterans' benefits and services.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Casino, Australian Capital Territory
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
(1) That we are totally opposed to the proposal for the establishment of a gambling casino in Canberra or the Australian Capital Territory.
(2) That a casino in Canberra would detract from the unique character and status of our National Capital.
Your petitioners therefore most humbly request the House of Representatives to reject any proposal or legislation which would permit the establishment of a casino in the Australian Capital Territory.
And your humble petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Road Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament Assembled
The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia respectively showeth-
That there is a general dissatisfaction in the community at the levels of road funding made available by the Federal Government.
While noting the commitment of the Government to maintain a high standard of roads in Australia, we are specifically concerned at the real cutbacks for road funding in the Local Government area.
We especially note that roadworks are a labour intensive industry and cutbacks will create unemployment and hardship in rural areas.
Your petitioners request that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, give due consideration to increasing the amount of funds available to Local Government authorities for roadworks.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Gold Mining
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament. The petition of certain residents of the State of Victoria draws to the attention of the House:
The tax exemption for Gold Miners, Gold Partnership and Gold Mining Companies.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the House withdraw the exemption provisions provided to taxpayers (Gold Miners, Gold Mining Partnerships, Gold Mining Companies) Under section 23 (o) of the Australian Income Tax Assessment Act.

PETITION.TITLE: 1988 Jack High Bowling Tournament
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Member of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

1. The decision by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation not to televise the Jack High Bowling Tournament in 1988 is cause for distress to the 500,000 bowlers and many non bowlers who, for years, have enjoyed this interesting programme on television.

2. The unilateral decision was taken after verbal assurances had been given that the 1988 event would be televised. This action is deplored and we feel should be reversed by the parliament in the interests of your many constituents.

PETITION.TITLE: Commonwealth Owned Land, Buckland Hill, Western Australia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth that we believe the Commonwealth owned land at Buckland Hill should be retained as public open space so as to recognise-
(i) its premier status in Perth's European heritage as the place of Willem de Vlamingh's landing in 1697,
(ii) its historically established identity as an open area since being the first site considered for the Swan River settlement in 1827, and
(iii) its importance for the future recreational needs of the people in an area already under pressure for high density residential development.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House urge the Government to:
1. Confer ownership of the Buckland Hill land upon the people of Western Australia as a Bicentennial gift.

2. Require as a condition of that gift that the land be reserved by the Government of Western Australia as inalienable public open space for the future benefit of the people of this State and the nation.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth that:
The fringe benefits tax will cause hardship to business throughout Australia, especially in the already severely-depressed rural sector and in the motor vehicle industry.
The fringe benefits tax will be a disincentive to employment and worse, will result in additional unemployment.

The economy of this country would best be served by policies that lightened the tax burden, not increased it, that encouraged enterprise, not stifled it and stimulated growth, development and jobs, not prevented it.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House will repeal this Legislation and your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Importation of Dumped Cement
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The humble petition of the employees of the Australian cement industry in Geelong and concerned citizens respectfully showeth their concern for the adverse effect on employment and the local economy if dumped cement is imported into Australia from overseas.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House will take all steps appropriate and necessary to prevent the importation of dumped cement into Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: Chlorofluorocarbons
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully requests that the Federal Parliament objects in the strongest possible terms to the use of chlorofluorocarbons as being detrimental to the ozone layer.
Your petitioners therefore pray that steps be taken to end the use of chlorofluorocarbons.

PETITION.TITLE: Food Irradiation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

The petition of certain citizens in Australia, draws to the attention of the House that the irradiation of food by any means degrades the nutritional value of food and is potentially harmful to the health of all consumers and to the environment.
Your petitioners therefore request that your honourable House:
1. Withdraw from the Asian Regional Co-operative Project on Food Irradiation and from the International Consultative Group on Food Irradiation.
2. Take all possible steps to prevent and disallow the irradiation of food in Australia.
3. Ban the export and importation of irradiated foods and animal feeds.
4. Take steps to obtain a testing device to make possible the identification of irradiated foods, as soon as one becomes available.

PETITION.TITLE: Telephone Services, Bredbo
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth: that there is great concern in the level of service currently offered by Telecom Australia in the Bredbo and surrounding districts; that this level of service is such that there is considerable unacceptable delays in the connection of new services; that there is unacceptable regular delays in the connection of calls; that there is unacceptable difficulties in the use of the Public Telephone in Bredbo; that these matters are causing personal hardship and the community is at risk in the cases of emergencies.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should: request Telecom to take immediate action to upgrade all aspects of telephone service in the Bredbo and surrounding districts.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding for Canberra to Batemans Bay Road
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully shows:
Grave concern with the insufficient level of Government grants provided for carrying out improvements to the Canberra/Batemans Bay (MR51) Road.

Your petitioners therefore pray that your House will call upon the Government to take whatever steps are necessary to allow for and provide special substantial direct funding to carry out the necessary improvements to the road, and, further, call upon the New South Wales State Government to accept greater financial responsibility for the upgrading and maintenance of the said road.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will every pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Concession on Fly Fishing Reels
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

The petition of certain residents of the State of Victoria being members of the Sunshine Fly Casting Club based in the electorate of Calwell, draws to the attention of the House that the Tariffs Concession Branch of the Australian Customs Service has revoked the tariff concession formerly applicable to fly fishing reels. As a result the import duty will rise from 2% to 25%.

Although some types of fishing reels are manufactured in Australia, fly fishing reels are not. Fly fishing reels are a distinct type of reel which represent a totally separate segment of the fishing reel market. As there is no Australian industry to protect we respectfully submit that there is no case for imposing this duty.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House re-instate the former tariff concession on fly fishing reels.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare Benefits
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully beseech that:
Parliament allow insurance for the gap between the Medicare rebate and the scheduled fee.
That the unfair discrimination against private patients in hospital be withdrawn.

Your petitioners humbly request that all patients receive an equal Medicare rebate for services regardless of where they are provided, on the understanding that all patients pay the same compulsory Medicare insurance levy.
And your petitions, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON EMPLOYMENT, EDUCATION AND TRAINING

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sullivan Mrs K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, on behalf of the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training I present the report of the inquiry on entry or return to the work force for social security pensioners, together with the minutes of proceedings.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —This report concerns itself with Government policy of the last 12 to 18 months. That policy has reflected a community concern about the growing numbers of people in Australia who are dependent on welfare and about an attempt to move those people to independence through employment. The Committee strongly supports those policies. The inquiry concerned itself particularly with cost-effective means of achieving Government policy objectives. It concerned itself particularly with those long term out of the work force. That phrase `long term unemployed' is used to refer to those who have been two years out of the work force but not necessarily on unemployment benefits. In the course of the inquiry, the Committee discovered that there were many barriers to these people re-entering the work force in line with Government policies and that they needed help. Numbers of them in particular groups have particular needs and will need particular measures of help.

SPEECH.PARA: Essentially, the inquiry uncovered the legacy of attitudes of past decades. That legacy has been reflected in previous governments' policies. There has been a conflict in that legacy with the imperatives of the last decade of the twentieth century. Those factors have affected particularly those who have been long term unemployed. When I refer to the legacy of the attitudes of past decades, the particular aspects with which the inquiry has concerned itself have been the low average education levels in this society, the lack of previous attention to problems of illiteracy, the issue of female dependence and a lack of understanding of cultural conflicts which present themselves in Australia today.

There have been figures available for some time about the low average education levels in Australia. In particular, there have been figures available about the even lower average education levels of those people who are on social welfare, in whatever category. For several years those who have been concerned with illiteracy have been trying to inform the Australian community that this is a real and a wide problem. In the course of the Committee's inquiries we continually encountered evidence of the effect of neglect of attention to the subject of community literacy on people who are dependent on welfare.

A notion of female dependence which prevailed in the past was based on certain assumptions and led to certain consequences. It has had the result that the average level of women's education in Australia is lower than the average level of education of men. The report contains detailed statistics comparing the position of women and men, particularly sole parents and those in two-parent families who are on welfare. It shows a very dramatic difference and a very strong need. Because of assumptions that women would be dependent on their husbands in their adult lives, previous generations did not give attention to the education and training of girls, nor did they pay much attention to the work force skills that they entered the work force with, on the assumption that women would be needed only short term and would never have the responsibility of supporting a family. Of course, those assumptions have been shown to be badly founded as a result of social change in the last 15 years.

In the case of Aborigines and non-English speaking migrants, there has been a lack of understanding of the cultural conflicts between the prevailing Australian culture and theirs. Indeed, in the past there was a lack of tolerance of those conflicts. That lack of understanding has manifested itself in a much higher rate of social security dependence by those groups. These people now face the imperatives of the age of technology when highly developed skills are needed, redundancies in industry come quickly and adults have great difficulty in getting access to retraining. That has all been compounded by social change which means that people who were educated perhaps 20 years ago now find themselves in a position which they never expected and which, certainly, they were not prepared for by any of the structures of previous years. Nevertheless, in saying all that I pay tribute to the attempts that the Government has made to move towards solving those problems. The policies it has put in place certainly have been moves in the right direction.

The Government has in place certain access and equity policies. It is unfortunate that those access and equity principles have not been observed in recent times. The periods with which the Committee was particularly concerned were those involving changes resulting from the 1986 Budget and the 1987 May economic statement. We received a great deal of information about what had happened to recipients of supporting parent's benefit and widows' pensions as a result of changes announced in those two important policy documents.

It was not surprising that a great deal of the information received by the inquiry related to women because the overwhelming majority of recipients of supporting parent's benefit and, of course, all recipients of the widow's pension are female. Those two groups which were particularly affected by the changes of 1986-87 showed dramatically how good intentions can go wrong. I will quickly describe to the House the effect of those changes. Essentially, after being eligible for benefits, all recipients of supporting parent's benefit and widow's pension had to report regularly to social security for, we were told, an assessment of their continuing eligibility and for counselling on how they might prepare themselves for an ultimate return to the work force. Several months later, in the May economic statement, there was a change of eligibility for those two forms of welfare. Those recipients whose youngest dependent child had reached the age of 16 years were transferred unceremoniously from their existing benefit to unemployment benefit and found themselves in a catch-22 situation.

I particularly recommend Appendix 6 in the report, which is a long, very lucid letter from a male supporting parent who had attempted to assist himself and who had embarked on a course of education which was designed to get him effectively back into the work force with reasonable support when his youngest child had finished high school. Terminating of the benefit when that child was at the age of 16 years completely wrecked what had been well laid and very intelligent plans.

The changes revealed a conflict of government policies. The Government has stated that it is a major objective to raise the average education levels of Australians, and that is to be welcomed. However, removing the sole parent's benefit when the youngest child reaches the age of 16 years is in conflict with that policy. It has meant that many of those children have had to leave school before finishing their high schooling and go into dead-end jobs or perhaps onto social welfare when their parents could no longer financially cope because of the lower support given to unemployment beneficiaries.

The 1986 Budget change to Austudy given to sole parents also had a dramatic effect. Many of these beneficiaries found their weekly income from Austudy reduced from $38 to $15 and they simply could not continue with tertiary education. The inquiry also revealed a lack of awareness of the profile of the group-an awareness which should have been there because statistics on these subjects have been available for a long time, particularly in relation to education levels and previous work force participation. It revealed a lack of coordination between departments-the Department of Social Security (DSS) and the Commonwealth Employment Service (CES) in particular-and within departments it showed that the counselling referred to in the 1986 Budget simply was never implemented by the Department of Social Security. It revealed poor communication on some occasions with those affected, and it revealed that the approach of the Department of Finance to issues such as those is arbitrary and not well founded.

The solutions that the Committee suggests cover a wide range of issues. The report strongly recommends a shift away from passive Government support of social security recipients towards active encouragement by Government agencies to help them get jobs. As a first step, there needs to be better communication between social security recipients and Government agencies.

An upgrading of DSS and CES counselling services and of the CES role, improved co-ordination between Federal and State activities and recognition of the value of programs which utilise peer group support are basic requirements for a policy of work force re-entry to be effective.

More short training courses, literacy programs and preparatory employment courses, and improved access to post-secondary and tertiary education generally, are necessary to improve welfare recipients' employability. The report also recommends expansion of the Australia traineeship system, and encouraging employers to be more active in training and retraining their employees.

In summary, the report provides a cost-effective framework for reducing social security recipients' dependence on welfare and for increasing their work force participation, with consequent benefits to individuals and the nation. I recommend the contents of the report to the Government and to all those who are interested in the welfare of this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jakobsen Ms C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pleasure to follow the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan) in this debate today. She and I have worked very closely in writing the report which has now been tabled. We have also, in the course of the inquiry by the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training, worked very hard to consider the evidence and discuss the report. As Chairman of the sub-committee she has worked particularly hard.

SPEECH.PARA: In line with the inquiry's terms of reference, the report concentrates on methods of facilitating entry or return to the work force by social security recipients. Obviously not all social security recipients are likely to be seeking full-time employment, and the report has tended to concentrate on people in receipt of unemployment benefit, widow's pension, supporting parent's benefit, invalid pension, and sickness benefit as the main groups concerned. Importantly, the report acknowledges that long term dependence on social welfare carries considerable costs for both the people concerned and the society in which they live.

Not surprisingly, it recognises that obtaining paid employment is the most effective means of attaining financial independence, contributing more to the community and increasing the self-esteem of individuals. The report therefore recommends measures which will encourage and support long-term unemployed people in their search for work or in pursuit of additional skills which will enhance their employability.

Even before we commenced the inquiry it was obvious to some members of the Committee that there would be a large number of submissions from, or on behalf of, supporting parents who had been affected by last year's May statement decision, as has already been mentioned by the honourable member for Moncrieff. It also seemed apparent that there would be a deal of criticism concerning the lack of liaison between the Commonwealth Employment Service (CES) and the Department of Social Security (DSS), as well as their respective communications with long term unemployed people seeking work. Suffice it to say that we were not disabused of these opinions during the inquiry, and much of the evidence pursued those particular themes to a greater or lesser extent.

As a consequence, several recommendations addressed the problems confronted by supporting parents who had to transfer to unemployment benefit, and several others suggested ways in which the role of the DSS or CES could be improved. We also received evidence from a wide variety of other groups presenting a great diversity of views and opinions on ways and means of assisting social security recipients into education, training or employment.

Although unemployment can be equated with a lack of jobs, the inquiry ascertained that other factors also presented barriers to access to the jobs available for many of the people who are currently in receipt of social security income support. These were seen as lack of training, lack of child care, poverty traps or economic disincentives, costs of employment and training and attitudinal barriers in the community at large. Many social security recipients suffer all these disadvantages and more. For instance, Aborigines, non-English speaking migrants and disabled people, as well as women, have particular attitudinal problems to deal with in the community.

Particularly interesting in the light of common misconceptions in the wider community were some statistics relating to supporting parents, that is, that more than 14 per cent of Australian families have only one parent and more than 80 per cent of these receive Commonwealth Government income support. The average duration for receipt by men of the supporting parent benefit is 2.9 years, with 32.9 per cent receiving it for one year or less, 48.8 per cent for one to five years, and a further 18.3 per cent receiving it for five years or more. The average duration for receipt of the supporting parent benefit by men is 2.15 years, with 41.7 per cent receiving it for one year or less, 46.4 per cent for one to five years, and 11.9 per cent for five years or more. I thought it was important to make these comparisons because many people believe that women are on the supporting parent benefit for a very long time.

From my point of view the recommendations of special interest to the Committee are those relating to the return to work allowance, which was recommended in recognition of the lack of financial resources of most long term unemployed people, including women, and their need to pay for appropriate clothing, transport and child-care costs as a preliminary to getting into the work force. The extension of eligibility for the supporting parent benefit while the youngest child is in secondary school was another important recommendation, as were preparatory courses such as new opportunities for women, for those people who are trying to get into the work force after having been out of it for a long time.
I thank the Chairman once again and all members of the Committee. I thank the secretariat for its assistance. I commend the report to the Government and to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brumby Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish in the time remaining to make a few brief comments about the report of the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training. As Chairman of the Committee, it is my pleasure to endorse the report. I compliment the subcommittee and its staff on bringing together this report on what is a very complex issue in such a short time span. Over the last five years many jobs, full time and part time, have been generated in the Australian economy. But, despite the growth in jobs, there are still far too many people in our community who depend on the social security system for income and who have great difficulty in entering or re-entering the work force.

SPEECH.PARA: The thrust of the Committee's report has been to identify ways of increasing work force participation amongst people who are in receipt of the unemployment benefit, widows pension, supporting parent's benefit, invalid pension or sickness benefit. The report highlights the benefits to the community in general and to individuals of having a paid job. Employment is very highly valued in our community. The level of income earned is a key determinant of an individual's social status and lifestyle choice. Most importantly, though, as we say in this report, a job is the most important factor in reducing poverty.

The report identifies a number of barriers which face social security recipients wishing to enter training and/or paid employment. The major barriers include a lack of access to education, training and retraining programs: difficulty in obtaining adequate and affordable child-care; poverty traps which are caused by the interplay of the social security and taxation system; and a lack of knowledge or understanding of relevant social security and Commonwealth Employment Service (CES) programs.

To reduce these barriers and to actively assist social security recipients to enter or re-enter the work force, the Committee has recommended what I think is a comprehensive range of measures designed to encourage that transition in a very positive way. There are numerous recommendations in this report but the major ones relate to the need to upgrade the counselling and information services of the Department of Social Security and the CES, to expand programs such as job clubs and now-new opportunities for women-courses, to increase the number and range of short term training courses and literacy programs, to improve access to technical and further education (TAFE) and tertiary education and to expand the Australian traineeship system.

A particular focus of the report is the special needs of certain groups. I mention in particular the long term unemployed. In February of this year 90,000 or more Australians had been out of work for two years or more. It is my view and the Committee's view that this is an unacceptably high level. For those who have been out of work for this period the Committee recommends that additional measures are necessary to assist work force re-entry. We refer particularly to the need to remove financial disincentives to paid employment through the payment of a return to work allowance and the extension of fringe benefits.

One of the key issues that came to our attention in preparing this report and a report on higher education tabled by this Committee last week was the vital role that education and training play in our community and the shortage of opportunities and lack of access for many people in our community to adequate training, TAFE and higher education programs. We mention it in this report.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT COMMITTEE ON THE NATIONAL CRIME AUTHORITY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleeland Mr P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority, I present the report of the Committee on witness protection.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Section 34 of the National Crime Authority Act 1984 provides that the Authority may make arrangements for the protection of witnesses appearing at hearings before the Authority. The National Crime Authority has expressed the view that it does not have sufficient resources to set up its own witness protection scheme and that there are significant deficiencies in the facilities for the protection of witnesses available in Australia. The Committee decided in April 1987 to pursue an inquiry into witness protection in Australia. The Chairman at that time was the honourable member for Maribyrnong (Mr Griffiths). It should be recognised that the Committee under his chairmanship was very much responsible for establishing the framework under which the Committee now works. It indicates that it would examine the nature of witness protection and its role in the fight against organised crime; the extent to which witness protection is an essential requirement of successful organised criminal investigation and prosecutions; the extent to which organised crime witnesses are presently protected and the nature, adequacy and cost of current arrangements; and the options available to the Government to improve witness protection.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee took evidence not only from government and academic sources, but also from witnesses who had been or were under protection themselves. Information from informers is responsible for the detection of the greater part of crime. This is particularly so in the case of the so-called `victimless' or `consensual' crimes in which organised criminal groups specialise such as drug trafficking, illegal gambling, the sale of pornography, organised prostitution and usury, where there is unlikely to be a complainant.

While the history of intimidation of witnesses in this country is not as extensive or as colourful as that in the United States of America, there is ample evidence to suggest that minor figures suspected of cooperating with the police will be murdered or assaulted to prevent them testifying. Confidential witnesses before the Committee told of constant harassment, physical attacks on them and their families and `contracts' on their lives. Moreover, a single example well known within the criminal community, such as the murders of Douglas and Isabel Wilson, gives the `enforcers' a powerful psychological edge when they come to threaten other potential witnesses.

The Committee considers that society has an obligation to protect all witnesses, not merely witnesses against organised criminal groups. However, the need for protection is greater in the case of witnesses in this latter class because organised criminal groups habitually resort to the violent intimidation of witnesses in order to avoid detection and punishment. Moreover, the arrangements for the protection of such witnesses will need to be more elaborate and may need to continue after the trial is over, in some cases for the rest of the witnesses' lives.

Although it has been suggested that the provision of effective protection will induce more witnesses against organised criminal groups to come forward, the Committee has concluded that protection is less an inducement to give evidence than a consequence of giving evidence. Many of the witnesses to whom the Committee spoke might not be alive today were it not for the protection that has now been provided.

In the context of the fight against organised crime it is clearly in the interests of the state to provide protection to witnesses. Without such protection the principals of organised criminal groups will not be brought to trial. It is in this sense that the provision of effective witness protection is of primary importance in the investigation and prosecution of organised criminal activity.

The Committee has examined the arrangements for witness protection in the United States, the United Kingdom, Canada and West Germany, and it has drawn together a detailed account of the present arrangements for witness protection in Australia. Despite progress made since the National Crime Authority first raised its concerns, problems remain with the witness protection arrangements in this country. In particular there are still difficulties with relocating witnesses across State boundaries. There is a lack of coordination and cooperation between forces and a lack of awareness, even within forces, of the witness protection arrangements which are available.

Although witnesses are presently living under new names in this country, only rudimentary attempts have been made to establish mechanisms whereby those new names can be entered into official and commercial records without compromising the witnesses' security. There are witnesses living under new names who cannot obtain social security benefits, who cannot file taxation returns and whose drivers licences would not withstand close scrutiny.

The Committee has rejected the option of a national witness protection scheme run by a new, independent agency as a solution to these problems. The Committee believes that there is insufficient demand to justify the costs associated with the creation of such an agency. Instead, the Committee recommends that a National Witness Protection Liaison Committee be established under the auspices of the Australian Police Ministers Council to provide a forum for coordination and cooperation between the eight police forces in the provision of witness protection and that the Australian Federal Police should assume an expanded national witness protection role.

The Committee stresses that the decision to provide protection to any witness should be preceded by an assessment of the credibility of the witness and an evaluation of the importance of the evidence which he or she purports to be able to give. The response provided by a witness protection scheme must be flexible, depending on the assessed level of threat. In less serious cases it may be possible simply to provide increased protection for the witness in his or her own home. In a small number of cases, however, police forces will not be able to guarantee the safety of the witnesses if they remain in their own homes and will recommend more drastic measures. In such cases the Committee considers that relocation under a new identity should be adopted as the preferred method of protection. The use of 24-hour guarding in a `safe house' is obviously unsuitable as a long term method of post-trial protection. In addition it imposes unacceptable pressures both on the witness and on his or her protectors, and it is resource intensive and prohibitively expensive.

The Australian Federal Police Witness Protection Branch already has considerable experience in the protection of witnesses by relocation. It provides protection on a user pays basis to witnesses from one State police force and the National Crime Authority and this service could be extended to other agencies which have not as yet felt the need to develop their own services capable of providing long-term protection to witnesses. At the same time the proposed National Witness Protection Liaison Committee may provide a forum for the development of arrangements for the relocation of witnesses across State boundaries by the State police forces. It could also facilitate the interchange of information concerning contacts in State and Federal agencies and non-governmental bodies who can assist in the relocation process.

Relocation should be viewed as a last resort. Other alternatives should be considered first. The agency providing protection should assess the need for protection and the suitability of the witness for relocation. This assessment should include a psychological evaluation. Before being accepted into the witness protection scheme the witness and any adult family members should be required to read over and sign a memorandum of understanding detailing the assistance which the agency undertakes to provide and the conditions under which assistance will be terminated. The agency arranging the relocation of a protected witness should provide accommodation at the new locality. The witness should be assisted in finding employment and an allowance should be paid to meet rent, living expenses, medical and dental bills and other incidental costs until such time as the witness obtains employment.

Immediately upon the acceptance of the witness into the scheme the agency should initiate the necessary steps to accomplish a secure change of name and the Committee considers that complementary State and Federal legislation is necessary to provide a mechanism to achieve this. Such legislation should also indemnify persons acting in an official capacity who alter records or issue documents to reflect the new identity of a protected witness. It should also create a criminal offence where a person compromises the security of a protected witness by revealing details of his or her change of identity. Where presently unavailable, appropriate complaints mechanisms should be established so that there is an avenue of review for witnesses who believe that they have been unjustly denied protection or who are aggrieved by decisions made by the agency protecting them, including decisions to terminate any assistance being provided to them.

Complementary State and Federal legislation should also give clear legislative authority for the protection of witnesses by relocation. It should set out mechanisms whereby protected witnesses may be prevented from evading their civil obligations and from avoiding obligations imposed on them by the Family Court. It should ensure that, if a protected witness commits a crime, the witness's criminal record under his or her old identity will be revealed to the responsible investigative agency. The Committee envisages that this could be achieved by the establishment of a central secure register, maintained by the National Witness Protection Liaison Committee, recording each case in Australia where a change of identity has been accomplished for the purpose of witness protection, together with details of the criminal record of the person concerned under his or her old identity. Finally, complementary State and Federal legislation should establish procedures whereby the hearing of cases in which protected witnesses are to testify--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My comments in relation to the tabling of this report will be necessarily brief. I congratulate the staff of the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority (NCA) who worked such long and arduous hours to produce what I believe is a first-class report which provides a blueprint for the rationalisation, indeed in some aspects the establishment, of a witness protection scheme in Australia. As the report so adequately summarises, the need for witness protection cannot be doubted for one moment. It was the mechanics of such a scheme which occupied so much of the time and effort of the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: I am confident, as is the Chairman of the Committee, the honourable member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland), that a number of the practical aspects and difficulties surrounding the witness protection scheme, such as relocation after evidence has been given, have been addressed. They have not necessarily been solved in all of their aspects because, quite frankly, it is not possible to set out an all-encompassing document to overcome every possible contingency, given that witness protection involves human contingencies and variations. One of the most telling points made during the hearings was that it is impossible to estimate properly and plan for all the variations in character and circumstances; there needs to be some inbuilt flexibility in any overall scheme.

I am pleased, as I am sure my fellow Committee members are, that this report can now be tabled in the Parliament, because it is long overdue. Whilst we have made great advances in the fight against organised crime in recent years, with the establishment of the NCA and the conferring on it of coercive powers and with a range of legislative measures which have been introduced into this chamber by the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) over the past 12 months-all those measures aid in the fight against organised crime-no-one has any misconception that we are winning that fight. The best we can say is that an impression upon it is being made. But it will be some time yet before there is tangible evidence of a turning of the tide of corruption in this country.

As the Chairman pointed out, the Committee envisages that we can establish a central secure register, maintained by a National Witness Protection Liaison Committee, which can record in each case a change of identity. That is terribly important because the great fear that many of us have is that where a witness is given protection and an indemnity to testify against co-conspirators, after the completion of that evidence, with all the advantages that a new identity provides, the person will commit more crimes, even graver crimes. We do not ever want the witness protection scheme to become a haven for criminals and to provide them with a new means of identity by which to further their criminal careers. The Committee faced that problem full on. We believe that any person who commits a further crime under the guise of the witness protection scheme should not be protected from his previous record; therefore, that person's record of criminality should be brought to the attention of the sentencing judge.

Given the absence of any Commonwealth prisons, obviously it is inappropriate to contemplate a national scheme for the protection of custodial witnesses, except-I stress `except'-through greater consultation on the issue between the various corrective services administrations. That is terribly important. The New South Wales Government may be prepared to permit its witness protection unit at Long Bay gaol to be used as a national facility for the protection of custodial witnesses whose evidence has national ramifications, but it would be necessary, in the first instance, to amend the complementary legislation relating to the interstate transfer of prisoners specifying the protection of a custodial witness as a ground for transfer.

The Committee is generally satisfied with the adequacy of the protection provided to custodial witnesses. However, we recommend that the fact that such witnesses serve their sentences under harsher conditions than would otherwise be the case should be taken into account in making decisions concerning their release on licence or parole. Further, custodial witnesses need to be assured that their families are being protected and arrangements should be made to ensure that that occurs. It is of fundamental concern to witnesses who are prepared to testify in criminal trials that their families receive the same degree of protection that they themselves do. Time and again witnesses whom we interviewed and took evidence from made that point. Custodial witnesses should be given clear undertakings as to the arrangements proposed for their protection on release.

I thank Mr Giles Short, the secretary to the parliamentary committee overseeing the National Crime Authority, and his very able assistant, John Carter. The tabling of this report provides me-I know that I speak for my colleagues-with a great deal of satisfaction. It will be of much assistance to law enforcement agencies in rationalising and setting down in print, for the first time, a national scheme so as to provide greater efficiency and better protection for those who come forward and thereby offer an inducement to, even inject new confidence in, those who are prepared to testify for the Crown in serious criminal cases. I commend the report to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a non-lawyer, probably one of the few, if not the only non-lawyer on the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority, it was a fascinating experience for me to have the opportunity of learning more about the way the legal system operates in practice and of speaking to some of the people who are being protected at present. I underline the remarks of my colleague the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) about the concern that witnesses under protection have for their families. We tend to think that a protected witness is concerned solely with his or her own safety. However, as my colleague mentioned, time and again witnesses made it very clear to us that they were more concerned about what was happening or may happen to their families rather than to themselves. That is an area which must be considered closely in any future decisions taken by the appropriate authorities.

SPEECH.PARA: In recent times we have had tragic evidence of the concern that potential witnesses feel in relation to major issues that may come to the attention of the public. The tragic suicide in Victoria recently of a potential witness before the National Crime Authority brought home to all of us in very stark form the pressure under which those people find themselves. Many citizens have the attitude that most protected witnesses are themselves under some conviction for a criminal offence and, therefore, in a sense they deserve everything they get. But the fact remains that if we are to combat effectively a lot of this organised crime, the services of such people need to be available and proper protection apparatus put in place.

I found the Committee's inquiry most fascinating. I think that the Committee's recommendations are practical, which is an important aspect of all governmental recommendations. The people involved with the Committee's work need to be thanked for the time and persistent effort they put into assisting the Committee. On behalf of the Committee, I wish to pass on my thanks, in particular, to Mr Peter O'Keefe and Mr Giles Short and the present and former research officers, Mr John Carter and Ms Rosa Ferranda. I also acknowledge the indefatigable work of the Committee's steno-secretary, Chris Migus. Without the support of such officers, this Committee and other committees simply could not get the job done. It is an important area and I think that the recommendations deserve the very closest consideration.

That the House take note of the report.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY (TOBACCO-SALE TO YOUNG PERSONS AND PROMOTION) BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Tickner.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —In one of the final days of sitting in the House of Representatives in the old Parliament House, I believe it is highly appropriate that this Bill be presented to the House as a private member's Bill. Members of parliament and the people of Australia would know that a private member's Bill is a relatively rare beast in parliamentary life. I hope such Bills will not be so rare in future years and, indeed, I hope this will not be the last Bill that I present. I compliment the Government on facilitating the extension of the democratic processes of this House to afford more opportunities for private members' business; and I also thank the Parliament for that.

SPEECH.PARA: I also thank my Party for having procedures that allow a member of parliament who has strong convictions about a particular area to bring forward a private member's Bill. I gently chide the Opposition and remind members that within their parties they do not have the same flexibility as we in the Australian Labor Party have to put new ideas for legislation on the agenda of parliament. I thank my Party for that flexibility.

TALK.START.PARA: —What rubbish! Have a look at the private member's Bill from this side of the House.

—The reality is that the honourable member needs the permission of his Party; I do not. I do not wish to be partisan in what I have to say because I believe the Bill I am introducing today transcends party politics. The Bill sets out its purposes; I will not refer to them in detail. They include the prohibition of the promotion, by way of publication and advertisement, of tobacco products and accessories; the prohibition of certain competitions; the prohibition of free samples; and a prohibition on the sale of tobacco products to people under the age of 16 years.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill is not only for the people of the Australian Capital Territory and in particular the youth of today and the children who will soon be in their teenage years, although it is certainly and primarily directed to them and for their benefit; it is also for my late father, who died of a tobacco-induced cancer, and for my eight-year-old daughter, whom I do not want to grow up to be subjected to tobacco advertising. I have said that this is not a party Bill, and I will be looking for support right across the political spectrum. I acknowledge freely that there are many people on the Opposition benches who strongly share my convictions. Indeed, the proposal for a law of this kind was first made way back in 1977 in the unanimous report of the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare, chaired by Senator Peter Baume, which called for legislation of the kind that I am proposing now. That, of course, was a unanimous recommendation made over 11 years ago. As I have said, I will be looking for bipartisan support.

I want to make a number of matters clear. First and foremost, this is not in any way an attack on smokers or their rights. This is 100 per cent directed towards the advertising practices of multinational tobacco companies, which deliberately set out to attract young smokers and new smokers. Their advertising is directly targeted, as honourable members can see from the picture I am holding up from a major newspaper, towards young people. It uses all the phoney tricks of advertising to secure new markets and new addicts among young smokers. I believe history will judge us very harshly. It is absolutely absurd that we take a restrictive view of advertising of tobacco products on radio and television and yet allow the free marketing of tobacco products in the print media; and one of the purposes of the Bill is to correct that situation.

I am delighted to have already received support for the concept of the Bill from the Australian Capital Territory branch of the Australian Medical Association; and I am confident that other public health bodies, parents and community groups in the Australian Capital Territory will warmly support the Bill. I thank the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore) for his seconding of the Bill. I thank the Parliamentary Library, and particularly Joanna Sutherland of the law and government group for her help, as well as the Department of the House of Representatives, which has also provided strong support.

We who serve in the House of Representatives are privileged; but with that privilege and the right to serve the people we carry an obligation to stand up for our convictions and to leave this place better than when we arrived. I commend the Bill to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.
—In accordance with sessional order 104a, the second reading will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.
