—by leave-Mr Deputy Speaker, I table a request from 300 residents of the Geelong district requesting in the strongest terms that positive action be taken by the Government to end the use of chlorofluorocarbons in order to protect the ozone layer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House determines that the present Speaker's chair should be relocated in the House of Representatives chamber in the new Parliament House before that House is occupied by members of parliament in the 1988 Budget sittings.

I think it is very appropriate that on this late sitting day in the provisional Parliament House we should discuss the final location of the Speaker's chair. The chair in which you are sitting, Mr Deputy Speaker, is a replica of the original House of Commons Speaker's chair and was presented to the Parliament in 1926 by the United Kingdom branch of the Empire Parliamentary Association, now the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association.

The foliated canopy, the intricate carvings and mouldings and the graceful pinnacles and pendants are truly fine examples of the carver's art. The Royal Arms which surmount the canopy are carved in old oak taken from the roof of Westminster Hall, built in 1399. The back of the chair contains many delicately worked linen-fold panels, each with the monogram `V.R.' and the wreath and intertwined cord. The hinged flaps are of oak from Nelson's flagship, HMS Victory. We all recall, of course, Trafalgar on 21 October 1805. There are Latin inscriptions carved on both sides of the chair and, as I have already said, it really is a magnificent example of the carver's art. I point out that the present Speaker's chair in the House of Commons in Westminster was a gift of the Australian Parliament presented to that House in 1950 after damage to the original chair was sustained during World War II.

I remind the House that in March 1986 the Joint Standing Committee on the New Parliament House decided that the Speaker's chair should be transferred to the chamber of the House of Representatives in the new Parliament House. That is important because it demonstrates very clearly that the design of the new Parliament House always incorporated the movement of this Speaker's chair to that chamber. It is not as though the design of the new Parliament House was not intended to accommodate the move to transfer the Speaker's chair to the new chamber. In fact, if one looks at illustrations of the new chamber, one finds that they include in them a depiction of this Speaker's chair.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was always accepted.

—It was always accepted that the chair should go up there. In this chamber on 6 October last year, Madam Speaker acknowledged that that decision was made on the basis of tradition and the symbolic link with the Westminster Parliament. But Madam Speaker also told us on 6 October 1987 that the Committee had subsequently reviewed that decision and reported on 25 September last year that the Speaker's chair should not be transferred because of the chair's present condition, the need for restoration after the move, practical considerations involved in its removal and the need for modifications to overcome previously recognised shortcomings.

SPEECH.PARA: Madam Speaker then advised the House that the Committee had recognised the significance of preserving the integrity of the present chamber as part of a future parliamentary museum; had acknowledged that the new Parliament House would be a contemporary building incorporating a great deal of Australian skill, craftsmanship and materials; and had decided that a new chair should be designed and fabricated in Australia by Australian craftsmen, from Australian material.

I understand that, when the subject of a Speaker's chair was being considered for this provisional building in 1922, the concept of a British designed and made chair was initially rejected because it was considered to be incompatible with the decor of this chamber. Here we have a fascinating example of history seeming to repeat itself.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are catching up slowly.

—The honourable member for Dobell has interjected. The fact of the matter is that one of the spurious reasons put forward for not taking the chair up to the new Parliament House is that it blends in so well with the decor here. There is ample evidence that Australians now place a high value on traditions and heritage. Why does this Hawke Labor Government want to reject the British built Speaker's chair while, of course, actively supporting the preservation and renovation of historical buildings, many of which were designed and built by the British? If we are to reject the Speaker's chair as no longer appropriate to the Australian Parliament, will the Hawke Government be disposing of the English made mace? I have heard no suggestion that we should not take the mace up to the new Parliament House. However, it is British made. I cannot see any consistency in the arguments being advanced by the Government. I understand also that a petition has been received by the Parliament, signed by all the surviving parliamentary Clerks, asking that the Speaker's chair be transferred to the new Parliament House. As far as I am aware, that is an unprecedented action and demonstrates the depth of feeling and the wish for continuity that this symbolic chair inspires in all those who have served in this Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact remains that the then Leader of the House, Mr Young, spoke on 6 October 1987 against the transfer of the Speaker's chair. In so doing, he rejected the importance of traditions. One can understand that in regard to Mr Young. He cheapened the debate by trying to equate the Opposition's support for moving the chair with the events of 11 November 1975. That is a totally spurious and cheap way of dealing with this problem. The chair is a symbol of the entire Parliament, not one side of the Parliament. It is a symbol for all those who serve within the Parliament, no matter which party they represent.

The reasons advanced by Madam Speaker and the Committee for rejecting the moving of the chair to the new Parliament House are plainly and clearly specious. The decision is wrong. The arguments used for the non-transfer simply do not accord with the facts. They cannot stand up to close analysis. The decision is wrong because it is a rejection of a revered and important symbol of Australia's parliamentary history. In my view, it reveals a total lack of understanding by this Government of the importance which Australians attach to our traditions. The fact of the matter is that when one observes the new House of Representatives chamber and looks at the chair which has been provided one realises, as somebody said to me on the day of the opening of the new Parliament House, that the chair is something which a minor local country shire might put up with but which nobody else would.

In no way at all is it possible to equate the chair provided in the new chamber with this magnificent example of the carver's art, this symbol that is so rich in tradition and so closely allied with our parliamentary history and the parliamentary traditions stretching from the foundation of Westminster. The decision is wrong. I doubt whether the present Government will change it. It should. However, I have no doubt that, as soon as this side of politics is elected to government, the transfer will and must be made.

TALK.START.PARA: -Is the motion seconded?
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lee Mr M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar) mentioned that in 1926 there was a great debate as to whether this chamber should have this Speaker's chair. After listening to the honourable member for Warringah I can imagine that his speech could have been given in 1926 when that debate was proceeding because, really, to have the honourable member arguing in this day and age, in 1988, that our close ties with the United Kingdom will be damaged if we do not take the Speaker's chair from this Parliament House to the new Parliament House is ridiculous. Perhaps it is quite appropriate that one of the last debates in this chamber is on this question. In 1926 who gave the Parliament the Speaker's chair? The United Kingdom branch of the Empire Parliamentary Association gave that chair. I think that just demonstrates Australia's position in 1926. We were a dominion. We did not have total control over our foreign affairs and defence. In a sense, we were ultimately answerable to the United Kingdom Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: I am proud to say that one of the great achievements of the Curtin Labor Government, I think in 1942, was to pass an Act of Parliament which ratified the Statute of Westminster and gave Australia control over its foreign affairs and defence. One of the great decisions of the last Parliament was to pass the Australia Act, which ensures that we have complete control over our Constitution and our affairs.

TALK.START.PARA: —And established our security links with the United States.

—At the same time the Curtin Government initiated our close security links with the United States, which continue. I thank the honourable member for reminding me of that. It is important to remember that this issue has been debated in this House on two previous occasions. It was debated twice in October last year. Perhaps it simply demonstrates the priorities of the Opposition, because, when the community is debating the economy, the May economic statement and all the other issues that really matter, it brings forward a debate on the Speaker's chair.

SPEECH.PARA: While I think that the Speaker's chair is a beautiful work of art, I regard it as part of the history of this chamber. I think that it belongs here in a parliamentary museum which will be open to the public and will allow the public to have a feel for what this chamber was like in the years from 1927 to 1988 when this was the House of Representatives. One can imagine the public coming into the parliamentary museum and this chamber and, perhaps, sitting on the front benches or in the Prime Minister's chair.

I hope that one day audio tapes of some of the proceedings of this House can be played in this chamber as part of that museum concept. We can imagine people sitting in this chamber and listening over the loudspeakers, perhaps to a replay of the events in this chamber on 11 November 1975 or Question Time in the Fraser years. People could actually hear what happened. Perhaps they would hear the voice of Speaker Snedden and look towards the place where the Speaker's chair would be. However, honourable members opposite have promised that if they are elected to government they will take the Speaker's chair up to the hill. In that situation the public would be in here listening to the audio tapes; but, when they looked to the place where the Speaker's chair used to be, what would they see? Perhaps they would see a sign like the signs that have suddenly sprouted on the walls in this building in place of the paintings that have been removed and taken up to the hill. Perhaps they would see a sign saying, `The Speaker's chair usually displayed here has been transferred'.

It is necessary to the history of this chamber that the Speaker's chair stay here. It is completely ridiculous for the Opposition to be suggesting that this great issue of the moment should be considered. I note with interest that the Opposition has not argued that the President's chair in the Senate needs to be transferred to the new building. The Opposition has been very quiet on that. Who donated the President's chair to this Parliament? Not the United Kingdom Empire Parliamentary Association, but the Canadian Government. Apparently our links with the United Kingdom are different from our links with Canada. We can insult the Canadians, but we cannot insult the 1,926 members of the Empire Parliamentary Association.
I quote from one of the papers prepared for the Joint Standing Committee on the New Parliament House, on which I serve. It states:

In addition to the historical argument, it may be argued that there are sound aesthetic reasons for avoiding a conflict in styles between the ornate Gothic carved chair and the open simplicity of the proposed Chamber design. Proponents of this argument do not demean the Speakership or the authority of the Chair. Rather, they would seek to have the position of Speaker symbolised in the new building in a fashion more appropriate to, and consistent with, the statements of Australian nationhood.

I am very proud of the fact that the new Speaker's chair has been made by Australian craftsmen from special Australian woods. That is in keeping with the aims of the architects of the new Parliament House to maximise the Australian content and the use of Australian labour. The mob opposite, always seeking to put down the efforts of Australians, should instead be congratulating the Government on the excellent standard of workmanship which is in that new building, and that extends to the new Speaker's chair.

I should say in passing that it would be inappropriate for the Australian Parliament in the new Australian Parliament House opened in 1988 to have the Speaker's chair which has the coat of arms of the monarch of the United Kingdom, which is the coat of arms in the chair in this chamber. Australians in 1988 believe that they are part of an independent country; they do not have to hang on to the apron strings of the United Kingdom, and they are quite happy in the new Parliament House to have a new Speaker's chair. Of all the issues that are being debated in the community today, when the newspapers and television and radio programs are dealing with the May economic statement made last night by the Treasurer (Mr Keating), what issue does the Opposition bring forward? The Speaker's chair. I believe this motion is a nonsense.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McArthur Mr F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support my friend and colleague the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar) in deploring the decision that the Speaker's chair is not to be moved to our new parliamentary home. The honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee) referred back to the paranoia of the Australian Labor Party and to the 1975 decision that refers to the chair having some symbolic significance to the political events of that year. Honourable members will recall that the design of the new Parliament House incorporated this chair. Only in the last year was that decision changed, so the argument that the honourable member for Dobell puts up that the new design should incorporate a new chair is completely out of order, because over the 11 years of construction the old chair was to be incorporated in the new Parliament House.

SPEECH.PARA: In making such a decision, the Hawke Government is thumbing its nose at tradition, insulting the people of Australia, and flouting the Westminster system. I have a deep personal regret that this symbol of impartiality is not to find a place in the new chamber in the House of Representatives. The chair is more than just a piece of furniture. It is a symbol of the independence of the office of Speaker and a part of our history.

Madam Speaker herself has flouted the Parliamentary tradition of Westminster by refusing to wear the Speaker's robes, thus maintaining a tradition of sorts for Labor Speakers in this place, all of whom have denied themselves the sartorial trappings of office. Honourable members on this side of the House have had good reason to doubt the independence of the Speaker in recent times, and the refusal of this Government to place this chair, which indeed symbolises the true Westminster tradition, in the new Parliament House, could indeed be interpreted as a further step in the decline of impartiality in the office of Speaker.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Corangamite could have been seen to be casting a slight on the Speaker in the remarks he made suggesting that the Speaker was not impartial. For the record, that comment ought to be withdrawn just in case there should be any suggestion that there was such a slur. The honourable member may wish to make it clear that he was not making a slur.

—I was making no slur on the Speaker's impartiality. The late Sir Billy Snedden advocated the adoption of convention as associated with the Speakership of the British House of Commons. There the Speaker withdraws from party politics and continues in office regardless of which party holds power. Sir Billy believed that such a move was essential to increase the authority of the Chair and acceptance of decisions, with an improvement in standards in the House as a consequence.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Deputy Speaker, the chair upon which you now sit, apparently comfortably, if I may say so, is one which is surrounded by history. It was presented to the Australian Parliament by the then Empire Parliamentary Association in 1926 for the opening of provisional Parliament House. The fact that it was seen as a temporary or provisional Parliament House then is very significant for the Empire Parliamentary Association clearly intended it should move to the permanent Parliament House when it was finally built. Thirteen of the 20 Speakers of the House of Representatives have used the chair since 1927. I am sure you, Mr Deputy Speaker, have been proud to take the seat today representing the Speaker. I ask honourable members to examine the Speaker's chair. As this Labor Government has decreed it will stay put, we have only one more day, after today, to enjoy it and reflect on its significance. You see before you not just a piece of furniture but a piece of our democratic history. It is a replica of the Speaker's chair in the House of Commons in London. When the original was destroyed in bombing during World War II, artisans and craftsmen came from England to measure our chair to make sure their replacement was correct in every detail.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time allotted by the Selection Committee for debate on this matter has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday. The honourable member will have leave to continue his speech when the debate is resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Griffiths Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House acknowledges the contribution of former Members to the rich and colourful history of this Chamber.

It is quite appropriate, having regard to the preceding debate, relating to the history of this chamber, that honourable members take some time today in a repeat of the nostalgic mood that preceded the closure of the last Parliament on 24 March 1927, not so much to sing Auld Lang Syne as they did on that occasion and as I hope we will do when we conclude the proceedings in this great chamber. In embracing that somewhat nostalgic mood I bring this motion to the attention of the House and seek its support, mainly as a result of having looked at a photograph that brought back many memories of the history of this chamber. That photograph is now stored in the office of the Sergeant-at-Arms. The photograph was taken from the entrance to this chamber looking into the Speaker's chair. It was a very memorable photograph for two reasons. One was-and I hope this will not be repeated-that at the time the photograph was taken the Clerk passed away, and his head is seen falling in a blur to the table just where our colleague sits in front of us now. At the same time as the photograph was taken there was a member for Barton-a fellow by the name of John Frederick Ley--

TALK.START.PARA: —Lemonade Ley.

—Lemonade Ley, who gained access to this august chamber by reaching the high water mark of electoral malpractice. He came from the conservative side of politics, and most people in this chamber today would be aware of the infamous Lemonade Ley, but very few people outside the chamber would be aware how he came to represent the constituency of Barton in this chamber. For those who are not aware I shall recount the story.

SPEECH.PARA: Lemonade Ley, a former Minister for Justice in the New South Wales Parliament, allegedly sought to bribe the then Labor member for Barton, one Frederick McDonald, into not nominating for the election immediately preceding the opening of this Parliament. It came to pass that Frederick McDonald, as he properly ought to have done, took this matter to the Court of Disputed Returns. Unfortunately, consequent upon an attempt to have a meeting between John Frederick Ley and the unfortunate Frederick McDonald, the Labor Party former member of this chamber disappeared, never to be seen again. The new member for Barton brought with him a very unsavoury reputation, and it was alleged that other people who had associated with him had disappeared previously. He served in this chamber for some three years before losing his seat and emigrating to England where, following his apprehension for a further murder, he was eventually sentenced to be executed. That sentence was set aside and he was sent to Broadmoor lunatic asylum where he subsequently died-hopefully, not held in high regard by many people at all. In looking at the history of the Speaker's chair, I think it is interesting to reflect on some of the mortals who have served in this chamber rather than concentrating, as some of my colleagues have done, on the bits of timber that are important to the chamber.

John Ley reached the high water mark of electoral malpractice, and the Australian Labor Party (ALP), even with its rich history in regard to matters electoral, cannot come anywhere near that particular exercise of tory ambition. It is a very important incident to recall, and I ask honourable members to view that particular photograph if they have an opportunity. Indeed, some of my colleagues, given that this particular former member for Barton sat almost immediately behind where I now stand, indicate that occasionally they can feel the cold breath of John Frederick Ley on the backs of their necks and it is a rather chilling feeling.

It has also been said recently that there have been some sightings of ghosts around the chambers. While I have yet to be convinced of the truth of that assertion, it is interesting to reflect, if indeed there are ghosts around this chamber and around these halls, on what they might be thinking now. Were they to have a vote, would they ask for the Speaker's chair to be removed to the new Parliament House, or indeed might they suggest that the Speaker's chair remain in this chamber because they may have every intention of continuing to meet at times other than those scheduled for our normal sittings?

If they were to meet, what a very rich, albeit crowded, meeting it would be. There would be not only John Frederick Ley, the villain, and his victim, the unfortunate former member for Barton, but a whole raft of colourful characters who have inhabited this chamber, sometimes for extraordinary long periods, such as `Billy the Rat', the former Prime Minister Hughes. There would also be those who should have served in this chamber longer; for example, a former member for Indi went along at 5 o'clock in the afternoon to nominate for election to this Parliament whereupon he was told that nominations had closed at 3 p.m. and that his Labor opponent had become the new member for Indi.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a good move.

—Yes, it was a good move. In fact, the ALP, having had one of its members murdered, was in for some luck, and there might have been some balance in that outcome. Numerous colourful characters have inhabited this chamber. For example, `Red Ted' Theodore right through his career was always the victim of many slurs, some of them I believe quite well founded. He was up on bribery charges and was subsequently embroiled--
—He was found not guilty.
—Yes, on the bribery charges. He was then involved in the Mungana affair.
—He was not guilty again.
—Not guilty, but certainly had his image knocked around. He eventually retired and went on to bigger and better things-if I recall correctly, as a newspaper proprietor.
—The Women's Weekly.

—Yes, he set up the Women's Weekly. A colourful Labor character was the catalyst for that great conservative Australian institution, the Women's Weekly. There were others like Frank Anstey, who was allegedly under the influence of the infamous John Wren in Victoria. There were major events right throughout this period and some of those that come to mind would be found shocking today. Wharf labourers were shot dead while on strike in Melbourne over, in part at least, the dog collar legislation which went through this Parliament, purporting to demand that wharf labourers hold a licence before being allowed to work. There were other people like Stanley Melbourne Bruce, the first Australian Prime Minister-as my colleague the honourable member for Dunkley (My Chynoweth), whose former seat was Flinders, would no doubt recall-to lose his seat in a Federal election. He lost his seat over issues such as the status of the conciliation and arbitration legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: My colleague the honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mr Scott) may be aware that Norman Makin, a former member for Hindmarsh and a Methodist minister, turned things upside down many years ago when, as Speaker, he dispensed not only with wearing the wig and gown but also with the use of the mace. That was only a temporary aberration, because in recent times they have been reintroduced. However, in those days it had enormous impact and was a matter of significant controversy. During the 1930s the unemployment level in this country was 28 per cent, something which is very hard to imagine. Prime Minister Scullin went overseas for an extended trip of some six months. It is now very hard to imagine a Prime Minister leaving the country at a time of acute social crisis, however well justified, for a period of half the year. There were enormous controversies in this chamber about the appointment of the first Australian Governor-General, Sir Isaac Isaacs. Of course, after he left that position it took many years before we reverted, I hope for all time, to the appointment of Australians to that august position.

There were also the battles of the Langites, not only in this chamber but in the Caucus room. There was also `Stabber' Jack Beasley, who allegedly resided for quite some time in the toilets at the back of the chamber, listening in a most improper way to the conversations of those who went to relieve themselves. He took great note of the information so derived and it was alleged that he used it to telling effect in his various Caucus schemes. There was also Eddie Ward, the wild man of Sydney, who came into this chamber with no education but with two great talents in politics-an unsurpassed vindictiveness and great prowess as a boxer and athlete. Many years later it was said that he put the latter of those talents, his prowess as a boxer, to almost telling effect when he chased a young fellow by the name of Gough Whitlam into the Caucus room, took a mad swing at him but punched the wall and then decided that he would thereafter not embrace violence as he had clearly lost his ability to land a decent punch.

There was also Mr Lyons who, like his forebear, Billy Hughes, swapped sides and ratted on the Labor Party. There were some great comments in this chamber about the activities of not only Lyons but also Hughes, who was still around at the time. There was a real social crisis in 1931 with the formation of the `White Army' in Melbourne and the `New Guard' in Sydney. Per capita in this country there were paramilitary organisations of far greater number than in the United Kingdom, a fact that is often unknown. That is a very sobering thought indeed because it placed democracy, as properly represented in this chamber, under enormous pressure.

In those days the Press Gallery comprised only six people. Many years later, of course, one member of that gallery, almost in a comatose state, distinguished himself by falling from the Press gallery onto the canopy of the Speaker's chair. Of course, he was dead drunk. Not a lot has changed over the years, but I suspect that that particular Press Gallery reporter at least had the decency to pay for his own drinks. The famous journalist Joe Alexander could reputedly read upside down. When interviewing him in one's office one had to be very careful with any confidential documents lest they be splashed over his newspaper.

The politics of those times are quite amazing to reflect upon. The conservative side of politics refused to pass the Statute of Westminster. Right across this chamber honourable members would find it very hard to imagine the type of thinking that prevailed in those days. Electioneering campaign slogans such as Lyons's election theme, `Let's tune in with Britain' now seem somewhat dated.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, I don't know.

—Some of my colleagues, such as the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) perhaps, may not believe that it is all that dated. It is interesting that the honourable member for North Sydney is in the chamber. I recall his distinguished and late father being elected as an Independent for the seat of Warringah. My colleague the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar) is also in the chamber. The honourable member for North Sydney having such a conservative status, it is interesting that his late and great father gained election as an Independent to the seat of Warringah with the great assistance of Labor Party second preferences. That is a very interesting bit of history. It started the Spender dynasty in this chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: We had the secession movement in Western Australia. My own seat of Maribyrnong has been around since 1906 and has been represented by some seven members, all with considerable political longevity. I hope the precedent is an important one for the existing member. In any event, the famous Maurice Blackburn played a part in Curtin's ascension to power. He despised Curtin, yet the then member for Maribyrnong, Mr Drakeford, was able to get the proxy vote of Maurice Blackburn and Curtin was elected by one vote. I think the scheming and the deals involved in election outcomes in those days belie any of our current experiences. Lieutenant-Colonel White, a former member of this chamber, was famous for his wartime and other exploits; for example, crash landing his aircraft somewhere near Baghdad, being captured by Arabs and executing his own escape in quite perilous circumstances. He was one of the very famous conservative members of this place.

In 1935 people were still to get into the habit of using aircraft, something which existing members would find very difficult to understand until they found out that the gold pass did not apply to air travel. Members of parliament tended for economic reasons to continue to use train travel and that involved a great degree of time and effort to get to this place.

In the period leading up to the War we had the exploits of pig-iron Bob, one of the greats of this chamber, notwithstanding his problems in that regard. It is interesting to reflect on what might have been. In 1940 the late Prime Minister Menzies nearly took a trip on a Lockheed Hudson passenger aircraft. As honourable members will be aware, that aircraft crashed, killing three Cabinet Ministers, Mr Street, Mr Gullett and Mr Fairbairn. It is interesting to reflect on what might have been had fate treated Menzies a little more harshly on that day.

Menzies, some 55 years after the formation of the Australian Labor Party, formed the Liberal Party of Australia. It is interesting to consider the different time frames. Chifley organised the postwar reconstruction and also put troops into the coalmines. There are some wonderful quotations in many of the books on these great times. There is a great one that indicates the tempestuous nature of Gough Whitlam. The Hansard for 17 November 1960 records the following conversation:
Mr ALLAN FRASER.—Stop sheltering behind the Sovereign all the time.
Sir GARFIELD BARWICK.—That is a remarkable remark. I have heard it from the honourable member for Eden-Monaro. Let the public know it. He said, ``Stop talking about the Sovereign so much''.
Mr WHITLAM.—He did not say that. You are cashing in on the monarchy . . .
Sir GARFIELD BARWICK.—I heard it and so did my colleagues . . .
Mr WHITLAM.—He is a liar.
The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN.-I call the Deputy Leader of the Opposition to order . . .
Mr WHITLAM.—I will not withdraw. This truculent runt thinks he can get away with anything.
The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN.-Order! I ask the Deputy Leader of the Opposition to withdraw that remark.
Mr WHITLAM.—I will not withdraw when the Attorney-General will not withdraw his untruth.

And so it went. That is an indication of Mr Whitlam's recollection of events. He was right on that occasion to ask for the ruling. That exchange indicates not only his very sharp tongue but also his ability subsequently to throw water over those with whom he disagreed in this chamber. I suspect that the ghosts of this chamber every now and then look at the water spread all over the table in front of us.

Many colourful and important characters have made a great contribution to this chamber from all areas of Australian politics. I hope we leave the Speaker's chair in this chamber. I think the ghosts of this chamber have the right to assemble out of our sessional hours to relive those very famous, very intriguing and very memorable times. I thank the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very much aware of the importance of the day. I thank the House for inviting me, on relatively short notice, to participate in this debate. My colleague the honourable member for Maribyrnong (Mr Griffiths) referred to the journalist tumbling out of the gallery onto the Speaker's chair. In the very first year of this Parliament there was a total prohibition on alcohol. That followed a move by the late King O'Malley who, himself a teetotaller, banned alcohol in the Parliament. It was only as a result of a referendum in the Australian Capital Territory which was passed with a bare majority of 2,218 to 2,161 that alcohol was allowed into this place. I am quite certain that, had that rule continued, many honourable members, particularly on the Government side, would never have aspired to come to this place. One can look back over the years and observe that people worked very hard at catching up for the year lost because of the late King O'Malley.

SPEECH.PARA: I regard it as a personal privilege and as apt that I am speaking today because I come from a clan that has been represented in this Parliament more than any other group.

TALK.START.PARA: —Too many.
—The honourable member for Brisbane says there have been too many. I say to him that there has been nothing wrong with any of the 14 Camerons who have served in this Parliament.
—Thirteen were all right.

—The honourable member for Hindmarsh says that only 13 were all right. The Camerons have come from all parties-Liberal, National and Labor. It shows the diversity of views which still exists in our particular clan. There have been only two years since 1927 when there was not a Cameron in the Parliament. That is quite an accomplishment. Very few have been even remotely related, but there must have been something special about the Scottish blood in the clan. My friend the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar) is sitting behind me and the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan) is on my right. I concede that people from all backgrounds are driven to this place.
—That is my husband's name.

—I am sorry. Only somebody who associates with the Irish could wave aside the great opportunity that came with the connection with someone of Irish blood. I refer also to the fact that in 1927, when this Parliament was opened, there was a total of 112 politicians. There were 76 members of the House of Representatives and 36 senators. I am pleased to note that we have a number of National Party and Labor Party members in the House at present. I have always believed that one of the great tragedies was the vote taken in about 1983 to increase the number of members of parliament so dramatically. The increase in 1949 was justified. The original politicians came here with a salary of #1,000 per year. It was not until 1947 that they received an increase of #500. Those politicians set an example to the nation and accepted a 50 per cent cut in salary. I believe it was in 1932 that they reduced their salaries from #1,000 to #500. The salary moved back gradually and it was not until 1947 that they reached the figure of #1,500.

SPEECH.PARA: In looking back at the politicians that have passed through this place, I note that the honourable member for Fairfax (Mr Adermann) is present. He and his father have chalked up some 45 years service between them-quite an achievement. Over the years only 20 members of the House of Representatives have served at least 30 years and seven senators have achieved that period of service. The grandfather of service, of course, was the late William Morris Hughes, who served a period of 51 years and seven months. He was a Labor Prime Minister and, as the years rolled on, he woke up to the Australian Labor Party, left that Party and joined the conservative side of politics.

If I were asked to choose one person about whom I would like to speak today, I would nominate Billy Hughes. I will not refer to personal aspects of his life, but I guess he symbolises, with 51 years and 7 months service, the aspirations of every person who arrives here for the first time. People come here thinking that they would love to stay for at least 50 years and match the Billy Hughes record. Of course, nobody has gone even near the record of Billy Hughes.

I would like to believe that the Australian public has been well served since Federation by the men and women who have come into this place. Some 385 members have sat in this chamber since 1927 and 567 politicians in total have served in the House of Representatives since Federation.

Moments ago I referred to Billy Hughes and to the men and women who have passed through here. I referred also to my belief that Australia has been well served by its democratic process. I realise that at times Australians are well and truly turned off by the rowdiness here and by the sometimes blatant lack of respect that is displayed for others. People cannot understand how members can say certain things to each other in this chamber and then go outside and speak civilly to each other.

TALK.START.PARA: —You would get sued if you said it outside.

—That is quite correct. This chamber, with its representatives of the Australian people, has contributed tremendously to the stability this nation has enjoyed for so many decades. The cut and thrust of this place is a release. At times a member of parliament will say something which is quite outrageous, but in the general community people can always relate to someone here or to something that happens in this place.

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst politicians-I use that popular term; most honourable members who come through these doors see themselves as statesmen-will fail in the future, as they have in the past, to fulfil the promises and the undertakings that are made, I believe more often seriously than flippantly, there is still no better system to serve this country than our parliamentary system. This chamber, with the lower sections clad in Australian timbers, its old green leather benches-parts of which have been replaced-that have served us well, the huge table in the middle of the chamber, and indeed the Speaker's chair, has been the centre of stability. We have all felt our disappointments personally, particularly at times when we have cast a vote on a matter, in which we probably did not have our full hearts. I have always held the view that when it comes to displaying independence it is a matter of principle and not a matter of opinion. I regard it as very fortunate that I belong to a political party which allows a display of conscience in terms of how an individual votes, as long as it is not indulged in too often-contrary to the Labor Party, whose members would not know what it is like to cross the floor. I guess that the floor crossing that has made headlines over the years has always come from this side of the chamber. That is a very special privilege that we have had.

In closing, I pay tribute to all those former members of the Parliament for their efforts, for their contributions, and for something that is not understood by the general public. Indeed, I may well have been fooled myself. When I was young I used to hear about what a great bludger's life it was being a member of parliament. I thought, `That will do me. I'll head for parliament'. People have always said that this is the biggest bludger's life in the country, and they are still saying it. I would like to assure people that, after a couple of decades here, I know that is not the truth. Perhaps people resort to those denunciations because politicians do not always meet people's expectations.

I am aware that the next Liberal member to speak is a former senator, now the honourable member for Moncrieff. She served in the Senate and is now a member of the House of Representatives, an achievement not many people have accomplished. She has mentioned to me that it is her intention to refer to a function that was held in this place in 1976, when the 1966 members celebrated their tenth anniversary. I ran a kangaroo dinner recently. It was only the second function I have organised, and I have come to the conclusion that every time I am associated with anything like this there is simply too much publicity. I undertake never to hold another dinner in this place-a very easy undertaking to make.

I just say to the honourable member for Moncrieff: go gently. My most hurtful memory about that woman who attended the function is the total disbelief of my elderly parents that I could have been associated with such a function. I will leave history to judge exactly what happened, but I can assure the House that I was not there on my own.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLeay Mr L.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to participate in this debate today and I thank the honourable member for Maribyrnong (Mr Griffiths) for placing this item on the Notice Paper. This is the last private members' debate which will be brought on in this chamber, and it might be worthwhile thinking about the spirits and the ghosts up there in the ceiling and some of the things that they are thinking about in what might be the last debate of any significance that we have in this place. If one accepts the view that parliament is about private members, this should really be one of the last significant debates because this is the last time we will have a private members' day here.

SPEECH.PARA: I guess there are old Speakers and old members of the Privileges Committee circulating around up there and they would all be thinking about what they should have or could have done. Clicking around behind them they will probably have the remnants of old Clerks. They say that old Clerks are like old soldiers. They do not die or go away, they just smell that way-or something like that. Those people might be looking at some of the things that happened in the past to backbenchers rather than Ministers. I recently led the first Australian Parliamentary Delegation to Ireland. Many of the people who have got themselves into strife in this Parliament in the past have been Irish born or of Irish descent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Never admit it.

—My colleague on my right says, `Never admit it'. Two of the people who spring to mind are Hugh Mahon and Michael Patrick Considine. Both were Irish born and served for some time in this Parliament, and both fell foul of standing order 74 in one way or another. People who take an interest in parliamentary democracy and the Westminster system would know that it is very improper to criticise the current monarch. Of course, one would not be able to raise any objections to criticising some previous monarchs, for instance, Charles II who led the massive assault on the House of Commons. Having laid that groundwork no-one had better try to sprag me on standing order 74 as I continue.

SPEECH.PARA: Considine was an interesting fellow. He probably has the record that the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) would like to achieve. Considine actually got thrown out of the House of Representatives by the Speaker three times. The first time he was thrown out he was suspended for 24 hours for making the observation that there was no difference between a particular member and a German. I do not think that we would find that happening today. He got thrown out a second time, for seven days, because he said that the country was run by a gang of murdering thieves. The Speaker in the House at that time considered that that was pretty bad. He was put out for seven days for saying that. A few weeks later he was put out for a month for saying that the government of the day was supporting the champion murderer of the working classes in Russia generally, namely, the tsarist Koltchak. That was enough to get Considine a month's suspension.

The interesting thing about Considine's month's suspension was that he had been roaming the country saying a few things as well and had only just got back into the House from serving two weeks in gaol. The reason he had spent two weeks in gaol was that they had managed to put him away for sedition because it seems that, in the company of some people at Melbourne's Green Room Club, he said, `Bugger the King, he's a bloody German'. He then went on and said some other things. It is interesting that Considine had only just got back into the House when it was decided to fit him for saying that the Government was supporting the tsarists in Russia. Considine managed to get three terms of suspension and two weeks in gaol along the way.

Considine was followed by another infamous Irishman in Hugh Mahon. Hugh Mahon is the only member of the House of Representatives to be expelled from the House and have the government of the day, on the floor of the chamber, declare his seat vacant. He was expelled for the same type of statement at that time, in the late 1900s to the 1920s, when there were troubles in Ireland. Mahon, a man of 63 years, addressed a meeting in Melbourne of the Irish Ireland League. At that meeting, which Mahon chaired, he was critical of the ruling British powers in Ireland at the time. He made a number of very disparaging remarks. I am pleased to see Senator McKiernan in the gallery. I think I can say that he is very lucky to be in the Parliament today because had he been in the Parliament in those days he probably would have been suspended for 10 years. When the Parliament resumed after this meeting in Melbourne, the tories on the government bench at the time decided that Mahon had to be put in his place; so they served him up to the Privileges Committee. The Committee reported that he had indeed said these things and that it was pretty bad. Mahon was not in the chamber but he received a notice that he would be dealt with that day. He sent a letter to Billy Hughes, in which he said:

My criticism, which was confined to the acts of British Ministers and their agents in Ireland, made no reference whatever to the Sovereign. I am not aware that the oath of an Australian parliamentarian binds him in allegiance to Mr Lloyd George and his associates . . . I regret that I am unable to accommodate you with a statement in person-
that statement was to say that he accepted his oath as a member of the Australian Parliament-

but really do you seriously think it would make any difference? If, as reported, your Caucus has already decreed my expulsion, then if one spoke with the tongue of an angel he would not alter in one iota their clandestine decree.

Of course Hughes, speaking in support of the motion to get rid of Mahon, played down the Irish question but that did not stop Hughes from moving that the seat of Kalgoorlie be declared vacant. There was a by-election for the seat. Ironically, Mahon then went into the history books a second time because it was the only time that the Opposition lost a seat in a by-election when the current member was standing. Mahon lost his seat, so another Irishman was dealt with by the Establishment here.

It is interesting to see the things that people were put out for in the past, the matters that the Privileges Committee considered in those days and the rather easy way with which it deals with those of us who are here now. Indeed, if former members of the Privileges Committee are rattling around up in the ceiling, they might say to the current Deputy Clerk, Lyn Barlin, `Well, you had better go downstairs and open up the safe and bring out the documents from the Browne-Fitzpatrick case and we will publish them'. It is an interesting fact that one of the few people left alive today who know of the evidence given to the Privileges Committee in that case is Lyn Barlin.

Having mentioned Mr Barlin, the Deputy Clerk, I might just mention a poem that Sir Robert Menzies wrote some years ago. It seems to be in vogue now to mention Menzies, seeing that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) mentioned him at the opening of the new Parliament House. Referring to the Clerks, Menzies said in this poem:
Two wise old owls sat at a table:
Their wigs were grey, their gowns were sable:
They looked so sad, so melancholy.
As if depressed by human folly.
Around them, carelessly displayed.
Were all their dreadful tools of trade.
The Standing Orders, Votes and Motions,
The Statutes, May and such like notions.
The glass, with sand so neatly piled
The rulings (wrong) so neatly filed.
The bells to call the members in
To tread the paths of verbal sin.
But wise old owls must sometimes think
Of what? Of women? Food? or drink?
Or are they, as they keep their places,
As really vacant as their faces?

I told Mr Browning, the Clerk, this morning that I would read that poem and he thought that was pretty disgraceful, but then I reminded him that the Clerk always gets his say on the last day of his tenure here. So maybe when Mr Browning addresses the House on his last day he will read out the rather disgraceful sequel written by one of the Clerks which really puts all of us in our places. I am very glad to have participated in the debate. I hope that all the ghosts in the ceiling here will move to the new chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sullivan Mrs K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unfortunately, the Standing Orders do not enable the Clerk to read out a reply when this House rises. Mr Browning, being the very scrupulous gentleman he is, would be the last to abrogate that. However, he had the forethought to give me a response which I will now read into the record. I ought to point out that it is not Mr Browning's response. It is actually the response of Mr Tregear who, if justice had its way, would be reading it. The response, entitled The responsive Lay of the Clerks-at-the-Table, reads:

SPEECH.PARA: If we look glum and vacant stare,
When wigged and seated `neath the Chair,
Please do not think `tis Nature's way,
It's rather service for our pay.
For if some thoughts we dare repeat,
We'd find ourselves out in the street.
A Clerk-at-the-Table IS like a bird,
And like a bird says not a word,
But give him chance to have his say
Of Members and their oratory,
Then ``Curse the Press'' would lose its bark
In louder cries of ``Curse the Clerk''.
We often do have thoughts of FOOD
Dispelled by Members being rude.
A move to sip the tasty bouillon
Is turned-We hear the voice of Kooyong.
We shake our heads and don our guise;
And vanish dreams of rich, cream pies.
Think of DRINK?-Ay, there's the rub,
Of hours at the corner pub,
Of schooners, nips and golden beer
Of toddies, yarns, and goodly cheer;
While reaching for a draught so cooling,
Some M.P. chirps ``I want a Ruling''.
So time moves on; we leave the MUSE
And lend our ears to Members' views,
We hear their claims, their wants, their quips,
We see their moves, and calls by Whips,
But we don't TALK-So who can label
The inner thoughts of the Clerks-at-the-Table.

When I was elected to the Senate 14 years ago, I came to the Parliament as a young and, I hope, very unassuming senator. I was a little overwhelmed by the grandeur of the place and some of the people with whom I was rubbing shoulders. I had a quite extraordinary experience. I had been very actively involved in politics for the previous 14 years and I thought that I knew something about the personalities of those in politics-certainly those who had been involved in it in that time. To my great surprise, as I sat at the table in the members dining room for lunch or dinner and listened to some of the old-timers talking about those who had left not long before, after serving for 20 or 25 years, I had never heard of most of them.

Undoubtedly, one would have thought that those who had served for 20 or more years, after all the things that they might have done, would have earned a niche somewhere but, in fact, they were very quickly forgotten. I came to the conclusion that those who serve in this place, both in the House of Representatives and in the Senate, are really only shadows that pass across a stage; they are part of a process. Individually, very few are remembered. Even very few Prime Ministers get their names into the history book. I conclude that it is not important what individuals do or might have done, but what they have been part of. Today we are acknowledging the contribution of former members of this House and what they were part of: they were part of establishing the history of this chamber.

Notwithstanding what I have just said, there are some legendary figures. As I thought-my position was similar to that of the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Donald Cameron) in that we were given very short notice-of what names came to mind automatically: Menzies, Eddie Ward, Billy Hughes, Billy Wentworth and Gough Whitlam. There are others who served with distinction-people such as Joe Lyons and Chifley-but they are not remembered with the same prominence and in quite the same way because I do not think they displayed publicly great force of humanity, humour, or whatever it was that those other people did.

I knew personally very few of those people. I served concurrently with Billy Wentworth, but he was in the House of Representatives and I was in the Senate. The same could be said of Gough Whitlam, but I will never forget the personal kindness that Gough Whitlam showed me when I arrived here. As I said a few minutes ago, I was very young, nervous and a little tentative. During the historic Joint Sitting which followed the 1974 election, I happened to be walking from the Opposition lobby of the Senate across King's Hall. Exiting from the Government lobby of the House of Representatives, which is on the opposite side of King's Hall, was Gough Whitlam. He crossed King's Hall, came up to me and said, `It's about time we met'. I was quite astonished, not to mention flattered, that the Prime Minister would think there was any imperative in that. I always found him, privately, an extremely charming, cultured and civilised man. From what I hear, I am not sure whether he was always like that in the party room, but I cannot speak with any authority on that.

To that list we must add the present honourable member for Moreton. I was not going to mention the 1976 incident, but it is clear that he wants it to go in the record. I am not sure whether it is in the record, but he certainly wants it mentioned in this context. In fact, I think that he would be disappointed if I did not mention it. I cannot think of anyone more appropriate to make even passing reference to it, because the simple fact is that if I had been part of the class of `66 it would not have happened. There was a stag night. There have been the odd occasions such as that in the House about which I cannot speak with any authority. The honourable member's flair for publicity came to the fore again and it is now part of Australia's history.

I do not intend to be too earnest this afternoon, but I want to say a couple of things. I am not the first member to have come from the Senate to the House of Representatives. There have been some distinguished predecessors, including a former Prime Minister, John Gorton. There are other former senators presently serving here; however, I happen to be the first woman. This House has a particularly macho reputation. I was not unfamiliar with its reputation or with the fact as I had been interested in the House of Representatives for some time. I had occupied the senators gallery and watched certain historic occasions and, sometimes, occasions which were not historic at all-I just watched them out of curiosity. This chamber has a reputation for vigorous personalities and accordingly, its proceedings tend to be fairly vigorous.

However, never let it be thought that the Senate did not have its characters. A former character of this place-Jim Killen, who is a former member for Moreton-was credited with the statement, `The Senate is proof of life after death'. That is an unkind and untrue statement. I cannot help thinking today of characters in my time such as John Wheeldon, who used to delight in having the Opposition-when we were in opposition and he was a Minister in 1974-75-killing itself laughing at his comments at our expense. Reg Withers was a real character, as were Ivor Greenwood, who unfortunately died prematurely, and Lionel Murphy. The presence of Lionel Murphy in the Senate was something very particular: the air tasted different. When Lionel Murphy departed the Senate and went to the High Court of Australia, the Senate did move a little further towards Jim Killen's definition.

I want to make a very particular reference to a couple of female characters. I note, not with any malice, that I am the only woman on the speakers list today, and I am sure there is no malice in that fact; but a couple of people ought to be mentioned. Dame Enid Lyons was the first woman to serve in this chamber, and served with distinction. The widow of a Prime Minister, she took his seat and became the first female Minister to serve in a Commonwealth government in Australia. She had been out of the House of Representatives and out of parliament for 20 years by the time I entered the Senate and for more than 30 years before I was elected to the House of Representatives. She had reared eight children and been the wife of a Prime Minister. Either of those occupations is strenuous and demanding. Nevertheless, she followed that with entry to the House of Representatives to serve with distinction.

I met her about 10 years ago. It would probably have been at least 25 years after she had left this place. I found her charming, vigorous, intelligent and articulate and still very keenly interested in what was going on in this place. She, in her own way, proved something by being here, and would have been treated very differently by those around her. I hope I do not do my colleagues an injustice when I say that I have a hunch that perhaps the House was a little more gentlemanly then. Maybe it was not quite as competitive. It certainly has the reputation of having become a little more raucous in recent years.

It would be remiss of me not to mention Joan Child. While she is currently a member, she has, I think, become one of the personalities of this Parliament, and she will probably be one of the personalities of the next Parliament. In occupying the chair in the way she does and under the extraordinary difficulties created for her-by members from both sides, on occasion-she has made her own contribution a very particular, unique and unrepeatable part of the history of this chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scholes The Hon G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The fact that this Parliament is about to leave this site, a temporary site, I think indicates the types of difficulties that a parliament can get into. In 1923, in order to move the Parliament to Canberra, the Parliament was unable to accept the permanent Parliament House proposed at the time. Since 1927 several hundred people-probably over 1,000-have participated in this chamber as members of the House of Representatives. A few have participated in both chambers. I have been here for near enough to 21 years. It has to be said that the chamber has never been free of personalities; it has never been free of recurring incidents; and it certainly has been a place where a major part of the country's history has occurred.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1927, Mr Bruce-later Lord Bruce-was Prime Minister and he lasted in this building for something approaching two years. He lost his seat-the only Prime Minister ever to do so-in an election that was created, as the honourable member for Maribyrnong indicated, because someone was stupid enough not to know where his electoral office was and did not get the nomination in, thus ceding the seat to the Australian Labor Party without contest; the only occasion, incidentally, when the Labor Party has ever held that particular seat.

Lord Bruce tried to divest the Commonwealth of the powers under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act which it had taken over way back in the first years of Federation. The Secretary of the Melbourne Trades Hall Council, Ted Holloway, in a number of speeches, upset the government of the day and was charged with sedition and convicted. He was fined #50-obviously the court did not think the matter too serious-which he refused to pay. While the charge was hanging over his head, he contested the seat of Flinders in the 1929 election and defeated the then Prime Minister. He stayed in this Parliament until 1951 and served in the Chifley Government as Deputy Prime Minister and as a senior Minister. Such was the fate of one Prime Minister.

Since we came to Canberra, some 17 Prime Ministers have sat at the table in this chamber, some for very short periods. Frank Forde was Prime Minister for a whole seven days, and I doubt whether he actually got into the chamber as Prime Minister. Sir Robert Menzies was Prime Minister for 16 or 17 years but did not always sit at the table free of concern. Sir Robert Menzies was one of the Prime Ministers who were defeated as Prime Minister by their own party. Scullin suffered that fate; Menzies suffered that fate. Scullin's Government was brought down; he did not lose the leadership of his Party. Menzies was removed from the leadership of his Party by his own Cabinet which was personally selected and appointed by him. It was during wartime. This chamber saw the still unrevealed secret sessions in the 1940s; and there is a great story-which is almost certainly untrue, but nevertheless bears repeating-of one of those occasions; told to me by James McCrae Dunn, who was sometime member for Geelong in the State Parliament and was a secretary to a number of Ministers here, including John Dedman, one of my more distinguished predecessors.

Jim McCrae Dunn reiterates that after the Coral Sea battle a private speech was made in this chamber by John Curtin. It was said to have been one of the most moving addresses ever made in an Australian parliament, and Curtin had a great reputation as an orator. When he sat down, no-one rose. Every member of this Parliament recognises that, while people might call it a talk shop, it is in awful trouble if no-one talks; there is just no remedy for that particular problem. A member, whose electorate will remain nameless because I cannot find him on the records of the Parliament, is reputed to have stood and commenced his remarks like this: `There we were, on the brink, a whole nation. Someone only had to pull the chain'. I rest the case.

In the time I have been in this chamber, we have seen many traumatic and historic events. I will not detail the events of 1975, events in which I participated, but they were traumatic and they were dramatic. No person who was in or near this chamber will forget them. Those who were around about five years earlier when John Gorton came down will recall this Parliament on a Wednesday debating the New South Wales Flood Mitigation Bill when 2,000 people queued up to get in to listen to the House pull John Gorton down, which was happening in a room out the back. Bert James started the demise of John Gorton. He made a speech on the adjournment, while sitting in the Deputy Whip's chair, which was drafted along the lines of the Mark Antony speech of a somewhat earlier time. He was immediately followed by Edward St John, who tore strips off the Prime Minister, a debate from which the Prime Minister never recovered; and his term as Prime Minister ended with a dramatic announcement in King's Hall by Tony Eggleton that the leadership of the Liberal Party of Australia had been changed and William McMahon was the leader. It is fair to say that William McMahon served in more ministries over a longer period than any other member in the Australian Parliament.

I should mention one other member before moving on, that is, Michael Maher. More than any other member who served in this Parliament I think he epitomised the local member. I was told-again, I think it is an untrue story-by a Commonwealth driver in Sydney on one occasion that when Michael walked down the main street of his electorate the dogs would sit up and hold out their paws to shake his hand. Unfortunately, Michael lost his seat in this place, as so many do.

I pay tribute to some of those members who have served here and to some of those who still serve here. I think the most courageous act and the greatest act of integrity that has taken place in this Parliament took place the day that Jim Cope lost the Speakership. He sat in this chamber; he complained to no-one, although he had been the victim of one of the worst acts ever perpetrated by his Party against any member of this Parliament in public. We will all miss this chamber. It has history and it has tradition. I have to say that I do not think that, at this stage, the new chamber has the capacity to be imbued with tradition. We will see. I think it is fitting that the people who have served here since 1927 should at least be remembered and that we should occasionally remember all of those who have been participants in the theatre, the drama and the importance of this chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robinson The Hon I.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is appropriate that at this time the House acknowledges, in the terms of the motion, `the contribution of former Members to the rich and colourful history of this chamber'. I wish to speak briefly about some of the illustrious people who served in the Country Party, later to become the National Party of Australia, in this Parliament. I refer particularly to the late Sir Earle Christmas Grafton Page. He was a member of this House for just over 41 years. I think his record is second, of course, only to William Morris Hughes's and embodies something that is perhaps inseparable from the timber, the structure and very history of this chamber. This is a chamber that I am sure will keep within its rather historic records many events and characters that we are not able adequately to refer to today.

SPEECH.PARA: Page was first elected in 1919 and shared with Bruce the historic occasion of the opening of this temporary Parliament House in 1927. At that time, Bruce said:
May those who enter this open door govern with justice, reason and equal favour to all. May they do so in humility and without self interest. May they think and act nationally.

Of course, the emphasis on acting nationally at that time was as a result of the great traumas of drawing together the States and getting acceptance of it by the so many Australians who saw this place as remote as the centre of government and the place from which government would emanate to the benefit of all Australians. In regard to that, Earle Page had an incredible record.

Earle Page was born of humble parents and educated in Grafton. He served first as a surgeon, gaining great distinction in that field, before serving in the Second World War. Immediately afterwards he was elected as the member for Cowper. As I said a moment ago, he had a very long record of service here. There are many people who have made remarkable initial contributions and then followed this with service of similar consistency. This is something that only history can properly record. Certainly, debate as short as this is unable to span that history. However, the book entitled Truant Surgeon, written by Earle Page, records much of the Page history and accordingly much of the history of this chamber. It refers to many of the events mentioned by those honourable members who have spoken in this debate today.

That history will continue. I was recently privileged to be associated with the election to the New South Wales Parliament of a grandson of Sir Earle Page as the first member for the State seat of Ballina. I mention that because there are other family names which I want very briefly to mention. Artie Fadden, who served as a Prime Minister and Leader of the Country Party, wrote a book entitled They Called Me Artie. I commend that book to all those honourable members and others who have an interest in learning more of the history of this Parliament and of this chamber. Page and Fadden were characters beyond belief. The stories that one told about the other and their practical jokes would fill a large volume. However, on the serious side, the contribution that both of them made is revealed only by the statute books and the legislation that embodies what is today the practice of government in this country. We think of others who have served here such as John McEwen who, as Leader of the Country Party, made a similar contribution.

Of course, much could be said about Sir Robert Menzies. I recall the period of my early service here when I was able closely to observe the Menzies approach. There has been no-one who has served in the Australian Parliament from its beginning until now who can be said ever to have emulated the capacity of Menzies as a member of parliament, as a Minister and as Prime Minister. I mention another family name, Anthony. Larry Anthony, the father of the former Deputy Prime Minister, Doug Anthony, became a member of this House in about 1938. I think he served for about 18 years. His son, Doug, who became Deputy Prime Minister within eight years of being elected to this chamber, served for 25 years. Again, we see established a record of service by father and son exceeding 30 years. Of course, there has been mention of others in the course of the debate. I will refer particularly to Charles Adermann, a Deputy Leader of the Country Party, and his son, Evan, who between them have served 45 years in this chamber. One can think of many other leaders and deputy leaders of the National Party. There was Charles Davidson and then those more recent leaders and deputy leaders who have departed. The names are too numerous to mention.

It is the intention of our Party to ensure that in the new Parliament House, visible to all visitors to the party room, there is a record of members who have given service in this Parliament. I believe that the history not just of one single party but also of all the parties and of all those who have served could be more appropriately recorded than has been the case thus far. Perhaps the future use of this building may take that suitably into account. One can but marvel at the contributions that have been made by so many who came from distant parts of Australia and who travelled here under really incredible circumstances. Of course, early travel to Canberra was by train. There were no air services. Let us think also of the conditions under which they attempted to participate in the function of parliament. They did not have the facilities then that we have today. They shared rooms. There were few secretarial services and there was none of the electronic equipment that is so much a part of the exercise of one's responsibilities today when, for example, one is able to pull out a fax from somewhere around the country within seconds. The transmission and communication of information across the continent were difficult and onerous tasks. That had to be taken into account in the working of this House. Certainly, I would like to be able to make some appropriate personal reference to so many of these members, but time precludes that.

Let me conclude by saying that it has been a privilege, as it must be regarded by anyone elected to this House, to have seen Prime Ministers from Menzies to the present occupant of that office, to have observed closely their capacity for leadership and to have been able to make comparisons. I note that there has been some frivolity in regard to what has been said in this chamber, but there is no doubt that democracy in Australia has been established to the extent that we now have a great record. It is a record that could well be the envy of virtually every other country in the world. That is dependent on the capacity of honourable members to recognise the Standing Orders; in particular, to recognise the human frailties and the personalities for who they are. People elect them and send them here, and we must respect them all. If we do nothing else today but acknowledge every person who has been sworn in as a member of this House, and say godspeed to all of them who have gone before, we must carry out our task to ensure that we uphold the dignity and the great responsibilities that fall upon the shoulders of anyone who enters this place.

It was said by Harry Truman that `a politician is a man who understands government, and it takes a politician to run a government. A statesman is a politician who has been dead 10 or 15 years'. How apt those words are when we think about them in retrospect today.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being past 12.30 p.m., the debate is interrupted.

INTERJECT.PARA: That so much of the Standing and Sessional Orders be suspended as would prevent the consideration of private members' business being continued until 12.40 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cross Mr M.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House for the courtesy it has paid me in allowing me to speak in this debate. I intend to speak about people I have known in my time here. I came here in 1961. The honourable member for Oxley (Mr Hayden) and I are the last two survivors of the generation of 1961, and the honourable member for Reid (Mr Uren) is the longest serving member in the House. The generation of 1961 was the largest contingent of Labor members elected until that time. Most of us came here as young people; we set aside the divisions which had characterised the Australian Labor Party since 1954 and directed our energies towards bringing about a situation where the Labor Party might enter government in due course.

SPEECH.PARA: Sir Robert Menzies-he was then Mr Menzies-was the dominant personality of the House. Although he had a certain aloof and distant relationship with many on his own side of the Parliament-and I imagine that arose from his experiences in earlier days, particularly in 1941-he was greatly encouraging to young members of the Opposition. If the honourable member for Oxley were here today, I am sure he would agree that he was encouraging to him and to me.

On the Labor Party side, one of the few people who could break Menzies' absolute control of the debate was Eddie Ward, the honourable member for East Sydney, who was a very tough gentleman. He was tenacious, rather like a bulldog, in pursuing the matters he believed in and the issues of the day. The Leader of the Labor Party in those days was Arthur Calwell, the honourable member for Melbourne-a marvellous man, a great human being, a person with a dogged adherence to the policies and principles of the Labor Party, and the father of our postwar immigration program. He was never to become Prime Minister, but he was certainly one of the great members of this House. I felt very sorry in 1969 and 1972 when many able members of the Federal Parliamentary Labor Party retired from parliament, some having spent 20 or 23 years in parliament, all of them in Opposition. Those of us who serve today are privileged indeed to have spent time-in some cases considerable time for Labor Party members-in government. Members of parliament today are better educated than they were in those days but the House lacks the colour of the blue collar workers of earlier times and the members of the then Country Party who had spent their earlier lives in rural occupations. I hesitate to say that I think there are many members of the National Party today who have not spent much time behind a plough.

I would be remiss if I did not refer to Gough Whitlam. Gough Whitlam led the campaign for a contemporary, participatory, democratic Australian Labor Party and the development of policies which were practicable within the restraints of the Australian Constitution. He played a notable role in bringing Labor to power in 1972 in what were to become difficult times. It was marvellous to be in government with such people as Frank Crean, Kim Beazley, Fred Daly and many others, implementing the policies that they had developed and advocated over the years. I would like to make a particular mention of Fred Daly, who was the great achiever for back bench members and an outstanding Leader of the House. When Labor came into office in 1972, as I previously mentioned, many of us had had experience of long years in Opposition, and Fred Daly, who had himself spent a considerable time in Opposition-since 1949-realised that much greater assistance and support had to be given to members and senators in order that they might carry out their duties. We got a second member of staff; we started to get contemporary office equipment. If we are going to erect another statue in the new Parliament House by subscription of back bench members, we ought to think kindly of Freddy Daly!

It is not just the people of great intellect and capacity who made their contribution here. I mention a couple of people on the other side of politics-Garfield Barwick, who was Attorney-General and a very competent Minister for External Affairs. He was brought in as a possible successor to Menzies, but never really made it in the hurly-burly of the House of Representatives. For all his ability-and I pay him a compliment for what he did as Minister for External Affairs in the days of confrontation with Indonesia-one always had the impression that he was never really comfortable in the House.

Paul Hasluck should have become Prime Minister, but he was regarded by his Party as not having a good relationship with the Press. He went on to become a distinguished Governor-General. Jack McLeay was a great Speaker, a World War I soldier and a great manager of the House. If I may pay a compliment to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, he exercised authority in the same way as you do. He was a very effective manager of the House.

I am reminded of Artie Fadden who said on more than one occasion that not all the good bowlers are on one side of the House.
