I think we all realise that on both sides of the House there are people who make their contribution to this nation. In a democratic parliament the issues of the day are debated with vigour, and the House respects the members who treat their opponents with courtesy and respect notwithstanding the heat of the parliamentary battle.

The members referred to today by all of those who preceded me in this debate passed on to those of us who serve today the torch of parliamentary democracy, and we who now serve have the challenge to carry that torch from this House to the House on the hill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I note in the spirit of the debate that has ensued in this chamber this morning that both the issues of private members' business have focused, not surprisingly, on the future of this chamber and on the sense of indebtedness we all feel to this place. Both the private member's motion moved by the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar), which focused on the Speaker's chair, and the private member's motion, which we have just debated, moved by the honourable member for Maribyrnong (Mr Griffiths), which was focused appropriately on those who have gone before us in this House, have given us opportunity to reflect, to be grateful and to comment on the history of this chamber. Therefore, I would like to use this, the last grievance debate in which I will have the opportunity of participating in this House, to reflect on some of the indebtedness I feel for the place and to grieve, in the spirit of the grievance debate, about some of the practices we have moved into that I think we ought to change.

SPEECH.PARA: `We are leaving this place and I feel certain regrets. I think, however, that we are going to our proper place. I trust that when we transfer our Parliament we shall continue the labours that have for that long period been carried on here with benefit to the people of Australia and credit to those who conduct the affairs of the Commonwealth. We feel regret at leaving a place that we have occupied for years, because we have felt the homeliness of the building even if the atmosphere of this chamber has not been so healthy as we should have liked'. Those are not my words but the words of a Mr Prowse, the then member for Forrest, uttered when the Parliament chose to leave its temporary home in the Victorian Parliament House on 24 March 1927 to come to this place.
I could be forgiven for saying that it seems nothing changes because, just as Mr Prowse felt on leaving the temporary Federal Parliament facility provided by the Victorian State Government-

TALK.START.PARA: —The Exhibition Building.

—The Exhibition Building; I thank the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs for his assistance. Just as Mr Prowse felt a certain reluctance on leaving the Exhibition Building and referred to its homeliness, all of us who occupy this building feel a sense of homeliness about it. We are here for two weeks of each month and it becomes a home away from home. Mr Prowse referred to the fact that the atmosphere had not always been healthy, and we would concede that there have been times when debate in this House has not been as honourable an experience as we would want, when the cut and thrust that is part of parliamentary debate has been replaced by scorn and derision from both sides, when we have been rude to friends opposite purely in the interests of partisan parliamentary point-scoring.

SPEECH.PARA: We too, as did Mr Prowse, feel certain regrets at leaving this place which has become home. As we leave it for the permanent Parliament House on the hill we must acknowledge, as did Mr Prowse, that we have carried on here principally with benefit to the people of Australia. I must concede, in the spirit expressed by the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Donald Cameron) earlier today during private members' business, that a real effort has been put in by colleagues on both sides of the House to represent adequately what we feel is the cry of our electorates. This chamber has seen a great deal of history. While members debated in this chamber World War II occurred, and prior to that there was a depression, which is almost unknown to most of the people of my generation who now occupy this facility. We must recognise that in 1988, with all the problems faced by Australia, my generation and our children belong to an exceedingly fortunate group of Australians who, in spite of what has happened in this chamber, have been well served by the parliamentarians who have represented them on both sides of this chamber over the past 61 years.

As one who occupies the conservative side of the House I recognise with pride that, in spite of what is sometimes said in debate, the conservative parties have been predominant over those 61 years. In spite of the faults on both sides of the chamber, in 1988 we have a nation that is a better place to be than was the case in 1927 when the chamber was first occupied. Here, in spite of us, democracy has been maintained. We would do well to remember that the majority of people in the rest of the world would give their right arm to have what we have here and to have what the people of Australia sometimes observe with a great deal of cynicism. This is the safety valve of democracy in our nation. Here, in spite of our partisan differences, we find common ground and the people of this nation, thanks to the system under which we are governed, thanks to the pre-eminence of the monarch, also have a common ground that bridges partisan differences. Inevitably, over the past 61 years some things have not changed, but some things do change.

In the spirit of a grievance debate I want to refer to some of the changes that I think have occurred in this chamber and have not necessarily been as helpful as those of us on both sides would have wanted them to be. Let us consider the changes that have occurred in our nation since 1927 when we moved from the Exhibition Building to here. Transport is vastly different. It is possible for me as a South Australian member easily to return to my electorate at the end of the week. That was not always so. It is possible for any one of us, thanks to the facilities provided to us and thanks to the sort of transport that is available, to go overseas for short periods instead of committing ourselves for six months, as was once characteristic in this place of overseas journeys.

Most of all, communication has changed and it is possible for what I am saying today to be heard around Australia and possible for what anyone says in this chamber to be reported and on the front page of the newspaper that lands in everyone's drive tomorrow morning. I grieve over the fact that I think what has happened in this chamber over the 61 years, looking back over Hansard, is that something of the quality of debate that was characteristic here has been lost. People have talked about ghosts in the ceilings; I think it is inappropriate. I sometimes sense a real presence in this place that almost oozes out of the walls and comes almost by osmosis out of the seats as we occupy places once occupied by predecessors either in Opposition or in Government.

As I look back over Hansard the change that I would grieve about this morning is, according to my discovery, that in the past debate in this place was much more lively. At the committee stage, for example, there would be a dozen speakers appearing in Hansard in a matter of two or three pages. I grieve that this chamber, which should be the cradle of democracy, is no longer a place where lively debate occurs but where much more frequently we turn simply to the cheap options of scorn and derision. I think one of the reasons for that is that the decisions that influence our electors are no longer made in this chamber. The debate no longer matters because whatever I say, no matter how persuasive I may think I am being, or how strongly I stand as advocate, the decision was made before I came into the chamber and made in one of the two party rooms. Why is the Press Gallery empty when the liveliest of debates occur? Because the decision has already been made.

I am pleased that I am part of a party that allows me to put my own personal loyalty first, then the loyalty of my constituents and, finally, loyalty to my Party. I am free to cross the chamber, free to be influenced by what is said by people on the other side. And my plea in this place, in this grievance debate, is that we ought to take into the new House the same sort of freedom that I have been able to take for granted, so that when I rise here, participating in a debate, I do it to influence those who sit opposite me and they are here to be influenced. It is a dreadful reflection on the Parliament that so many speeches are delivered to an empty chamber. What do the people in the gallery think when they look in here and hear such a speech being delivered?

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerr Mr D. J.

TALK.START.PARA: —A year ago to this day was the first day of the election campaign after which I had the honour of being elected to represent the people of Denison in this House. It is therefore an historic opportunity now, given that this is probably the last time I will be speaking in this place, to reflect on a number of the matters that have come to my mind since that time. I suppose that the first thing I should say is that we have come far in those months that have passed in terms of continuing the ongoing effort of the Australian Government to reconcile some of the fundamental problems that were facing this nation.

SPEECH.PARA: Amongst the most fundamental problems that faced us were those of the economy and those arising from the persistent conflict between the interests of those who were taking simplistic positions on the environment and employment. This Government has been able, in an historic way, to commence the task of showing that it can respect both the interests of those who wish to protect employment and those who know that the nation's future is not well served unless we can ensure that our natural environment and heritage are also protected. So, a year down the track from that election, we are moving in line with our commitments towards this historic reconciliation. We are approaching these issues with common sense, with rationality and with the proper sense of concern for both jobs and the environment which should characterise this debate.

When I first spoke in this House, I also raised what struck me as being a fundamental test of any government in Australia-the question of distribution of resources and wealth within our society. In that first speech I pointed out that although we have gone far in terms of making certain that those least well served in our community are protected from the economic difficulties that have been inherent in Australia's difficult passage through its adverse terms of trade, whilst we have done much to protect those least able to look after themselves, it is unfortunately true that increasingly there is a division between those with great wealth in our society and those who do not control such wealth-those who are at the bottom of the social order.

Reflecting on that, I think it is important that our Government has continued to put great emphasis on those most in need of assistance from government. Of course, that is a program that needs to be continued, it needs the support of both sides of the House. I refer to historic programs such as the family assistance scheme coming into existence, the maintenance and increasing of the real value of pensions, assistance that is going out to those who truly need the support of government, directed in the most efficient ways. These are historic steps towards a fairer, more just and more egalitarian society. But they are not sufficient steps, and our Government and our Opposition, those of all parties within our federal system, need to reflect consciously on the need for social justice, the need to move forward towards a society where those with the least in our community are given proper respect, protection and assistance in a way which our society is able to do if it is committed and has the will.

In my electorate I have seen some fruits of my own efforts to make sure resources are directed to those who are most in need. In the Denison electorate, in Glenorchy, for example, I am pleased to have been able to announce the program of information technology centres-a program that is directed towards retraining those who have been unemployed for lengthy periods, persons who have been unable to find a place in the work force without that program. It takes young people who have been unemployed for six months or more and trains them in high technology skills in areas where later they will be snapped up into the work force.

The history of these programs has been one of great success. I have been enormously pleased that the Australian Government has accepted a submission that was put to it through Anglicare in Tasmania, supported by the Glenorchy Council and the Tasmanian State Government ultimately. The Federal Government's very substantial financial contribution will mean that as of mid-year this year the first intake of young people into that program will commence. Disadvantaged job seekers in the northern suburbs of Tasmania will start getting assistance back into the work force.

I am committed to working to make sure that people in those areas of our community which do not have full access to the best of services have a fair go within the possible parameters of what is politically available, to make sure that they get the best deal that is possible out of this Government. Of course, in that context the Government has made enormous steps forward in making sure that it responds to its commitments, that it does live up to its word.

One point that I suppose I do grieve about in the terms of this grievance debate is the failure still of the Tasmanian Government to come up with bricks and mortar for the Claremont senior secondary college. Tasmania does have one of the poorest educational retention rates in Australia. I believe it is the poorest. We need desperately to have that northern community college operational so that the young men and women of Tasmania have the chance to learn the kinds of skills that are necessary to take their place in the employment market and not drop out, finding themselves unemployable. So, Mr Deputy Speaker, those are some important points.

Let me say something about one group of Australians who are extremely vulnerable and that is Aboriginal Australians. I had the honour, before my election to this House, to have once worked for the Aboriginal Legal Service Ltd of New South Wales, where I was principal solicitor. At the moment, Aboriginal legal services throughout Australia, through their national organisation, the National Aboriginal and Islander Legal Service Secretariat, are providing legal representation to the many families that are before the Muirhead Royal Commission on Aboriginal Deaths in Custody. There are now 106 inquiries being proceeded with before four separate commissioners.

This is presenting a very great difficulty for those who wish to ensure that the families concerned do have adequate representation, to make sure that funds are adequate to enable lawyers to represent those families before those proceedings. I note that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) is at the table. He has, in all instances, approached this issue with the greatest of sympathy, with the greatest of concern for those people who have been affected. It is his initiative which caused the Government, as one of its first steps after its election, to establish the Royal Commission.

It is this Government's commitment to Aboriginal rights, Aboriginal respect in Australia, that puts it at the forefront of civilised nations in the world in responding to the problems of indigenous peoples within their communities, but we still do have a very significant funding problem. I press upon the Minister the necessity to make sure that within that Royal Commission process adequate funds can be made available to assist the National Aboriginal and Islander Legal Service Secretariat to provide counsel for the multitude of hearings that are involved in the Royal Commission process.

Finally on this question of Aboriginal affairs, I grieve at the failure of the Liberal and National parties to join with the Government in this historic opportunity to pass a resolution jointly at the opening of the new Parliament recognising prior Aboriginal habitation of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are going to have a chance to vote on that.

—I understand that the Minister will be putting forward that proposition. I can only hope that in the course of deliberations between now and the opening of the new Parliament House, those parties opposite see it within their hearts to join together in consensus to express their common support for what should be a very basic and simple proposition-the recognition and respect for those who inhabited our nation before the arrival of Europeans. I would join with the Minister and with all honourable members, I am sure, on this side of the House, in requesting that those opposite review their position before that Parliament sits and I grieve lest that not occur.
— Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prosser Mr G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, it is less than 24 hours since the Treasurer (Mr Keating) stood in this place and delivered Labor's mid-term campaign speech. Commentators have described it, among other things, as a grand plan and clever. I would have to agree that this is probably the best attempt to mislead the people of Australia and he has had plenty of practice at it. Apart from the three or four positive points, the Government has failed miserably to provide any worthwhile gains for the average family. On the few occasions he has been able to achieve this, it inevitably has been a case of robbing Peter to pay Paul. In fact, taken as a package, the economic statement was a slick trick.

SPEECH.PARA: The Treasurer has conjured up some tasty morsels to disguise the Government's failure to make any inroads into its own level of government expenditure. The Treasurer boasts about cutting $982m of government spending. However, there is a large question mark over some of his fancy accounting and footwork which I am sure my colleagues in this House will elaborate on in due course. Even taking the total spending cut of $982m at face value, nearly 90 per cent was achieved by slashing State government revenue, or revenue to the States. Not even the Treasurer's creative accounting will hide the fact that the Government has baulked at funding tax cuts by cutting expenditure.

Even more disgraceful is his clumsy threat to withhold future personal tax cuts to prevent average families from seeking to improve their falling standard of living through reasonable wage increases. After all, the average family is already $42 a week worse off than in 1983. Now on top of the tax cut-wage restraint trade-offs, the Government has imposed extra costs on the Australian families such as an increase in the maximum cost of pharmaceutical prescriptions from $10 to $11 and, indirectly, increased State government charges, postal charges and Telecom telephone costs.

On closer examination, even the supposed positive areas of the economic statement are flawed. Let us turn for a moment to these generous concessions. I will not take up a lot of the time of the House on this point because there are not many of them. Firstly, the reduction in the corporate tax rate from 49c in the dollar to 39c in the dollar is great, except that it really does not take effect for 18 months and it will not help those small businessmen who run their businesses on individual or partnership bases. In effect, it rules out the large proportion of business communities, certainly in my electorate.

An income equalisation deposit scheme has been established. At last Labor has seen the folly of its decision to scrap the scheme in September 1983. Technically the scheme will benefit, for example, woolgrowers who are currently enjoying a buoyant period and taking advantage to deposit money in readiness for a downturn in the industry, so stabilising their income over the long term. Under this scheme, the deposit would be tax deductable in the year of deposit and assessed in the year of withdrawal. But the scheme will not apply until 1 July 1989, so that unless the wool industry's present boom continues until 1990, this scheme will not benefit woolgrowers at all.

Finally, the crowning achievement of the Treasurer's economic statement is an increase in the maximum pensioner rebate from $250 to $430. I know that the pensioners in Forrest will say, `It is not before time'. This Government has acknowledged that even pensioners have certain rights in this society, but will it really make up for the previous deferral of index benefits? If the public comments of pensioner groups are anything to go by, it seems that the elderly in our society do not think so.

Taken in the context of the whole economic package engineered by the Treasurer, these small steps forward fade into insignificance against the monumental setbacks for rural Australia. At the top of the list must be the decision to slash road funding by $50m in 1988-89. The Government has dismissed out-of-hand the massive opposition to the long term plan to destroy our road network, a vital communication link in rural communities. It is now inevitable that the national asset will become a national disgrace.

The policy of this Government over the last four years has threatened the safety of road users and has increased the cost of road transport. Now after the mini-Budget, the standard of our roads could soon be beyond the point of no return. The total road funding in 1988-89 will be just $1,215m, a reduction in real terms of more than 50 per cent on the level of road funding four years ago. What we desperately need is a significant increase in order to catch up four years of neglect under this Government.

The Treasurer and his merry men have rejected the opinions of experts and pleas of hundreds of local authorities around the country in regard to this matter. But the Government's motive is only too clear-to pass the buck for local road funding to local councils, but not to give them any money. Make them pay for the roads but do not give them any money to pay for them. Make them dig into their own coffers for finances they do not have. And in the end force them to go, yet again, to Mr and Mrs Average Australian and bleed them dry. That is the philosophy of this Government in a nutshell-wringing the last few cents out of a dry sponge. Its view is that people owe the Government everything but the Government does not owe them a damn thing. At the same time it takes away incentives from people to get off the canvas and start again.

I refer to the agricultural sector, for example, a not inconsiderable industry in my electorate, the Forrest electorate. Livestock and horticultural inspection fees and service charges are to be increased by a massive 20 per cent. As horticultural inspection fees were put on only this year, that particular sector has taken quite a beating this year. From 1988-89 the prescribed minimum value used for valuing natural increases in livestock numbers has been raised as well: $4 for sheep, $20 for cattle, $12 for pigs, $20 for horses. The values can take into account the quality of livestock, an important consideration in drought-affected areas where real values of livestock are almost certain to be lower.

Of course, fertiliser subsidies have been scrapped at a cost to the industry of $137m a year over the next three years. At a time when Australia desperately needs incentives for investment in plant and equipment, especially to develop a stronger manufacturing base, the existing arrangements enabling plant and equipment to be depreciated over three to five years will be scrapped.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Chair has been rather tolerant with the honourable member. Whilst he is free to raise matters of general economic interest, he is not free to anticipate debate listed on the Notice Paper. So I would suggest to him that he not make specific reference to the matter which awaits the proper attention of the House in due course.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, in this grievance debate I am raising the matters that will affect my electorate as a result of this mini-Budget.
—The honourable member is not free to address the mini-Budget, as he describes it. It is on the Notice Paper and he is free to address it, presupposing he gets the call, when it is before the House.

—Very well, sir. Mr Deputy Speaker, generally the rural sector of Western Australia has been hit hard. You will be well aware that the rural sector of Australia has been hit hard by costs. In regard to this particular matter, groups in my electorate have been severely disadvantaged. You would be well aware that pensioner subsidies and those sorts of things are means tested. You would also be aware that the family allowance supplement to rural Australia is to be asset tested. When many, many rural properties do not have a high income, those people will further be disadvantaged.

SPEECH.PARA: The road funding in my electorate is of crucial importance. In Western Australia roads and the transportation link are vital to all of the people in rural areas. To turn around and decrease funding in that particular area not only places a massive burden on the councils, shires and the State Government but also places a major burden on the people of rural Western Australia. It is their livelihood and their way of getting between particular points. We do not have flash and regular air services as do many other sectors of the country. In addition to that, all of my constituents, when they make a phone call to other areas of the country, of course do so on the basis of a subscriber trunk dialling charge. So again they are hit by ever-increasing costs.

Mr Deputy Speaker, it is a scandal that this Government does not recognise the needs of not only the average family, the business sector-the small business sector more particularly-but also those people in rural Australia and rural Western Australia. I would at least tell this Government that those people will not sit for ever and a day and take the sort of treatment that they have been given in regard to their livelihoods and those of their families and the pensioners of this community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brumby Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —During this debate today I want to take the opportunity to make a few comments and observations about my experience in this House over the last five years, since I have been a member from March 1983. During that time, as I look back, I have seen in here some nine economic statements and Federal Budgets presented. I have been here when we have passed hundreds of Bills. I have sat through many hundreds of Question Times and no doubt, of course, there have also been hundreds of divisions and an even greater number of quorums called. But I want to make a few points about a number of areas, the perceptions that I have of my experience here.

SPEECH.PARA: I guess I should start with some comments about the procedures and the practices of the House. I think it is easy to forget the degree of change which has occurred in five years in the practices and procedures of this House. We no longer have what I consider to be that silly business at the beginning of the day when we would come in here and members would jump to give notice of motions, knowing that in most cases those motions would never ever be debated in this place. I recall that Question Time has been shifted to a later hour of the day and it has now become established and accepted practice for Question Time to occur in here at 2 p.m.

We no longer read petitions individually, these being summarised and read in total. In recent times the opportunities for private members' business I think have been expanded and I welcome that. I note too that our patterns of sittings have changed. When I first came here we sat regularly on three days a week, Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday, and we would do that most commonly for three weeks of the month; but that pattern has changed and we now sit many more weeks of four days at a time.

More recently, of course, we have seen the expansion of the committee system as we know it in this House. Following the election last year, the House committee system was dramatically expanded. The new system is not a perfect system and committees still do not, in my view, play as important a role as they should but I am sure that with the new facilities in the new House, the new meeting rooms and so on, the opportunities for further participation and a greater contribution from committees will continue to grow.

I also welcome the recent decision providing for a smaller number of members to be present in this House to form a quorum. I think that decision would continue the momentum that we have established in here towards a more effective parliamentary process. Many would argue that over recent decades, with what I think has been an inexorable shift towards executive-style government, this chamber has become something of a moribund institution. To a degree I have to say that that is true but I have to say also that during the period in this place in which I have been a member, the Parliament has changed its practices and procedures and perhaps it has not done that to a great enough degree. It is certainly my view that in the period I have been here the chamber has become a more effective institution today than it was five years ago.

I have a few comments also about the composition and, if you like, the style of the members who make up this place. I guess one thing that comes to mind is dress; the double-breaster has made something of a resurgence over the years in which I have been here. Looking back, who would have thought in 1983, as we looked forward to our bicentennial year in 1988 and the opening of the new Parliament House, that our Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in these times would have appeared at that opening dressed in a double-breasted suit. So there have been changes in dress.

The composition of the House has also changed, perhaps in subtle ways but also in significant ways. More women are representatives in this place. I am particularly pleased to note that in this House now we have a front bench Minister, Mrs Kelly, as Minister for Defence Science and Personnel. More government backbenchers are now representatives from Queensland and in the time I have been here, we have also seen a decline in the relative importance in this place of the role of the National Party of Australia.

Also during this period we have enjoyed a remarkably stable period of leadership from the Government. I am not trying to be partisan or political about that, but over the last five years we have had a Prime Minister who has remained unchanged, and a Treasurer (Mr Keating) who has remained unchanged, as have the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin), the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) and the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden). All those Ministers have remained in their portfolios for close to 5 1/2 years. They have done their jobs very well and professionally, and I doubt whether anyone looking back through the history books would find any other time in our history when that stability in leadership has been enjoyed by any government.

I guess the final point that comes to mind about the composition of this place is its size; that is, of course, that the Parliament has been expanded during the time in which I have been a member from 124 to 148 members. What about the media and the way the business of this House is reported? Again I think there have been numerous but subtle changes to the way the business of this House is reported. The electronic media, for instance, are now able to use recorded excerpts of statements in their reporting. I think this is something that has added life and authenticity to reporting, particularly in radio.

There have also been massive changes during this time in the structure and ownership of the media. A number of newspapers, the Brisbane Telegraph, the Sydney Sun, the Times on Sunday and the Western Mail no longer exist. Like all other areas of the economy, the media too have been the subject of some structural adjustment forces. We now have regularly established in this place, Mr Deputy Speaker, the televising live of the Treasurer's Budget and May economic statement.

I guess also, looking at the media, there has been a continued sophistication by journalists in the use of the mixed metaphor. Greg Hywood's achievement last year of the mixed metaphor award comes to mind. If I recall it correctly, his mixed metaphor was, `Is there life at the end of the tunnel? Alternatively, is there light at the end of the tightrope?'. They are expressions which he used eloquently, I think, to explain the Government's dilemma following the terms of trade collapse in 1985.

The language of this place has also changed. The expression `putting in place' in relation to policies has become very common, and I think more policies have been put into place here than ever before. Our Treasurer has brought a new aesthetic and artistic dimension to the way in which we understand concepts. We talk now of the big picture, the main game, the broad canvas and the broad brush. Words which years ago were judged to be technical economic jargon now seem to be commonplace. All members talk knowingly now of the PSBR, the public sector borrowing requirement, and the TWI, the trade weighted index; of the balance on current account and the terms of trade. At the same time some of the older economic language, such as the money supply, M1 and M2, seems to have gone from our vocabulary for all time.

The facilities and the resources available to members have also been improved in the period I have been a member here. When I was first elected in 1983, both my electorate office and my parliamentary office had more in common with a nineteenth century factory than they did with a twentieth century member's office. The technology was obsolete and staff resources were inadequate. Members' offices are now well equipped with decent typewriters, computer and facsimile technology and our staffing allocation has been increased to more reasonable levels.

Finally, Mr Deputy Speaker, what of the big debates and the issues in this place which come to mind? Predominantly, I think they have been economic. There have been heated debates, for instance, about reforms to the tax system, the capital gains tax, the fringe benefits tax and the assets test. There have been debates about policies which I might say that now, despite heated debate and the claims that the world would come to an end if these things were implemented, have become pretty well embedded as a part of our tax and social security system.

Other heated non-economic debates come to mind, and I refer particularly to equal opportunity legislation and immigration. In immigration in particular, the debate we had here in 1984 was not one that I would like to see repeated, because it was not based on logic or objectivity, but to too great a degree on prejudice and short term opportunistic political gain. I am privileged to have served in this place over the past five years. I will have some nostalgia about leaving it, but I can assure you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that I am very much looking forward to taking my place in the new House on the hill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I want to make a smorgasbord of the grievance debate today and mention a few matters. One is of a constituent who referred to me a patent he has developed for what is called the electronic polarity therapeutic stimulator. It came to my attention at the same time as we were debating in this House the Commonwealth Employees Rehabilitation and Compensation Bill which threw up the examples of the tremendous costs now being faced by the Commonwealth in connection with compensation claims, particularly in connection with repetition strain injury.

SPEECH.PARA: In the debate the shadow Opposition spokesman of the time mentioned that in the Defence Department 30 per cent, or 4,737, of the 15,600 employees succeeded with claims and only 14 had failed. In the Department of Primary Industries and Energy 31 per cent, or 1,000, out of 3,516 employees had made claims and only 11 had failed. When we come to a situation of debating in this Parliament the costs of government, this is the material content of it. I just mention that as far as the Federal Government is concerned. One would have to multiply that by the number of similar cases in State Public Services and then there is again the tremendous cost in industry that is incurred through these claims for compensation.

I am raising this matter today because a constituent of mine by the name of Mr Tom Lester, while not by any means saying he is a sports physician or is involved in sports medicine, has for a long time been the strapper for one of the Australian rules teams in Mackay. He developed this machine out of a sympathy for and a reaction to the types of injuries, muscular and otherwise, that sportsmen and sportswomen were getting. On that basis he wrote to the State department and got a very sympathetic hearing from the Minister of compensation in that State, saying that he thought it was a good idea but he would have to get not testimonials from people he had used it on but advice from a bank of medical practitioners who could then, as they say, provide a double blind trial of the stimulator and proceed from there.

I would have to say that there appears to be a prejudice by medical practitioners against anything that does not really relate to the traditional forms of medicine, and obviously this is one of them. I am mentioning it today on the basis that perhaps it has relevance in view of that debate on the Commonwealth Employees Rehabilitation and Compensation Bill to our own Federal Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett), probably the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West) and particularly those in command of employee compensation. I would have to give credit to this man. He has persevered over many years. He is not a young man but he has devoted a lot of time to the public. He has learnt a lot from it and I hope that some recognition can be given in that regard.

The other matter I want to alert the House to today is a comment arising out of the papers that came through last night on the mini-Budget relating to the proposed removal of the sugar embargo and its replacement by a tariff. I mention this because the sugar industry is absolutely alarmed and startled at this move.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member may not have been in the chamber when the Chair had the requirement to acquaint a member speaking of the fact that he could not anticipate debate on a matter listed in the Notice Paper. If the honourable member wishes to address matters relating to the industry, he should not do so by way of direct reference to the ministerial statement made by the Treasurer.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, this matter is not going to be raised today because it is not in any of the primary industry Bills. It will be a Bill in the future, but not today.
—There is a motion on the Notice Paper that the House take notice of the Treasurer's statement and that will be coming up for debate.

—Without reference to that, then, I would say that the industry was contemplating a review by the industry review panel and this was promised. It was indicated that this was going to happen but at no stage was the industry alerted to the problem that might present itself in the form of the statement made yesterday. I go on record as saying that the sugar industry has been well served by the embargo. If there is any threat of its removal the industry would hope that there would be deep consideration given, and as the Treasurer (Mr Keating) mentioned this morning, discussions could be held on these matters as the industry would avail itself of that opportunity.

SPEECH.PARA: The sugar industry is probably one of the most decentralising industries that we have in Australia. The embargo has served well; it has served both industry-the producer and the miller-and also the consumer well and any suggestion of its removal should be well considered. Even though there is a suggestion of replacement tariffs it should be well considered in view of that record and the longstanding arrangements that have existed.

The other matter I wish to mention is that in December last year I was alerted to a situation of a potential contract or tender that had been let for the Cocos Island run. On 29 December I issued certain statements in regard to it, because, as far as I could ascertain from the Department of Administrative Services, there is a lot of toing and froing. As a result of that, a lot of publicity was given subsequently in the Western Australian, Northern Territory and shipping Press to what I was saying. On 7 January, the contract was eventually but very hastily awarded to a Western Australian State shipping line, Stateships, even though before that date comment had been made that this was likely to happen.

On 8 January I lodged a freedom of information (FOI) request with the Department of Administrative Services for all the documents relating to the Stateships tender. In a Press release the same day, I said that the following questions must be answered: `Did the Federal Government give Stateships reason to believe they would be given the Cocos contract before it was awarded? Did the Western Australian Government approve Stateships leasing a vessel for the Cocos contract service before the contract was awarded. Did Stateships purchase or lease such a vessel before the contract was awarded? Was the sudden awarding of the contract to Stateships an attempt to paper over the above?'

I also reiterated my concern about the ability of the Stateships vessel to be able to negotiate the Cocos Island channel. As a result of my freedom of information request, I am now aware that the massive publicity given to the circumstances surrounding the awarding of this contract resulted in the Department of Administrative Services conducting both a preliminary and detailed review of the procedures and paperwork involved. Even the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) asked the Department for a briefing on this particular matter.

The documents I have show that the preliminary review of the Department of Administrative Services basically whitewashed the whole matter. I do not have the result of any detailed review because this was completed after my FOI request had been fulfilled. However, the fact that Stateships still has this contract and in fact has gone on to get the Christmas Island service as well speaks for itself. Having received and analysed a pile of over six inches of documents on this matter, I am now in a position to answer these questions, as well as to raise other matters of serious concern to do with the putting to tender and letting of this contract.

The questions I raised at the time were: `Did the Federal Government give Stateships reason to believe they would be given the Cocos contract before it was awarded?' The answer is obviously yes. `Did the Western Australian Government approve Stateships contracting a special vessel for the Cocos Islands service before the contract was awarded?' The answer again is yes. `Did Stateships contract such a vessel before the contract was awarded?' Again, yes. And, `Was the sudden awarding of the contract to Stateships an attempt to paper over the above?' In all probability this answer is also yes.

However, I do not wish to dwell on these points as they pale into insignificance in comparison with other irregularities I have discovered in connection with this matter. I do not intend to raise these now, but will issue a detailed report on this whole matter in the next fortnight or so. Suffice to say, it will disclose major deficiencies and bungling by the Department of Administrative Services which could have been avoided if the two Ministers I have mentioned had followed the advice that I was giving at the time. In fact, in all respects the whole letting and awarding of this contract may not be any different from what we have pursued in this House in what became known as the Amann affair.

I should also like to say something in connection with Christmas Island. As this House will be aware, I have been concerned for some time about the continuing project for Christmas Island, particularly as the phosphate mining was discontinued by the corporation in December last year. In February I was given an assurance that expressions of interest would be called for. These were received by the end of March, but I was alarmed just recently to learn that the liquidator in being appointed the assessor for those contracts or tenders had extended the time for expressions of interest. This has concerned me greatly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snowdon Mr W.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, let me say how pleased I am to have this opportunity to speak for probably the last time in this House during a grievance debate. The matter I wish to address this afternoon is one which I first mentioned to this House on 19 April this year. It is in relation to a money-raising effort by the Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) personnel from Darwin and Edinburgh. I am pleased that the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly) is at the table this afternoon because I would like to applaud the efforts of these RAAF personnel. They set out to contribute towards the raising of $1.5m for the provision of an aircraft for the Royal Flying Doctor Service, that aircraft to be based in Alice Springs which, as honourable members will know, is my home.

SPEECH.PARA: The run was sponsored by K-Mart which assisted in the publicity for the run and the effort to raise these funds. The RAAF contingent-the two teams, one from Edinburgh and one from Darwin-had as its organiser and public relations person, Tony Rafferty. Tony Rafferty, as you will know, Mr Deputy Speaker, is the current holder of the international 1,000-mile record-British and Australian-and was the first man to run from Sydney to Melbourne and across the Nullarbor Plain. He was also the first man to run across the Australian continent, from Fremantle to Surfers Paradise, a distance of some 5,931 kilometres.

The objective of these runners from both Edinburgh and RAAF Base, Darwin, was to run from Darwin to Adelaide, a distance of some 3,051 kilometres, in nine days. There were 20 runners and 15 ground support staff. I am happy to say that they succeeded in their endeavours and I would like to pay special tribute to Squadron Leader Owen Hammond from Darwin who, as the Minister knows, is a very dedicated member of the RAAF personnel and is very highly thought of, not only in the RAAF community but also in the wider community within Darwin.

The Darwin personnel who were in fact running in this effort were Flying Officer Gary Adrian, Flight Sergeant John Carr, Sergeant Bob Rhorig, Corporal Bone, Corporal Air, LAC Wright and Corporal Sullivan. The team from Edinburgh had a similar number of runners and each team included a woman runner. The woman runner from Darwin was Lisa Downes and there was another woman, Sharon Noyes. Unfortunately, Sharon sustained an injury in the course of the relay and was unable to complete it. The lady from Edinburgh was Corporal Wilson, who ran in this relay from Darwin to Adelaide.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why did you not run?
—The honourable member asked why I did not run.
—No. I was asking the Minister at the table.

—I ran in her stead. I was thinking of the Minister while I was jogging. The runners left the Casuarina shopping centre at 12 noon on 11 May and arrived in Adelaide at 12 noon on 20 May. For the benefit of the honourable member for Dawson, I inform him that they arrived in Alice Springs on Sunday 15 May and it is there that I joined one of the runners to run a few kilometres through Alice Springs, in an effort to publicise their endeavours.

SPEECH.PARA: I am happy to say that the runners are now world champions. The two teams ran-10 each from Darwin and Edinburgh and, as I suggested earlier, there was a woman in each team-the total distance, as I have said, of over 3,000 kilometres. In fact, they had to add 150 or so kilometres because they were running ahead of time and they needed to arrive in Adelaide for publicity purposes at 12 noon. It necessitated their running, I believe, an extra 150 or so kilometres.

The highlight perhaps of the effort is that they averaged around 3 minutes 53 seconds per kilometre for every kilometre which easily broke the previous world record of 4 minutes 12 seconds. The total amount raised for the Royal Flying Doctor Service in this relay is as yet unknown and the RAAF runners are travelling back to Darwin today and are collecting on the way. However, $70,000 has definitely been raised with the possibility of at least another $10,000 on top. Of course, Mr Deputy Speaker, when one takes into account that for every dollar they raise there is a dollar contribution from the Commonwealth, this will mean a total of somewhere in the vicinity of $160,000 which has been raised directly as a result of the efforts of these RAAF runners.

The runners are expected back at the RAAF base at Darwin this afternoon at 4.15 where there is expected to be a large welcome. I do not want to take much more of the House's time other than to say that this demonstrates, I believe, the commitment of armed service personnel to the community interests. I know from the words of Royal Flying Doctor Service officers in Alice Springs that the efforts of the RAAF Base, Darwin, and Edinburgh are highly regarded and I would anticipate that the profile of the RAAF community in Darwin has been raised quite significantly in terms of the contribution they are making, not only to the Darwin community but also to the Northern Territory community generally.

I know, as the Minister at the table will testify, that the contribution they are prepared to make is enormous. Indeed, our discussions with RAAF members and Navy and Army service personnel in the Top End have shown that they are prepared to make a long term commitment to remote north Australia. They want to make it their home; they want to make a contribution; and this is a demonstration of the type of contribution they are prepared to make. It is an enormous sacrifice, a personal sacrifice. I spoke to Owen Hammond prior to the run when the Minister was in fact at RAAF Base, Darwin, and he said to me that he was having to run as part of his preparation about 130 or 140 kilometres a week and he was getting pretty tired of it. He was looking forward to the rest that he could enjoy at the end of the relay. I wish him well and I am sure that he will have his feet up for the next few weeks and perhaps will gain a few ounces as well.

I know at first hand that the runners all enjoyed the assistance-the stimulus, if you like-of a touch of the amber fluid at the end of each evening during their run. I am sure that this afternoon when they are celebrating in Darwin they will recall the relaxation that they enjoyed then, but they will enjoy it much more now that the run is finished.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McArthur Mr F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I wish to grieve on behalf of the pay as you earn (PAYE) taxpayers and wage and salary earners throughout Australia because of the very high tax rates they are now sustaining under the Hawke-Keating Government. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) has built up a so-called international reputation for fiscal responsibility and tax reform. The figures confirm the stark reality that under the present Labor Administration taxes have increased in every quarter and the major defect of the Hawke-Keating Government is its reputation for extracting tax from hard-working Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: A close examination of the Budget Papers reveals that under the Keating regime government revenue is almost doubled. The 1982-83 Budget estimated that $44.3 billion would be received in revenue. Compare that with the 1987-88 Budget that estimates the Government will collect $78.1 billion. On a close examination, the impact on companies and individuals is even more apparent. Tax levied in 1982-83 was $22.9 billion. However, in 1987-88 the Treasurer is estimating that $41 billion will be drawn from this source. This is a doubling of the tax received from companies and individuals over the five-year period that the Hawke Government has been in power.

Against this backdrop it is hard to substantiate the responsible approach to taxation when figures of this magnitude clearly demonstrate the tax grab of the Treasurer. In both the United States of America and Great Britain the issue of tax reduction has been addressed by President Reagan and Prime Minister Thatcher. They have the runs on the board in reducing the impact of direct tax on individual taxpayers. In Australia all we have managed to date is extra taxes and a tax summit. The only achievement of the tax summit was to increase the size and complexity of the tax Act and to introduce more taxes into the system.

The impact of PAYE income tax on individual Australians is now the focal point for discontent and a lack of incentive for Australians to work hard. Not only are individuals suffering the effects of less take-home pay, but the impact of bracket creep is becoming apparent as taxpayers compare their position in March 1983 with November 1987. In March 1983 a single income family on average weekly earnings had an average tax rate of 17.5 per cent. By November 1987, however, this tax rate had increased by 5 per cent to 22.5 per cent. The other quite dramatic change as a result of bracket creep is the increase in the marginal tax rate from 30 per cent to 40 per cent over the same period. In sheer dollar terms the single income family on average weekly earnings paid $65 each week in 1983. By November 1987 the same family was paying $117 per week.

The problem of bracket creep was vividly demonstrated in the papers tabled at the tax summit in 1985. Treasury estimated that in 1954-55 it took 18 times average weekly earnings for an individual taxpayer in full time employment to reach the top marginal tax rate, whereas in 1985 it took only 1 1/2 times average weekly earnings for an individual taxpayer to reach the marginal rate. This insidious increase brought about by inflation has moved individual taxpayers into higher tax brackets without any government legislation or regulation.

Successive governments have managed to increase their revenue from PAYE taxpayers quietly and almost secretly without the taxpayers being aware of the impact of the progressive tax system. In 1988 taxpayers around the world, and especially in Australia, are revolting against this increased imposition. The bracket creep is clearly demonstrated by a table which I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. The table illustrates very clearly how taxpayers move into the top bracket. The table shows that in 1957-58 2.4 per cent of taxpayers were in the top bracket, yet by 1987-88 47.7 per cent of taxpayers had reached the top marginal rate.

SPEECH.PARA: Margaret Thatcher has led the way by restoring incentive to the tax system. Beginning with a poor economic base, Prime Minister Thatcher has endeavoured to reduce the incidence of personal taxation. Upon gaining government in 1979 high income earners in England were subjected to a staggering 98 per cent in tax at the marginal rate in some instances. In 1988, nine years later, the Thatcher Government had reduced the marginal rate to 40 per cent, with middle income taxpayers paying 25 per cent. In the recent British Budget the Thatcher Government was strongly criticised for neglecting the poor and favouring those who were prepared to work and take risks. The Chancellor of the Exchequer, Mr Nigel Lawson, was quite clear in his philosophic position when he said, `You do not make the poor rich by making the rich poor'. He made further reductions in the rates of capital taxes that individual taxpayers were required to pay.

The British economy has recovered from the doldrums because individual taxpayers are now prepared to work hard in order to gain more take-home pay so that they can better themselves and their families and improve their standards of living. This is a move away from the welfare dependent syndrome which the Attlee Labour Government implemented progressively after the Second World War in 1945.

One of the key factors of the vigorous British economy is the continuing tax reform which has changed the nation's attitude towards productivity, wealth creation and self-worth. The British disease, which was brought about by an appalling industrial relations system along with a punitive tax system, contributed towards Britain's postwar decline. In the United States similar pressures emerged to reform the tax system. In 1984-85 the United States Treasury put forward tax reform proposals which had as their objective a simplification of the income tax system and a reduction in the marginal rates. The reform legislation which was finally passed through Congress reduced the number of personal rates from 14 to two and lowered the top marginal rate from 50 per cent to 33 per cent.

As honourable members would be aware, these reductions in America were achieved by removing many special exemptions and tax shelters. There was also a switch of the tax burden from personal taxation to the corporate sector. These are reforms by the Reagan Administration and the politicians improved incentives to work and save. The United States tax system has special characteristics such as interest being deductable for the principal and second residence along with other offsets which have been built into the system.

The industrial and economic power of the United States was founded on the work ethic and legislators were keen to preserve this attitude within the tax system. Within their flexible industrial relations environment American workers have striven to improve their personal standard of living by earning more money on the job.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 1.45 p.m., in accordance with standing order 106, as amended for this session, the debate is interrupted, and I put the question:

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Torrens Road Drainage Authority-Pensioners-X-rated Videos-Australian Society-Wool Promotion-Speaker's Chair-Tasmania-Bowling Clubs-Industrial Relations-Gold Tax

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pratt Mr M.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the impending winter in Adelaide, the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West) and the 200,000 residents I wish to represent in this debate who concern me. The Torrens Road Drainage Authority (TRDA), representing four councils for 16 years, has had an easement on a parcel of land known as the Gillman ponding basin. This ponding basin controls winter, storm and flood waters. The State Government funded and recognised authority, the TRDA, has committed $8m of capital works to this project and is in danger of losing control over its deal over its drainage because the Federal Government has welshed on a deal.

SPEECH.PARA: The TRDA represents not only 200,000 residents of Adelaide but also downstream the South Australian fishing industry's most important nursery benefits, as well as the eco-balance of marine life, the World Heritage mangroves and the sand-fast swamp and Magazine Creek wetlands. Significantly, this pondage basin prevented a major pollutant spill from wiping out these areas. Previous Labor Government Ministers had filed approaches on this matter in the too-hard basket and the current Minister can be added to this list. His weak reply to my question yesterday shows he does not care a damn about my constitutents' stormwater problems.

Yesterday Minister West claimed he did not know which area I was referring to. However, he signed a letter on 20 November 1987, seven months ago, referring to this precise matter. I call on the Minister to stop the proceedings to sell by tender the 67-hectare parcel of land, section 4/40 and parts 450 and 100 of Port Adelaide. I call on the Minister to abide by the decision of the arbitrator suggested by his predecessor and to accept the State Valuer-General's figure of $120,000 rather than the opportunistic $2m asked for by the Commonwealth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —When I was elected as the member for Lilley in October 1980 I was fired by a need to support lower income people and pensioners. I wanted them to have a better go and this is reflected in my maiden speech on 3 March 1981. I want to put on record that, while I have learnt the lesson that the world cannot be changed overnight, I have faith in this Hawke Labor Government and am pleased that it has done so much to better the conditions of pensioners. We recognise that there is more to be done but it is this Government which has raised the pension from just over 22 per cent of average weekly earnings in 1983 to the promised 25 per cent of average weekly earnings.

SPEECH.PARA: We brought in the important carer's pension. We have done a lot, including a great increase in funding for people with disabilities, and, particularly as announced last night, in a time of great stringency, we are able to raise the pensioner tax rebate from $250 to $430 as a fine finale to the excellent moves which the Government has made while in this House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Webster Mr A.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to express my hope that the Government will take action and provide leadership in the defence and strengthening of this nation's moral and social values. The Parliament has before it the final report of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material, which confirmed both anecdotal and behavioural science evidence that a great deal of M- and R-rated film material and all X-rated material are harmful, especially to children. The Parliament has before it a resolution of its Senate passed on two occasions recently calling for a moratorium on X-rated videos. The Parliament is aware of the unanimous desire of the State governments to ban X-rated videos and to tighten censorship standards.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, the Parliament is served by the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) who has expressed disappointment at the time this censorship review has been tied up by the deliberations of a parliamentary committee. The Attorney-General must move immediately to ban X-rated videos and to restrict access to violent R-rated videos. Too much time has already been lost. As a result, a massive amount of video material has already entered the community to the detriment, in particular, of children and women.

I have here a drawing produced in an art class in a public school in my electorate. It depicts the video imagery which now burns and poisons the minds of our children. When asked to draw a picture of his dreams this student drew dismembered bodies, headed `My dream, shades of massacre three'. That is the legacy of this Parliament's apathy and confusion on censorship, a legacy of child abuse and degradation of women. That is an example of why the Government should not waste further time before acting on this problem. I seek leave to table this drawing.
Leave not granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harvey Mrs E.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In my last speech in the old Parliament House I would like to pay tribute to those Australians who were living when this building was opened in 1927, those who are now senior citizens. The Australians who were children or very young adults in 1927 have lived through a remarkable and eventful era in Australian history. They experienced the deprivation of the Great Depression and the trauma and loss of the Second World War. Then in the 1950s and 1960s they re-established their lives and raised their families in an era of relative stability and prosperity, when life was simpler, when material expectations were lower and when, in the words of the old song, east was east, west was west and women were women.

SPEECH.PARA: Things have changed in the last 20 or so years. That stark black and white delineation between what is right and what is wrong, between who are our political enemies and who are our friends, between man's role and woman's role has been blurred or broken down entirely. Many of these changes have been positive. They have brought about a more tolerant, a more humane and richer society. But they have also led to the erosion of some of those old-fashioned values, self-respect, consideration, discretion and family solidarity.

Elderly people I talk to in my electorate, while they support social advances which have been made, are confused and distressed at their social fall-out. Family breakdowns, drug addiction, theft and vandalism are things that they do not understand and certainly do not welcome. It will be our job in the new Parliament House to continue to set the legislative and policy framework to minimise the dark side of social change and to set through our own behaviour an example of responsibility and altruism to the young people of Australia.

and note this-
