QUESTION.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Treasurer. I refer him to an article in the Sydney Morning Herald of this morning by Ross Gittins, which said:

QUESTION.PARA: By postponing our next tax cuts until the financial year after next, Mr Keating has saved himself-and cost us-a small fortune. By pushing income-earners into higher tax brackets, he has saved himself about $1.5 billion.
I ask the Treasurer whether Mr Gittins's estimate of $1.5 billion is reasonable.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can only put the context of the tax cuts in this way: the revenue to gross domestic product (GDP) ratio of the Commonwealth will be falling. That is, there will be great reductions in the size of the Commonwealth government sector, with outlays falling from 29.9 per cent of GDP in 1983-84 to 25.5 per cent in prospect for next year and 24.5 per cent the year after. This fall in Budget outlays will surpass anything during the Fraser-Howard years and take Commonwealth outlays back to the pre-Whitlam years of the late 1960s and early 1970s. The fall has been occasioned by cuts to public spending.

ANSWER.PARA: This Government made large discretionary tax cuts in 1985 and 1987. Those large discretionary tax cuts have been a de facto indexation of the system. We are saying that we will contemplate further substantial tax cuts in 1989-90, provided there is an appropriate wage-tax arrangement. In doing so, we will meet the point about the non-indexation of the tax scales. The question was a quite interesting one to come from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition after his Party promised indexation of the tax system in 1977 and then squibbed it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, in this my last opportunity to ask a question in the old Parliament House, I take the opportunity to congratulate you formally on the way you have conducted the responsibilities of the Chair in this House. My question is addressed to the Minister for Social Security. It concerns the pensioner tax rebate. Last night the Treasurer announced an increase in the level of the pensioner tax rebate. Can the Minister explain what this means for pensioners across Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the Treasurer's announcement last night because of the significant relief this will provide for pensioners. The Treasurer has moved to ensure that those dependent on social security pensions are not subject to income tax. Given this Government's commitment to the indexation of pensions every six months, we are acutely aware that in the financial year 1988-89 the level of pension will increase above the effective tax free threshold for pensioners.

ANSWER.PARA: There are two different and separate issues involved, which must be made quite clear when talking about pensioner income levels and the level of the pensioner tax rebate. Let me take first the issue that was addressed by the Treasurer last night, the pensioner tax rebate level. The pensioner tax rebate addresses the level of annual income at which pensioners must start paying tax. What the Treasurer did last night was to increase the annual rebate by $180, from $250 to $430. This means that from 1988-89 pensioners will not have to pay any tax until their taxable income is more than $6,892.

There has been some confusion, evidenced by calls on social security hotlines this morning. Let me say that the pensioner tax rebate is not connected with the pension free area; that is, the amount of income pensioners can earn every week before their pension is reduced. This income test free area allows pensioners to receive extra money each week in, say, interest or from some casual work and still receive the whole of their pension. The income test free area was not changed by the Treasurer's announcement last night but last year there was a significant easing of the income test to $40 a week for single pensioners and $70 a week combined for pensioner couples. That easing of social security tests, together with the measures announced by the Treasurer last night, is part of the Government's overall integrity policy to ensure that we have a reduction in the effective marginal tax rebates and that there are not disincentives for pensioners to attract some additional income.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I inform the House that we have present in the gallery this afternoon a delegation from the House of Representatives from the Parliament of Cyprus, led by the President of the House of Representatives, His Excellency Dr Vassos Lyssarides. On behalf of the House, I extend a very warm welcome to the members of the delegation.

—My question is addressed to the Treasurer. I refer him to the fact that the superannuation package announced last night will tax lump sum superannuation benefits in excess of $60,000. I also refer the Treasurer to the fact that a lump sum of considerably more than $60,000 is required to yield an income equivalent to the existing age pension. I ask: Is not the tax on lump sums of above $60,000 a disincentive for people to provide for their own retirement and, hence, will it not reduce the prospective savings on outlays for aged pensions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We on this side of the House have a different view from the Opposition about the role of superannuation. We do not regard it as being a proposition for people to forgo cash, particularly cash productivity increases, in return for superannuation merely to diminish their pension by the same amount. What kind of a proposition would it be if we said, `Please save so that we can withdraw your savings from the pension on a dollar for dollar basis'? We reject that proposition absolutely. We support the concept of superannuation.
—You brought in the assets test.

—Yes; we have a sensible structure. We have an assets test and an income test, but pensioners' savings are not being withdrawn dollar for dollar. Of course, honourable members opposite would not know that because they do not know how the system works.

ANSWER.PARA: What I find amazing about the question is the lack of any conceptual grasp of what the whole superannuation arrangement is. The Government is reducing the 15/30 tax-that is, the existing 30 per cent tax on lump sums over $55,000 and the 15 per cent tax on lump sums under $50,000-to zero and 15 per cent. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition is proposing that the 15 per cent tax ought to be removed from lump sums over $60,000 because he believes that the concessionality of superannuation ought to be enhanced by diminishing that tax to zero. That is the implication of his question. That would simply see much higher levels of income streamed through the concessional provisions of superannuation, which would restore it to being a tax ramp and not a concession. So the Government fixed that. The honourable member's Government never had the courage to touch it for 30-odd years; we fixed that in 1983. What we are doing now is bringing forward that taxation, from the deferred basis that it is currently on to be paid when lump sums are taken over 15, 20 or 30 years hence, without any diminution in benefits.

The most important point is: what we will have is a proper basis of superannuation taxation which will remain concessionary and which will encourage employee contributions because the system is now biased in favour of employee contributions. We have removed the lump sum tax on the earnings of employee contributions. That will lead, hopefully, to a higher level of aggregate savings in the community via superannuation in a proper, progressive structure. The highest benefits will not go to the highest income earners, which is what the Deputy Leader of the Opposition would like. He would like to see the highest benefits go to very high income earners with massive tax concessions. That is the Liberal regression in tax policy that we have always seen over the years. What this is about is Labor progression in superannuation tax policy, which these new arrangements both ensure and guarantee.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Industrial Relations to the Government's decision, as announced by the Treasurer last night, to remove the current requirement for employees who receive shares at a discount from their employer to pay income tax on that discount. Can the Minister inform the House why the Government has taken this step at this time?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is introducing this measure at this time because the right environment exists in which to do it. The environment is right in two key aspects: firstly, as a result of the policies of cooperation rather than confrontation pursued by this Government, there has been not only a dramatic change in industrial relations outcomes but also much greater willingness by the industrial relations parties-the unions and employers-to contemplate employee participation than was previously the case. That has resulted recently in a very important agreement by the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the Confederation of Australian Industry in relation to participative practices in industry and to the principles by which those practices should be applied. That creates a uniquely favourable environment in which to promote employee participation, including employee financial participation, one aspect of which is employee share ownership. Under that agreement the parties are committed to promoting the concept of participation with their own affiliates and to doing all they can to try to expand participative practices in industry.

ANSWER.PARA: To add to that fact, my Department has undertaken some substantial research in relation to employee financial participation schemes which are operated both in Australia and overseas. What comes out of that research is that quite clearly the benefits, in terms of industrial relations pay-offs and in terms of better work place industrial relations and so on, are to be found only where there is involvement of the employee financial participation scheme with wider participative practices. Where those schemes are introduced in isolation there is not much in the way of a correlation with improved industrial relations outcomes. What comes out of that in the current environment in relation to the willingness of the parties to pursue participation, including financial participation, is the ability to develop this factor in a wider context where it is likely to be most productive.

In relation to the taxation regime, we also have now something existing which was not applicable earlier. The problem for employee financial participation in respect of the tax system has been that, where shares were issued to employees at a discount, they were obliged to pay a tax on that discount in the year in which they acquired the shares. That clearly was a disincentive to take up the shares because there was a tax obligation when there was no realised gain. However, to remove that obligation would have meant that there was no tax payable at all. With the introduction of the capital gains tax we were able to remove that disincentive so there was no tax obligation on employees in the year in which they take up the shares, but they will still have to pay tax on that gain through the capital gains tax at the time when they sell those shares and have a realised capital gain.

In respect of both the environment in relation to participative practices and that in relation to the tax system, we now have a uniquely favourable time in which to introduce this employee share acquisition scheme concession which was announced by the Treasurer last night. It contrasts markedly with the situation which existed in 1982 when the Fraser Government announced a scheme of this kind. None of this environment existed then. There was no capital gains tax. The parties were at loggerheads about employee participative practices. They had great differences in relation to that, and the prospect of there being wider participation introduced at that time was minimal. We now have a much more favourable environment. It is very much the appropriate time in which to make this concession.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Treasurer. I hope he can lift his game in relation to answering questions on superannuation. Is it a fact that the new arrangements for superannuation taxation will impose a tax of 16.25 per cent on the capital contributions made by retired public servants, Defence Force personnel and employees of statutory authorities such as Telecom Australia if placed in approved deposit funds? As some personnel, especially members of the defence services, are forced to retire early and have no other way of protecting their funds, will the effects of the Government's new tax be to reduce the final benefits made available to them at age 55 or later?

—That just shows a very muddled understanding of the arrangements, which comes, of course, as no surprise to me. The existing tax treatment of lump sums, particularly for unfunded public sector schemes, remains the same. It does not change. For instance, all of us in the Parliament who retire are subject--
—ADFs. You do not understand the question.

—I will get around to the bit of it which has any lingering semblance of rationality. I will get there. The unfunded public sector schemes will continue to attract the same tax treatment. Let me say this about approved deposit funds: before this Government reformed the tax treatment of superannuation in 1983 and established approved deposit funds, anyone who had superannuation entitlements had to take them at the point of departure from that fund and pay tax on them. And that was it. He could not leave them in any vehicle-there was no such thing as an approved deposit fund. If an employee chooses to retire at age 55 and places those funds in approved deposit funds, that will enjoy the same effective tax treatment.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Blanchard Mr C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Social Security inform the House of progress in achieving the Government's commitment that no child need live in poverty by 1990?

QUESTION.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not unusual for the word `poverty' to cause some amusement on the other side of the House. There is no commitment more central to the Government's agenda than delivering our promise that no child need live in poverty by 1990. Last night's economic statement is a central component of meeting that strategy. It provides the solid base for continuing employment growth in Australia. The Government clearly recognises that the surest way out of poverty is a job. That is why our macro- and micro-economic policies so clearly focus on employment.

ANSWER.PARA: Let the House compare the approach of this Government with that of the conservatives. Last night the honourable member for Kooyong, the shadow Treasurer, let slip some of the results of that cosy weekend in Coolangatta the Opposition enjoyed just a month ago. He renewed commitments that the Opposition would engage in wholesale cancellation of sole parent pensions and would cut out unemployment benefits for families-even for families whose members were unemployed and actively seeking work. They are the policies of the Opposition. They are the policies of the honourable member for Bradfield, the honourable member for Sturt and the honourable member for Cook. Indeed--

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I raise a point of order. The question to the Minister asked him to account for how the Government had failed to meet the Prime Minister's rash promise that no child would live in poverty. It has nothing to do with anything that might have been said by any member on this side of the House.
—The Minister is in order. He is answering the question.

—Madam Speaker, there is no member of the Opposition who is more insensitive to the unemployed than the honourable member for Richmond. These policies of the Opposition are spawned from their politics of blaming the poor-the politics of hatred that so mark the Opposition.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable member asked about our progress in meeting our central commitment that no child need live in poverty. To meet that commitment requires an integrated and consistent strategy. Indeed, it requires policy-something which has been totally lacking from the Opposition. It requires micro- and macro-economic policies to deliver a sustained pace of job creation; income security policies to deliver adequate income to all families in need; labour market programs to ensure all Australians have a fair chance of participation in the labour market; and social policies to ensure that no Australian family is denied access to quality and decent essential services such as health, housing and education.

Last night's economic statement illustrated once again, in the most glaring terms, the great difference between the Government and the Opposition. What the Government is concerned about is economic and social security for all Australians-and last night we were building the foundations of economic security. Because we are doing that and because we have created more than a million jobs, we are able to tackle, through our social policies, a range of problems which were essentially the inheritance of seven years of Fraser and Howard-and an inheritance of 30 years inability on the part of members of the Opposition, then in government, to deal fundamentally with central aspects of either economic or social policy.

The families package fits in with the concepts of economically responsible government, directing social security assistance not only to those most in need but to those who are moving in to the million jobs that the Government has created. The commitment that this Government has made-in terms of access and equity, rebuilding and reconstructing, and access to education and training programs-is further evidence of the integration between economic and social policy. In that regard, I draw attention to the statement made by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training last night.

We are able to make a commitment around child poverty with some credibility because we, as a Government, have economic credibility and we have been able to make the hard decisions which enable us to have real social priorities. Those hard decisions enable this Government not simply to say that child poverty is a priority but also that on our agenda it is the goal that no child in Australia should live in poverty by 1990.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Treasurer. I hope that this time he will show some knowledge of the detail of superannuation. Will the Treasurer confirm that under the old superannuation tax arrangements-please listen carefully-death benefits paid to widows from superannuation were tax free? Will he confirm that, under the new arrangements, such benefits, which would already be reduced by the 16.25 per cent tax on employer contributions, plus the 16.25 tax on funds investment income, will in fact result in widows receiving reduced benefits? Will he confirm that the same result will apply to employees who retire early due to disablement?

—All that has happened in the tax arrangements is that the 15-30 per cent tax, which is in fact 16.25-31.25 per cent with the Medicare levy, has been changed to zero and 16.25 per cent, with the 15 per cent front end loaded as employer contributions enter the fund. The other change is that the earnings on employee contributions will no longer attract the lump sum tax. That will change, as I said, the balance of superannuation funds towards employee contributions. Beyond that, the tax treatment has not changed. I said that earlier.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Cleeland Mr P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank you, Madam Speaker, for the opportunity of asking my last question without notice in this House.

QUESTION.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —They can try in vain, but they will not get rid of me. Has the attention of the Minister for Transport and Communications Support been drawn to Press reports and statements by Opposition members criticising the Government's record on local road funding? If so, what has the Government done to alleviate that concern?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question and commend him for his interest in this very important subject for people in country Australia. It seems that Opposition members tried to forecast the results of the Government's May statement in respect of roads, and they got it all wrong. I will come back to that in a moment. Let me just outline the main features of the Government's innovative road programs for the next five years. They are these--

—Honourable members opposite have a problem because the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, in this place only a few days ago, was accusing the Treasurer and the Prime Minister of making Clayton's cuts. If honourable members opposite really want to talk about cuts they had better talk to their Leader and Deputy Leader. The Opposition cannot on the one hand clamour for more money and, on the other, complain that the cuts are not severe enough. Let us have no regard to the Opposition's credibility in respect of government expenditure and most of all in respect of roads.

ANSWER.PARA: The program covers the next five years. This is the first occasion on which the total Federal roads program will be funded from an earmarked share of fuel excise. The amount of money-$1,215m-is $35m less than this year's expenditure. But, in the parlance of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, that cut should have been greater; it is not enough; there should have been a greater reduction in road funding. The $1,215m to be provided by this Government in roads expenditure will be indexed in the second and third years of the program. It will cover funding for local roads to local government bodies; it will cover funding for the maintenance and construction of the national highway system, which is fully met by this Government; it will cover arterial roads, which have been subdivided into national arterials-those roads of economic importance that will contribute to improved competitiveness in our export trade. Lastly, it will cover funding for local roads with an increase of some $14m next year on this year's expenditure.

I quote the words of the honourable member for Deakin. I happen to have a Press release from 1985. The honourable member for Deakin is one of the new breed of Liberals. He is 100 per cent in support of abolishing any Federal expenditure on roads. He wants it abolished. He is in the invidious position of having to carry a policy that says that there should be a continuation of roads funding by the Federal Government. He even had to put out a Press statement last night saying that we are really not giving them enough. But I know that he is an honourable man. I know that he believes what he said in 1985. I challenge anybody to say that he was not telling the truth in 1985 when he said that there should not be any Federal expenditure on roads. He has the invidious problem of having to explain how he has to get up here now and support more Federal expenditure on roads when his heart is not in it, when he does not believe it. But he is an honourable man.

The Government will continue to provide specific purpose funding for local government roads. The funding next year will be this year's funding maintained in real terms; it will be maintained in real terms in 1988-89 and 1989-90. Last night I saw a Press release on this from the Leader of the National Party of Australia. We all know that he is really conversant with the problems of the people in country Australia. He travels our country roads regularly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I rise on a point of order. Is there any significance in the fact that the honourable member for Kalgoorlie has left the Parliament?
—That is not a point of order, and I suggest that honourable members should not misuse points of order.

—As I was saying in support of the Leader of the National Party, he travels country roads regularly. If anybody is conversant with the national highway system in this country, it is the Leader of the National Party. He travels on it from Bendemeer to Tamworth quite regularly. He said in his Press release last night that the Government has cut road funding by $30m. The honourable member for Deakin says that it has been cut by $50m. In actual money terms the cut for next year is $35m. The Leader of the National Party went on to say in his statement:

ANSWER.PARA: This will hurt rural roads, especially as the government is planning to change-
its priority away from rural roads to national highways . . .

Around 75 per cent of the national highway system is in country Australia. So the Leader of the National Party does not really know where the national highway system is. He does not recognise that most of the national highway system is in the country and is serving country Australia.

We on this side of the House have rejected the argument of the honourable member for Deakin that there should not be any Federal expenditure on roads and the proposition from his quarter that we should adopt the policy of absorbing local and State arterial roads money into State revenue grants, and we have put together the most innovative roads program that this country has seen. In its 5 1/2 years the Hawke Government has done more than any other government in any comparable period in history. We will maintain our commitment to local government and local roads, and we will maintain the progress that has been made in the last 5 1/2 years.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ECONOMIC STATEMENT: EFFECT ON PRIMARY PRODUCERS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Treasurer. The Treasurer may not be aware that his economic statement, as well as causing anger in the rural community over the more than $100m net additional taxes and charges farmers will be forced to pay, is causing confusion because of contradictory statements issued by him and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Today I refer to only three matters, and ask: Will the termination of the immediate tax write-off for mains electricity in relation to farms apply only to connections or will it apply also to upgrading, and is the Treasurer aware that this is of particular concern to Victorian farmers who are being forced to relay their power underground? Secondly, will the reduction in the five-year depreciation rate for on-farm storage facilities for grain and fodder be a reduction to 10 years or 33 years? Thirdly, will machinery and plant which is purchased and used by primary producers in water or soil conservation continue to enjoy the 5/3 depreciation rate?
—Madam Speaker, I rise on a point of order. Is it normal for a shadow Minister to ask three questions in one go?
—I think it was one question in three parts.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me deal first with the mains electricity connection point. Expenditure incurred under contracts entered into after 25 May 1988 in connecting mains electricity to a property on which business is carried on will be eligible for write-off over 10 years. Such expenditure had previously been eligible for immediate write-off. The pre-25 May concession discriminated against energy sources other than electricity and in favour of those businesses which have grid connection potential. The new write-off will be concessional when compared with an effective life write-off. There were other components to the question; but they have escaped me.
—The first point was whether it is only for connection or will apply to upgrading, and that is the matter on which you have given us an answer that is different from that of the other Minister.
—I would have to check that and let the honourable member know.
—The second part of the question concerned depreciation for the on-farm storage of grain and fodder. Has that gone from five years to 10 years or from five years to 33 years?
—That will go to the depreciation rate in the schedule. In other words, we will move from the accelerated depreciation--
—What is that?
—I do not not know off hand, my friend; I do not carry those sorts of figures around in my head.
—You don't carry much up there.

—I do not carry superfluous information. Let me refer to the changes I announced last night in respect of rural industry and rural Australia. This Government has done more for the rural industries of this country than any other since Federation. For a start, the National Party of Australia-formerly the Country Party-under Sir John McEwen, Mr Anthony and Mr Sinclair lifted industrial protection in this country and put it onto the backs of farmers. While they went around misrepresenting themselves and pitching their policies at the rural constituency, they were putting the monkey of tariff protection on the back of every farmer in this country. That happened between 1949 and 1983-for nearly 40 years. Then they went out and overvalued the exchange rate, because of other particular hang-ups and phobias that they had in their Party, which destroyed rural incomes for years. Rural people had to wait until we floated the dollar, which cut the real value of its exchange rate. All of the changed adjustment burden fell on this Government.

ANSWER.PARA: Then we cut marginal tax rates for farmers from 60 to 49 per cent and from 48 and 46 per cent to 40 per cent. Now we have cut the rate for incorporated farmers so that, instead of paying 46c in the dollar on some and 60c on the balance, that is, 78 per cent of every dollar of company income, that has been cut by half to 39 per cent. That is what we have done. The tariff cut announced last night is worth at least $350m per annum to rural industry. The reason the Opposition parties did not do that was that basically for years they were up there bludging on country interests. They have been bludging on rural interests for years. They have been misrepresenting themselves. They have been taking country votes but have voted for more tariff protection. They liked to see Jack McEwen and Doug Anthony handing out the slabs of industrial protection in order to ingratiate themselves with industry. That is what they have been about in the play between the Country Party and the Liberal Party of Australia over the years. They never represented rural interests properly. They always went out and gave the electorate some sob story, relying on its basic conservative instinct to vote for a rump party which destroyed its economic viability.

So, honourable members opposite should not tell this Government about the rural sector or the farm sector. We have done more for it, properly, sensibly and structurally. The impact of the Opposition parties' contribution is minuscule, particularly in comparison with what we have done for members of the rural community. We have given them a change to a fairer tax system. Honourable members opposite should not ask dishonest questions about the $100m costs when they know full well that there is a $350m per annum impact from the reduction in tariffs. We have had enough of the National Party with its squalid politics and dishonest economics and so have the National Farmers Federation and most Australian farmers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Madam Speaker. Apart from the Treasurer not answering the third part of my question, his point about dishonesty goes straight to him because over $100m--
—Order! There is no point of order. The honourable member is abusing the forms of the House.

—Is the Minister for Community Services and Health aware of the substance of a letter by Dr Alan McPhate, a country general practitioner, which was published in the Medical Journal of Australia on 18 April in which a number of epidemiological studies were cited drawing attention to the increased incidence of breast cancer associated with as few as three standard drinks of alcohol per day? Is he also aware of the response by Dr Tony McMichael of the Department of Community Health, University of Adelaide, that we are now on notice that alcohol, with its widespread consumption within our community, may be an important source of breast cancer? In view of those authoritative reports, will the Minister give further consideration to the recommendation of the 1977 report of the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare that the advertising of alcohol on radio and television be discontinued?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the research referred to relating to the links between moderate alcohol consumption and breast cancer in women. While these studies give cause for concern, it is important to understand that, although alcohol has been identified as one of a number of known risk factors for breast cancer, overall these factors appear to play only a minimal role in breast cancer incidence. The Government is concerned about problems in relation to breast cancer and has initiated a program with the States over three years to evaluate effective and cost-efficient ways of delivering mammography testing.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government is concerned about the health effects of alcohol and, of course, we wish to minimise the health impact of the abuse of alcohol. We believe that the most appropriate way to do that is to ensure that the Australian population is quite clear about it and is provided with educative information about the risks of alcohol abuse and health. In the last five years we have taken a series of steps to bring before the public that kind of awareness. The National Health and Medical Research Council has published guidelines on responsible drinking behaviour and safe levels of alcohol consumption. The Government is currently running a media campaign which is designed particularly to warn young people about the abuse of alcohol and, in addition, to make plain to parents the role model they play for their young people. My colleagues the State health Ministers are developing a national policy on alcohol.

It is not this Government's intention in any way to consider banning alcohol advertising on television or radio, but we do expect the alcohol companies to play a role in responsible advertising. They have a duty in their advertising to warn of the health impact of alcohol abuse. I very much welcome the actions taken by a number of leading alcohol companies in this country to play a role in their advertising and to place stress on non-drinking and driving. A number of wine companies have recently made use of their advertising to stress moderate and responsible drinking.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Treasurer. I refer to his claims last night about expenditure restraint in the May economic statement. Is it not a fact that new accounting methods retrospectively increase expenditure for the current financial year, more than for 1988-89, thereby making next year look better than it will be? Is it not also a fact that-if former accounting methods had been used-real expenditure in 1989-90 will fall by only 0.8 per cent instead of the 1.5 per cent claimed by the Treasurer? Is it not also true that the Commonwealth's own outlays will actually rise by 0.3 per cent in real terms?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Total outlays, excluding assets sales and the Civil Aviation Authority, which has been moved off Budget, will produce a real change of minus 1.7 per cent in 1987-88 and minus 1.6 per cent in 1988-89. This will be the third consecutive year in which real outlays have been reduced. I might say that there is some prospect of a fourth consecutive fall occurring. I said earlier, and I will repeat it, that Budget outlays will be 25.5 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP)-down from 29.9 per cent in 1983-84-and a prospective 24.5 per cent in 1989-90. No government in the postwar years has presided over a greater fall in the real level of Commonwealth spending than this Government. This is the only year in 35 in which we have had a Budget surplus, with the prospect of a substantial Budget surplus in 1988-89.

ANSWER.PARA: In six years we will have cut the size of the Commonwealth budgetary sector by 15 per cent. I want the honourable member for Wentworth to listen to this because he was an adviser to the honourable member for Bennelong when he was Treasurer. In today's dollar terms that represents $13.5 billion, whereas in the last four years of his tenure, when the honourable member for Wentworth was advising him, it grew by 11 per cent. In the Opposition's last four years in office it grew by 11 per cent and in our period it has fallen by 15 per cent, or $13.5 billion. Yet we have these antics, this crazy parroting, by both the Leader of the Opposition and the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, that this is a big spending government which has taken outlays back to late-1960s and early-1970s levels.

Now we have a question from the honourable member for Wentworth about having moved some authority off Budget or reclassified some premiums and whether or not the decimal point will be here or there on these massive real reductions. I simply say that whatever changes we make to the base of outlays is adjusted to the base. For the benefit of all those wise fiscal heads lolling over there, let me repeat the figures: there has been a 15 per cent, $13.5 billion, reduction. Have those opposite got that? A 15 per cent, $13.5 billion, reduction. I want to get it through their thick heads. There has been a 15 per cent, $13.5 billion, reduction from the late 1960s-early 1970s outlays to GDP levels.

Opposition members should not talk to this Government about cutting outlays. Last night the Deputy Leader of the Opposition ran around saying, `There could have been tax relief provided there were further cuts in government spending'. Beyond what? Beyond the early 1960s level-is that what he is arguing? The Leader of the Opposition wandered around saying that he would cut Commonwealth spending back to 23 per cent of outlays as a proportion of GDP. That would be the princely amount of precisely 1.5 per cent below where this Government will have it the year after next. That is about $1,200m-worth of outlays.

I can only say to the Leader of the Opposition that if he wants to reform the world and turn that into a vote buying grab, he will not get many votes for $1,200m, on the analysis of his last try, when he had $6 billion of unfunded tax cuts and went backwards electorally. Relying on a $1,200m reduction by taking outlays to 23 per cent of GDP will not help him very much.

So we have seen the Liberal Party of Australia in action. We know what the Liberal Party is like in spending. We know the Liberal Party has blown us into massive Budget deficits and has left the Labor Government to drag us back to surplus; and everyone out there knows; and that is why the Liberal Party will stay in opposition for a long time. I do not mind members of the Liberal Party asking me these kinds of questions. I hope they will keep it up for a long, long time.
