DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The failure of the Government to cut personal income tax rates.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night's economic statement, as I have been saying in about 37 interviews this morning alone, is a political and economic sham. The simple fact is that, for those who are in the greatest need of relief from an economic statement-namely, the great bulk of Australians-there will be no personal income tax cuts in 1988-89. We know that improvements in productivity and reductions in taxes offer the only effective way of improving the living standards for all Australians. But, once again, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) will not and, indeed, cannot deliver. I might say that it would be wise not to be deceived by the Treasurer's rhetoric that he has to cut Commonwealth outlays significantly. The tortuous manner in which questions were sought to be answered today underlines that reality as well.

SPEECH.PARA: Certain elements of fact in the document that was brought down last night cannot be denied. Total Commonwealth outlays were reduced by $982m for 1988-89, and $870m of that was accounted for by cuts in grants to the States. In other words, the States are bearing almost 90 per cent of the spending cuts in the forthcoming year, 1988-89. This is indeed testimony to the Treasurer's utter hypocrisy. Let us see what some of the Premiers had to say of the Treasurer's economic statement. I quote the words of the Victorian Labor Premier, John Cain:

I think it's unfair. Tax cuts are due. They're overdue and I believe it would have been fairer to introduce those tax cuts at the same time (as concessions to business) . . . The Federal Government has really come in on the states' coat-tails.
Nick Greiner, the Premier of New South Wales, said:
The States are being asked to carry the can so that Mr Keating can live up to his macho image as an economic manager.
John Bannon, the Labor Premier of South Australia, said:

One big omission I think from the Treasurer's statement is an acknowledgment of the fact that the Federal outcome . . . has largely come through cuts to the States . . . He ought to acknowledge that and he ought to acknowledge it with some gratitude . . .

Therefore, even the Treasurer's Labor colleagues can see that they have been duped. I will move away from what Labor politicians have said to what journalists have said. I will take Kenneth Davidson as an example. In this morning's Age he said that the corporate tax cuts of the May statement mean that before 1991-92 `there will be an income transfer from individuals to corporations of about $1.5 billion'.

While the Opposition welcomes any cuts in corporate tax rates we are, of course, concerned that working people, farmers and small business people will have to wait at least another year before they get any personal tax relief. The Treasurer did not promise any specific tax cuts even then. By that time the Treasurer can rely on even more revenue derived, of course, from bracket creep to finance a tax cut. Bluntly put, that is blatant fraud.

The fact is that many Australians are paying more tax now than they were two years ago before the Treasurer's phoney tax cuts of 1986 and 1987. I will just give a couple of examples to illustrate that reality. A taxpayer on average weekly earnings with a dependent spouse and two children, that is, somebody earning just over $470 a week, is paying more tax, as a share of income, than in 1985-before the Treasurer introduced his so-called tax cuts. Similarly, for someone who is on about $380 a week, that is, less than average weekly earnings, tax, as a percentage of income, has risen over the last two years. Again, for somebody on about $565 a week, just above average weekly earnings, tax, as a percentage of income, has increased.

In all of these cases people on average incomes or thereabouts have been slugged and slugged mercilessly by the Treasurer as he has used bracket creep to rip more and more tax from their pay packets. These are the very people being asked to forgo tax relief. Between now and 1989-90, the earliest we will see any personal tax relief, the tax take will increase even further. It really comes down to letting the Treasurer grab a bit more tax revenue as inflation pushes us into higher tax brackets and then next year, maybe, we will get a tax cut if the Treasurer can do a deal with the leadership of the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU).

Last night's statement made it clear that personal tax cuts for all Australians are being used as a bargaining chip with the trade union leadership. It all depends on how the wage negotiations go with the ACTU leadership-the Creans, the Keltys; the de facto Ministers, as it were, to whom this Labor Government panders.These people are leaders of the trade union movement, not elected members of parliament. They are not even representative or leaders of small businesses, farmers or other groups which have been asked to wait and see whether they will get tax cuts.

In what can be described only as an incredible act of political cowardice, the Treasurer has abdicated personal responsibility for personal tax cuts. This argument against personal tax cuts-honourable members probably heard it last night-for alleged macro-economic reasons, is abundantly weak. It is a weak justification for his failure to develop the necessary expenditure cuts to finance cuts in personal tax rates. Cuts in government spending are made all the more imperative by the preliminary results of the private, new capital expenditure survey released today. Honourable members may not be aware that the figures that came out today show that in the March quarter 1988 investment in plant and equipment actually fell in real terms by 4 per cent compared with the December quarter and business expectations were for a real decline in plant and equipment investment in 1987-88. Therefore, it is clear that investment is faltering.

The argument for cuts in government spending are abundantly clear. They permit reductions in the tax burden, thereby increasing the incentives to work and to invest. They release resources to the private sector for use in the export and import competing industries. There is no reason to believe the Treasurer's assertion that one cannot achieve both a Budget surplus and cut taxes in 1988-89. Last night he said that there is a need for the Budget surplus and that that surplus precludes tax cuts. That is just not true. Of course, there is a need for a surplus. Obviously there is a need for two reasons, if not for others. Firstly, there is a need to prevent inter-generational transfer-the dumping on our kids of the debt we now have. Secondly, there is a need, for the macro-economic reason of States expenditure. However, to say that one has to have a surplus and therefore one cannot have tax cuts is absolutely wrong. It is false because significant cuts in government spending can provide for tax cuts as well as a Budget surplus. The Treasurer would say, as he has said time and again, `If you cut taxes you will allow consumption to rise, demand will be extraordinary and you will suck in imports'. That overlooks the reality of what we put forward. The demand for tax cuts should be funded by cuts in government spending, which would mean that public demand would fall and resources would be transferred to the private sector. However, that element of a fall in public demand resulting from a reduction in government expenditure has been totally overlooked whenever the Treasurer has produced this argument.

The Government's failure to cut expenditure significantly is yet another wasted opportunity. It has failed to take the necessary action to increase incentives, to work and to increase incentives to invest so that we can start trading our way out of our huge foreign debt. The bottom line is that the Treasurer is not prepared to deliver at this stage. We know about the actual political element. The political element which he would not wish to be addressed at this juncture is very real and is quite separate from the economic element. The Treasurer wants it neatly packaged so that, by the time the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke) is removed or removes himself as Prime Minister, the Treasurer, who believes he will move into the position of Prime Minister, can go to the polls at the end of next year, having provided an alleged tax cut en route.

That might be neat planning at a political level. If one is a practitioner of the notion of corporatism, of big government, big business and big unions, and one puts these blocks together and they allegedly mesh together rather well, one might be fooled into thinking that it can be planned in that way. Out in the community there are millions and millions of people who are demanding relief now. They are entitled to that relief now. They know that if it is done on the basis on which the Opposition has argued-by reductions in expenditure-those reductions in income tax not only will be of relief to them but also will have a powerful macro-economic effect which will lead to further regeneration of investment and an ability to work more without handing over half of every extra dollar earned to the Commissioner of Taxation. This Treasurer, indicating that there can be no tax cuts because we need the surplus, overlooks the harsh reality that tax cuts, funded by government expenditure, will give a surplus as well as tax cuts.

Of course, last year the Treasurer forecast that inflation would be 6 per cent through 1987-88. Regrettably, it is extremely unlikely that that will be achieved. The Treasurer, in his statement last night, was talking of an inflation rate of 4.5 per cent during 1988-89. To put it mildly, that appears overly optimistic.

Let us look at the Government's record on micro-economic reform. I mentioned the fundamental element: the Opposition believes that there ought to be tax cuts and that we want such cuts both for macro-economic reasons as well as for the relief of individuals. Behind it all there has been the trumpeting throughout the last 12 months that the hallmark of the third term of the Hawke Government was to be substantial reform in the micro-economic area.

What happened last night? We applaud the moves that the Treasurer has made in phasing in the changes to protection and the like to bring about the mobility of capital required within the economy. But when one turns to the other side and asks, `What about the necessary mobility of labour?', one sees not one mention of labour market deregulation in the economic statement presented last night, because the Government cannot deliver on it. So the craft structure of unions, the restrictive trade practices and the demarcation disputes go on. Where is the abundant need for micro-economic reform being met in this arena? And, as the Leader of the Opposition said a moment ago, what was said of privatisation? The word was not even mentioned. There was no blueprint; no schedule for reform. `This is not the main game', the Treasurer says. In a way I do not blame him for saying that, because he does not want to enter that arena in which the Australian Labor Party is so divided.

I said that the Treasurer could not deliver; he did not deliver on the forecast figure of inflation last year; he will not deliver again this year. He has not delivered on the tax cuts as he ought to have; he has not delivered on the cuts in Government expenditure as he ought to have. And he has not delivered on what was to be the main game of the third term of the Hawke Government-micro-economic reform. Last night's statement could not even embark on that arena. In short, the statement that the Treasurer brought down last night reeks of hyperbole that we have come to expect from this Government: micro-economic reform not tackled; tax cuts not tackled; States bearing 90 per cent of the cuts in government expenditure; and the need for surplus allegedly being the reason for no tax cuts.

I end on the note on which I began: the need for tax cuts is abundantly clear. There is a need for real relief for taxpayers in this community, but there is also-and this marks the significant difference between the Opposition and the Government-a need for them to be funded on the basis of expenditure cuts so that resources can be transferred from the public sector to the private sector, from the non-tradable goods sector to the tradable goods sector, to restore the incentive for both investment and work in this nation so that we can start trading our way out of our economic difficulties.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the last points made by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), was that the need for tax cuts is abundantly clear. One may ask: Clear to whom, and why? What would be the likely outcome? The Deputy Leader of the Opposition does not seem to comprehend the simple point that personal tax cuts would overstress and overheat the economy by pumping up consumption. The Government would be extinguishing its surplus, that is, government saving, to finance a new splurge in imports. Thus, the results of such gross irresponsibility would be a current account blow-out with a consequential rise in interest rates and inflation. This is Liberal economic illiteracy, 1988-style.

SPEECH.PARA: It is entirely in character with the reckless approach to public money of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) and the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. The 1982-83 Budget was built around tax cuts which could not then be afforded. The outcome of this is well documented, including by me and by the shadow spokesman on finance, Senator Stone, and of course it speaks for itself. The Leader of the Opposition's cynical election bribe of last year-that flop-was again based on the cynical presumption that greed will beat the national interest any day. The Liberals were wrong then, and are wrong now.

It is unbelievable that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition is talking about the need for tax cuts. Members of the Opposition do not comprehend any kind of matrix and economic policy. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition said that we need public demand to fall by cuts in real government spending. But one asks: falling on whom? We have cut the size of Commonwealth Government outlays from 30 per cent to 25.5 per cent in the coming year.

TALK.START.PARA: —But who got them up to 30 per cent?

—The Liberal Party of Australia did, by blowing the Budget out in 1982-83 and 1983-84. That was done by the irresponsible economic policies of the former Government, and the Labor Government had to reduce it to 25.5 per cent. But apparently the Deputy Leader of the Opposition thinks that now we have cut out anything which has any semblance of fact. We have been cutting real programs for years. Now he says we ought to hop in and start ripping another billion or so off pensions, sickness benefits, unemployment benefits, aged care, home and community care, and funding to schools-the only areas where this money is available. Do honourable members think it is fair and reasonable or justifiable that people who rely upon the transfer system of the Commonwealth to maintain their lives ought to have it cut around to increase the savings pool while other people will squander it by bidding up the price of real estate or other property? Do they really think it is fair and decent to go cutting public outlays more than this, with that burden falling on the weakest people in the community? This is what the Opposition is saying.

SPEECH.PARA: The Deputy Leader of the Opposition said that we needed further falls in public demand. I would not mind that if he, as a Minister, or the Leader of the Opposition, as a Minister, had had any semblance of understanding about the need for better public policy, particularly better fiscal policy; but they never did. They never cut programs in the way in which this Government has cut them, and they never had the same care and attention to detail that this Government has shown. We hear this empty rhetoric about the need for tax cuts being abundantly clear and how we can provide them by further cuts in Government spending; in other words, we belt some single mother living in a rented flat with a couple of kids--
Opposition members-Ooh!

TALK.START.PARA: —Opposition members say, `Ooh!'; that is what it means. If the Government takes $1 billion, it comes out of pensions and sickness benefits and all these areas. And the Opposition thinks the Government should do that to give the yuppies a tax cut! Is that what they really think? Basically that is what the Opposition's proposition is, and it is wrong. The tax cuts should be given in the proper time in the economic cycle, not the wrong time, and it cannot be done by unfairly penalising the poor and the weak. This Government is not about unfairly penalising the poor and the weak.

SPEECH.PARA: The Deputy Leader of the Opposition talked about hyperbole and said that no micro-economic changes or tax cuts had been tackled. There has been a 20 per cent cut in tariffs, and massive changes to the corporate tax system. We have cut in half the tax burden on distributed income in this country. It was 46 per cent, and then 60c on the balance. It was 78 per cent on each dollar of distributed company income for people on the top marginal rate. We have cut that in half, to 39 per cent. The Opposition occupied the treasury benches from 1949 to 1983, bar three years, and had all these opportunities to change the micro-economy and the tax structure of the Commonwealth, including for companies, and it never did so.

The Deputy Leader of the Opposition in ignoring that massive change, that is, imputation and a cut in the company tax rate from 49 per cent to 39 per cent, says the Government has done nothing about the craft union structure. The Liberal and National parties formed the Government from 1949 to 1983, bar three years, and they are now saying to us, `You have not done anything about the craft structure'. They had the place for nearly 30 years. For nearly 30 years they governed this place with control of both Houses of parliament, and they left everything the way they found it. The place got old and tired and worn out, just like members of the Opposition. Now they are saying that they want to turn back 80 years of centralised wage fixation with the wave of a wand. That is their proposition.

We have had nothing from the Liberal Party. All we had was Black Jack McEwen trowelling on the tariff protection while he was kidding farmers he was representing them, and Liberal Party Treasurers sitting up like slugs while being handed speeches by Treasury officials. They could not even read the stuff, much less comprehend it. That is how they ran the Commonwealth. They would have Sir Richard Randall or Sir Frederick Wheeler or whoever sitting over there with the permanent heads-the mandarins; they ran things. Liberal Party Ministers were given speeches; they did not bother with the details; that was for the public servants. They did not worry about the details because they never ran the policy-they never ran the place. Let me tell honourable members this: We run the place. We run the departments. We run the policy. We comprehend. We know. And that is the difference between this Government and that lot over there. That is why members opposite will remain in Opposition.

Why do members opposite think the Public Service holds them in such contempt? It is because it knows what members opposite did to the place. There are decent, hardworking, earnest and committed Australians, working in the public sector on diminished salaries. They have been working for some decent altruistic outcomes, relying on bums in ministerial jobs for 40 years to try to change the place. We have changed it. Members opposite are now saying, `You have not touched the micro-economy and you have not touched the craft union structure'.

One can imagine how switched on and concerned are members of the blue rinse set at meetings of the Liberal Party of Australia in Toorak about the craft union structure. They are worried about the craft union structure in the leafy glades of Toorak! They are worried about the single mum in a flat in some tenement in Melbourne or Sydney! They could not care less, and they never could care less. Basically, the Liberal Party is the party of reaction and conservatism-it is the `do nothing' party.

We bring in these vast changes-floating the exchange rate, opening up the economy to external forces, letting interest rates be set in the market, cutting Budget deficits, changing the tax system, changing personal tax, changing company tax and dropping tariffs-yet members opposite say, `You have not made any changes'. Members opposite have no concept of nation and no concept of structure in government. They have no policy, no leadership, no heart, no guts, no courage and no ideas, and that is why they will remain in opposition. I am supposed to stand up in this place as Treasurer and say, `Oh yes, I have a responsibility to answer the matter raised by the shadow Treasurer about how the Government has not provided tax cuts this year'.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pity you do not say something about how you are going to help people.
—Order! The honourable member will cease interjecting. I warn the honourable member for O'Connor.

—The shadow Treasurer knows that the tax cuts proposed by the Liberal Party last year would have destroyed the economy, and that is why the public voted against his Party. He knows that such a tax cut now would destroy the demand equation and blow the current account out the door. This stuff is trotted in in the name of economic decency but, in fact, it is simply political opportunism. Members opposite expect the rest of Australia to say, `Oh, yes, that is a good point. There are Mr Peacock and Mr Howard arguing for a tax cut for us'. The people of Australia are not silly; they understand what that policy would mean-that the economic system would rip it off them in higher inflation and higher unemployment. The people of Australia have been there and done that. They have been tricked before by the Liberal Party with tax cuts that the nation could not afford. They understand it very well.

SPEECH.PARA: In this day and age, in 1988, after five years in opposition, one would think that the Liberal Party would start to say, `Let us get a high side of the street debate going. Let us forget any nonsense about tax cuts because we know that the nation cannot afford them. Let us have a debate about tariffs, about structural change, productivity, budgetary policy, a proper social structure, the social wage and the wage system'. We would welcome such a debate, but members opposite will have no such debate. Instead, we get nothing from the Opposition. There is no structure and the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) has no policies. Any semblance of policy which he had to destroy the honourable member for Kooyong when he was Leader, has been dropped and does not exist. It was just empty rhetoric. There is no structure at all. Is it any wonder that Elliott, McLachlan and other people outside are saying, `God, what can we do with this parliamentary party of ours? What can we do to try to put something back into it?'. Where are the people who gave the Liberal Party some form and structure? They are gone.

We have members opposite wandering around in this place playing parliamentarians, picking up their salary and asking questions. They have no structure. They are not saying, `We are out of government. We can no longer think we were born to rule and we must earn our way back to government. So let us do some thinking about concept and structure'. No, they still believe that they are the born to rule squad and they say, `We have been out for five years and we will be returned some day. We can go on as usual because we are the chosen few who were born to rule the rest of you'.

Where members opposite all come a gutser is in the fact that members on this side all think that we were born to rule you. It has been ingrained in me from childhood to think that my mission in life is to run you, and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) thinks that his mission in life is to run you. In fact, the labour movement-that is, the Australian Labor Party (ALP) and the great industrial labour movement of Australia-thinks that its mission in life is to run you. That is what is producing the change, that is what is modernising the Australian state and that is what is putting us back up there so that we can hold our head up among developing industrial nations. That is what is giving us back our pride and sovereignty and getting the debt off our back. That is what is again giving us our proper place in the world-the creativity and intellectual freedom of the labour movement, the ALP and the great industrial trade unions of this country. That is what is changing Australia-not sick, tired, old hacks from old middle class blue-rinse Liberal Party branches. What is changing Australia is the dynamism in the statement I delivered last night, and it is that dynamism that will carry Australia into the twenty-first century and carry this Government over the line at the next election.

TALK.START.PARA: —You want to bring the kids in again, Paul! They might believe it.

—Order! If the honourable member for O'Connor interjects again, I will name him. I have already warned him and I draw his attention to the fact that he has interjected four times already in this debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hicks Mr N.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Was that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) of this nation talking about running this, running that and running something else? Does he still think he is in Sydney running the right wing of the Australian Labor Party (ALP)? I can tell the Treasurer that he has a shock coming because the workers of this nation have a few words to say about members of the Labor Party, those Bollinger socialists who think they are doing great things for this nation. In fact, they are breaking down the families of this country. I will say a few words about that because obviously the Treasurer believes his own rhetoric. He says things over and over again. I saw him come into this place last night all powdered up and ready for the television cameras. He is an aspiring Prime Minister but, if he continues on the way that he has been going, he will finish up holding the bag, and the bag will be empty. So enough of this nonsense of directing us and telling us what we are going to do and what we are not going to do.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a time for reminiscing. In the eight years that I have been in parliament I have witnessed a number of Budgets and a great deal of legislation pass through this House. I am extremely disappointed to say that as time goes by I have become convinced that there is a conspiracy in this nation against what I will term the average family with one breadwinner, which is trying to feed, clothe and educate its children. I am galled to be a member of a parliament which governs a country that has the most anti-family or, more specifically, the most anti-child tax system in the Western world. It has been confirmed that in 1986 the value of tax related assistance-including family allowances-for two-child families in Australia amounted to only half the average in other Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) countries when measured as a proportion of average weekly earnings in each country. The larger the family the greater the disparity.

Now that family allowances have been means tested, Australia has become possibly the only Western country not to have a significant tax relief measure which recognises the costs associated with raising children. Mr Deputy Speaker, I do not know whether you are like me but when I sit at the breakfast table with my family and see the price of things on labels on the cornflakes and other cereals, on the milk and on the bread, I tell my wife to put them away because it gives me indigestion. As a member of parliament I have a reasonable salary; I just wonder how the rest of Australia copes with these inflated prices and the cost of things when trying to raise a family. As a person who has raised a family of four, I know that the cost of living has increased dramatically. Families, particularly single income families, have received no help from the Government. In fact, in most small communities the St Vincent de Paul shop and the Smith Family shop would do far more business than all the other shops put together. I point out that I have nothing against St Vincent de Paul because I know myself that it has good clothing. But it is no joke that people are being forced to shop at these establishments because the Government is not looking after families in this country in the way that it should be.

Following the announcement of the Hawke Government's most recent social justice policy, before the last election, Mr Hudson of the Victorian Council of Social Service was very enthusiastic at the Government's welfare assistance scheme for families. He said just recently that under the Hawke Labor Government the number of families living in poverty had doubled since 1983. Can one imagine the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) or anyone else getting up in here and saying that poverty amongst children would be eliminated by 1990? The whole thing, if it were not so serious, would be a great joke.

I am a great supporter of immigration. It gives growth and vitality to our nation and we need to keep our population in a younger age bracket. Honourable members can imagine how appalled I was to learn of homosexual partners being approved for immigration while average Australian families are being penalised by a tax system which is acting against Australia helping to increase its own population. One thing certain is that homosexuals do not reproduce. I know that a lack of income is not the only reason why people in Australia do not have a family, but I can assure the House that, from my experience, if the Government gave more support to the family unit through the taxation system we would have far more young Australians in this nation. Surely the Government knows that providing tax concessions to families is the best form of welfare spending. Last night's mini-Budget statement, I am sad to say, has continued the trend. Certainly we heard of a reduction in tax scales for companies and a few other changes, but once again the tax burden falls on the real workers of this nation. The Government would do well to remember that the real workers of this nation are still family oriented, despite the actions of trendies who try to socially engineer us all.

Let us look at what happened last night. On the wider issue, the Government proclaimed that it has cut $1 billion from next year's Budget. At first we could be forgiven for thinking that that was wonderful, but $650m of this amount was cut from the States' allocations. Most of the other $350m came from cuts to roads, local government, housing and what could be loosely described as welfare. So the States will be shouldering most of the burden, which will be passed on in a number of ways to the average middle income earner. The Government will reap $200m from Telecom Australia, Australia Post, the Australian National Railways Commission and the Federal Airports Corporation. The imposition of a State payroll tax on Telecom and Australia Post will have to lead to an increase in postal and telephone charges and will almost certainly delay the upgrading of telephone services, particularly in rural areas.

The cost of pharmaceutical prescriptions is to rise by $1 a script and new regulations will make it harder for people to fill the 25 prescriptions a year that are required in order to qualify for free drugs under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. The first home owners scheme has had the maximum benefit for applicants with dependent children cut from $6,000 to $5,000. The Government should be looking after Australian families.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where should we cut?

—I will tell honourable members later where they should cut. I am coming to that. This is despite the fact that we are all very aware of the present disastrous situation in the housing market, largely brought on by the Government's capital gains tax regime and its removal of negative gearing provisions. Negative gearing has been reintroduced by the Government, but it is too late to help thousands of middle income earners who cannot afford to buy or even rent accommodation. I am told that in Sydney today hopeful couples seeking housing turn up at vacant properties for auctions, not to purchase the dwelling but merely to bid for a rental price.

SPEECH.PARA: Not only will cutbacks to local government in direct grants and road funding mean an added rates burden to all home owners, which will be particularly onerous for single income families, but also some of the breadwinners will find themselves without a job. This is particularly so in rural areas where it is difficult to find other employment. The only answer for them-because of the capital investment in their homes and the high cost of housing if they move to coastal areas-is to stay home and live on the dole. Of course, cutbacks in road funding in the long term will mean a sustained level of death and injury on our road system, with the accompanying economic cost to the nation's health and welfare systems. Many workers will be pleased that at first glance their superannuation entitlements have not been drastically changed, but I am waiting to study carefully what I believe to be a thimble and pea trick. I cannot understand how, if the Government is to impose millions of dollars of tax on superannuation funds, the superannuants will be better off.

Once again the personnel in our defence forces are being affected by the Government withdrawing its promise to pay defence personnel a $10,000 cash grant under a special home loan scheme. Certainly, loans are still available but an undertaking was given. Most of these people in the armed forces are family men who have depended on the grant, but no-one is free from the anti-family attitude of this Government. What really riles me in all of this is that while we continue to cut back on families we still manage to increase our overseas aid program based on ideological considerations. This includes the $100m to the front line African states over three years, with $9 1/2m for the Marxist state of Mozambique. These amounts have not been cut back.

I am not surprised that the President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions. Simon Crean, has described this mini-Budget as sensible and well balanced. After all, the Government would have to get his approval before the Parliament or the taxpayers of Australia saw what was in the mini-Budget. To propose that tax cuts should not come to the wage earners of Australia until July next year smacks of opportunism and cynicism. It is an insult to the intelligence of the Australian electorate. We all know that with fiscal drag the tax concessions will not be worth the proverbial zack. We all know that interest rates are about to skyrocket. We all know that Simon Crean and his mates will not be able to control wage rises, particularly after this mini-Budget. We all know that the average wage earner is now $42 a week worse off in real terms than he was when this Government came to power, and we all know that the Government's promises are worthless. Much of my electorate is based on the rural community, and because I have spoken mainly of the wider community I think it is sufficient to say that the new President of the National Farmers Federation, Mr John Allwright, said, amongst other things, `The Government is practising economic apartheid'.

In concluding, I leave the Treasurer and the Government with some thoughts and expressions given to me at a recent gathering of workers in Broken Hill, and when I say `workers', I mean real workers. They said, `Noel, we are sick and tired of working our guts out, paying taxes for every weirdo bludging group that comes along. We work hard to feed, clothe and educate our families but we always seem to be getting further behind. The message has to be given to this Government, which prides itself on looking after the worker, that it has to stop looking after its wealthy paper-shuffling mates and the bludgers and start to give us-the workers-some incentive for our efforts and a fair go'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know what is happening in the Opposition but, when it has to get the National Party Whip in there to follow up on a matter of public importance, in our terms he is being given a hospital hand pass. Clearly, the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair) should have been making that speech, but he ducked out on it. The trouble with the Opposition is that it has a sorry history, with all the years of the rotten boroughs of the National Party mucking up this economy, messing up its structure, keeping the exchange rate too high and maintaining a high tariff regime. All of those things the National Party of Australia has to explain away. A decent man such as the honourable member for Riverina-Darling (Mr Hicks) has been dragooned in here to put the Party position because the Leader of the National Party cannot front.

SPEECH.PARA: I notice that many members of the Opposition have cartons in their offices, they are packing up their things. There is probably a big shift on in terms of who is to lead the Opposition parties and where Opposition members are going. Some of them seem to think that they are packing up their cartons to go to the new Parliament House. I suggest that many of them should just keep going, straight past the new Parliament House and out into the electorate, where they can be increasingly irrelevant. Those opposite are the mob which, when in government, ran a $9.6 billion deficit. That is what they left us with. Fraser and Howard slid out of office leaving behind a $9.6 billion deficit. Who pulled the rabbit out of the hat? John Stone, now a senator for Queensland, pulled the rabbit out of the hat, saying, `I had better tell you all that you are facing a $9.6 billion deficit'.

We have set about cutting that deficit, but the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) has come in here saying, `We think you should have gone further. You should have made some more cuts'. We say that we have made all the sensible cuts and we have looked after the pensioners. We have made changes where we think it is necessary. Last year we introduced a family assistance package providing up to $80 a week tax free for needy families. We have done all that. Where else should we cut? We hear silence. Then the National Party comes in here and says, `You should not be cutting road funding. You should not be cutting State assistance. You should not be imposing these extra levies because that is not the way we want the world'.

Those opposite are engaging in a massive exercise in hypocrisy, and all my colleagues on this side of the House know that. On the one hand we hear those opposite talking about cuts. They say, `The Business Council is right, we ought to go for the big $3.5 billion cuts', but when it comes to the test they fail it, and they fail it because they cannot front the real issues. One of the real issues is where the cuts would be made. My colleagues the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth) and the honourable member for Barton (Mr Punch) can suggest where they would be made. It would be where they were always made under Fraser and Howard: the poor, the less well off, would cop the pressure. That was always the case and it would still be the same because the Opposition still has the same ideological baggage that it carried when in government. It was that ideological baggage that meant that it never reformed this economy. It did not do a thing to reform the economy. The coalition Government nearly did all these things. It nearly floated the exchange rate, it nearly brought in financial deregulation, and it nearly cut spending. It nearly did so many things, but it did not face up to the real issues.

What were the real issues? One was the need to modernise the Australian economy. Those opposite could not take that on because it would be too tough. Why? They said, `We still have that legacy of Black Jack McEwen. We have to have high tariffs, we have to provide protection, because we look after our mates'. That is their history.

What else could they not do? They could not deregulate the financial system. Why? Because they seemed to think that somehow there was an important appeal to having these banks in a humidicrib in the economy. They did not do any of those things. They did not face up to the real issues. In fact, the Australian electorate knows that.

They did not get the tax system working either. They let it slip into disrepair. They made sure that their mates were looked after. The bottom of the harbour scheme became the order of the day under honourable members opposite. They were not willing to face up to a fair and equitable tax system. People here say, `That's terrible. People are paying tax'. Of course people are paying tax. People who always should have been paying tax are now paying tax. The free lunches and the fringe benefits have gone. The fringe benefits tax and the capital gains tax are now being paid. They were never paid under the Liberal and National parties.

The Opposition wanted a situation in which the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) and Malcolm Fraser could slide out of office making sure that they had not wounded anyone-certainly not their mates. The people they wounded, of course, were the less well off. We always knew that. That is one of the reasons they were tossed out of office. But they never faced the taxation system. They never modernised it. The top marginal rate was 60c when they left office. Yet the Opposition members talk in here about high taxes under this Government. We cut the top marginal rate to 49c and we foreshadow further cuts next year. That is in the May statement. The May statement faces the reality of the Australian economy. The important thing about the May statement is that it is a statement with vision.

The problem with those opposite is that they have no vision, no future, no sense of history of Australia, no sense of where they are going because all they ever did in those long dreary years in government was look after those who had influence over them. They would not face the real issues. They got the easy pushover try. What they expect again is an easy pushover try. They somehow think they will fall back into government, but the world has changed. There are many people on this side of the House who will make sure they do not get back into government. There are also many people in the electorate who do not want them to get into government.

When I talk to people in my electorate in Western Australia and to people across the country they say, `Let's hope to hell that those Liberals don't get back into power because they are not up to it. They are not up to the game. They cannot face the tough issues'. They can do one or two things. When they are speaking to little select audiences they talk about the cuts, the deals, the arrangements and the fixes they will do to keep certain people happy, but then the mirror is turned around and someone says, `Hang on, let us see how the ideas go in the wider Australian picture'.

Will the Opposition face up to the taxation system? The Opposition tried us on in the last election but its numbers did not add up. It then said, `That's not very good. We'd better get up to Coolangatta and have another go at it'. Following that it said, `This is what our tax principles will be, but we won't give any numbers because we really don't want to be subjected to any testing'. If the Opposition did that in a school situation it would not just not pass; it would get a C minus because it is not up to the difficult task of making economic decisions.

Then we find an extraordinary situation. This must make everyone in Australia wonder. In the five years we have been in government we have brought the $9.6 billion deficit back. We have made cuts with equity. We have done some redistribution to look after those who are less well off. We have done that through tax changes and welfare changes. We have cut the $9.6 billion and we now say that there will be a $3 billion surplus. But the Opposition says, `Perhaps you should have made more cuts' or, on the other hand, `You should have more expenditures. We're not really sure what you should have done. But we know that we will have to find some carping thing that we can go on with because we are paid to do it. We are not paid to have any vision, mind you. We are paid to be carping and negative'.

It is all there. We have seen it before. We have sat here for five years. The Opposition has had various leaders. They should keep their things in cartons so they can move things around easily and more quickly when the time comes. The leaders of the Opposition have not come up with any principles, any policies or any statements of position. Members of the Party outside the Parliament such as John Elliott are saying, `When are you going to get your game together? When are you going to have some vision on tax?'. John Elliott is saying, `I think we should have a consumption tax, then we can pay for all the rorts we will put back into the system'.

Party members then get together and say, `Hang on. That won't wash because the National Party won't cop that and Senator Stone won't cop that. We went through that agony last year in the election. We can't go down that path. We had better bury the consumption tax which is John Howard's preferred position. But now that we have buried the consumption tax where will we go on tax policy? We will go up to the north coast and look at it. We will come out and give some principles. Incidentally, we won't have the media there because they might ask some difficult questions. We want to keep them out of this exercise'. So media people were up trees trying to get photographs of Opposition members.

After that exercise the Liberal Party of Australia put out a position paper. Just imagine President Reagan and Mr Gorbachev coming out of a meeting in Moscow saying, `Here is a position paper, but we don't know what we will do on disarmament'. The Opposition came out of its meeting and said, `Here's a position paper on tax but we won't put any numbers in because we might be subjected to the same questions about where the money will come from and whether everything adds up'. Things did not add up in July 1987 and do not add up now. The Opposition does not have the commitment to getting policies together.

We have had five years of this from the Opposition. I think the Opposition is hoping for the next election to fall into its lap. It will not do the hard work. It has had five years to develop policies but it thinks that somehow it can sit around and score the pushover try, that all of a sudden it will be over the line and it will have won an election. It will not work because people are wise to the Opposition. They saw what it did to the Australian economy. It let it slip and slide. The exchange rate was too high, the financial system was over-regulated and business was buried under an avalanche of regulation. It had a wages system that fell into disrepute. Industrial disputes got right out of hand. People have seen all of that and they will not go back for more of it.

If honourable members look at last night's statement and what the Treasurer (Mr Keating) said they will realise that the Australian economy is on the move, that the economic agenda of change is there, that we are on top of that agenda, and that it will work.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the seventh report of the Standing Committee on Publications sitting in conference with the Publications Committee of the Senate. Copies of the report are being circulated to honourable members in the chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: Report-by leave-adopted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nehl Mr G.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, I present the 290th report of the Committee titled A better deal for our veterans.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-This report presents the findings of the inquiry of the Public Accounts Committee into the management of repatriation general hospitals by the Department of Veterans' Affairs. The Committee began the inquiry in November 1987 as part of a general review of the Auditor-General's reports on audits undertaken between 1985 and 1987. In this review the Committee found that the Auditor-General had reported adversely on aspects of the Department of Veterans' Affairs management of its repatriation hospitals on a number of occasions over that period.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee was concerned to find fundamental deficiencies in the management information systems maintained by the Department to monitor and assess the performance of the various repatriation hospitals. In particular, the Department lacked measures capable of comparing the performance of the repatriation hospitals and State public hospitals and of monitoring the performance of visiting medical officers engaged by the Department.

The Committee was also concerned by the lack of an effective management structure within the Department and by its apparently cavalier approach to responding to the findings of the Auditor-General. In the three-year period reviewed by the Committee the Department of Veterans' Affairs either failed or lacked the capacity to ensure that deficiencies in the management of repatriation hospitals reported by the Auditor-General were systematically rectified at a national level.

The Committee experienced a number of delays in obtaining information from the Department and admonished the Department for failing to approach the Committee's initial investigations with a degree of seriousness appropriate to a Commonwealth parliamentary inquiry.

The Committee affirms the Commonwealth Government's responsibility to provide comprehensive health care services for Australian veterans. Throughout the inquiry the Committee emphasised that it was incumbent on the Department of Veterans' Affairs to maintain information systems and management structures capable of ensuring that the Commonwealth's responsibility to care for the health of veterans and their dependants is administered as efficiently as possible. The Committee does not believe that the Department has achieved this objective or that it has the capacity to provide objective information on the relative efficiency of the repatriation hospital system even if it were being managed efficiently.

The Committee's recommendations are aimed at promoting the development of an improved management structure in the Department, and at establishing more comprehensive management information systems in the repatriation hospitals. It is the Committee's belief that the implementation of the recommendations of this report will not only lead to improved administrative efficiency in the repatriation hospital system but will also promote the development of a health care system which is more responsive to the health care needs of veterans. The Committee will be monitoring the Department's implementation of its recommendations with considerable interest. I commend the report to honourable members.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, I present the 291st report of the Committee-Revised procedures for reports of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The 291st report of the Public Accounts Committee outlines, for the information of the Parliament, a number of changes to the Committee's procedures in dealing with reports of the Auditor-General and monitoring of action taken in response to recommendations contained in reports of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. These changes are the result of a review by the Committee aimed at ensuring that it carries out its work in a more efficient and targeted manner. The Committee has been concerned that it should deal more efficiently with reports of the Auditor-General. Consequently, it has made changes to the procedures it will follow in undertaking its statutory duties to review reports of the Auditor-General tabled in the Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee has decided to introduce the practice of seeking comment from the Auditor-General, subsequent to the tabling of a report, on matters believed to be of importance and which may warrant further investigation by the Committee. This advice will be sought as soon after the tabling of Auditor-General's reports as is possible. The Committee will, with this information in mind, conduct its own separate considerations and decide on its actions. This action may be either: a full, immediate inquiry; or where a complete inquiry is not warranted but there is significant need for parliamentary scrutiny of matters reported in the Auditor-General's reports, the Committee will write to the relevant departments and authorities highlighting its concerns and seeking an immediate response to matters raised in that report. The need for further action by the Committee will then be assessed on the basis of the reply provided to the Committee. The Committee's initiatives in this area will be the subject of a report to the Parliament.

The Committee has adopted this new approach in its consideration of the Auditor- General's Report on Audits to 31 December 1987, tabled on 24 March 1988. The Committee has written to a number of departments, detailed in the report, relating to problems raised by the Auditor-General. The Committee requested that responses from these organisations be supplied by 20 May 1988. The Committee has received advice from all departments and authorities concerning the matters raised and is currently examining those responses. These responses will be the basis of further decisions regarding action by the Committee, including the potential for full inquiries into these matters. The Committee will report to the Parliament the result of its deliberations on these matters.

The 291st report also outlines changes to the follow-up procedures for reports of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. In the past the Committee has tabled separate Finance minutes, outlining action taken in response to recommendations contained in its reports. The Committee will continue the practice of requesting a response to each of its reports from the Minister for Finance in the form of a Finance minute. However, in the future the Committee will table a separate Finance minute report only if it is urgent, lengthy or for some other reason requires immediate reporting to the Parliament. Otherwise, the Committee will table all Finance minutes as one report. This report will be presented annually to the Parliament. The Committee stresses that in reviewing its procedure it has not reduced in any way its oversight of the responses, nor has the importance with which the Committee views the Finance minute process been reduced.

In addition, the review of action taken on recommendations contained in Committee reports will be strengthened by changes to the Guidelines for the Preparation of Departmental Annual Reports. In a statement to the Parliament on 4 June 1987 concerning guidelines for annual reports, the Chairman outlined that the Committee was strongly of the view that annual reports of departments and authorities should provide details of any reviews by the Auditor-General and parliamentary committees. The Committee has also stated that these details should include recommendations made in the reviews and any action taken to address the recommendations.

Revised guidelines, tabled by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on 17 November 1987, announced that he had accepted the Committee's views together with other recommendations contained in report 262-Guidelines for Annual Reports. The Guidelines for the Preparation of Departmental Annual Reports now state that each report should:

contain information regarding any reviews by the Auditor-General or Parliamentary committees which directly affect the department, showing recommendations arising from such reviews and the action taken to address them.

The Committee will, as part of the follow-up procedure for its reports, review annual reports of departments for compliance with the relevant guidelines. The Committee considers that annual reports are an extremely important element in ensuring the accountability of public expenditure. The Committee will be writing to each department highlighting the relevant section of the annual report guidelines and stating that the Committee will be examining annual reports for compliance.

The changes to the practices of the Committee outlined in this report aim to ensure that it conducts its work in the most efficient and effective manner. The changes in the procedures of the Committee have not diminished its workload; however, it has enabled the Committee to turn its attention to additional and significant areas of inquiry. The Committee has recently initiated the following major inquiries: reform of the Australian Audit Office; engagement of external consultants by Commonwealth government bodies; management of the Antarctic Division; and safety principles for explosives. The Committee also has in progress an extensive inquiry into therapeutic goods evaluation and testing. There are also, of course, other matters that arise generally out of Auditor-General's reports from 1985 to 1987 which have been more generally canvassed.

Last year the staff resources available to the Committee were substantially reduced, from 15 to five. Since that date, and following discussions held with Madam Speaker, an additional two staff were allocated to the Committee. The Committee has expressed its appreciation for this allocation. The Committee, however, continues to be concerned to ensure it has adequate staff resources allocated to it and has resolved that, with the workload it should be undertaking to fulfil its obligations, a staffing level of 10 is required, including secondments and consultants, noting that in the past secondees were in addition to the permanent staff. These matters could be canvassed more fully, Mr Deputy Speaker, but, having in mind your role in this matter at this time, I simply commend this report to you and to honourable members.

SPEECH.PARA: I think, if the Australian Labor Party wants the record to show that it has dealt with legislation in this way, this will do it little credit in the eyes of the public and little credit in the eyes of those who will consider this legislation and it will do it little credit in terms of the way in which people will become aware of the faults that will no doubt exist in some of these Bills.
