PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 25 May, on motion by Dr Blewett:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The National Health Amendment Bill seeks to amend the National Health Act and deals primarily with increasing the cost to the individual of purchasing a pharmaceutical benefits scheme prescription-in other words, purchasing the drugs prescribed by a doctor-from $10 to $11. As such, it is just another move to impose more costs on the community without any offsetting tax deductions. That is what is proposed in the economic statement. It is pleasing to note, as the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) advised in his second reading speech, that free prescriptions to pensioner health benefit card holders will be maintained and, for others who have means tested pensions or are on certain other benefits, the charge will be maintained at the concessional beneficiary rate of $2.50.

SPEECH.PARA: Nevertheless, what we are being told by this legislation is that those in the community whose wages have been steadily eroded by an ever-increasing tax burden will have to make this further contribution. As I will point out later, some other aspects cause concern. The Minister also advised us that the safety net arrangements will be maintained. Of course, the safety net arrangements provide principally that people who are chronically ill and have to obtain more than 25 prescriptions in any one year need only pay for those 25 after which they will get any prescriptions free. So we are really talking about ordinary people in the community.

My inquiries point out to me that there are 1,017,000 elderly persons in Australia who do not carry a pensioner health benefit card. Some of those would be subject to the $2.50 arrangement; many would not. Consequently, they must find the additional dollar. Between a married couple, it could work out at another $50 or $60 a year. That is quite a substantial amount. People with children and others throughout our community will have to carry the additional burden. We have to look at this in the cost perspective because at all times we see a substantial growth in government revenue. All the time people are being asked to pay more and more, and that is the point.

When we look at the March figures put out by the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) regarding these matters, we find that total revenue for March increased by 22.5 per cent over that for March 1987; that pay as you earn tax collections were 8 per cent higher than they were for March 1987; that receipts under the prescribed payments system had increased by 23.2 per cent; that company tax collections were 26.3 per cent higher; and that sales tax collections were up 17 per cent. I remind honourable members that sales tax is paid by pensioners. They might get free pharmaceutical benefits, but they contribute to government revenue through their taxes because they buy pet food and many other things that are included in the sales tax regime. There has been a massive growth-25 per cent-in government revenue. Certainly, there has been a 20 per cent increase, on average, in additional income to the Government. But that is not enough; the Government has to get another dollar out of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. Legislation seeking to increase that charge to the community by just a dollar has been introduced to the Parliament as a result of last night's financial statement.

Page 37 of the economic statement gives further evidence of what will happen under the pharmaceutical benefit arrangements. We find that the Government proposes to reduce the forward expenditure estimates by $69m in 1988-89; $100m in 1989-90; and $123m in 1990-91. Quite clearly, the receipt of an extra $1 per prescription will not generate those savings for the Government, so it has proposed other measures. Some of them have been brought before the Parliament on previous occasions and are known to the community. They are being extended or tightened in these arrangements. One is to extend the authority that is required for the prescription of certain pharmaceutical benefits. This has been described by the Australian Pharmaceutical Manufacturing Association in a manner which I think is worthy of quoting because I see this as the way the whole medical benefits area is developing:
The Effects on Consumers of Extending Authority Requirements for the Prescribing of Expensive Drugs:
A faceless bureaucrat will be placed between doctor and patient. Doctors will be forced to seek prior approval before prescribing more advanced and thus more expensive drugs.
The patient will no longer necessarily have what is in the opinion of his doctor the best drug available. The Association goes on to say:
Presumably products such as ace-inhibitors (new effective treatments for hypertension) and similar products, will be amongst those restricted by virtue of their cost.

So a huge saving is to be achieved by denying Australians new developments in the drug industry because those drugs are not yet listed. Of course, that is convenient for the Government, facing some very substantial blowouts in its pharmaceutical expenses. The Minister for Community Services and Health refers to that in his second reading speech in which he says, as I recollect, that steps announced in the May statement will reduce this rate of growth. He says:
. . . rate of increase . . . would have seen expenditure on pharmaceutical benefits almost double over the next three years.

That is the Minister's concern. As I explained to the Parliament yesterday, the Minister has become so involved in defending his ailing institution of Medicare and the associated medical benefits that the individual-the ailing individual, in this case-is of secondary importance. And here he is going down the road of cutting back.

Ever since I have been the shadow Minister for health in this place, I have not dealt with one piece of legislation in the health arena that has improved the lot of the Australian people. I have dealt with that 25 per cent increase in the tax that is imposed upon them. That was at least positive in dollar terms; it took more money from people. Everything else has been a proposition to remove something. Here we are, at it again: with one piece of paper, one sheet of the economic statement, we are imposing additional financial burdens-an extra $1 per prescription-and we get into this process of saying, `I am sorry, you can't have that'. Of course, the problem is not only the introduction of this bureaucrat who stands between people and medical services and applying that in the pharmaceutical area. If we are Medicare patients, we literally now need the stamp of approval from a bureaucrat, a person who need not have any qualification in medicine, to have access to a hospital. It is no longer so simple as to say, `I am feeling ill; I will go to hospital'. It is no longer so simple as to have a doctor in the western areas of New South Wales say to some young Aboriginal child or some other person, `You need to go to the Manly Far West Children's Home. That is where I think you should be treated, because of the difficulties you have in your family that I know about as your local doctor'. It is no longer sufficient for that doctor to make those decisions and send that child to the hospital, because that hospital is now taking some government money and a Department of Community Services and Health official makes the final decision as to whether the child will go to the hospital. Sometimes the official has no understanding whatsoever of the reasons why that child should go to that hospital.

Under this arrangement, what do we find in the February and March statements issued by the Minister for Finance? He points out that, in the month of February, pharmaceutical benefits were up by 30.9 per cent over the corresponding period last year, when they were supposed to be 14.8 per cent. That has come back a little. Taking in the month of March, the Government is now looking at an increase of only 26.4 per cent compared to that 14.8 per cent. The Minister for Finance now believes he should give us a few explanations as to how he put his numbers together, after I made some comments about them last month and the Minister said to me, `You do not know how to read'. I cannot read blank pages. At least the information has been provided this time. The Minister says that the growth is due mainly to the increased prescription of expensive drugs and that Budget estimates for this program are likely to be exceeded.

What is the concern of the Minister for Finance? That doctors are actually prescribing expensive drugs. One does not have to be Albert Einstein to know that there is a huge cost in developing new pharmaceutical products. Somebody makes those products, and we do not have much subsidised government enterprise in the pharmaceutical manufacturing area throughout the world. Huge costs go into establishing what is needed to find the new drugs that save lives. When a drug is eventually developed, of course it is expensive; but this Government is of the view that if it is expensive people had better not have it.

We dealt with other legislation here relating to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee, which lists these drugs. When we last dealt with that legislation in this place, it was interesting to note that the Minister in his second reading speech said that the Government was placing another constraint upon this Committee. It was giving them some more resources so that they could go into things a little better, but they would have to be more careful in what they listed because the Government was terribly worried about the expense. The Government can take all this money-26 per cent, 20 per cent and 17 per cent increases in taxes from people-but when it comes to giving them something that might save their kids' lives the Government has to think about that. It has to have more resources to decide whether it is necessary. More, we now instruct this Committee that decides what pharmaceutical products might be listed on the pharmaceutical benefits scheme (PBS) that it must look at the alternatives to prescribing that pharmaceutical product that might be necessary for the patient's good health. We want the Committee to consider surgery as an alternative.

I have already been through that process-fortunately, before such instruction was available. I had surgeons arguing for a $200 operation on my knee and microbiologists arguing for $5,000 worth of drugs and an extensive period of hospitalisation. I am pleased that the microbiologists and I won because I still have my kneecap. But is it a fact that that instruction means in future that the decision must go the other way? It is not the public's fault that this Government chose to become the provider of all medical benefits in Australia. That was imposed upon them; and yet this Minister told us yesterday-if he were speaking today he would repeat it-what a wonderful system it is. He quoted the American official who told him it was great. All we know is that we have massive waiting lists, and here we are dealing with matters cutting back on what people can get in the way of pharmaceutical benefits.

Every now and then we have in Australia a person who develops a rare complaint. It is extremely important to that person as an individual. That person is suffering pain and needs treatment, but he is one of 50 or 100 and, under a socialised system, we do not make arrangements for them; it is all too difficult. That drug is not listed and those patients have to pay 100 per cent of the cost. We have all of these other protective mechanisms in place. We take years to certify that certain drugs are good enough. It seems that the more expensive they are, the longer the investigators take to decide that Australians can have that drug. Of course, if it happens to be some cheap generic drug from South Africa, we let people start taking it first and then we have an inquiry when we find that it is not up to standard. Such an inquiry is still going on, and the Minister will not tell us what he has done about those 30 generic products that were brought in to save some money and which were proved to be unsatisfactory. We are not told much about that; that is embarrassing.

The whole situation is that the people suffer. They have had their sales taxes increased by 16 per cent; they have had their pay as you earn taxation increased by 8 per cent; they have had many of their other taxes increased and, in total, all their taxes have been increased by 22 per cent. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) boasts about balancing the Budget. How much skill would any housewife need to balance her budget if the family wages were unlimited? She could just go out and say to her husband's employer, as the Treasurer is saying to us, `I am ruling things here. My instructions to you are that you will pay more'. Life would be very easy in the average household, if that were the situation. But, of course, that is not the way it goes.

We are constantly being lectured on social justice. We are being told here day after day about social justice. The Minister at the table, the Minister for Community Services and Health, took so long trying to explain social justice the other day that on a couple of occasions Madam Speaker had to ask him to bring his answer to a close. We have the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) getting up day after day and telling this Parliament that the Australian people have never had it so good. We have had the Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples), the mini-Minister for nursing homes, putting in his contribution.

How does that reflect in the community? All of the working class suburbs of cities in New South Wales had massive swings of 10 to 15 per cent against the Australian Labor Party at the last State election. Blue collar workers are not convinced by this rhetoric. The mass of Press releases with which the Minister for Community Services and Health bombards the Press Gallery-which I read, but which are never published-tell the people that they have never had it so good. The Press Gallery is bombarded with lengthy Press releases, one after another, telling Australians that their health services have never been better. Those Press releases are being ignored by the Press Gallery because they do not mention people.

We had the Treasurer telling us a little while ago that this is a government about getting things done. However, the Minister for Community Services and Health never tells us how he is going to fix the problems of an ever-declining medical service, an ever-declining pharmaceutical benefits service and, of course, increasing costs, more taxes and more expenditure. People have to pay more for the service which the Government imposes. But they have to pay more taxes as well. There are no trade-offs in this for ordinary Australia-for ordinary people with kids. Of course, we know that average weekly earners have seen their tax as a percentage of what they earn go up by about 4 per cent. What about the people below that level, who, on the basis of the cost of living today, really and truly cannot afford to pay anything? Another factor introduced in the economic statement is worthy of some consideration, too. It is proposed that, in order to save money, doctors prescribe more items on one prescription. The Pharmacy Guild of Australia does not entirely believe that to be a good idea. It has pointed out that it will, of course, take longer to reach the safety net of 25 prescriptions and the prescription will involve double the cost. Furthermore, pharmacists are saying, `How are we going to manage?'. They have been screwed down by successive governments for the last 30 years, since they decided to participate in the PBS.

It might be of interest to the Minister to know that when we took out some figures recently we found that in real terms pharmacists actually earn $1,000 a year less on average than they did in 1963-64-all those years ago. Of course, since then there have been some massive changes in pharmacy practice. In 1963-64 when one went into a pharmacy it was full of pharmaceutical products. Today one needs a map and a water bag to find the dispensary because one has to find one's way through the beach balls and all the other products which the pharmacists have been forced to carry to maintain their standard of living at a point at which they are $1,000 a year worse off anyway than in 1963-64.

Pharmacists are not too happy about these arrangements; nor should they be, because in those areas in which the average of 2,000 prescriptions a month is not being reached pharmacies are closing down. Nobody knows that better than I because they are closing down in country areas and leaving the people-the people we should be concerned about; ordinary Australians; not necessarily the rich farmers, but all those people who are employed in country areas-to travel 50 or 60 miles to get a prescription filled. If the Minister considers that an improvement to the health system, I would be surprised.

There are other problems. There is the increased likelihood of wastage when people take a lot of drugs home at one time. There is the increased likelihood of inappropriate consumption as a result of all these drugs lying around the place. As I said, there is a loss in the dispensing fee for the pharmacist. However, we are told in the statement that, of course, there will be more frequent visits to the doctor. I do not know where we will save money, because that will be an extra bulk billing charge. All in all, it is not really a very helpful situation.

The Opposition does not intend to oppose this pharmaceutical increase. It is a Budget matter; and we have a fixed policy on that. Unfortunately, we cannot protect the Australian people when matters such as this are introduced in this fashion. I think that this is a highly inappropriate charge unless adequate tax reductions had been given in the mini-Budget. We know what the Government is about. We know when it wants to give the tax reductions. It is a purely cynical exercise to make people suffer so that they will feel better when the pain is relieved just prior to an election. It is a shame and a disgrace. Again, as I said, it is clear evidence of this Government's view that we must have socialised medicine; that we must, whatever we do, stick to telling people that they have never had it so good when, of course, the people themselves are rebelling.

I will close on the simple reason for their rebelling. This Government does not understand the situation because it is not composed of people of the working class. The Minister drives his Volvo. I drive my Jaguar and admit to it. But I do not claim to be anything but a person who understands the working class. The Government has been hijacked by the academics. It does not understand working people. The Government does not understand that working class people have simple economic indicators. They are not interested in the Government's figures. They are not interested in the rantings of this arrogant Treasurer. Their simple economic indicators are their bank passbooks and, of course, their wallets. People know that they have not anything in them any more. That is why they are rejecting the Government. The Government is not helping the condition of those wallets by adding another $1 to the prescription fees people must pay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crawford Ms M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the National Health Amendment Bill and perhaps to offer to those people who have been listening to the debate some explanation of what is going on and what actually is proposed within the terms of this Bill. This Bill proposes that the maximum general patient contribution be increased from $10 to $11 per prescription. What we are talking about in real terms-in terms which people can understand-are those prescriptions which currently cost more than $10 and less than $11. We are talking about a maximum contribution or ceiling. Drugs that currently are more expensive than $11 will have the extra cost met by the taxpayer.

SPEECH.PARA: Therefore, the proposal does not represent an additional $1 on every prescription. Rather, it will mean the addition of $1 on the ceiling or maximum cost of a prescription. For those prescriptions which currently cost more than $11 we, the taxpayers of Australia, will continue to support those people who need expensive drugs and who rightfully deserve to have that sort of medical treatment. Hence, we are committed to ensuring that they are able to have that treatment. It is a fact also that people on drugs which currently cost less than $11 will not have the cost of their drugs increased to $11; they will simply be paying what they are paying now. I think it is very clear. It should be very clear to every honourable member and to everybody listening that what we are currently talking about is a maximum cost or ceiling in relation to prescriptions coming under the prescribed drugs and pharmaceutical benefits scheme. That is the first point.

The second thing about which I think we need very definitely to reassure people is that pensioners who still have a health card will still be able to receive their drugs at the current level. In fact, what is probably more important is that many pensioners will be able to receive double the quantity if that has been deemed safe by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee. That will be a saving for them not only in money terms but also in terms of time and convenience. The Government is not interested in seeing how many pills we can have; how many journeys people need to take to doctors and pharmacists; how many times doctors can overservice people. We are simply looking at treatment levels, and those people who are deserving of treatment will still be serviced under the provisions of this Bill.

The same applies to the safety net provisions, which are still in place. The Opposition spokesperson on health, the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), has great difficulty in suggesting that it will take longer for some people to reach the safety net requirements. Indeed, this may be so, but we are not talking about the length of time in terms of reaching safety net provisions; we are talking about safety net provisions receiving treatment. If people are receiving double their quantity of drugs for less than half the current price their treatment is being ensured, and that is what we are about-ensuring that people receive treatment and are able to provide for themselves and their families the pharmaceutical materials necessary for their health.

It is ironic that a person who comes from a party that is committed to cutting expenditure should now look at this Government which is proposing to make some cuts in expenditure and suggest that something is wrong. I find it extraordinary that it is suggested that the Government has no proposals. Obviously the Opposition is prepared to continue to allow the money which the Government would spend on pharmaceutical benefits to double to more than $2 billion in three years time-this from a party which has a platform of cutting expenditure. Where is the Opposition proposing to make the cuts? What is it proposing to do? We hear no mention of this. Indeed, we are derided because we mention the term `social justice'.

We believe that those people who can afford to pay should pay, and that those who cannot should still be entitled to receive health and medical care under our system despite the fact that they may be in straitened circumstances; they may be poor and they may be unable to afford it. Is this so wrong? Is it so bad that we should allow pensioners to continue to receive their free health care cards? Should we not enable families and people with chronically ill children to be provided with the safety net provisions of this pharmaceutical benefits scheme and ask those who have been deemed to be able to pay to pay a maximum ceiling of a further $1 to ensure that we all receive better pharmaceutical benefits? I am sure the Australian community is quite prepared to accept that. After all, it accepts the notion that health care is the right of our citizens, irrespective of the amount of money they may earn. Allied with that are the pharmaceutical benefits people may need to ensure that their health and that of their families can be upgraded.

The provisions of the Bill take a serious look at the ways in which overexpensive drugs have been prescribed. Many of those measures establishing tighter controls on the availability of expensive drugs are directed not at the patient but rather at the methods by which doctors prescribe drugs, and that should be of concern to us all. There are some examples where doctors have prescribed drugs which obviously have been unsuitable. There are cases where doctors prescribe drugs which are dearer simply so that they and their mates can receive more money.

The Government is not about that sort of system. What we are about is ensuring that the least expensive drugs which can be dispensed should be dispensed for the benefit of us all, and what we are saying is that this Bill looks not only at the health of all Australians, but also at saving taxpayers money. I am sure the Opposition spokesperson on health can have no quibble with that. We have heard him say here today that taxpayers are paying too much, and yet when we propose a program which will enable taxpayers' money to be saved over a period-a whole $1 billion in the next three years-he finds some flaw in this. I simply ask: Where does the Opposition spokesperson stand? If he believes in taxpayers' money being saved-and we are doing this-why then is he arguing with us? If he believes that health care is the right of all Australians, irrespective of how rich they may be and how they have acquired that wealth, surely he would have to support the kind of program we offer.

Therefore I must support the National Health Amendment Bill, which will ensure that the kinds of services which are delivered through the pharmaceutical benefits scheme will continue to be for the benefit of us all and will continue to benefit pensioners, to provide a safety net for families, and to ensure that controls remain upon drugs so that doctors' prescriptions can be monitored carefully. It will also ensure that nobody will need to pay more than $11 for a prescription. I emphasise that statement because it seems to be a point that has been missed by many people that what we are talking about is a maximum ceiling and that it affects only those prescriptions that currently fall between $10 and $11.

I commend the Bill to the House, as I commend the Government's health care and pharmaceutical program to the House, because it ensures that all Australians, irrespective of their incomes, have a right to health care and are treated fairly and justly under the scheme.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woods Dr R. L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The main point at issue is the price rise of prescriptions from $10 to $11. It has been represented as a 10 per cent increase, but in fact, if one looks back to November 1986, not so long ago, when the cost of a prescription was $5, one realises it is an increase of 120 per cent. That should be borne in mind when talking about a minute price rise. Let me also point out-and these are not my own figures or statements but the statements of Sophie Hill, who is a researcher in the Health Issues Centre in Melbourne-that any price rise, however small, affects the poor significantly more than the rich. These are the people who are going to be affected by this proposal of the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Dr Stephen Leeder was quoted recently in the Sydney Morning Herald as having quoted from a book called In Search of Excellence that if B does not work, try A. It is a well-known theory for improving performance. In the health system one could say that if B for bureaucracy does not work, try A for `adhocracy'. B could also stand for bandaids in this health system.

I welcome one aspect of the proposal, and that is the proposal to inject more funds into the education and information aspects of health care. They have been underfunded in the past, and that, I strongly believe, is the way we should be going in the future. We should be educating not only doctors and nurses but also the public in what is the optimal health care in looking after themselves and in the prescribing of various drugs and what is appropriate and inappropriate in a given situation. Unfortunately, as well as injecting into the health system some sensible measures, the Government has injected a lot of rather stupid and ad hoc measures. It has injected some more red tape and price rises-the regular stand-bys of governments all over the world, but of this Government in particular.

Let us look for a moment at what the Government is actually doing. It is going to cut costs-that is the main aim of the whole process. One of the ways of cutting costs is by making pharmacists do more work for the same pay. The Pharmacy Guild of Australia, incidentally, clearly opposes this aspect. In many cases it is doubling the actual size of the prescription in terms of the numbers of tablets or the volume of drug given out. It means the pharmacists on the whole will still get the same dispensing fee, and often less than they were getting in the not too distant past because of the new computerisation rules, but in many cases they are doubling the size of the drug given out.

Those sizes were put there for a good reason. They were not put there just for the fun of it. The Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee did not say, `Eeny, meeny, miny, mo, we will give this drug in 10 aliquots and that drug in 20', the dosages were given for reason, and that was basically safety. They were given so that there was good medical supervision of the results of therapy, and so that a doctor would not give a patient so much of a drug that the patient would suffer all sorts of side effects and be caused irreparable damage, in some cases, before coming back and seeing the doctor again.

The previous speaker, the honourable member for Forde (Ms Crawford), referred to this as over-servicing. In my book, this is looking after the health of patients in an appropriate way, a way decided by the Minister in previous times and by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee, amongst others. It seems to me that this is an appropriate way of caring for patients rather than leaving them to their own devices and to the potential side effects of many drugs. Let us not beat around the bush-many drugs have side effects and need fairly close supervision. Apparently, in terms of safety, at least, and in terms of how many times one visits a doctor and discusses whether one is having problems with the therapy and whether it is working, we seem to be saying, `Don't you worry about that'. It is almost as if the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) came from Queensland. He seems to be endorsing less supervision of therapy and at the same time endorsing lower fees for pharmacists. I apologise to the Minister; that was the worst insult I could have offered him. The general hypothesis in this regard might be: never mind the quality, count the cost. Cost seems to be paramount in this regard.

A few moments ago we talked about the safety net. It is clear to me that the numbers of patients who will avail themselves of free drugs under the safety net provisions will be markedly reduced. That is because the legislation as it stands means that a prescription does not count in terms of the safety net unless it is written for the maximum amount. We can understand why that was introduced, but what it means now is that, even if that maximum amount is inappropriate-and in many cases it is inappropriate to give large volumes of drugs, particularly to pensioners who may not be clear about the possible side effects-that prescription does not count towards the safety net counting provisions. So really we are encouraging doctors to prescribe the maximum amount, even when it is inappropriate, so that the pensioner, or whoever it may be, can actually count it under the safety net provisions and eventually reach the safety net level and obtain his free drugs. There is some very muddled thinking in that sort of approach.

The shadow Minister for health, the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), mentioned the question of authority drugs. I can speak with some authority on this matter, if honourable members will pardon the pun, in as much as for a long time I was involved in prescribing a number of drugs which required the authority of the Department of Community Services and Health before they were able to be prescribed. One particular drug that I was involved with in my medical practice was a drug with the trade name nolvadex and the generic name tamoxifen and made by ICI (Australia) Ltd. It is a superb drug which is very good at controlling and, in some cases, curing cancer, particularly breast cancer. At that particular time that drug was required to be approved by the Department of Health before it could be prescribed. I was faced with a ludicrous situation, therefore, whereby I would see a patient suffering with, and often at serious risk from, breast cancer, which would need urgent therapy-urgent being a matter of days rather than hours, but it was still urgent-and I would fill in a prescription which would go off to the Department of Health. If I was lucky, and I must say that that was not often the case, we would receive the drug in about six weeks. In the meantime, during those six weeks, in a number of cases, and in fact in the majority of cases, there could have been significant and perhaps irreversible deterioration which in some cases may even have led to death.

What actually happened was that the pharmacist would say, `I cannot let this patient go without the drug for six weeks. I will assume that he will get the authority because it is such a sensible thing and any reasonable person can see that authority should be given in this situation. I will assume that he will get the authority, so I will prescribe the drug and cover the cost out of my own pocket'. Thank goodness pharmacists do have a heart in this regard because to wait for six weeks often would have been significantly deleterious to the patient. In regard to some of the drugs that it is proposed to include in this group, if the leaks are accurate, the same thing will apply.

By including more drugs on the list of drugs which require authority, we are lowering dispensing costs by preventing patients from going onto those drugs. That is the whole aim of it. It is not a question of making sure that a particular drug is appropriate. It is a way of excluding those patients from receiving a given drug. If the leaks are accurate, number one on the hit list of drugs to come under the new authority drug provisions are the angiotomin converting enzyme-ACE-inhibitors. Briefly, they are drugs which are very useful and valuable in treating blood pressure. I believe that, in terms of cost to the pharmaceutical benefit scheme, they are pretty well at the top of the list.

These drugs are not prescribed because of the whim of a doctor, and they are not prescribed because they are promoted with glossy advertisements. Contrary to what we have heard from the Government, they are not like other drugs which are prescribed because the advertising of a particular company manages to persuade doctors to prescribe them against their better clinical judgment. They are prescribed because they are excellent drugs and in particular because they have much lower side effects and allow a much better quality of life.

In regard to blood pressure control, many of the drugs used cause major side effects; a couple of the more common are fatigue and impotence. Honourable members would understand that reducing those two side effects would be very beneficial. I guess we can hope that some Government members are not on any of the blood pressure drugs-and I talk in terms of the fatigue and not the impotence.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope you are not talking about me.

—I am sure that the honourable member for Canning need not worry about the impotence part. Certainly I hope that fatigue is not the cause of any problems. What will happen to these patients who will now have to obtain authority for the prescription of this drug? Sure, directly speaking, they will not be prohibited, but doctors will be put off prescribing them because they know that they will have to go through an enormous amount of red tape which could take several weeks; but, more importantly, while they wait for that red tape to be processed patients could suffer because they cannot have the appropriate drug for six weeks. So patients will suffer the risks associated with blood pressure for six weeks and, as honourable members would know, that could result in major strokes and cerebrovascular accidents.

SPEECH.PARA: I found the imputation of the honourable member for Forde about doctors' prescribing habits despicable. Her proposal, which, if I understood her correctly, is that basically we should just prescribe the cheapest drugs available, I found to be unbelievable. In fact, I cannot believe that I heard her correctly. I sincerely trust that I did not. To say that we should prescribe the cheapest drugs, regardless of what is actually the best drug, is inappropriate. Quality must be paramount. Certainly, we can economise within that quality, but we must surely not sacrifice quality for the sake of convenience on economy.

I said earlier that the poor are affected most, and the honourable member for Forde also raised this matter. She tried to imply that it was the Labor Government that was concerned about the care of the poor. I point out that the 40,000 people on the waiting list in New South Wales alone are, on the whole, in the lower income brackets. There seems to be little doubt, when one examines the breakdown of who is on waiting lists, that it is the poor who suffer most. In regard to discrimination against the poor, I was interested in the development of a two-tier health system that we are seeing and how it is clearly the poor who suffer in Australia. The World Health Organisation (WHO) published a report recently entitled Health for All. In Australia a report entitled Health for All in Australia was published under the auspices of the Government. Some interesting statistics come out of the report, clearly showing that it is the poor who suffer in this country. For example, there is a higher rate of cancer amongst the lower paid. One is 1.454 times more likely to get cancer if one is in a lower paid group. One is 4.88 times more likely to suffer from a severe mental disease, and in fact die from a mental problem, if one is a member of that group. Even the incidence of accidents is much higher among the poor.

The report notes that cerebrovascular accidents and cardiovascular accidents have been reduced by about 25 per cent over an approximate 10-year period. It also notes, however, that almost all of that reduction has occurred amongst the better off. In other words, the poor have not benefited from the improvements in health care in our society. There are fewer pap smears amongst the poor. The immunisation of children amongst educated people is much higher than for those who have not undergone tertiary education. The WHO resolution and report were aimed at banana republics. What has happened, of course, is that this is an appropriate resolution for Australia. With our nationalised health system, which is clearly what we have, we have reached a situation where we are in the same category as a banana republic. I think it is quite clear that the death knell is sounding for nationalised medicine in Australia.

Recently we saw from the United Kingdom a report which basically says that the national health system there is running down and cannot work any longer. What they are allowing people to do now, and encouraging them to do, is take out private insurance so that they can have adequate health care. The same is true of nationalised health systems all over the world. It is true of Holland and other European countries. The problems with the health systems everywhere are the same: there are waiting lists and there are quality problems. The quality of care that is offered is vastly inferior.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time allotted for the remaining stages of the Bill has expired. The question is that this Bill be now read a second time.
—The question is that the remaining stages of the Bill be agreed to.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 25 May, on motion by Mr Barry Jones:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BARRY JONES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek your indulgence to correct two minor errors in the second reading speech delivered on this Bill yesterday.
—The Minister has the Chair's indulgence.

—In my second reading speech on this Bill, as reported on page 3035 of Hansard, I said that tariff rates for sugar and tobacco imports would be phased down to 15 per cent in each case by 30 June 1992. That date should in fact have been 1 July 1992. I regret the error.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Customs Tariff (Rate Alteration) Bill, which we have been given one half-hour to debate, is a matter of tremendous importance to people and industry in Australia. I very much regret that time limitation. We are debating reductions in tariff in general and, more specifically, in certain areas. I make the comment that, if the Government were going to give some encouragement to industry to stand on its own feet, this move should have been made 12 months ago when the exchange rates were at rock bottom. It is not as though the Government was not told about this matter because it was an additional form of protection in a declining market.

SPEECH.PARA: I have obtained from the Parliamentary Library figures which indicate that in July 1986 the value of our dollar against the United States dollar was 59.8c. That would have been the lowest figure reached. Today it is valued at, I think, 79c. The trade weighted index at July 1986 was 49.3 and at this stage it is 58.4. At that time the Australian dollar was valued at 90c against the yen and it is now valued at 99c. Against the pound sterling it was valued at about 37p compared with 42p at the moment. So this move has come basically two years too late to allow the affected industries to respond. In that light, it has always been the policy of the Opposition parties to provide tariff protection in order to support industry and to take the drain off primary industries. We heard a question about that asked in Question Time today.

The Bill provides for a gradual decline in tariffs and the abandonment of the 2 per cent revenue duty on imports, which falls most heavily on capital equipment and which has been a burden on industry inputs. The purpose of this is to offset some of the impact of other tariff cuts in affected industries. Most tariffs now above 15 per cent will be phased down to that level over four years. The cuts will be implemented in five equal annual steps beginning on 1 July each year. Tariffs between 10 and 15 per cent will fall to 10 per cent over the same four years. In all, the reductions represent a 20 per cent fall in protection. Tariffs that have already been phased down to 15 per cent or below will not be touched. Some industries, such as the passenger motor vehicle industry and the clothing, textile, and footwear industry, are exempted from this provision because of the package debated in this House just recently. That is understandable because these industries are already suffering a decrease in tariffs.

This legislation has some interesting features. The tariff preference arrangements will remain unchanged provided this does not prevent the general rate reduction from coming about as detailed. Protection to a number of primary industries such as the sugar, tobacco, dried vine, citrus and wine industries, will be phased down and all tariffs will eventually be reduced to 15 per cent. The Opposition does not oppose these measures. In fact, we believe that they are long overdue, as I mentioned earlier.

One area to which I would like to pay a bit of attention and which reflects a lot of the problems of primary industry is the sugar industry. We have been alerted within a very short time to the concerns of the sugar industry in both New South Wales and Queensland, particularly as to the Government's intention to rescind the embargo as at 30 June 1989 and the termination, because of the sunset clause, of the Commonwealth-State agreement on sugar. Unfortunately, this has all been done without any consultation whatsoever with the sugar industry. The messages we get from both Queensland and New South Wales are that they are appalled by the suddenness of the decision at a time when they are expecting another Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) review. They are prepared to suffer another IAC review. I say `suffer' because the previous reviews seem to have been to the detriment of the industry. So far there have been two reviews-one in 1979 and the other from 1983 onwards-at a time when the industry suffered the most adverse conditions it has ever known. That is significant because at that time the price of sugar was at a world low. The 1982, 1983 and 1984 prices were the lowest prices ever received on the international markets, dropping in some cases to about US3c a pound. That drop was associated with bad climatic conditions in certain sectors. In combination, this spelt disaster. I am advised by the Queensland Cane Growers Council that 10 per cent of the producers are still in grave difficulties. They will either have to get out or get better, but there is a situation beyond which some farmers cannot decrease their costs and improve their efficiency and performance.

It has been a matter of great concern to this Government to interfere as much as it possibly could in the State arrangements. The sugar industry is really a State industry. One of the great catchcries of the IAC and the Labor Government is over deregulation and rationalisation. The industry has been forced to accept the plans imposed by the Commonwealth. To a large extent they have not been detrimental, except in the method of their implementation. When this was first mooted I suggested that the industry would not mind deregulating provided that there was a level playing field-we hear that phrase a lot now. I suggested that all of the other market forces could also be deregulated.

Only last week we debated in this House the new Industrial Relations Bill, which provides for the most highly regulated, highly centralised and high cost labour that any industry in Australia has had to face. The sugar industry is no exception. So while the industry has moved tremendously in the areas of production, milling and marketing to meet the deregulated situation which this embargo implies will now continue, the labour market has not. It is just as rigid, inflexible and costly-and work practices and such matters have not been properly addressed-as it was three or four years ago when this situation was forced upon the industry.

Over time the embargo has benefited Australian consumers. It has also benefited Australian producers by giving them stability and a direction in an industry that at the moment sells about 20 to 25 per cent of its products on the domestic market and the rest on the world market. About two or three years ago figures I took out indicated that the benefit to sugar consumers in Australia was about $400m. That is significant. Anybody who suggests that the embargo has been an added protection or benefit to Australian producers in a cost sense is not correct. We ask in that respect that there be more consultation before this eventually takes place on 30 June next year.

There are some problems in connection with the legislation. As I understand it, once the embargo goes, as from 1 July 1989 there will be two rates of tariff on sugar. Raw sugar will attract a tariff of 35 per cent and refined sugar 25 per cent. The European Economic Community (EEC), which produces refined raw sugar, is most likely to want to dump its products. To what extent will the 25 or 35 per cent tariff be applied because, above all others, the EEC will be trying to get its sugar into Australia to take advantage of the situation? How effective will be the anti-dumping procedures that we debated this week in the House? For instance, how do we determine a world price for a commodity such as sugar, particularly if it is in a raw state? I refer again to the EEC example.

The last matter I raise refers to the preference given to developing nations. Is this to apply to the tariff rate? In other words, will developing nations get a benefit? I will give the House a possible scenario. Cuba, which is a major producer of sugar and which has been frozen out of the European markets, might find an advantage, with that preference, in putting it on the Australian market. I would like the Minister to answer the two questions I have raised. In the absence of an embargo, how will the tariff be applied to the raw sugar from the EEC? To what extent will the preference to developing nations be applied as far as sugar coming into Australia is concerned? The Opposition does not oppose this legislation. Because time is short I give the floor to the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cunningham Mr B.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Customs Tariff (Rate Alteration) Bill. The Bill seeks to introduce alterations to rates of duty imposed by the Customs Tariff Act 1987. I do not intend to take up much of the House's time. Because the Opposition spokesman, the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite), asked the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) to answer some concerns the Opposition has about this legislation, I will shorten my remarks and, with the cooperation of the next speaker, the Minister may have time to answer those concerns.

SPEECH.PARA: The changes before the House do not affect tariff arrangements in some of the industries where we have plans in operation. In the motor vehicle industry we have recently announced substantially reduced protection. The textiles, clothing and footwear industries are also the subject of separate arrangements which the Government announced last night. The changes will not apply to the chemicals and plastics industry, where tariffs are already phasing to 15 per cent or less.

There has been a fair amount of publicity relating to the changes, so I would like to cover the impacts that may occur and the directions the Government will be taking in relation to structural changes in general, of which the tariff arrangements are only part. With the changes that have been occurring in the economy over the last couple of years, it is not only tariff changes that are acting upon employment and labor market adjustments; there has also been technological change. In Australia there has been stagnation over many years. Many of our industrial areas developed in the late 1950s, after the Second World War. They have run their course for 30 years and much of the technology is out of date. We have also seen massive changes with company takeovers. New management has taken over many of the industries in Australia. This is all to the good because at this time we need to adjust quickly. It is a pity that perhaps we are trying to put 30 years of steady adjustment into place in two or three years. That is a much tougher task than to change as we go along. That is a problem that has developed because we have been working behind a tariff protected barrier for so many years. We have not looked to the world markets, but the day has arrived when industry must adjust and adjust quickly.

We have developed a policy to quicken the pace of industry restructuring, which will produce an economy that can compete on the world scene and broaden our export base. We also have to take into consideration what will happen with these changes. For the vast majority of workers, the changes will provide opportunities to increase their skills, take part in more rewarding careers and enrich their job experience. However, in a small number of cases workers in some declining industries may have to change their jobs, not necessarily because of tariffs alone but because of what is occurring naturally in the economy after so many years of stagnation. The magnitude of that labour displacement is expected to be small in relation to the growth of new jobs and the positions vacated through normal labour turnover.

About 500,000 jobs a year are filled by people moving from one broad industry sector to another and about 200,000 net new jobs have been generated each year on average since this Government came to office. Nevertheless, the Government recognises that some people will need to retrain and possibly move home to obtain a new job. Programs and services to assist this process of change and to cushion the effects of any disruption have been available through the Department of Employment, Education and Training for a number of years. However, the Government is now establishing an Office of Labour Market Adjustment within the Department of Employment, Education and Training to focus more effectively these assistance measures on those displaced by structural change. The office will be responsible for monitoring structural change processess and their local labour market implications and for the development and administration of policies for labour adjustment assistance. In this way, it will be able to anticipate the assistance needed within particular industries and regions and be ready to put in place assistance packages at the appropriate time.

These packages will be drawn from the existing range of programs which have proved successful in the past. However, emphasis will be placed on tailoring the assistance to the particular needs of displaced workers, taking into account their work experience, educational skill levels as well as labour market conditions and prospects in their region and industry. These programs will be supplemented by other action if necessary. A flexible use of retraining and relocation and wage subsidy programs should ensure the quick and successful reintegration into employment of displaced workers. Similar measures have already worked in a number of regions and industries such as the New South Wales coal industry, where much work still needs to be done, heavy engineering, and the textile, clothing and footwear industries. The Office of Labour Market Adjustment will keep forms of adjustment assistance under review to ensure the continuing effectiveness of programs and methods of delivery. If required, additional forms of assistance will be provided. Assistance will be delivered through the Commonwealth Employment Service (CES), technical and further education (TAFE) colleges and other providers as appropriate.

The office will have a significant liaison role with employer and employee bodies, individual firms and industries affected at the national, regional and local levels,with existing structural adjustment authorities and other relevant Commonwealth and State Government bodies. Also at the local level there will be a job for Federal members of parliament in relation to the structural changes taking place. I know of several programs that have now developed in different parts of Australia where we have local task forces in place. I have one in my area-the La Trobe Valley area of Victoria. I know of one in Gladstone, where our new member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice) has a very good program in operation. There is one in the Port Kembla area in which the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin) and the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) are vitally involved. I am sure that other members are also starting to take an active interest in developing local programs whereby they tap into those resources that are available to the local community.

I am working with the executive officers of some nine organisations in my area, which include the CES, the Department of Social Security, the TAFE college, the college of advanced education, the executive officers of local government, and trade union representatives. We are able to use the facilities at the local level, the data that is available; we have discussions with the companies involved, at both the national level and the subsidiary level, in our regions; and we can monitor the positive and negative aspects of structural change as it takes place. I think we will see a lot more of this develop, particularly now that we are putting in place this Office of Labour Market Adjustment. The Government will be providing the sort of support that is required to put into operation a program in which the total community will be involved at a very active level.

Members of parliament, along with the executive officers of a lot of these organisations that we already have in place, can pull together the data at the local level and make good use of it on behalf of their people. The changes are taking place and will continue to take place, and we cannot ignore that. I am very happy to know that in my area the trade union movement is involved, that our local government is involved, that our colleges of training are involved, and that the companies themselves are now starting to say, `This is something that needs to be looked at. We do have to give perhaps a year's warning if it is possible but at least six months warning of structural change'.

This is happening all over the world; it is not just an Australian phenomenon. It is something that I think both sides of the House should take a particular interest in, because we all represent people and we all represent workers. It is something in respect of which we have an obligation. The Government has given the lead. There is no doubt that, as a total package, the tariff and structural economic changes that we are making will provide a better Australia in the future, and I am sure we can all participate. I commend the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business, who is at the table, for the work that he is doing in this area. I will close my remarks on that note and ask the next speaker also to be brief so that the Minister can reply to the questions that have been asked of him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In what will probably be my last speech to a Bill in this chamber, I am delighted to be speaking about lowering tariffs, because I largely attribute my win in my original preselection to the work I had done in this area. Even in my maiden speech, I called for a reduction in tariffs due to the devaluation that was starting to take place in this country. I am pleased that the Government is going in this direction. In fact, there are many elements in the Customs Tariff (Rate Alteration) Bill that very much parallel what the National Party of Australia proposed in its policy in this area in the last election campaign. I am delighted that that is the case. This is a Bill of major importance and it is a shame that we have only a ridiculously short time to debate it. In many aspects it is probably the best thing that came out of the mini-Budget. Many other areas of it were, quite frankly, a fraud, but this is a desirable move.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the main elements of the Bill which I would like to discuss is the measure to remove the 2 per cent import duty on all goods, which I see the Government lists as a $240m cost to it. I think the paper work in this area-the administrative costs, the calculations, et cetera-probably led the Government in the end to decide that it was not worth a candle to it or to industry. I think this is a move in the right direction and I congratulate the Government on that particular aspect of the Bill. It has also laid down that goods with import duties over 15 per cent will have their duties reduced to the 15 per cent level in progressive stages between 1 July this year and 1 July 1992. Another element is the provision whereby duty rates of between 10 and 15 per cent will be reduced in progressive steps to a level of 10 per cent. The cost to revenue of all this will be $460m in the next financial year, rising to a cost of $900m in the financial year 1992-93.

There are some disappointments in the Bill in that all the big ticket items seem to be exempted. I realise that many of these are covered by other programs and that their tariffs are being reduced. But protection for the textiles, clothing and footwear industry, for example, which is now about 205 per cent, in 1992 will be down to only the 55 to 60 per cent level. So the present plan in that area will largely be adhered to, and I think that plan is far too slow. The passenger motor vehicle protection levels are coming down, but they are still too high and they will be high at the end of the program. We are told that tariffs for the chemical and plastics industries are already coming down by about one per cent a year. That is a very small reduction.

Chemical protection levels are, of course, very important to agriculture, which has been asked to bear a disproportionate amount of the cuts in last night's mini-Budget. Agricultural protection, is very much less than manufacturing protection, by a ratio of, at the most, 1 : 2; and in some years agricultural protection has been only one-tenth of the protection manufacturing receives. Agriculture is one of the real wealth producers in this country, particularly in earning export income. One of the tables I have before me indicates that protection for vegetable products is to come down from 40 per cent to 10 per cent over that time span. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard three short tables listing existing protection level rates, the rates that will apply in 1992 and the revenue implications for the Government.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. Of course, the cuts, when they are made, will lower prices and will therefore have a beneficial effect in lowering inflation. Labour and capital will shift slowly and progressively from inefficient industries to more efficient industries. That will tend to lower the exchange rate, it will increase trade between Australia and other countries and it will increase the standard of living both here and overseas. I know jobs are a worry to some but, overall, jobs will be created. Some jobs will be lost in the short term, but I do not believe we should concentrate on that because jobs will be gained in better areas. In fact, jobs will tend to shift from one industry to another, from one occupation to another and from one region to another around Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe the proposals in this Bill are quite mild. Let us not forget that most industries have tariff rates of less than 20 per cent, so the cuts for most industries in Australia will be of the order of less than one per cent a year. No doubt there will be some resistance to these cuts from those who still do not understand the tariff debate. However, nowadays most people on both sides of the chamber acknowledge that cuts are necessary. In summary, I would say that the cuts do not go far enough, that there are too many exemptions and they have come too late. Had they been implemented back in 1983 we would have had the benefits of them now, especially with the devaluation that has taken place since that time. It is as if the train we should have caught has left the station and we are now to catch a later and slower train. In that regard, let us hope there is some truth in the old saying `Better late than never'.
