DEBATE.TITLE: COMMONWEALTH AUTHORITIES LEGISLATION (PAY-ROLL TAX) AMENDMENT BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 25 May, on motion by Mr Peter Morris:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question certainly is that the Bill be now read a second time, but how curtailed is the second reading debate to be by the constraints on democratic discussion in this Parliament introduced by an autocratic government that has as its finance spokesman a man who walked into the House this afternoon and said he was born to rule? Extraordinary stuff. That complements the approach that the Government collectively takes to stifling discussion on issues that the House has before it today. The Bill we `debate' now is the Commonwealth Authorities Legislation (Pay-Roll Tax) Amendment Bill. The coalition parties will not be opposing it. The purpose of the legislation is to give effect to a decision that from 1 July 1988 Commonwealth Government business enterprises currently exempted from State and Territory payroll taxes should be liable for such taxes.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition supports the principle behind this move, namely, that such enterprises should be subject to taxation on the same basis as private business. But there is an additional motive that has pushed the Government into taking this step, and that is that the annual payroll tax liability of the authorities concerned is estimated at approximately $220m. In recognition of this increase in revenue to the States, the Commonwealth's payments to the States for the year will be reduced. The Government is simply trying to push over to the States, and therefore off its own Budget, millions of dollars which will still be paid by taxpayers through increased charges of these authorities. The Minister for Transport and Communications Support (Mr Peter Morris) said in his second reading speech that this reduction will not be by the full amount but by approximately 90 per cent of the total amount of payroll tax involved, and this should amount to just under $200m.

The Government sounds as if it is being generous to the States but, believe me, it is doing them no favours at all. This decision of course came out of the Premiers Conference earlier this month. It was part of a package of spending cuts to the States of $650m. That was a real reduction of 4.2 per cent, infinitely more than any real reductions in expenditure handed down by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in his statement last night. I can recall the Treasurer making pious noises at the Premiers Conference about the continued need for fiscal restraint. He said that the States had to pull their weight and take a share in the burden of restraint. I do not disagree with that. But last night's statement showed the hypocrisy of the Treasurer and his Government. Of the total estimated outlay reductions of $982m for the financial year 1988-89, nearly 90 per cent is accounted for by general purpose payments to the States. The Commonwealth is contributing only $112m in spending cuts. To be more accurate, some of that $112m in cuts appears to be made up of reductions in specific purpose payments to the States.

So again the States are dragged in on what is allegedly a form of Commonwealth restraint. The Treasurer has simply wimped out. His prime ministerial ambitions are clearly worrying him. The Government is patently unwilling to bear its share of the burden of restraint. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer smoothly talk about tougher times and the need for the States and individual Australians to tighten their belts but they will not do the same themselves. It is the easiest thing in the world to talk about how tough it is and how we have to show restraint but that is said on the principle of do as I say but not as I do, for they will not do the same thing themselves. As Mr Cain, the Labor Premier in Victoria, said a couple of weeks ago, this Government has tax revenue sloshing around its armpits, and from that comes the Treasurer's Budget surplus. I debated with him on television last night how successful the Government has been with the surplus it has achieved. The surplus has been achieved by taking more and more revenue from Australians under the regime of the highest taxing, biggest spending government in Australia's history. The surplus arises from all the revenue that is flowing in and not by getting Australia's house in order and contracting the Commonwealth's expenditure items.

It is false also to suggest that the need for a surplus precludes personal income tax cuts. Last night the Treasurer said we must have a surplus and to have a surplus we cannot give income tax cuts. That is patently false. He knows that the Government could have that surplus by cutting its expenditure, and it could have that surplus by cutting that expenditure and giving tax cuts. The Opposition certainly is not arguing about the need for a surplus. We need it to try to eradicate so much of the debt, and we need it in a macro sense so that we can run the economy properly in view of the state of economies in various States. To say that a surplus precludes income tax cuts ignores the reality that we fund those tax cuts by cutting government expenditure and still having a surplus. If the economy is actually overheating, as the Treasurer claims, tax cuts funded by spending cuts certainly cannot aggravate that situation.

The Treasurer has delivered the possibility of future personal income tax cuts but he has delivered them into the hands of the trade union leaders. I am not even sure that we will get the income tax cuts. Why? Because this Government does not have a wages policy. The Treasurer says that if he can work out an arrangement where the wage-tax outcome is all right, we might get spending cuts. So it is Crean and others-the trade union leadership-who will determine whether the Australian people, now suffering under the greatest weight of tax ever imposed by a government, will have their tax cuts come through because the Government has not the capacity, the wit or the courage to formulate a wages policy which would be predicated on real wage increases related to increases in productivity. Last night the Treasurer said:
The Government is prepared to give substantial tax cuts provided there is an acceptable wages outcome in 1988-89 and an appropriate wages/tax trade-off in 1989-90.
The Government will stress this point in its discussions with the Australian Council of Trade Unions over the next 12 months.

So much for the democratic analysis and formulation of policy. It is taken out of the Government's hands and put into the hands of Simon Crean and the boys. Yet again they are deciding government policy. The corporatist element of big government, big unions and big business has never shone so brightly as it does in the Treasurer's attitude to income tax cuts determined primarily by the deal he can do with the Australian Council of Trade Unions. It accounts for the Government's inability to make any coherent decision in another important area, that is, the issue of privatisation.

The Bill before the House seeks to make the Government's business authorities more aware of the commercial realities. Like private businesses, they will now have to pay payroll taxes. The big issue, when looking at the question of making public sector enterprises more commercially aware, is whether to privatise them. All the Government is doing at the present moment is freeing up some of these enterprises. I welcome the fact that under Labor's big government dogma the Government makes management and the like more flexible and able to run its own affairs. But it is still the taxpayers' money that is funding it.

What special purpose is there? What special purpose is served? What social role is dispensed by a government owning two airlines, a bank and a merchant bank? While ownership in these cases continues to rest with the government, they will never be subject to the efficiency demands that full commercial realities require.

Five enterprises are mentioned in the Bill. The coalition parties are already looking at the consumer and taxpayer benefits of selling part of the operations of Australian National Railways and the Federal Airports Corporation-of a whole schedule of entities that we have indicated to the Australian people we will privatise. Two of those mentioned in this Bill are also under review. We are reviewing, for example, whether or not to put the operation of airport terminals into private hands. The relevant micro-economic reforms that are needed in this country have to extend to an examination of some of the functions of two others that are mentioned in the Bill-Telecom Australia and Australia Post.

Telecom's first-phone monopoly has to be broken down. The Government's decision to retain the key telecommunications function under Telecom's monopoly control will mean that ordinary Australians will continue to be forced to pay higher telephone charges than necessary. Telecom and Australia Post can no longer absorb the continuing costs imposed on them by government. However, rather than providing genuine reform, the Government appears to be treating the various government business enterprises as milking cows for higher tax collection. That is the nub of the Bill we are currently debating. I understand that Telecom and Australia Post have already announced that they expect to raise postal and telephone charges as an inevitable result of the decisions of the Premiers Conference. The Government's micro-economic reforms have a very long way to go.

No mention was made last night by the Treasurer of the need to address the rampant inefficiencies in the area of coastal shipping. No mention was made of that one key area in vital need of reform; namely, that of the labour market. The Opposition has a coherent policy approach to labour market deregulation. Principally, we oppose the Government's corporatist approach to create big unions. We support the concept of enterprise-based unions, a system that allows workers to deal directly with their employers, to their mutual benefit. The number of unions should not be decided by the will of the Government. There should be as many as the labour market demands for its efficient operation. However, the Government cannot offer the necessary reform in this and so many areas because it is hamstrung by its union affiliations.

The Australian Labor Party often claims that its members comprise the party that represents the poor and the needy. Last night's statement, with its lack of personal tax relief, confirms the historical fact that the Australian Labor Party does not represent the poor; it merely represents the trade union bosses-that organisation from which the Labor Party had is germination; the political arm of the labour movement. The Government, in regard to this Bill, and with that in mind, has simply wasted yet another opportunity. While I admit-and I noted the concluding remarks of the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) on the Customs Tariff (Rate Alteration) Bill-that the Government has gone some way along the path to reform, the necessary reforms to address Australia's foreign debt problems, huge as they are and quadrupled as they have done under this Government, are nowhere near enough. The scope is there to offer much more to help Australians by giving them personal tax relief. In that way they will be encouraged to work and to invest more. As I have said, the coalition does not oppose the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had no idea that this legislation was so comprehensive.

—The Chair might intervene, by virtue of that remark, and say that the Chair was fully conscious of the fact that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, in the course of his remarks, was overtaxing relevance. I call the honourable member for Charlton.

—I was impressed by the extent to which the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), was able to apply the essentially fairly simple principles of this legislation to a whole variety of other concerns. I suppose there was a need for him to use up the time in some way, but I accept that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition canvassed a number of important issues.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to respond to a couple of matters raised by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. He claimed that this Government was the highest taxing government in the Commonwealth's history. I suppose he was referring to the fact that, during the five years that this Government has been in power, total taxation revenue has increased. It has increased very substantially. I emphasise to the Australian people that they should be very grateful that it has. There are two important aspects of that increase. The first is associated with the enormous growth which has taken place in employment. We now have in excess of one million more people in employment-earning incomes and paying tax-than when we came into government. So why should the tax revenue not be higher? Those people-in excess of one million-are delighted that they are paying tax. They are paying tax because this Government has provided them with that fundamentally important personal dignity, the right to be able to be employed and to earn an income and the right and the opportunity to contribute to national revenue and all of those great national purposes that all Federal governments have a responsibility to pursue.

The second aspect of that increase in taxation revenue is that, on successive occasions during that period, this Government has reduced, more substantially than any government in the history of this Commonwealth, the marginal rates of taxation. We know that for the high-fliers the top marginal tax rate when we came into government was 60 per cent. Out of every extra dollar that the people whom the Opposition purports to represent earned, the previous Government ripped 60c off them. We have reduced the top marginal tax rate to 49c. Mr Deputy Speaker, as you know, just last night the Treasurer (Mr Keating) announced that company taxation would be reduced from 49c to 39c. We know what that augurs for personal taxation. It must come down: otherwise, we will have a whole range of artificial private, personal incorporations so that people can take advantage of a company tax rate which is lower than the personal tax rate. That was indicated to the Australian people last night.

What we will do now is follow up those very significant adjustments in previous marginal tax rates by additional adjustments that will reduce the tax burden on Australians very substantially. Why will it be possible for us to do that? Fundamentally we are able to do that because of the very significant improvement that we have been able to bring about in general economic performance. As you know, Mr Deputy Speaker, this Government's economic management has been nothing short of magnificent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! That may well be the case, but it would be enormously helpful to the Chair if the honourable member would mention the Bill now and again.

—I appreciate your intervention, Mr Deputy Speaker, because I was just about to link all my remarks to the Commonwealth Authorities Legislation (Pay-roll Tax) Amendment Bill. It is important, because the Deputy Leader of the Opposition drew attention to the fact that the legislation was also linked to the general question of privatisation. I do not resile or retreat from or apologise for the very strong belief that I have in the important role that the public sector necessarily plays in the type of mixed economy in which we live. Different honourable members have mentioned that this is possibly the last occasion on which they will be able to contribute to debate in this provisional Parliament House. That is probably the case for me as well. I am not disappointed by that fact, as it gives me the opportunity to make some observations about public enterprises.

SPEECH.PARA: We know that this legislation now provides the right for State governments to impose payroll taxes on some Commonwealth public enterprises. I do not know whether section 114 of the Constitution has significantly been tested or whether it has yet been resolved that that section relates as well to taxes being imposed on payrolls as it relates to Commonwealth and State properties. Of course, that particular section of the Constitution makes it clear that neither the Commonwealth nor the States can impose taxation on property which is held by the other. The extent of that section of the Constitution has been a matter of some controversy for some time, but the Commonwealth is indicating that, if we are going to have public enterprises-and I support their role and their concept-they have to stand on their own feet. They have to be commercially competitive; they have to be commercially efficient; they have got to be subject to exactly the same types of constraints, exactly the same types of requirements, and exactly the same types of obligations as private sector enterprises are.

I have no doubt that, given the opportunity and being subjected to the same types of constraints and the same types of obligations as private sector enterprises, our great public enterprises will perform just as adequately. In fact, they have done so, and the Australian people can be very proud of the fact that they are joint shareholders in some of the greatest public enterprises anywhere in the world. I need only refer, for example, to Qantas Airways Ltd, an airline of international standing and reputation. Qantas belongs to every Australian, as do Australian Airlines, the Australian National Railways, the Civil Aviation Authority, the Federal Airports Corporation, Australia Post and Telecom Australia-those public enterprises to which this legislation specifically and clearly relates.

The Deputy Leader of the Opposition also drew attention to the fact that the annual payroll tax liability of the authorities concerned is estimated at about $220m-very substantial. As a result of that, we are now providing the opportunity for State governments to impose the payroll tax to collect the $220m. It is not unreasonable at all that we should then say to the States, `Since you are getting this additional $220m, it is appropriate that we should reduce any additional grants that are going to you'. It is not unreasonable, and that is precisely what we propose to do; but we are not saying to them that the Commonwealth is going to reduce their funding by $220m. It is significantly less than that. In fact, the States, as a result of this total exercise, will be better off because of the performance of some of these enterprises and where they are centred.

TALK.START.PARA: —Particularly New South Wales.
—Particularly New South Wales, as the Minister indicates.
—Qantas.

—And Qantas, of course. A very substantial proportion of the payroll tax from those authorities will be generated in New South Wales. We have been very generous to the new Premier in New South Wales. No-one can assume that this Government adopts a political attitude to any of the States. We are more than generous. I am pleased to see that there are members in the chamber who nod their heads in assent.

SPEECH.PARA: I have said that it is necessary for public enterprises to show their worth. They are capable of doing it. If we ensure that they are subject to the same types of commercial pressures, the same managerial obligations and the same financial obligations, we will find that the efficiency and the effectiveness of public sector enterprises will match that of any enterprises anywhere. Some of the big private enterprises were moribund. They had been featherbedded because the management had been so cushioned by a significant structure of protection that had been placed around them by successive governments that they had become very tired and very inefficient and were not able to compete against imports. But now, as a result of a number of substantial and structural changes that have been introduced to the Australian economy by this Government, they are all starting to perform, whether they are within the private sector or the public sector. And the Australian people can feel a great deal of pride in the fact that the Australian industrial sector generally, whether it is private or public, is now starting to measure up.

The restructuring process is under way. It will continue with this Government, and the great achievements that this Government has been able to make in the area of general economic management and in the area of fiscal responsibility will extend right through the economy, and not only will the benefits be available to men and women throughout Australia and Australian families today, but also they will be continuing benefits which will substantially increase, time and time again, well into the future, all of those benefits, all of the changes. They are substantial and deliberate and they will be successful. The final beneficiaries will be the more than 16 million Australians who look forward to the opportunities for themselves and their families that this country can provide.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beale Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the four minutes that remain before debate on the Commonwealth Authorities Legislation (Pay-roll Tax) Amendment Bill is gagged, I would like to say a few words about what I regard as a rather ominous trend that is developing in the way in which the government is approaching what it does with its Government business enterprises. As the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) said, this legislation simply involves a transfer of taxes from the Federal arena to the States; a transfer, in this case, of around $200m. The taxes that are levied by the States as payroll taxes will have to be recovered by those statutory authorities and they will, of course, be recovered by additional charges on the very Australians that the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) has been talking about. The people whom he said at the end of his speech he wants to protect will have to pay more.

SPEECH.PARA: I mentioned the trend because I think that is important. I want to refer to the Government's guidelines on government business enterprise reform, and particularly, so far as Telecom Australia is concerned, to page 7 of the confidential attachment to the letter that the Minister for Transport and Communincations (Senator Gareth Evans) presumably has written to the Chairman of Telecom, which says that Telecom will be made liable to pay State payroll tax from 1 July 1988-the matter that we have been discussing tonight. In addition to that, local government taxes, rates and charges will be applicable from 1 July 1989. That will mean more increases to the people to whom the honourable member for Charlton referred. Telecom's exemption from Commonwealth income tax will be removed from 1 July 1990.

So we have here a sort of off-Budget fiddle as the Government causes charges to be increased to those people to whom the honourable member for Charlton referred. Another matter is that the Government is requiring that these Government business enterprises revalue their assets. I refer specifically to page 3 of the confidential guidelines for the Australian National Railways which state that the Board will ensure that revaluation of the railways assets in accordance with prevailing commercial practice takes place. What has happened with the Civil Aviation Authority and the Federal Airports Corporation-and it is what will happen here with all of the other enterprises that are named in the Bill-is that the Government is causing a revaluation of assets. Against the revalued assets, the Government will discuss with the Authority what it wants to do about dividends. That means that the Government will cause these authorities to increase the value of their assets. Once they have done that, the Government will talk about dividends which will require a commercial rate of return-and the honourable member for Charlton talked about commercial rates of return-and that will mean that these enterprises will be forced to pay out more funds; and that means that charges will be increased even further.

We are seeing with this Bill and with everything else that has been foreshadowed in these confidential attachments to letters that have been written to the Government business enterprises the very beginning of a dubious and doubtful plan to increase the amount that those businesses will charge to the ordinary, average Australians who will be hurt so badly by what the Government is doing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, last night's economic statement is not the radical reforming document so boastfully claimed by the Treasurer (Mr Keating). It does not contain the clear economic goals to take this nation into the 1990s. Rather, it is the product of an arrogant Treasurer and an out of touch Prime Minister, both of whom are blissfully unaware of the real financial burdens being carried by the overwhelming majority of Australian families.

SPEECH.PARA: Two words were missing from last night's speech-`productivity' and `family'-and their omission symbolises the warped priorities of this Government. Our response to this statement will be based upon our clear national economic goals, and those goals are to provide the incentive for greater productivity, which is the only path to rising living standards. Without greater productivity there can be no return to higher living standards, there can be no stabilisation, and there can be no reduction in the massive overseas debt of this nation.

Last night's statement did contain a number of decisions which the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia support. In the main they have been proposals we have recommended over the years, which the Government has derided and has finally seen the wisdom of embracing. The Treasurer's failure to refer to productivity is hardly surprising because over the last five years it has become a skeleton in Labor's cupboard. It has fallen sharply-so much so that we are faring badly on the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development productivity table. We must ask ourselves in every facet of economic activity whether we can as a people use our physical, human and financial resources more efficiently, because that is what higher productivity is all about. The answer to that is yes, we can, provided we give people the incentive to use those resources more efficiently.

That is why we support lower taxes paid for by lower spending. That is why we support reform to our labour market. That is why we support reduced business regulation and charges. That is why we support privatisation, which gives to the Australian people direct ownership of the great national enterprises of this country and gives to Australian consumers greater choice. That is why we support freeing up the transport infrastructure of this country. That is why we support a dramatic shift in the migration program of this country towards a larger intake based on a greater skills component. They are the criteria against which the Opposition will judge the economic statement delivered by the Treasurer last night.

Before doing that, let us not forget a few facts of economic and social life in Australia. Let us not forget that in the last five years Australia had become a less fair, more unequal society. Let us not forget the policy U-turns of this Labor Government. From 1983 to 1985 credit was claimed for everything good that happened, and then all of a sudden, as the tide turned, it all became the fault of the foreigners and former governments. Until May 1986 we had never had it so good. `Set your sails for growth' was the clarion call of the Treasurer. Then we had the banana republic statement, and almost overnight $9 billion, he said, had been cut from our national income. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) likened it to wartime, and we went into the economic trenches. The reality is that in that five-year period our foreign debt has soared to $110 billion. In March 1983, when the Labor Government came to power, 26.5c of every export dollar was needed to service our overseas debt. That figure has now climbed to a staggering 64c in the dollar.

The great majority of ordinary middle income earners have gone backwards under this Government. A family on average weekly earnings with a dependent spouse and two children needs more than $40 a week to restore its real disposable income to March 1983 levels. Those families now face a tax rate of 40 per cent on every additional $1 of income compared with 30 per cent five years ago. If earnings grow by 6 per cent to 7 per cent this financial year, a person on average income in the next 13 months will pay $13 a week more in personal tax.

Family health insurance premiums have doubled under the Hawke Government. Home loan repayments now average $606 a month, and they take a record 27.4 per cent of median family income. The figure in March 1983 was 19.2 per cent. Family allowances have fallen by 41 per cent, and over 2.6 million people, of whom 20 per cent are children, now live below the poverty line. That is 600,000 more than in March 1983.

It is against the background of our national economic goals and Labor's failure that I comment on some of the details of this statement. Reductions in government spending, lower corporate tax, lower personal tax rates, reductions in industry assistance, greater commercial freedom for government business enterprises and the changes to the monopoly powers of Telecom Australia have long been advocated. It is clear, however, that the measures announced by the Government do not go nearly far enough. Moreover, in spite of all the self-congratulation and all the hype, the expenditure cuts in this statement are wimpish, and the lion's share has been carried by the States. In net terms this May statement cuts $982m off the Forward Estimates. Of that, the States have contributed no less than $870m.

The forecasts for growth and inflation are extremely optimistic, in particular, it is questionable whether the inflation figure will be down to the 4.5 per cent forecast by the Treasurer in the June quarter 1989. The Treasurer proudly boasts of a surplus of over $3 billion in 1988-89 and says that Australia will be repaying some of the debts. That is welcome, but most of that debt has been incurred under the stewardship of the current Treasurer. We all know where the surplus is coming from. It is coming from the average taxpayer. The Treasurer can rely on booming revenues to produce that surplus. It is a taxing surplus, not an axing surplus. The Treasurer uses personal tax cuts as the carrot for a new wages deal with the unions. If Simon Crean says so, average Australians may get a tax cut in 1989-90. The company tax cut is most welcome. We put forward a similar proposal last year and were criticised as economic vandals. Today the tax cut is presented as a stroke of economic genius.

The superannuation changes are a mixed bag. We welcome the higher rates of deductions for the self-employed and the small business people. More broadly, the Treasurer has sought to trade off higher taxes on superannuation now against lower taxes on future payouts. This has allowed him access to a large pool of household savings which he is in effect passing on to the business sector. He says that the final benefits will be reduced. The Opposition, the superannuation industry and many others are still studying the fine details of the Treasurer's changes in that area and, judging by the answers given in Question Time today, even the Treasurer is still studying the fine detail in that area.

We reject entirely the Treasurer's specious claim that now is not an appropriate time for tax cuts because the economy is overheating. The real motive behind the Treasurer's argument is to make sure that any tax cuts are as close as possible to the next election. By the time Labor's personal tax cuts come along, the Government will have taken up to $3 billion from ordinary Australians through bracket creep. It will just be handing back to Australians what it has ripped off them over the preceding couple of years. The Treasurer's argument about overheating is a red herring.

The Liberal and National parties remain committed to a substantial reduction in the overall taxation burden. We will provide a flatter tax system with two steps in order to provide incentive to people to work harder and to exercise greater enterprise and initiative, and we will give priority to assisting families with children. Our proposals will particularly help lower and middle income families whose ability to support children has been savaged by this Government.

We will not be introducing a broad-based consumption tax, but reform and rationalisation of the existing ramshackle indirect tax system is long overdue. For example, what is the logic in taxing fruit juice and chocolate milk but not $1,000 ball gowns or pornographic videos? We want in government the flexibility to address such anomalies and inequities. We will abolish Labor's capital gains tax, which discourages longer term savings and investment. However, shorter term gains will be taxable on a sliding scale over five years. After five years there will be no tax of any kind on gains. The current exemptions will apply, including exclusion of the family home, and we will tax only real capital gains. Our tax on shorter term gains will encourage investors who buy significant assets to produce a cash flow rather than those who shuffle paper for short term speculative gains.

We will abolish Labor's fringe benefits tax, but we will not countenance fringe benefits involving tax avoidance and, where a non-tax benefit is clearly and deliberately provided as a substitute for cash remuneration, that benefit will be taxed as income in the hands of the recipient. We will not tax non-cash benefits which are provided to enable employees to discharge their duties. These principles form the basis of a genuine process of taxation reform.

Yesterday's statement indicates the lack of stomach in the present Government for long term micro-economic reform. Remember the Government's hostile response to the Industries Assistance Commission report on coastal shipping? That report clearly and objectively documented the massive inefficiencies in our coastal shipping industry-inefficiencies which greatly inflate transport costs and product diversification. Today it costs $30 a tonne to ship phosphate rock from Christmas Island to Australia, while phosphate rock shipped here from Florida costs only $16 a tonne and the same phosphate rock can be carried to New Zealand in third country ships for about $10 a tonne. That is a sham that the Treasurer and other Ministers in this Government will do nothing about. We will implement essential services legislation in this area and other aspects of our industrial relations policy in order to reduce union abuses and to encourage greater productivity on the waterfront. We will encourage greater competition in liner shipping, privatise the Australian National Line and encourage the States to adopt more efficient forms of port ownership and management.

We welcome the tariff reductions announced by the Treasurer last night. They go in the right direction. However, they are not as large as they might be and they should have been brought in earlier. They will do little in themselves to improve industry efficiency.

Labor has adopted our policy, and we welcome that, in its decision to convert Telecom to a public corporation. This will give Telecom a more commercial orientation and free it of bureaucratic controls which impede decision making and flexibility. It is also Liberal National Party policy, but not Labor's, to reduce Telecom's monopoly powers by allowing competition in the provision of the first home telephone, small business systems, data transmission and information systems, value added services and maintenance functions. Labor's failure to deal now with Telecom's outrageous first telephone monopoly is a cowardly concession to the power of the Telecom unions. That first telephone monopoly imposes significant costs on Australian consumers. That monopoly costs consumers about $250m a year in extra and completely avoidable costs.

In no area is fundamental economic reform more essential and more needed than in the area of our industrial relations system. That system needs fundamental restructuring. We need less trade union power, we need greater emphasis on enterprise based agreements and we need greater emphasis on productivity based wage increases. Almost everybody now accepts the need for labour market reform. Two years ago I and many others were excoriated as captives of the New Right for even raising that issue, but today most people realise that Labor's centralised trade union dominated system has failed.

It has failed to deliver internationally competitive wage outcomes. It has failed to deliver sustained productivity growth and investment. It has failed to deliver genuine cooperation between employees and employers. It has failed to deliver greater flexibility in work practices. It has entrenched and extended trade union power over our economic and social life, and it has undeniably entrenched an inflation rate which is double that of our major trading partners.

We support increases in real wages. However, those increases must be earned. Inflation linked wage rises quickly lead to higher prices and not higher real incomes. Only increased productivity will lead to increased real incomes. We will give greater freedom to employers and employees to reach mutually acceptable industrial arrangements. In particular, this will improve working opportunities for women, especially in the area of part time work.

Under our industrial relations policy we will introduce the following voluntary work agreements at the enterprise level: provision for small firms to opt out of the existing arbitration system; the principle and practice of voluntary unionism; a more comprehensive employee share ownership and profit sharing scheme; and, finally, infinitely more flexible awards. Our commitment to voluntary unionism is unequivocally based on our commitment to freedom of choice. Under our industrial relations policy we intend to bring trade unions fully within the laws of Australia. We will significantly strengthen the secret ballot provisions of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act, including the use of such ballots in the case of strike action.

Finally, we are committed to an industrial relations system which encourages employee share ownership. We welcome the Government's decision, however belated it may be, to move to a slight extent in this area, as announced by the Treasurer last night. I remind the House that six years ago, in the 1982 Budget, such a measure was proposed. It was rejected by the incoming Labor Government and has remained on the back burner for the past six years.

Privatisation, particularly in so far as it affects the internal politics of the Government, has been very much in the news in recent weeks. Privatisation is not an arid accounting exercise, despite the claims to that effect by many people on the front bench of the Government. It is an exciting opportunity for Australians to directly own some of our great national enterprises. It is a way of exposing government business operations to the winds of efficiency, competition and change. It will benefit the consumer; it represents no threat to the worker; and those who have most to gain from it are those employed in government enterprises, who will be encouraged under our policies to take up shares in the enterprise that employs them. The consequences of Labor's paralysis on privatisation are evident. Without privatisation, either the various enterprises urgently requiring capital injections-Qantas Airways Ltd, Australian Airlines and the Commonwealth Bank, which require $1 billion over the next few years-will bleed slowly to death because the Commonwealth cannot fund them, or other budgetary programs will have to be substantially scaled back.

The Liberal and National parties, unlike the Government, which is in total disarray on this issue, have a clear and comprehensive policy on privatisation. We believe that government business enterprises that tie up taxpayers' money in activities that the private sector can perform better should be privatised. Our decisions on privatisation will always be determined according to three basic principles. First, people must benefit from any privatisation. There must be consumer benefit, there must be improved competition, and it must be in the public interest. Secondly, the position and job security of existing employees will be given special consideration. We are committed to encouraging the sale of shares to employees on a preferential basis wherever possible in order to promote employee participation and hence productivity and industrial harmony. Thirdly, the quality and availability of services to remote areas will not be allowed to deteriorate. It has always been the view of the Liberal and National parties that Australians, wherever they might live, are entitled to certain basic services at a reasonable cost. These include telephones, mail services and certain transport facilities.

Our parties have already decided that Australian Airlines, Qantas, domestic and international airport terminals, the Australian Industry Development Corporation, 49 per cent of the Overseas Telecommunications Commission, Aussat Pty Ltd, the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation, the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation, Medibank Private, the Pipeline Authority and the Commonwealth Bank should be privatised. That represents a bold commitment to a program of involving the ordinary citizens of Australia in the direct ownership of our great national assets. It is fascinating how much objection to that concept is coming from the benches of the Australian Labor Party. There is no real alternative, given the voracious capital demands of these enterprises in the years ahead, to a sensible program of privatisation. The Liberal and National parties are committed to it; the Labor Party remains in total disarray on that issue.

Last night's statement, despite the self-congratulation, despite the hype, despite the smugness and despite the arrogance, did not pass the basic test of providing real economic leadership by the Government. It failed to state clear national economic goals. In contrast, the Liberal and National parties have an integrated, consistent set of economic policies to address Australia's economic problems and, through the incentives to greater productivity, over time to lay the basis of raising living standards. We used in this country to have an Australia in which anyone who worked hard was a hero. Under this Government, if one works hard one is penalised by higher taxes.

The message in last night's statement from the Government-if there is a message-is that perhaps we ought to go easy on the business community but we can go on picking the pocket of the average taxpayer for another 13 months. The message out of that statement is that that process of paying higher taxes if one works harder will go on for the next 13 months.

We used to have an Australia in which members of a family were bonded together and looked after each other. The family used to be the most important part of our social fabric. In recent years it has been put under enormous financial and social strain. Under this Government, families are under pressure, sectional interests are being pandered to and welfare has become a long term right rather than a short term assistance measure. We used to have a government with integrity and whose decisions were fair and seen to be fair. Under this Labor Government, big mates are looked after, and, unlike everyone else, the Treasurer does not have to get his tax return in on time.

Under this Labor Government, the health system is in a mess, trade union bosses are making policy decisions, bureaucrats are being given more and more personal information on individuals, Canberra is growing bigger and its power is getting greater. Only the Liberal and National parties offer Australians a vision and a program to create a fairer and more productive Australia into the 1990s and beyond.
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the House that Mr President, the Minister for Administrative Services and I have agreed that the commencement by proclamation of the major provisions of the Parliamentary Precincts Act 1988, particularly the provision which gives the Presiding Officers control of the new Parliament House, will occur on 1 August 1988. The Minister previously gave an undertaking to the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, as reported to the Senate, that the relevant provisions would come into operation no later than the first week of July 1988. It has been agreed, however, that 1 August would be a more convenient time, having regard to the activities of the Parliament House Construction Authority. The change of the day for the proclamation will not affect the operations of the two Houses in the new building.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a big night for John Elliott and a big night for the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock). They have been given the greatest opportunity that they will ever have to seize the leadership of the Liberal Party of Australia. I say to my colleagues who have been here since the last election that what we had tonight was simply a re-run of what we had at this time last year. It is always the same. At that time the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) sat the test and failed. Again tonight he has failed that test.
—Even the honourable member for O'Connor could do a better job.

—The honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) would certainly have an opinion and he may well do a better job. There are many expectations out there in the Australian community that policies will be thought through by the Opposition. Once again it has had the opportunity, and once again it has failed. The honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown), the honourable member for Brisbane (Mr Cross) and I have sat here for five years, waiting for the Opposition to produce this miracle formula, and it has not come. Tonight we had more pepper and salt policies. They are all over the place. There is no structure, there is no direction and there is no philosophy. Worst of all for the Robert Menzies party there is no vision. That is the real test.

SPEECH.PARA: There are people out there-earnest members of the Liberal Party; people who have voted for the Liberal Party for years-who must really wonder where this great Party of theirs has gone to. I can tell them where it has gone; it has gone down the path of opportunism, the quick fix and the search for the pushover try where one can win an election by accident. I have news for the Liberal Party: the game has changed. People want policies, people want performance, and we are not getting it from the Opposition. The prospect is that we will never get it from the Opposition. As my colleagues well understand, we will never see the hard work, the background work, the unspectacular efforts that are required.

To make an analogy with sport, there is no pushover try for the Opposition. It has to work the ball in the back line and do the hard stuff. It is not doing it. The thing that really staggers us is that it has had five years in which to put forward policies. It has had the opportunity. Tonight we heard the same dull, dry prescription that we heard before the July election last year, and we know the results. My colleagues here reflect very accurately that the reaction of honourable members on the back bench of the Liberal Party and the National Party of Australia was a clear indication of the way it was received tonight. Pepper and salt policies do not stir up the rank and file. They certainly did not stir them up here. If I were a Liberal tonight I would feel even more dismayed. It is like the day after one's team has lost the grand final. The Opposition has been beaten again. It knows it has been beaten again, and it has a long, long winter ahead. I have news for the Opposition: it does have a long winter ahead of it and it is a long time until the next election. It will have a long time in opposition.

Let us look constructively at the sort of test it has to pass. We asked: Where is the exchange rate policy from the Opposition? It did not have one when it was in government. The fact that it did not have one meant that we had a massively overvalued exchange rate the consequence of which was that the Australian export industry never took off but collapsed when the commodity price collapsed. That was one of the legacies. We have heard a little about an industrial relations policy. We have heard all about `opting out', but where is the Opposition's wages policy? We know what its ideological kneejerk reaction is. It is simple: kick workers, kick unions, suppress those who are worse off, and then it has an industrial relations policy. I have more news for the Leader of the Opposition and his cohorts: the Australian people will not wear that because they had a lot of that. Look at what happened in 1981 and 1982. Australia became the scene of industrial disputes. There were more strikes, more trouble than one could possibly imagine. That was because of failed policies. It became synonymous with industrial disputation.

We have reduced industrial disputation dramatically and people are back to work. The Opposition makes great play about families but when we talk to the ordinary people in this country we find that they have jobs. They have some certainty of getting work because there are few industrial disputes. Let us take this point even further. People have houses. When the Opposition was in government housing starts were 105,000, a 20-year low. We have got housing starts up to 155,000 now with a constructive housing policy that has put roofs over the heads of ordinary men and women and their children in Australia. I will take that theme further. We have provided child care arrangements that were certainly never provided by the previous Government. Child care was something it was not interested in.

We have also provided this country with some hope and vision. The trouble is the Opposition took the easy path. It would not crack down on tax avoiders. We all know that. That became the order of the day. The big growth industry was tax evasion. This May statement specifies 60 tax havens. The Opposition never followed up on those. It was not interested because that was where its mates went. That was where all the money was socked away-in tax havens. It was not prepared to make the tax system work and the ordinary Australians knew that. In 1983 they delivered a very harsh judgment on the previous Government. It let the tax system slip and slide into disrepair. Evasion became the order of the day. We have restored some respectability in the tax system.

What really interests many of us here tonight is that the same old story is being dredged up. The Opposition says, `Let's go back to the free lunches. Let's go back to the fringe benefits. We will make some changes but we will blur the tax laws a little so you cannot enforce them'. The Commissioner of Taxation in 1981-82 told the then Treasurer, the present Leader of the Opposition, `I want to enforce the tax law. Give me the resources and the political support so I can make the tax law work'-but no. Tonight, we have the same old prescription, `Let's blur the edges of tax law. Let it slip and slide into disrepute because we do not want those people who ought to be paying tax paying tax'.

I have news for the Opposition. We put equity back into the system. As a consequence of that we can face in the next couple of years a further round of personal tax cuts. That is the vision. There is a train running in this country. People get on that train and get jobs, get houses, get moving and they certainly get wage increases and tax cuts. The Opposition train stalled at the station. It happened in 1983 and it has done nothing to kick start it since. It has the same tired old formula. What worries us is that there is no sign of improvement. As I said, Mr Elliott must feel pleased tonight. Certainly the honourable member for Kooyong must feel pleased. The opening is there. He has the rails run, in sporting parlance. The Leader of the Opposition has drifted off the track further to the right. He has the same old material.

Opposition members all went up to Coolangatta. They did not want to take the media because they might have wanted to ask questions. So the media people were in trees trying to get photographs of them running on the beach. The Opposition says, `Let's not talk about policies; oh, no, don't worry about policies'. To use the phrase of a famous politician, they said, `Don't you worry about that. Don't you worry about those policies. We don't want you subjecting us to any tests or asking questions about our tax policy, or our wages policy. We don't want to have to answer those questions'. The trouble is that the sun got to Opposition members in Queensland. They did not come out of it with anything substantial and they have not done so tonight. We have the same tired old prescription.

Let me follow that up. When we look back, whether it be at the media policy which the Opposition has been skirting around here, at the tax policy-we are still not sure where it is headed-or at a wages policy which is only basically described as an opting out arrangement for people so they can destroy the industrial relations system, we see an opposition in the throes of trying to come to terms with the 1980s. The problem is all the props it relies on are back in the 1960s. The late great leader of the Liberal Party, Sir Robert Menzies, would wonder what sort of legacy he left. The Opposition has really made a mess of it.

People ask, `What have we got? What are the options? Let's have some vision'. There is no vision. On the other hand, let us look at our statement. There is vision. It is about taxes. There is clearly a vision on the corporate side with the reduction in company tax from 49c to 39c. A reduction in personal income tax is to come in next year. There certainly is a vision in how the Australian economy is going. We will cut costs in this economy because we are cutting tariffs. This is the sensible way of doing things. Let us talk to management. Let us talk to the trade unions, because we believe they are part of the Australian community. They are not lepers as the Opposition treats them. We believe that ordinary men and women in Australia should be talked to and not lectured, which seemed to be the characteristic of the Fraser years. We believe they have a stake in this country and we want to see that stake fulfilled. We follow that course. The sad part about the Opposition's position is that it wants to exclude people. People will not be excluded any more. They have had enough of those tired old prescriptions.

I want to take that point even further. The Opposition has made much noise about families. It has said that the Government is anti-family. It has thrown one or two cheap shots in. But as my colleagues will know, with the family assistance package last year ordinary families with four children could get up to $88 a week tax free under the family assistance package. I ask Opposition members to try talking to those people as I did last Christmas when all of a sudden they got money in the hand that they desperately needed. What a change that meant to them. Let us also talk about the families who have jobs, but who never had jobs before. When the Leader of the Opposition was Treasurer 1,000 jobs a week were lost. That was the prospect people had. They had no vision, no hope and no future.

TALK.START.PARA: —They would not face up to it.
—The Opposition would not face up to it, as my colleague says. Now people have vision because we are providing them with that vision.

SPEECH.PARA: The big change in this country in the last five years has been the establishment of a partnership. People are not excluded from the decision making process. People are not treated as second class citizens. We treat Australian managers and workers as though they have a stake in this country. The subject material of what was said in last night's statement tells management and employees that this country is on the move. It will be a more efficient economy. There are lower costs. There are lower pressures on people in the economy. We are providing incentives in terms of taxes and this economy is going places. We see ourselves as having a future.

It is a very sad indictment of the Liberal Party that the work has not been done. The vision is not there. The policies are not there. If honourable members talk to people over the weekend, as all of my colleagues in the Labor Government will do, they will certainly be told, `We know what the Government's position is, we have some questions about it, but what does the Opposition offer?'. The answer is that we do not know. It has pepper and salt policies. They are all over the place. They have no structure, no direction and no future. There is no clear structural direction in the Opposition's policies.

The Opposition is characterised as being the Opposition that nearly did things when it was in government. It nearly deregulated the financial system; it nearly floated the Australian dollar; it nearly restructured Australian industry; it nearly got the economy moving; it nearly got industrial relations working; and it nearly reformed the tax system, but it never won in any of those tests. Again tonight, as my colleagues will attest, it has not passed that test-and that is really a very sad indictment of it. We know what happened last year. We know that the National Party distorted the attempts at good policy making by the Liberal Party. That is all on the record.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is.

—As my colleague says, it is on the record. The casualties are to be seen in Queensland, in the divisions there. The thing that has to be said here is that honourable members opposite still have not come to terms with how they will work matters. We see this every week when a big issue comes up. Let us go back a couple of weeks to the media policy issue. There was a different media policy every half day. We still do not know what the Opposition's exchange rate policy is. We still do not know how the Opposition will face up to the industrial relations question.

SPEECH.PARA: It is very clear in this May statement that we have set out a vision. Look back at the reductions in outlays by this Government; look at the prospect of a $3 billion surplus; look at the prospects for personal income tax cuts coming through next year; look at the fact that we will be able, because we have a wages policy, to negotiate with the trade union movement to have wage rises and tax cuts phased in. All of those things are possible. These are the issues honourable members opposite would choose to reject. But I have news for the Opposition: the community will not reject them, because the community knows that we can provide this country with a vision, a direction and some energy.

I have to say that we have one of the most energetic, enterprising, enthusiastic countries in the world. We have some of the best people in the world. Our people have all this energy and enthusiasm. When honourable members opposite were in government they treated women as if they had no part to play; they treated workers as if they were their enemies; they treated the Aborigines as if they were beyond the pale, because that was the way they ruled. What happened in 1983 was that the judgment was delivered on them. Honourable members opposite still have not learned, and that is the sad part about it. We live in a very dynamic part of the world. The Asian region where we live is the fastest growing industrial area in the world. What we in this Government are saying is, `We have an industrial engine in this country. We know how to get it moving', and it is moving. We are giving it further incentive to move. We have a wonderful people in this country and we are prepared to work with them to achieve more for Australians as a whole.

The sad part about tonight-I am sure my colleagues share this view-is that there is no vision from the Opposition. There is no future; there is no hope; there are no policies. In fact, the Opposition has displayed a sad reworking of its past failures. We would have hoped that, before the move up to the new Parliament House, in this last sad try from the Opposition it might at least have put some score on the board. As honourable members opposite pack their cartons to move to the new Parliament House, the observation about many of them is that they are packing their cartons to move out of political life. If tonight's performance is anything to go by, that would be better for the Australian community. What I can say is that the test was there, the Opposition Leader has failed it, but there are further tests to be gone through over the next weeks as we look through the sets of policies which, in the view of my colleagues and myself, provide a vision for the Australian community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SINCLAIR
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The sad part about the contribution that has just been made was its demonstrable lack of vision, understanding and recognition that the Australian Labor Party has yet again failed the Australian electorate. In my brief time in the debate on the economic statement of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) I want to look at the circumstances as they affect one of the more aggrieved sectors of the Australian community. There is little doubt that the Australian taxpayer-the Australian wage earner, the small businessman, those who will not receive their tax cuts until some time after 1 July 1989-is paying dearly for the reduction in taxes to be provided to the corporate sector.

SPEECH.PARA: The Treasurer, because he has some grand political plan, some concept of his taking over from the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), unfortunately, has been prepared to put all on the backs of the taxpayer by deferring those personal tax cuts. To me, that is the first and major condemnation of the economic statement. The Treasurer himself admits that his budgetary situation is much better than it had been expected to be. He admits that the Budget surplus next year could be as much as $3,500m. This year he has identified something better than $1,000m. Yet none of that is to be passed back to the personal taxpayer. The reality is that the Treasurer sees it as necessary to be prepared to let ordinary Australians suffer in order that he can advance his own personal master plan. I think it is a total indictment of him that there are no personal tax cuts.

Unfortunately, it is the components of the Treasurer's method of paying for that domestic surplus that worry me and my colleagues in the National Party of Australia most of all. Most people need to understand that, with Australia's debt increasing, as it is, with Australia's chronic balance of payments problem, it is becoming more and more serious for Australia to redress the overall debt position and that continuing chronic balance of payments. That we have been able to do a little better and the Australian dollar has appreciated is not any consequence of the economic policies of the Labor Party. It is purely and simply because the rural and mineral sectors have been fortunate in enjoying better commodity prices than expected and because of excellent marketing, largely by those bodies which are so roundly condemned by the Government, they have been able to contribute a near record amount to Australia's export earnings. But neither the rural exports nor the mineral energy exports will be seen in that light next year. As commodity prices vary, as the Australian dollar appreciates, as imports continue to grow, the sad situation is that elements within that rural sector in particular continue to suffer. Honourable members might recall that in the Australian of 12 April last Julian Cribb wrote:
Of the 37 poorest electorates in Australia (that is, the bottom 25 per cent), 33 are rural seats . . .
The median family income in those seats ranged from $16,500 to $20,100 a year in 1986-on average about 53 per cent of those in the wealthiest.
He continued:
Ninety per cent of the poorest electorates in Australia are rural. Their family incomes average barely one-half of those in the more affluent metropolitan areas.
The highest proportion of families on incomes below $12,000 are also in rural areas.

I think it is essential that people not get bemused, because our exports are high, into thinking that the average situation of the family farmer and of those who are the contributors towards Australia's export wealth is as good as it should be. Indeed, we know that the general circumstances of family farmers will now be significantly worse because of the Treasurer's mini-budget last night. Of course, at Question Time today we heard from the Treasurer that we really did not have to worry; that these people would benefit because of the tariff cuts. The tariff cuts I applaud; but those tariff cuts, particularly in the areas that affect the family farmer, largely will not fall into place until about 1992. We need to understand that each of those areas-particularly chemicals and plastics and passenger motor vehicles-which affect farmers the most is in the phase-down period and that the most benefit will come at the end of the five years, certainly not now.

The reality is that there are now to be no personal tax cuts, at least until after 1 July 1989; and then it will depend on what Simon Crean says and perhaps what the Treasurer sees as best suiting his political ambitions, not on what the electorate needs. Not only will there be this unfortunate delay in personal tax cuts; there is also an additional immediate impost on the rural sector, and it is that that concerns me most. I am concerned about the way in which the disproportionate allocation of the so-called cuts is to fall. We have already heard tonight that $872m of the tax cuts will come from the States. In addition, another $20m will come from local government. Some $50m is coming from the roads. So State revenues are being cut, and we know from the statements by the Premiers that they feel they will have to increase their State taxes and charges. Those impositions will fall on ordinary Australians, including rural Australians and, in particular, family farmers. Let us all understand that very few of those family farmers will be in any position at all to enjoy the benefit of the reductions in the corporate tax rate to 39c in the dollar. Of course we applaud that reduction, but we in the National Party are concerned that those whom we represent will probably be at least $100m worse off in terms of direct additional expenses next year, and they will share in the additional tax burden as a result of the cuts to the States. They will certainly also suffer because inadequate funds are being provided for road construction and maintenance, and because local government will suffer yet a further reduction in its personal income tax sharing percentage.

When one looks at the detail of the changes and at the expectations of the National Farmers Federation, one has to understand that the Treasurer has taken from those areas which in normal circumstances might be reduced but he is not repaying to the family farmers affected any of that amount in the next financial year. He is going to hit each one of those family farmers, those people who are contributing towards the improvement in Australia's export performance; but he is not going to give them anything back.

It is important that we understand that not only is he not going to give them anything back but the one real benefit to come out of the changes in the future lies in the tax benefits that will flow through the reintroduction of a tax related income equalisation deposits (IED) scheme. But that income equalisation deposits scheme will not commence until 1 July 1989. So, at a time when there is expected to be some increase in rural incomes, when wool prices, cattle prices and lamb prices are good and when there is some improvement in our general agricultural products, the Government, by failing to pass on personal tax cuts, is going to take a far larger than normal percentage of the income of rural people. IEDs were introduced to try to offset the cost to the Government of the inevitable downturn in seasons and the downturn in commodity prices.

TALK.START.PARA: —We introduced them.

—Of course we introduced them, as my colleague says. We need to understand that the IED scheme will not be in place this year. Therefore, the tax burden on family farms-most of which operate on some sort of partnership arrangement between the farmer and his wife and family-will be significantly increased.

SPEECH.PARA: But we also need to recognise that some of the components of the Government's proposals will bear even more heavily on the rural sector because of the way in which the changes are directed. It is not satisfactory to have a situation where one group in the community is so discriminated against, and discriminated against because of the inevitable prejudice of the Treasurer who says that everybody in the bush must be making money because the gross figures in the statistics show improved returns for rural commodities. But that belies the fact, as I repeat, that the biggest percentage of poverty struck families live in the rural electorates. It is absolutely essential that those people not be passed over.

Of course there is to be some assistance through the rural adjustment scheme, but the application of its criteria is still far too tight for those who could be viable farmers. The new funds provided for in the Treasurer's statement are essentially to get people off the land, not to keep the family farmer on the land.

TALK.START.PARA: —Social welfare.

—My colleague the honourable member for Mallee interjects. There have been droughts in his area for the last few years. Wheat farmers have suffered an incredible reduction in their income. There has been a bit of an upturn this year, but they find that they will have to pay more tax. We know that fertiliser subsidies are to be terminated immediately and we know that IEDs will not be in place, so those who may well be non-viable will not be assisted.

SPEECH.PARA: I did not go into the rest of the article to which I have referred, but it says that something like 2,000 family farmers a year are leaving the land and all the rural adjustment scheme changes will do is help them get off the land more quickly. This country needs to keep those family farmers on the land. Of course there has to be a turnover in the generations. We need to have IEDs tax related, and we need them now. We need to provide a macro-economic climate in which our farmers can compete internationally and domestically. It is for that reason that we welcome the tariff reductions, but they will not provide the benefits now.

I have mentioned the problem of road funding. General road funding is becoming more and more critical. People have seen the schedules. Under Labor, roads have progressively become more and more discriminated against. Under this Labor Government, real funding for roads is now something like $400m less than it was in March 1983. The results of this reduction indicate that inevitably there will be a further deterioration in the roads used by producers in the bush, in the byways they use, rather than the main arterial highways. As they are squeezed there will be more pressure on local government, and that is in addition to its $20m personal income tax sharing reduction. So, the people in the farming community are suffering a particular cut in those areas I have specified, and they will also be affected by general reductions in local government and road funding.

I want to speak briefly of one particular industry-the sugar industry. The sugar industry is a major contributor to Australia's exports. It contributes about $1 billion a year. There are about 7,000 growers in Queensland, and they produce about 90 per cent of Australia's sugar. Nobody believes that the circumstances of canegrowers in Australia in the last 12 months have been good. We have seen a collapse in the price of sugar. Of course it has picked up to a degree, and the benefit of the devaluation of the Australian dollar has flowed through to many of those producers. But it has been assessed that as a result of the changes arbitrarily being introduced by the Federal Government in this mini-Budget, canegrowers will suffer something like a one-third cut in their income.

The sugar industry does represent the core from which most of the development of all that great stretch of country in north Queensland began. We know how many new Australians came and developed the industry there. It is not so long ago that about half of the population of Australia north of the Tropic of Capricorn depended on the sugar industry for its sustenance. We on this side of the House do not say that the regime affecting an industry can never be changed, or that the regime affecting the sugar industry can never be changed. But to change it at a time when the sugar industry is on its knees, to change it at a time when the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) has been telling us that he has new arrangements, that new deals are to be provided for the various sugar mills in Queensland and that there is some sort of bright hope for the future, is absolute rubbish. The consequence of the mini-Budget last night is to ensure that the income of canegrowers in north Queensland will be reduced by about a third.

To introduce that sort of Budget reduction arbitrarily, without consultation, without consideration of the consequences, is to emphasise starkly the real concern that this Treasurer and this Government have for ordinary Australians. They are denying tax cuts to the wage earners and they are denying the real benefits that should flow to those who are contributing to our export earnings. They have selectively discriminated against those in the poorest element of Australia, and any talk of social justice has gone completely out the window.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Leo McLeay) Order! The right honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Mr H.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose it was predictable that in their response to the May economic statement the coalition parties would come out with the same tired old line. Earlier today, in discussing a matter of public importance, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition and present shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), argued that tax cuts and a surplus are achievable by significant cuts in government spending. This reminds me of the debate earlier in the year on the Supply Bills. The honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite)-I acknowledge his presence in the chamber-had this to say in reply to comments I made:

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that tax reform in any sense must involve an element of looking at expenditure to see what is real and necessary. The honourable member for Scullin (Mr Jenkins), in his address, challenged the Opposition to say where these expenditure cuts would come from.

I repeat that challenge because in none of the Opposition contributions we have heard tonight has there been any indication of where these quality cuts would be made. It is the same tired old line. As always, there is no indication of where the Opposition would make the cuts. In reality, government programs have been cut to the bone. Government expenditure has fallen from 30 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP) to 25.5 per cent. This is the third consecutive annual cut in real Budget outlays and in the following financial year we have in prospect the fourth consecutive annual cut. These are the expenditure cuts that the honourable member for Bennelong, the present Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), calls wimpish. It must be remembered that when the Government came to power it faced a $9.6 billion deficit in prospect. That has been transformed to a $3 billion surplus in prospect, all in the space of five years.

The coalition, which describes itself as the opposition, as always, is in disarray. Far from joining the calls of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition for more cuts during today's discussion on a matter of public importance, the second Opposition speaker, the honourable member for Riverina-Darling (Mr Hicks), pulled out a dusty old speech filled with rhetoric about the plight of families and complained at length about cutbacks in last night's statement. Speaking before me, the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) repeated those cries. For instance, he highlighted perceived cuts in road funding. I assume the proposed tax rearrangements put forward by the Leader of the Opposition tonight will have some cost. Are we to hear those cries for cuts along with cries for increased expenditure in other areas? When will the Opposition get its act together? I suppose it is quite easy to talk of the Opposition's role as being one of opposing Government policy, but I think that the people of Australia expect a little better from the coalition. Has the Opposition not learnt that when it parades itself around Australia it really needs to parade itself as an alternative government? It will never parade itself as an alternative government when it is totally devoid of concrete policies. The lesson of the last election just has not come home.

Tonight the Leader of the Opposition talked about changes to tax arrangements. He advocated abolishing the capital gains tax. Yet he has the cheek to go on to talk about fairness. In that one policy he indicated that he would return to the policy of benefiting the greedy at the expense of the needy. He talked about abolishing Labor's fringe benefits tax and putting in some other form of fringe benefits arrangement. I think that the Australian public, after hearing him describe that fringe benefits arrangement, will realise that it is very similar to the law as it was when he presided over taxation law as Treasurer. He proposes to treat fringe benefits as cash which would be taxed in the hand of the recipient. Those arrangements and conditions applied when the Leader of the Opposition was Treasurer of Australia. But what did he do? Did he use the law? No, he allowed fringe benefits to explode. Yet he now decries this Government's efforts.

I now turn to the May economic statement's proposals in the area of corporate tax. Let us get it clear from the outset. As the Treasurer (Mr Keating) stated last night, the cut in the company tax rate from 49c to 39c will put Australian companies at the leading edge of world business. This reduction has been achieved by broadening the company tax base to create a fairer system.
