Let us not get the idea that this decrease in the company tax rate has been funded out of some magic pile, that it has been funded directly from workers. It has been funded by a general broadening of the company tax base. The taxation of company income in Australia was already more than competitive by international standards. Australia's corporate tax burden of 2.8 per cent of GDP is below the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development average of 3 per cent. This reform package should finally put paid to the myths peddled by the leader of the IXL Liberals, John Elliott-he who would Fosterise the Parliament-that Australia is a high taxing country.

The crackdown on corporate tax rip-offs and international tax havens is welcomed. About 60 countries, including the Bahamas, Bermuda, the Channel and Cayman Islands, Liechtenstein and Monaco will be designated. Those are countries with nominal tax rates below 25 per cent or with domestic laws that shroud a foreign entity's real ownership and financial affairs in secrecy. Companies which seek to take advantage of those havens will now be taxed. Although it is fair, this reform will probably draw a negative response from Mr Elliott. It has been reported in the Australian Financial Review that the AFP Investment Corporation is moving its domicile to Monaco. Under the old system, that would have allowed it to avoid virtually all Australian tax. Guess which company is one of AFP's biggest shareholders: Yes, it is Elders-IXL Ltd with 19 per cent. So, again, one of the loopholes has been plugged. One of those devices that lead to tax avoidance has been changed.

I now turn to the superannuation reforms in last night's statement. I am not sure whether the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) will continue the vein of his questions in Question Time, but I noted the Leader of the Opposition's comments that the coalition was studying the fine detail. I wish it luck in studying the fine detail, because I do not think that it will come to any conclusions different from those that are in the statements which accompanied the Treasurer's statement last night. The reforms to superannuation are a recognition of the cost in revenue forgone that has resulted from the treatment of superannuation for the purposes of taxation. In appendix A at page 18 of the paper Reform of the Taxation of Superannuation, which was tabled with the statement last night, we note the major sources of superannuation tax expenditure: under-taxation of pre-1983 lump sums, $1 billion; non-taxation of employer contributions, $1.8 billion; and no direct taxation of fund earnings, $2 billion. Those concessions are costed in gross terms in the Treasury's tax expenditure statement dated December 1987.

I invite honourable members who have some interest in the tax arrangements for superannuation to study that paper, because in two models the Treasury has set out the different ways in which superannuation receives a tax concession. Therefore, I was amused to see an article in the Taxpayer, the journal of the Australian Taxpayers Association, which said boldly that there are no tax concessions for superannuation. Unfortunately, that is very much a nonsense and has to be recognised as such. The reforms to superannuation announced last night are generally welcome. The package honours the Government's commitment not to make any changes which would retrospectively reduce already accumulated end benefits. Shifting the 15 per cent tax burden from end benefits to deductable contributions will bring forward revenue but leave after tax benefits undiminished.

Superannuation remains an integral part of the Government's retirement incomes policy. There is a great potential for the revenue brought forward under this change to be used to boost retirement income support and other areas of need. The inclusion of superannuation funds in the imputation system will greatly reduce the scope for tax avoidance. The fact that superannuation funds have not been eligible for imputation credits has produced distortions in investment behaviour. Allowing superannuation funds to utilise imputation credits to offset tax assessed on their income will limit their present distorting influences. The proposed taxation regime is intended to shift the funds' portfolio choice towards greater holdings of domestic equity yielding franked dividends, and that is a positive aspects of the proposals.

As I said at the commencement of my speech, it is unfortunate that the Opposition's response to last night's statement has been predictable. Even more unfortunate was the predictability of the statement of policies by the Leader of the Opposition, which indicated that we would go back to the bad old days of the Fraser-Howard Government. Look at his comments on industrial relations-the evoking of some form of essential services legislation, which can lead only to confrontation. Again it would be an industrial relations policy based on confrontation.

It disappoints me that, in the five years, the coalition has not moved away from those types of policies. It disappoints me that yet again tonight the Opposition has shown that, under any government that it was fortunate enough to form-for the Australian people it would be a misfortune-there would be a direct return to the policies of looking after the greedy at the expense of the needy. We only have to look at the way the Opposition would treat taxation. We only have to look at its stance on the referendums. All those proposals which would empower those disadvantaged in the community are being opposed by the coalition-opposed at the expense of those disadvantaged and to the advantage of those with the power. I think that that is a sad indictment of the way Australian politics is at the moment.

This Government has taken the long, hard haul, as the Treasurer would describe it; and for the Leader of the Opposition to describe some of the things that have been undertaken as wimpish defies explanation. When he got up here tonight and indicated that he would take Australia down the road of Thatcherism, people would have reflected on what Margaret Thatcher has meant to the working-class people in the United Kingdom. I think that, in looking at that and in drawing their conclusion, they will know that we are lucky. We are lucky that, under the Hawke Government, we have seen definite progress.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night, the Commonwealth Treasurer (Mr Keating) made a most important economic statement to the House and to the nation. He commenced his address with the somewhat grandiose words:

SPEECH.PARA: I will announce to the people of Australia far-reaching economic reforms that will take our nation into the twenty-first century.

Perhaps he has more ambition than luck, but I think it most unlikely that he will be still with us, and certainly will be neither Prime Minister nor Treasurer, at the turn of the century. However, whatever the objectives of his address may have been, in substance it was, regrettably, what is best known as light on.

I want to spend the time available to me tonight to address the issues of superannuation, which in the debates in this House today have really been demonstrated to be beyond both the capacity of the Treasurer to understand and the capacity of other people to be prepared even to ask questions of any depth about. My major concern is that, in the future-that twenty-first century of which the Treasurer speaks-Australian historians will look back on these days and at the Hawke-Keating Government's record, and I believe they will conclude that the last five years have introduced into the area of superannuation more utter chaos than has been seen at any other time this century. Having made that observation, may I pause and add that the Opposition does not oppose sensible reforms to superannuation; but the difficulty we are facing in the superannuation industry today is that it has constipation with reforms.

In May 1983 we saw the first set of major tax changes. Prior to that, people were taxed on 5 per cent of their total amount at marginal tax rates. The changes introduced in that month meant that tax of 15 per cent was introduced on the first $55,000 and 30 per cent on everything over that. No sooner had we recovered from that change than we had a set of regulations introduced on the basis of Press releases. Finally, late last year we saw introduced into this House a piece of legislation on superannuation which I described on that occasion as a skeleton Bill. Little was I or anybody else to know that subsequently, when the regulations were introduced early this year, we would see the substance which, in many respects, has been but a stinking carcass of what is left of the superannuation situation in Australia today.

We have heard much said by the Treasurer and other speakers from the Government and elsewhere about how the basic objective of the Government's retirement incomes policy is to ensure that all members of the population have an adequate and secure level of income in retirement; and of course the Opposition supports that perfectly clear and simple objective. What I find impossible to accept-and, frankly, I find difficult to understand-is how the Treasurer today in this House, in response to a question from me, made the observation that he saw no need to connect superannuation payments on the one hand with access to pensions on the other. It was a peculiar statement because elsewhere in the economic statement we were told by the Treasurer:

Savings for retirement through superannuation (or other means) are not simply alternatives to age pensions. The Government considers that superannuation should be seen as providing benefits additional to the age pension.
Later in the same document he stated:
The Government wishes to encourage superannuation because it is a form of saving which is specifically designed to meet retirement income needs.

The inevitable conclusion of those conflicting statements is that what we really need in Australia is a fully coordinated income maintenance policy which has two arms directed to the same objective: one to encourage people to save for their retirement, and the other to give those who, for one reason or another, are unable to achieve that level of saving an adequate income in retirement, funded by the state. But the fundamental problem which we have faced for many years in this country is what is best known as double dipping; that is, the capacity of people to save their superannuation throughout their 30 or 40 years in the work force, get their lump sum, dissipate it by one means or another and then, at age 65, come along and say, `I have no further financial resources, thank you very much. I can qualify under both the assets test and the means test. Please, will you give me a pension?'.

Is it any wonder that this Government has made the point in documentation tabled in this House from the Department of Finance that the cost of now giving superannuation support is in excess of $2 billion to $3 billion a year? Indeed, the industry may question that; various people have done other studies. However, one thing is certain: the cost of superannuation support through taxation advantages is massive. What is equally certain is that the saving in terms of pensions is simply not there. In other words, the costs which all people in the community, whether they have superannuation or not, are providing to those who do have superannuation have not been adequately covered in relation to the ability of those who have cover to make a more substantial contribution to maintaining themselves in retirement. And why? So that more funds are then available to help those most in need in our community.

For a government which claims to be full of compassion and concern, it is to me extraordinary that even now, after five years of consistent change to the basis of superannuation administration in this country, it has still not been able to introduce a viable set of regulations which cover all circumstances in relation to vesting, preservation and portability. One may well ask why. I do not know why, because nobody from the Treasurer down, on the Government's side, has ever bothered to tell this nation why. But we do know that when the Government introduced the regulations it made some worthwhile changes in those three key areas of superannuation planning.

However, what the Government did not do was cover the two million-odd Australians who currently had superannuation but who were not affected by those regulations. One of the weaknesses in the current structure was that people could take their contributions plus, in some cases, their employer contributions as a form of deferred pay every time they changed jobs. Consequently, when they finally got to age 60 or 65 years or, under this particular Administration, 55 years of age, they could say, `We have no viable superannuation left'.

I found it extraordinary to note in last night's economic statement a number of things. Firstly, the Treasurer claims that there are to be no losers under this arrangement; in other words, the benefits which accrue to existing superannuants will remain intact. He says this despite the fundamental changes to the way in which tax will be applied to superannuation funds.

Let me look at this now in more detail. We are told, for example, that the existing lump sum tax will be removed and that it will be replaced by a tax on the income earning of funds. The Opposition has no objection in principle to a change in the structure of tax on superannuation. However, we have very real doubts about the level of tax which should be applied. Why? We object for two reasons. Firstly, we object because since May 1983 the objective of this Government, covered as it has been by a very efficient smokescreen, has really been directed at increasing revenue. We were told by the Treasurer last night that the Government would be able to increase revenue by over $1 billion by having an income tax on superannuation.

The problem with the old lump sum tax, as far as this Government was concerned, was that the level of tax it garnered from beneficiaries was too small. It is true that it was going up by about 30 per cent a year, but it was a miserable $120m-odd. Since 1983 the Government had been looking down the road and seeing that pot of gold which represents-every penny of it-the contributions of employers and employees and, except for public servants, not the contributions of government except, of course, in terms of the tax support I referred to earlier. The Government said to itself, `Why should we remain with this miserable little return when it is possible for us to get access to this $1 billion golden handshake at the end?'. Naturally, of course, that was the direction in which it went. Now we have a situation in which, the Government claims, there are no losers. But the evidence is building up that that is not so.

The Treasurer said that the object of the exercise was to protect people who had lump sum benefits of around $60,000. Those people with benefits above that would still continue to pay a lump sum tax of 15 per cent. I must emphasise that that was in fact not a 15 per cent tax but a 16.25 per cent tax because it also involved the addition of a Medicare levy. That tax will be applied as a hidden fringe benefits tax on the contributions put into funds by management-by the employer. Those contributions will be taxed. Secondly, the dividend generated from the investment of those funds also will be taxed at 16.25 per cent. If one is unlucky enough to have done the right thing and tried to take the maximum level of superannuation coverage that one could afford and, therefore, have a lump sum benefits in excess of $60,000, one will have a third level of 16.25 per cent tax imposed. This is in spite of those key words of the Treasurer in the documentation to the effect that there would be `no double taxation'. Perhaps I cannot count, as probably I will be told by members of the Government, but the fact is that if we have three levels of tax it can hardly be denied that that is triple taxation. That is just one example.

The more we look in detail at this situation, as demonstrated by the way in which the Treasurer was not able to answer my questions in the House today, the more we realise that this is evidence that he does not even, for example, understand the very real difference between a pensioner on a benefit, especially for a widow or for somebody who has been forced out of the work force for physical or mental reasons, and a person who is a genuine retiree. The genuine retiree does quite well under this arrangement provided, as I said, the lump sum is below $60,000. However, if one is a widow of a would-be retiree one will be taxed at that additional 16.25 per cent. If one has to leave one's job for physical, mental or other reasons one will also be taxed that 16.25 per cent. However, one need not worry because we have a government that is totally wedded to compassion and concern! Concern for whom?

The reality of the program is simply this: in the administration of superannuation we are now facing the fact that over the next five years or so we will see a very real reduction in the 200,000 individual superannuation schemes in this nation. What will come out of that is a growth of vast superannuation funds. The existing life offices will be the basis of that. That is inevitable because the cost structure now associated with trying to manage a small superannuation scheme is simply beyond the capacity of small business, in fact, probably of most business. It will certainly be beyond the capacity of individuals.

The result will be that while on one hand the Government has introduced full tax imputation which, incidentally, it sees as a virtue, on the other hand, on the obverse of the coin, it has introduced non-taxing superannuation. This represents the most extraordinary use of language I have seen. If one says to the industry, `Do you want full imputation or do you want to have tax free status?', I can tell honourable members that one will get a 100 per cent vote for the latter and a zero vote for the former.

Nevertheless, the Government has given the industry imputation with the objective of having more funds coming into the market. However, there is again the very real risk that the flowing in of those funds will cause another boom in the stock market. The Government has to determine the economic implications of that for investment planning. There are just not enough Australian companies on the stock market which have a full capacity for imputation at this stage. The major difficulty is that we are talking about funds of over $80 billion, of which about $20 billion currently is offshore-much of which will now have to come back to Australia.

The reforms which the Government has introduced are absolutely fundamental. Whether they will achieve the objectives which the Government has set remains to be seen. We support the advantages which will result from this legislation, especially for the self-employed who will get an increased cover. They will now get $3,000, although that is still not indexed as it should be. There are other reforms in the package which are well worth while. However, my basic plea is: do not keep changing the basis of superannuation in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lee Mr M.

TALK.START.PARA: —For my sins, it appears to be my role in this House to follow the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) on many occasions. While I quite enjoy responding to the comments which the honourable member makes, it is often difficult to tie the honourable member down when he makes a bit of a blunder. I suppose the most famous is the occasion when he mixed up the Sydney suburbs of Mount Druitt and Campbelltown. After pointing that out to the House he then went away and altered the Hansard of his speech so that the Hansard did not confirm the fact that he had mixed up the suburbs of Mount Druitt and Campbelltown. That is perhaps understandable because the honourable member represents an electorate on the North Shore of Sydney.

SPEECH.PARA: Tonight we have had another example of the honourable member for Bradfield making a bit of a mistake. When he sought to explain what action this Government took in 1983 to change the tax on lump sum superannuation, he made a bit of a mistake. He claimed that in 1983 the Government introduced a tax of 15 per cent on lump sums under $60,000 and a further tax of 30 per cent on lump sums over $60,000. He completely forget to mention-or perhaps he did not understand-that the component of the lump sum which has accumulated before July 1983 is still taxed at the old rate. It is only the proportion of the lump sum which has accumulated after July 1983 which is subject to the 15-30 per cent rate. The honourable member for Bradfield completely ignored that, but I would not be surprised if later on tonight the Hansard proof is altered and even that problem gets fixed up.

The honourable member went on to say that he was upset that someone who retired with a lump sum of more than $60,000 would still pay 16.25 per cent tax. I was a little surprised at the arithmetic of the honourable member, because he forgot to mention that, given that the Government will be taking 15 per cent of the employer's contribution and the fund earnings, those people will be paying exactly the same amount of tax as they are paying today. Today they pay 31.25 per cent, and if one adds 15 per cent to 16.25 per cent, one gets the same figure-31.25 per cent. Quite simply, the honourable member for Bradfield does not understand the changes that have been made to superannuation.

Given that earlier this year he was seeking to whip up controversy and create fear in the community over the question of lump sum superannuation taxation, it is perhaps understandable that he is seeking to make the Government's changes appear as bad as possible. Perhaps he is to blame for the fact that the former Minister for Roads in Queensland, Mr Russ Hinze, retired a couple of days early. We now know that if Mr Hinze had not followed the advice of the honourable member for Bradfield, who thought that the Government would increase taxes on lump sums, and if he had retired after yesterday rather than before, he would have been better off. Perhaps that is a question that Mr Hinze and the honourable member for Bradfield can discuss later.

The changes the Government has made to lump sum superannuation are fair and equitable. The Government is reducing the tax concessions which are currently going to those very high salary earners, perhaps general managers or senior executives of large companies, who arranged as part of their salary packages to receive very generous superannuation. Because the Government does not tax the employer's contribution or the earnings of superannuation funds, people on salary packages of over $100,000 a year could receive extremely large tax concessions from the Government. So the Government has said that it will cut back the tax concessions that the wealthy salary earners are getting. I fully support that proposal. It will ensure that the Government has more funds to provide tax cuts to ordinary wage and salary earners next year.

In addition, I totally endorse the announcement by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) that he will introduce a secure tax file numbering system to ensure that people who earn interest on bank accounts and receive share dividends pay their fair share of tax. Mr Deputy Speaker, as you would know, the Government sought to introduce the Australia Card proposal last year and it was blocked by the Opposition and the Australian Democrats. As a result, hundreds of millions of dollars in tax are currently being avoided by people who receive share dividends and earn very large amounts of interest.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shame!

—The honourable member for Gilmore says that it was a shame to seek to introduce the Australia Card. He forgets that at various stages he advocated the introduction of the Australia Card on his own local radio and television stations when he did not think anyone was listening. I shall be very interested to see how he votes on the modified tax file number proposal, because he knows how fair the system is. The honourable member knows it is wrong for people to be receiving income from interest on share dividends and not to be paying their fair share of tax. I will bet that all the pensioners in the electorate he represents are forced by the Commissioner of Taxation to pay their fair share of interest, and I want to make sure that those on the very high incomes who are receiving share dividends and interest payments also pay their fair share of tax.

SPEECH.PARA: In my view, the biggest winners from the May economic statement were the pensioners, and, given the fact that my electorate contains the largest number of pensioners of any electorate in New South Wales, one can understand that that is a major factor in my analysis of the statement. The Treasurer increased the pensioner tax rebate from $250 to $430 from 1 July this year. That means that a pensioner can earn up to $10 a week in non-pension income before starting to pay income tax. At the moment pensioners start to pay income tax after receiving a little more than $3 a week of non-pension income, and that is too low. I am pleased that the amount has been increased to $10 a week. In addition, any pensioner, whether a social security or repatriation pensioner, receiving less than $10,332 a year will receive some benefit from this increase in the pensioner tax rebate. Better than that, the Treasurer has announced that he will be increasing the provisional tax threshold for pensioners by implementing a decision that any age pensioner, service pension or social security pensioner earning less than $10,332 a year will be exempt from provisional tax. I totally endorse that proposal. It means that more than 225,000 pensioners will be removed from the provisional tax net.

I have raised this issue in parliament on a number of occasions at the request of several combined pensioners associations in my electorate such as the Mannering Park, Gorokan and Toukley combined pensioners branches, so I am very happy to endorse the Treasurer's decision. It will certainly alleviate a lot of anxiety and pain amongst pensioners who have received assessments for provisional tax. Many of them do not know what to do with the forms; they do not understand why they have suddenly received a provisional tax assessment, and the Treasurer's decision to exempt pensioners earning less than $10,332 from provisional tax is something that I hope will have the endorsement of members on both sides of the House.

The Treasurer announced last night that from 1 July company tax will be reduced from 49 per cent to 39 per cent. This is being funded by a reduction in the tax concessions which the business community currently receives. The Government will abolish the 5/3 depreciation ratio concession and will introduce a tax on earnings from foreign tax havens such as the Bermudas and other places like the Caribbean. In addition, from 1991 the Government will be introducing a tax on the profits from goldmining-a tax which I believe is fair. Given the fact that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) gave an assurance that no gold tax would be introduced during the life of this Parliament, the Government has made a very responsible decision in this area.

The Treasurer also announced that the reduction in company tax is to be paid for by an increase in the prescribed payments system deduction rate from 15 per cent to 20 per cent. I understand there is some evidence that a number of taxpayers involved in the building game and other industries are prepared to allow the Commissioner of Taxation to take the 15 per cent prescribed payments system deductions, remain hidden and never put in any tax returns, so the fact that the Government will now be getting 20 per cent rather than 15 per cent of these earnings is certainly a step forward.

In the film industry the Government has taken the long overdue decision to abolish the 10ba concession. Given that many hundreds of millions of dollars in tax revenue have been lost because of that concession, I applaud the Government's decision to abolish it along with the decision to establish a fund this year of $70m to assist the Australian film industry. I emphasise, to those who say that the Government is providing company tax cuts this year and no income tax cuts until next year, that the company tax reductions will not be paid out of the Budget until 1 July 1989, so the companies will not be receiving that benefit until about the same time as the personal income taxpayers.

The bravest decision contained in the May statement was the decision to reduce tariff protection-an area which has been very controversial in Australia for at least the last 15 years. There has been a lot of debate about the extent of industry protection in Australia. The statement contains a provision to reduce protection to a maximum of 15 per cent for any industry, and for those industries currently receiving between 10 per cent and 15 per cent protection, the rate of protection will be reduced to 10 per cent.

I suppose one has to understand protection for Australian industry in its historical context. The National Party of Australia, whose members claim to represent free enterprise, was the party that sought to increase protection any time an industry ever got into trouble. An industry would come cap in hand to Sir John McEwen or any of the other National Party or Liberal Party Ministers of the day, and the Government's response to its problems was to provide higher tariff levels or to increase the value of the dollar, even though it was already overvalued. The result was that Australian industry was strangled; it got fat and lazy and inefficient. It has taken a government of the Hawke-Keating mould to take the tough decisions to wind back protection, to float the dollar and provide incentive for Australian industry, especially manufacturing industry, to improve its game, become more efficient and to look for export-led growth.
I happily endorse the May economic statement and I look forward to some positive contributions from the Opposition, given the excellent proposals currently before the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aldred Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night the Treasurer (Mr Keating) announced an expanded tax file number system, ostensibly to enhance the Australian Taxation Office's income matching system. Under this system interest reports, such as are made on interest and dividends, are supplied to the Tax Office and are then matched against the details supplied by the recipient to identify any omissions or understatements of income. Previously, income matching was carried out by attempting to match name and address details, a cumbersome and not always successful method. The new arrangements mean that the expanded tax file number will be used in the principal areas in which income reports are currently obtained by the Taxation Office. For example, these new arrangements will apply to bank and building society accounts, cash management and property trusts and the purchase of shares in public companies. There is, however, another matter, not mentioned by the Treasurer, that could be intimately connected with this expanded tax file number.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government currently has before it, awaiting signature, a document known as the OECD Convention on Mutual Assistance in Tax Matters. On 23 March 1988 during the adjournment debate I spoke at great length about this document, particularly highlighting the horrendous implications for the privacy of Australians should the Government decide to sign. This Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) Convention involves the international exchange of confidential tax information on Australian companies and individuals. The Convention encompasses not only major corporate and personal taxes, but also motor registration fees, minor local government charges and a catch-all clause for any other taxes. As a result of the provisions of this tax treaty an Australian tourist could be relentlessly pursued over some unpaid minor government charge, unknowingly incurred while travelling overseas.

Australia as a signatory to this convention would be compelled to surrender to a foreign government tax files, computer tapes or any other information foreseeably relevant to the company or individual concerned. The Government's expanded tax file number system will greatly facilitate this should we become a signatory to the Convention. In the case of this Convention's powers being used against an Australian company, it is not inconceivable that, in a foreign country where there is a close relationship between government and certain business interests, on a favour owed basis a foreign government could request the taxation files of an Australian company with whom the business in the foreign country is in competition. The advantages a competing foreign company will thus gain through this are self-evident.

Documents I have obtained from the Australian Taxation Office under the Freedom of Information Act show that numerous countries have already indicated that they have reservations concerning this Convention. They include the United Kingdom, Belgium, Denmark and West Germany, whilst Luxembourg, Portugal, Austria and Switzerland have gone as far as stating their total opposition to signing it.

Others of the freedom of information documents I have received show that Australia has legal and other difficulties with the OECD Convention and that the facility for the spontaneous exchange of information already exists. The documents further show that, where there are problems with the existing arrangements, the Australian Taxation Office is working them out with the countries concerned. The existing methods of exchanging information were covered briefly in my speech of 23 March last. On that occasion I said:

Australians need to ask this Labor Government why they are seriously considering signing this tax treaty when Australia is already a signatory to a treaty of mutual assistance in criminal matters. This clearly covers taxation offences to the extent that they prima facie constitute a criminal offence. In addition, existing bilateral agreements between OECD member nations satisfactorily cover the matter of double taxation.
A file note dated 29 September 1987 under the FOI material obtained from the Taxation Office says:
Australia had indicated earlier it had a number of objections which have been partly overcome.

Reading this it is not unreasonable to presume that the legal and other difficulties I earlier referred to are being smoothed over with a view to allowing the Government to sign the Convention. A further FOI document, a file note from the Tax Office dated 1 March 1988, refers to a telephone conversation between a taxation officer and an officer of the Attorney-General's Department. The file note records that the officer from the Attorney-General's Department advised the Tax Office that the OECD Convention would need to be ratified by parliament to have the force of law. This requirement will, thankfully, ensure that before the Government can foist this Convention upon us it will have to bring it out into the open. It will not be able to keep it secreted away from the scrutiny of the Parliament and the electorate, something it has gone to extraordinary lengths to do thus far.

The Taxation Office's treatment of my FOI request has been quite extraordinary. It decided to refuse me access to about 90 per cent of the available documents for the reason that it considered they were documents affecting national security, defence or international relations under section 33 of the Freedom of Information Act. The documents exempted under section 33 were exempted because `disclosure would be contrary to the public interest for the reason that the disclosure would, or could, reasonably be expected to cause damage to the international relations of the Commonwealth'. That is an incredible process of reasoning. It really is Sir Humphrey at his best. All I asked for were documents relating to a tax treaty that will affect every Australian individual and company. From the Tax Office's reaction one would have thought I had asked for the latest astrology chart on President Reagan.

It is not good in a healthy democracy to keep secret from the people documents such as this OECD Convention. If we become a signatory to it, it will affect each and every one of us. We all have a right to know just what it involves.

On advice from experts familiar with dealing with OECD documents I have now taken the matter to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal in an effort to gain access to more of these documents that the Government seems so intent on keeping secret from the Australian people. The Opposition does not see a problem of itself with the expanded tax file number system. However, we will be examining the detailed proposals very carefully, particularly given the implications it would have if this Government were to sign the OECD Convention. Listening to the Treasurer's speech and reading the accompanying documentation, the expanded tax file number system appears to have some value in preventing the tax avoiders from further ripping off the honest taxpayers. In concluding, I seek leave to table documents from the Australian Taxation Office obtained under the Freedom of Information Act in relation to the OECD Convention on Mutual Assistance in Tax Matters.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baldwin Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The May economic statement is fundamentally different from a number of earlier such statements in the sense that it is a comprehensive economic statement as distinct from a fiscal policy statement of the sort that we have seen earlier. As the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and others have pointed out, there is a comprehensive array of structural changes embodied in the statement and, considered together, they amount to one of the most significant sets of economic policy changes that have occurred since the Government was elected. As such the statement deserves very serious consideration by all honourable members. In assessing these changes I believe that it is necessary to look at them from two broad perspectives. The first is to ask in what way they contribute to the economic restructuring task the Government faces. All sides of the political spectrum acknowledge that the Australian economy needs to be fundamentally restructured if we are to achieve an external payments balance and the potential for rising living standards in the long term. We need to reduce our dependence on primary commodity exports and increase our production of high value-added manufactured and sophisticated services. That much is common ground amongst virtually all participants in the Australian economic policy debate. Of course, there is a great deal of difference among those participants about how best to achieve that structural change. Obviously, this economic statement aims to make a contribution towards facilitating that process.

SPEECH.PARA: Another aspect that needs careful consideration is the contribution that the measures contained in this statement make to the achievement of greater social equity. In other words, to what extent do they contribute to or detract from the goals embodied in the Government's social justice strategy? I intend to deal with those two areas separately. I will talk first about the contribution that the measures make to the task of economic restructuring. There are two aspects of this. One is the broad macro-economic strategy that is involved in the statements. We see a continuation of the attempt to constrain government expenditures, to reduce the Government's call on financial markets. That is consistent with what has been done in all the earlier Budgets and economic statements. There is some controversy there in the sense that there is a view that the Government's Budget deficit on the one hand and the current account deficit on the other are closely linked. That viewpoint is described as the twin deficits hypothesis. It underpins a lot of current thinking about fiscal policy. I have some doubts about the validity of the so-called twin deficits hypothesis. I think the link between Budgets and current account deficits is nothing like as strong as some protagonists of that viewpoint would have us believe. That is one aspect of the strategy embodied in this document. We see, to that end, a continuation of expenditure restraint. The degree of expenditure cuts involved here is relatively modest by comparison with some of the earlier statements; nonetheless the broad strategy continues.

The other aspect of the strategy involves the wide range of measures addressed to the so-called micro-economic reform in an attempt to achieve better performance at the individual firm and industry level. A range of things embodying both the private and public sector is involved here. Changes are made to the business tax system, to tariff protection, to the regulatory framework within which government enterprises operate and to a whole range of things which I will not attempt to describe at length. The Government is aiming with a combination of these measures to bring about a leaner and more efficient economy.

I turn to the changes in business taxation. An attempt is being made to achieve a so-called level playing field. We have seen a substantial one-off cut from 49 per cent to 39 per cent in the rate of company tax, which is to be funded in the long run by the elimination or reduction of a range of existing tax concessions, the major ones being the accelerated depreciation provision and such things as the research development concession. I will not attempt to list them all but the 5/3 depreciation provision is the major one so far as the revenue effects are concerned. It is perhaps worth pointing out that the elimination of those concessions will produce savings over a number of years. We will not see the full value of those savings for several years, so for the next couple of years the Government will experience a net loss of revenue as a result of the changes to the business tax system.

It is important when evaluating those changes to look at the economic task facing the Government. As I said at the outset, all sides of the political spectrum acknowledge that the Australian economy needs to be substantially restructured. The main thrust of Government policy is to try to effect a shift of resources into the internationally traded goods sector in an attempt to produce an increased level of investment in that sector. There are a couple of aspects of this matter that cause me a bit of disquiet. According to a study presented by the Bureau of Industry Economics to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology, if one eliminates the accelerated depreciation provision, or substantially reduces it, as has now been done-we have economic life plus a 20 per cent loading-the effect on the cost of capital is reasonably significant. According to the Bureau's estimation, as the average gearing ratio for Australian companies is 25 to 30 per cent we would need to reduce the company tax rate from 49 per cent to 24 per cent to offset completely the effects of eliminating the accelerated depreciation on the cost of capital. That is a bit of a worry.

In addition, restructuring business tax by funding a cut in the general level of company tax through the elimination of or a substantial reduction in the accelerated depreciation provision tends to disadvantage industries where plant and equipment have a relatively long economic life. To a considerable extent, that involves the manufacturing and mining sectors, which are precisely the internationally traded goods sectors that we need to transfer resources into if we are to bring about structural adjustment. I have some difficulties with that proposition.

I make those few observations because the economic effect of this sort of combination of change is controversial. If one believes that market forces ought to be supreme and sovereign it is not a problem. To the extent that it brings about such a shift in emphasis, there are those who would say that that is not a bad thing, that it would produce a more efficient and ultimately productive allocation of resources. I am not so certain about that and I wonder how those various effects will net out.

However, there is a whole range of extremely positive measures in respect of the business tax system. I am very pleased to see that we are finally tackling a number of hard core avoidance mechanisms which people have complained about for some time. One is the abuse of overseas tax havens. We will finally see that tackled in a serious way. The inter-corporate dividend rebate provided for under section 46 of the Income Tax Assessment Act has been subject to considerable abuse over the years. Quite a bit of hard core avoidance has revolved around the abuse of that particular form of rebate. I am very pleased that the Government has sought to tackle that problem.

I have a suspicion that the revenues stipulated in the statement will be substantially exceeded in some of these measures, as was the case with the income tax base broadening measures undertaken in 1985. There is a whole range of aspects to this. One is the tariff changes which, by and large, leave the existing industry plans more or less intact. There are some changes but they are not major. I am very pleased that the Government has recognised the importance of providing a climate of stability and predictability in which the process of industry restructuring and investment can take place. The hard core market forces advocates would favour slashing protection and disregard industry plans, but those voices have been overcome. I think that the approach that the Government has taken in that area will not meet with too much difficulty from either the employer or the employee side of the industries concerned. However, I believe that it is important to monitor the effects of the changes and to make sure that appropriate adjustment measures are in place to complement the changes in tariff protection.

The statement also addresses a range of social equity measures that make a positive contribution. The superannuation changes tackle a very delicate problem in a way which is both consistent with equity and reasonably politically astute. The Opposition has tried to portray these changes as a pea and thimble trick when in fact they alter the time scale in which revenue collections have to be made in that area. I believe that what has been done there has been very intelligently constructed. I congratulate all those involved in the Government in putting that together. The Government also has altered the taxation of pensioners, with a substantial increase in the pensioner tax rebate. That is very equitable and is something we can all applaud, together with the easing of the provisional tax arrangements.

Finally I refer to the announcement by the Government that it is reviewing, as well as substantially reforming, the regulatory framework within which government business enterprises operate. It is also looking at possibly exempting the airlines and the Australian National Line from the Loan Council global borrowing restrictions. I regard that as a very positive step. One of the artificial factors behind the drive for privatisation in recent times has been the cosmetic reduction in the public sector borrowing requirement that can be achieved by transferring these things from the public sector to the private sector. That is utterly spurious and I am very glad that the Government has recognised that borrowing by government business enterprises has essentially the same economic impact as borrowing by private enterprises engaged in essentially the same type of commercial activity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fisher Mr P.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I note the very perceptive comments that have been made by the honourable member for Sydney (Mr Baldwin), particularly when he related his comments to the effect of the company taxation change and the accelerated depreciation changes in relation to it. As this is my final speech in this provisional Parliament House and after almost 16 years of having the privilege to represent the electorate of Mallee, I am sure you will allow me, Mr Deputy Speaker, one sentence of tolerance to acknowledge the loyalty and talents of my staff in my electoral office and the support, of course, of my wife, Judy, who is in the House tonight, and my two children, Tony and Nicole.

SPEECH.PARA: I am sure that you will also allow me some tolerance to acknowledge the fact that Australia's primary industries, both mining and agriculture, have contributed some 80 per cent of our export income over many decades. This is evenly divided between agricultural income, of some 40 per cent, and mining income, of 40 per cent. It is a fact that it will now take every dollar produced by these primary industries from exports over the next 15 years to pay for debts that have been incurred on overseas borrowings.

Despite the significance of this continued production to the future of our nation, I have to say that government policies have aggravated our economic circumstances through excessive taxation on production imports. This mini-Budget has continued that trend. Declining cereal prices have been the direct result of international market factors. However, the continued increase in farm costs is a direct result of domestic factors. These industries acknowledge that it is difficult to influence the price received for commodities. They firmly believe that a number of domestic matters can be influenced to reduce the magnitude of the increases in farm cost and hence improve farm incomes.

At the same time as commodity price drops have been occurring, Australia's inflation rate is much higher than that of our competitors. It is interesting to look at some comparisons. In 1987 Australia's inflation rate was 9.3 per cent; in the United States it was 3.7 per cent; and in the United Kingdom it was 4 per cent. The major effect of high inflation has been to place upward pressure on producers' costs of production, which in turn has seriously eroded growers' incomes. A recent Victorian rural economic study by Professor Alan Lloyd commented:

The task for macro-economic policy is to exploit the gain in competitiveness already achieved which requires that inflation be contained. This involves further wage and fiscal restraint to provide reasonable outcomes on the balance of payment, also lower interest rates to stimulate investment.

It is therefore quite obvious that, so long as our domestic rate of inflation remains at a high level, cost pressures will continue and the full effects of devaluation of the exchange rate will not be realised. Of course, the most significant impact on rural industry has been interest rates and there is no doubt that Australian levels of prime bank interest rates seriously disadvantage producers with our competitors.

The dependence of the Government on monetary policy has contributed significantly to the record real rates of interest. The Government has argued that this policy was necessary to defend the dollar against further devaluations and to slow domestic demands and growth in order to prevent the re-emergence of inflationary pressures. It is generally recognised that interest rates, when they were at record high levels, were five percentage points higher than they might otherwise have been in the absence of a high interest rate policy. This represented a cost of $6,000 per farm.

It is clear that Australia's international competitiveness is still being eroded by the comparatively high interest rates and inflation. Importantly for the primary industry sector which sells its produce on the international markets, the domestic cost structure reflects the high rate of inflation, whereas the income levels have not inflated. Therefore, the Government should have a responsibility to maintain Australia's comparative advantage in agriculture and other export and import competing industries.

The level of interest rates nearly doubled from around 13.5 per cent to 20 per cent and sometimes higher in the years 1984 to 1987. This has had a significant impact on growers, particularly growers in my electorate of Mallee. Some farmers who were debt free in 1981 or 1982 and bought land became unviable because of the accumulated effect of the corrupted international markets, the increase in farm costs and the effect of interest rates. The extent to which interest rates have added to farm costs is highlighted by the fact that, as a proportion of total costs, the interest component of costs increased from 11 per cent in 1983-84 to about 18 per cent in 1985-86.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is this Government's responsibility.

—Yes, it is. Some farmers who borrowed heavily in the late 1970s and early 1980s subsequently were unable to fund repayments and now have a vast accumulated debt. Naturally, the rate at which the debt has been accumulating has been significantly increased by this record level of interest rates. The Federal Government, through rural adjustment schemes, subsidised interest rates for some farmers. Some, however, have moved so swiftly from a position of being debt free and viable to being debt burdened and non-viable that they were not eligible for the rural adjustment scheme support. It is therefore likely, as interest rates ease, that some people, particularly governments, will assume that the problem of high interest rates has gone away and is of no concern. This is not the case for those producers who are left with the legacy of the high interest rate period.

SPEECH.PARA: Some wheatgrowers in my electorate have had to borrow money this year to plant their crops. Some growers in my electorate have been denied the capacity to borrow money to plant their crops. They, unlike producers in other industries, cannot defer investment decisions until the price of money falls to a reasonable level. Furthermore, they cannot expect to pass on the high cost of interest rates. Farmers, therefore, must borrow money in accordance with the seasonal and biological nature of their operation. If the crop is not profitable they must carry that loss onto the following year. If the level of that loss is worsened by the level of interest rates, that too will be carried forward into future years.

It is important that government, when making decisions that affect agricultural policy, recognise two factors: firstly, some producers have had virtually no choice but to borrow money at interest rates at record levels just to plant their crops; secondly, many are still carrying forward a debt that is in part due to those record interest rates. The viability of these farmers has been destroyed and many in the industry carry the legacy of the former high interest rate regime.

The following trends in the distribution of grain growers' income emphasise what has happened. In 1984-85, 25 per cent of wheat producers had a negative income of more than $13,653. In 1986-87, the same number of producers had a negative income of almost double, $27,000. In 1984-85, 50 per cent of producers had an income of less than $10,584, and in 1986-87 the same number of producers had an income of less than $2,700.

TALK.START.PARA: —Absolute poverty.

—It is poverty. As I mentioned in my opening remarks, the tragedy is that the rural sector still contributes some 40 per cent of our export earnings. I want to link my opening remarks about the state of agricultural industries in this country to what has happened in this mini-Budget. One would have expected this Government to have acknowledged the contribution that agricultural industries have made. In this time of rural crisis-which still exists in almost all agricultural industries, probably with the exception of wool-one would have expected that there would have been some recognition of this factor. The agricultural sector and the rural sectors which depend upon it have borne the burden of adjustment more than any other sector. In this mini-Budget some $100m has been taken from the agricultural sector.
—How much?

—It is $100m. This year $10.4m has been taken from wool promotion. The termination of the fertiliser subsidy amounts to $37m. Of course, it is proposed that domestic pricing arrangements be changed in the sugar, dried vine fruit, tobacco, citrus and dairying industries. We will see price underwriting tightened up in several areas for the wheat, dairying, apple and pear and dried vine fruit industries. We will see $11m taken from livestock producers with additional costs for export inspection services. Of course, we acknowledge the fact that the whole rural community will suffer from the $50m being taken from our road network.

SPEECH.PARA: I acknowledge, of course, that there have been some gains for the rural sector, particularly in relation to soil conservation, the proposals to reduce the level of salinity in the Murray-Darling Basin and the addition to the rural adjustment scheme. But I simply say that the additions to the rural adjustment scheme have basically been in the areas of welfare and rehabilitation. There has been no money--

TALK.START.PARA: —What about IEDs?

—I will mention IEDs in a minute. No money at all has been put into the rural adjustment scheme to enable people to stay on their properties. The only money that has been put into rural adjustment has been to ensure that people who have to move out of the farming areas can do so with some dignity.

SPEECH.PARA: I conclude by mentioning the income equalisation deposits scheme. We introduced this scheme when in government. It was highly successful. But the Government of honourable members opposite emasculated it as soon as they got into office. By bringing this measure back into rural policy the Government is simply acknowledging its mistake-and I am pleased that it has done so. But I say to honourable members opposite, as a representative of a broadacre farming area in Victoria: if the income equalisation deposits scheme had still been in place in 1982-83, many of the tragedies may not have occurred with the impact on about 1,500 primary producing properties.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sciacca Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to rise in support of this package of economic measures that make up the May statement. I congratulate the Treasurer (Mr Keating) on what almost every expert commentator around the country has said is a responsible package of economic reforms which will put this country in the forefront of Western world economies. It would probably not be apt if I did not make some comment with respect to the 26 minutes of drivel that we heard tonight from none other than the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard). He was all decked out and he had all of the media watching him. But, in real terms, it was a negative statement-more like that of a little boy who had just had his marbles taken away from him.

SPEECH.PARA: He said that we took the Opposition's idea from it. Maybe we did take some of the Opposition's ideas, because they just happened to coincide with some of ours. The fact is that when honourable members opposite were in government they did not have the guts to implement them. The Leader of the Opposition blames this Government for the international debt. But, in real terms, what he does not say is that the international debt is not the fault entirely or even largely of this Government; it is attributable to State government borrowings, State government statutory authorities and the private sector. So it is incorrect and an absolute untruth to say that the international debt is all the fault of this Government.

I have said previously on a number of occasions in this House that the Leader of the Opposition has become nothing short of a clone of Senator John Stone-and he proved that here again tonight. In fact, looking at the way he attacked the industrial unions and talked about privatisation and everything else, it was obvious that the speech had been written by Senator John Stone. This attack on the union movement, as I said, and on our system of industrial relations and arbitration in this country, was clear evidence of this fact. His whole demeanour was that of a frustrated and bewildered man. He could not fault the Treasurer's statement, so he had to resort to nitpicking, because that is all he could do. His parting cheap shot at the Treasurer was indicative of the quality of what he had to say.

This Government in fact has had the courage to do what the Opposition, with all its rhetoric over the many years its members were in office, did not have the guts to do. It has been this Government that has been prepared to make the hard decisions. It was this Government that floated the Australian dollar; that tackled the deregulation of the financial markets. The people of the financial markets throughout the world decide the value of our dollar on world markets, rather than the old rate fixing system with the managed rate that we had in the past which, of course, in part at least, contributed to the balance of trade problems we have had over the last five years and which this Government has done a lot to redress.

TALK.START.PARA: —A courageous decision.

—It was a courageous decision, as the honourable member for Fisher says. The Government has introduced far-ranging measures of taxation which have now become a permanent part of the economy, such as the fringe benefits tax, the assets test and, of course, the capital gains tax. These are measures which the Opposition has howled about for many years. But, in fact, not only did we win the last election but we will win the next one as well. They are measures which the Opposition, if it ever got into power, would most certainly retain.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition has been desperately trying to discredit these economic measures since they were introduced last night. But, in my submission to this House, it has failed miserably to do so. In fact, at Question Time today, when one would have expected an array of questions on the economy and on the May economic statement, what did we get? We got two questions from the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) about superannuation. That really was it. There might have been a few other furphies, but they were the only two substantive questions asked.

I want to talk a little bit about the change in superannuation arrangements. I am sure that I am not Robinson Crusoe when I say that, as a member of this House, I have had to listen to numerous inquiries from constituents. Over the last four months they have asked me, `What will happen to our superannuation? Will we lose half of it? How will these changes affect us?'. Of course, I have tried to tell these people what in effect the Treasury has told me; and I told them as well the answer that was given by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in this House to a question from the Opposition. That answer made it very clear that the Government would not consider any changes which would impact adversely on already accrued superannuation benefits. Further, the Prime Minister, in answer to the question, said that superannuation will continue to be treated on a concessional basis.

The saddest aspect of all these questions, all these media reports and all these mischievous attacks by this Opposition is that for the sake of scoring cheap political points honourable members opposite undertook a scaremongering campaign to the point where the public started to believe some of their lies and propaganda. Aided and abetted by some sections of the media, people started to get worried and concerned. Some of them actually telephoned me and asked, `What is your advice? What are you going to do?'. Of course I usually do give good advice, as the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron) knows. The position is that I said them, `Look, I can't tell you any more than what the Prime Minister said in answer to the question'. I have already told the House what that was.

TALK.START.PARA: —Russ Hinze did not wait to retire.

—As the honourable member for Fisher indicates, as it turned out had the member for the South Coast in the Queensland Parliament waited one more day he might have been a bit richer. He believed the propaganda of his Opposition mates down here who sold him down the drain, as well as many of their supporters who retired on lump sums as a result of the scaremongering that the Opposition went on with.

SPEECH.PARA: A number of people contacted me with regard to these fear tactics. They included a magistrate, a couple of school principals and airline pilots. In fact, I was contacted by everyone who worked at the Ampol refinery in my electorate-ordinary working people who had put away a little bit of money for their retirement and who were scared by what these people over here were saying, aided and abetted by some sections of the media.

Some sections of the media went along with the Opposition. Some of the publications that came out, and I have had a look at a couple of them, indicate just how bad that misrepresentation was. The Australian Taxpayers Association's newsletter dated 27 February 1988 carried the headline, `52.6 per cent slug planned on retirement lump sums?'. The article stated:

Income tax of a flat 30 per cent can be taken on all but a return of employee contributions. Calculations on following pages show a 15 per cent tax on superfund income charged year by year, with 30 per cent tax on the lump sum when received, is equal to an overall 52.6 per cent if charged on retirement.

Of course that is absolute hogwash, as it turned out. This group even published a table which said how much people would lose. It was absolutely disgraceful. It was disgraceful because this association was being fed and leaked all sorts of stupid information from members of the Opposition, and probably from the honourable member from Maranoa himself.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us about your new taxes on super.
— Order! The honourable member for Maranoa will refrain from interjecting.

—Thank you for your help, Mr Deputy Speaker. I am not really all that concerned; the honourable member for Maranoa makes some fairly inane interjections from time to time. He reminds me of an article in the Sunday Mail in Queensland of 20 March 1988. It ran a full page article, with the headlines, `How you'll lose half of your nest egg'; `Review could cramp payout plans'; `Only top earners can afford contributions'; and `What it would mean to women'. All these Press releases and the information that appeared in the newspapers led people to retire before they really wanted to do so. People were taking their superannuation benefits because they were scared. I say to those people: there is only one mob to blame, and that is the Opposition. Members of the Opposition are the ones who, for cheap political point scoring, turned around and tried to scare everybody in this country who had saved and scrimped out of their superannuation benefits and thought they were going to lose them.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is that the Treasurer has simply introduced a 15 per cent tax on employer contributions and the earnings of employer and employee contributions, but not one cent will be charged against employee contributions or on the lump sum. So everything that the Prime Minister said here that day and everything I have said to my constituents who have asked me has been true. If only people had believed that, there would not have been all these people who took their money and ran, so to speak. We would not have lost all these airline pilots from Qantas Airways Ltd who took jobs with overseas companies. We would not have lost all those highly trained people who became so concerned by the scaremongering that they went ahead and took their money and ran. As I say, I blame none other than those opposite. They ought to be ashamed of themselves. Once again they have been proven wrong. It is not the first time, and it certainly will not be the last. I congratulate the Treasurer on what he has done. This is an enormous package. It has been accepted by the community. The only ones who are sorry about it are members of the Opposition because they cannot find anything wrong with it. They are really sorry about that, and they will be whingeing for the next two months.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Liberal Party of Australia and the coalition have always been in favour of lifting the burden of taxation from Australians by reducing the role of government. For that reason alone, none of the criticisms I will make tonight of the economic statement of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) should be taken as criticising genuine attempts to reduce taxation and government expenditure. However, the simple facts presented in the Treasurer's statement indicate that no such genuine attempt has been made. By 1989-90, measures introduced in this mini-Budget will raise at least $1.5 billion per annum in revenue from new sources. That will be to offset the company tax rate reduction. Spending cuts are minimal, with no changes to any major spending program. The intrusions of government regulation will continue. The mirage of a declining role for a new, lean Federal Government is entirely dependent upon optimistic growth figures which would see the gross domestic product expand more rapidly than Federal outlays.

SPEECH.PARA: The measures announced by the Treasurer will attempt to cement in the excesses of the early years of the Labor Government. The disastrous costly failures of Medicare, on the one hand, and the relatively small but unprincipled waste of the Constitutional Commission on the other have never been repudiated by the Hawke Government. Instead we have had to suffer a plethora of new and higher taxes to pay for those excesses and the huge Budget deficits that went along with them. Medicare levies, the fringe benefits proposal and capital gains taxes are only some of the more obvious imposts suffered by Australians under this Hawke-Keating regime.

We have also had to suffer the ruinous effects of high inflation and interest rates, continued unemployment and declining investment. The deliberately high rate of inflation maintained under this deservedly maligned Treasurer has been the single most important cause of burgeoning tax revenue for the Government. Bracket creep has seen the average taxpayer move into the highest marginal rates, to the extent that the average wage and salary earner is now on a marginal tax rate higher than the proposed new company tax rate. What the Government did last night was to announce with unjustifiable fanfare a shuffling of the pack. It has made moderate and minor structural adjustment decisions which avoid the tough problems particularly in the textiles, clothing and footwear industries. It has abandoned the hope of major reforms through privatisation. The Government's half-hearted structural changes are an anti-climax because the Government is more than ever in the thrall of the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) and bound to a lesser but nevertheless important extent by the Australian Labor Party National Conference.

Over the five years of this Government, it has become clear that the Treasurer is not the master of economics so much as an amateur conjurer who can shuffle the pack and perform some clever tricks which excite the less watchful, and who always dreams of the opportunity for one big performance which fools everyone. The economic statement is not a masterpiece of real magic. As many people have observed, what it gives with one hand it takes with the other. While the tariff and regulatory changes in this package are desirable, they are cautious, minor and usually belated. In the limited time available to me, I will concentrate on the budgetary considerations of the expenditure and revenue changes presented last night. The expenditure restraint in the May statement is simply a farce. It produces a deficit in line with predictions if no policy changes had occurred. Around 87 per cent of expenditure cuts will impact on the States. Commonwealth outlays have hardly been cut at all. In fact, the Medicare mess is becoming an increasing drain on the Federal Budget as quick fix schemes are proposed to prop up an unworkable system.

The honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson) pointed out in a Press statement a number of areas where savings are the result of an exercise in creative accounting. Last year's Budget cuts, despite their dependence on the sale of assets, were more substantial than last night's proposals. These most recent proposals lack substance and show the warped priorities of this Government which is so out of touch with Australians. No-one represents that lack of touch with Australians more than the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke).

The burden of Federal restraint again relies at least to some extent on a further major cut in the growth of defence expenditure. The proposals of the Dibb Review of Australia's Defence Capabilities and the Defence White Paper must be seen for what they are-a real shambles. Both those reports have assumed modest real spending growth which has now been cut. Stability and long term planning in defence have been severely undermined by the unspecified cuts in the economic statement. With all the waste of other departments and the cynical spending on favourite social engineering projects, the last area which should have been cut is defence. Defence is the only legitimate Commonwealth function subject to cuts in this statement. What that indicates is that the Treasurer can no longer carry the day in Caucus with badly needed spending cuts and that the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) has little or no influence whatsoever.

The Treasurer's inability to deliver on major reductions in Federal spending has denied Australians personal income tax cuts, which are long overdue. They have been deferred for yet another year. That should remind Australian voters of the arrogance of the Treasurer, who thinks that the Government can spend people's money better than they can spend it themselves. The most significant feature of the five long years of Labor Party Government has been the growth in government revenue. The Government will not reverse that trend. At best, the growth in tax receipts, especially for pay as you earn taxpayers, will stabilise in 1989-90. But there are no guarantees of that. The greatest concern to most Australians is their tax bill. Every time someone does a little bit of overtime and finds 40 per cent of the extra money earned going to the Government, he sees a very sad demonstration of the effects of high marginal tax rates and bracket creep.

The Treasurer wants to have his cake and eat it too. He promises income tax cuts, but he cannot say how much or how soon. The Government's policy, it seems, is to be determined by another deal with the ACTU when it was those deals which led, more than any other single circumstance, to our current economic malaise. In my limited time I cannot refute the shonky economics of the Treasurer about the danger of income tax cuts. I point out only that, if what he said were true and he gave a cursory glance to the make-up of the fluctuations in the national accounts figures for imports, he would not reduce the company tax rate either.

Another standard trick of those with a thirst for greater tax revenue is to increase the frequency of tax payments to better approximate the pay as you earn tax system. Examples of this trend include provisional tax, fringe benefits tax and the prescribed payments system. Last night the Treasurer increased the prescribed payments advance by one-third. Under the present tax regime all of those taxes have significant effects on the operations of small businesses. The early payment of due tax has detrimental effects on the planning and cash flow of Australian firms. The funds available for short term investment are limited and they are to be further limited. Instead, the Government will have the use of money until the end of the financial year. That is a relatively recent development. It involves some $10 billion of tax each year. Bringing forward tax income is a sleight of hand, something which the May statement reinforces and makes further use of, in respect of, firstly, the increase in prescribed payments and, secondly, the taxation of superannuation. Despite the rhetoric about levelling the taxation treatment of all sections of business, the primary purpose of the changes to taxation of superannuation is to bring forward $925m of future tax income to the years when the Treasurer will need it for his short-sighted political gain. Other major tax changes include those dealing with income from foreign companies and the extension of company tax to the gold industry.

For five years the Government has talked about the need to crush the tax evasion industry. That shallow rhetoric continues in the 1988 May economic statement. The effect of that rhetoric has been to inflict on ordinary Australian taxpayers a draconian regime of hostile tax collection subject to no rules other than the squeezing of maximum revenue out of the existing laws. Of course, the economic statement is completely inadequate in the vague promise about income tax. There is little prospect for change in this imbalance in the Budget. The May economic statement takes some steps to right the wrongs of five years of Labor Government; but those five years have left us in such a precarious economic state that the Treasurer feels he has to continue with the rising taxation which was the product of his earlier inflationary economic policies. Above all, the Treasurer arrogantly told all Australians of his desire to rule them. That statement, with echoes of a less democratic past, is a very sad symptom of the problems of Australia under Labor. Australians do not want politicians as their rulers. If they want us at all, it is to represent their desire for a government which does its limited job without intruding on their private affairs or being a burden on their productive efforts. I can only wonder whether the economic statement was motivated by the interests of Australians or by the desire of honourable members opposite to rule.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the task of the Opposition to criticise, but it is also the task of the Opposition to come forward with some sort of constructive debate in this assembly and to present some alternatives. A number of honourable members, including the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), who have spoken tonight have said nothing except that Labor has taken some of their policies. That seems to be their excuse. Let us make some comparisons with the past. The honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher), who has just resumed his seat, talked about trying to rectify the problems of the last five years of Labor Government. The problems occurred between 1976 and 1983. That is not just my judgment as a Labor member; it is the judgment of organisations such as the Metal Trades Industry Association Inc.
