It put in a report saying that the real problems in this country began when industry moved offshore. That occurred under the Fraser Government. The Liberal-National Party Government refused to address the problems of this country.
—Mr Keating said you evicted 100,000 from jobs in the metal trades.

—Order! The honourable member for Capricornia will resume his seat. The honourable member for Curtin, as a Deputy Chairman of Committees, knows full well that every member of this House has the right to be heard without interruption and interjection. I ask him to remain silent.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I never mind him interjecting because he makes better interjections than he makes speeches.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. I want you to know that I did not intend to interrupt the honourable member for Capricornia nor did I succeed in doing so.
—Order! There is no point of order.
—But when he talks about the Metal Trades Industry Association, he knows that Mr Keating admits that it cost 100,000 jobs.
—Order! There is no point of order. The honourable member compounds his error. He will resume his seat.
—That is his third attempt at making a speech and he still has not hit the mark.
—Order! The honourable member for Capricornia will not provoke unnecessarily.

—I take your point, Mr Deputy Speaker. Let me return to what took place between 1976 and 1983. We had an era of tax rorts and tariff protection that caused great harm to this country, but nothing was done about it. We had major problems with a huge tax burden on the people of Australia. The highest tax limit was 60 per cent. We had double taxing on business. Business would make a profit on which it would pay tax, then, having distributed the dividends, it would pay tax on those. But the previous Government did nothing about that. As I have said, it is the Opposition's task to criticise; it is also its task to bring forward alternatives. The people of Australia want to hear the Opposition say what it would do. What it has said tonight is that the tax cuts--
—You weren't here for his speech.
—I listened intently to the honourable member's speech.
—You weren't here for the Leader's speech.
—You do not call that a speech, do you?
—Order! The honourable member for Capricornia will address the House through the Chair.

—Through you, Mr Deputy Speaker: what the Opposition has said tonight is that there have not been enough cuts. Yet it dared to criticise the Government for the cuts that have been made. This is the first Government in this country's history that has been able to end up with such a surplus-$3 billion. The Government has taken upon itself a strategy and a commitment to reform the economic thrust of this nation, to ensure that the effects are spread across the nation and that everyone carries some of the burden as we turn the economic corner. That is what is taking place.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government has seen the need to restructure tax on business, but I do not hear any praise from the Opposition. This Government changed the double tax on business profits and dividends. This Government brought down personal tax from 60c to 49c and this Government has now brought company tax from 49c to 39c. But, of course, we hear no commendation; we just hear this bleating about how bad it is. Let us see how bad it is. We ought to listen to independent opinion, not just to the Opposition. I read today the commentary in the Brisbane Courier-Mail, which is not exactly a pro-Labor paper. It sums up its editorial by saying:

This May economic statement is an impressive document, both for the Government and for Mr Keating. It reveals that hard decisions can be made by confident governments, that lessons can be learned and that economic rationality will triumph over politics, given half a chance.

That is a pretty good summation of what took place last night when the Treasurer (Mr Keating) delivered the May economic statement. It is a pretty good judgment of what is taking place here. It is a conservative newspaper that has made that judgment. We might understand why, if we consider what has taken place. We have heard Opposition members talking about cuts in road funding, but they have not bothered to see the point that, since the Hawke Government has been in power, including last night's announcement, this Government has spent or will spend $7.38 billion on roads. All the talk about local roads and how they have suffered is nonsense.

Throughout my own State at the moment, National Party State members are rushing around saying how road funding is being cut in the local areas. It is simply untrue. The facts are that, for this coming financial year, local road funds have increased by $13.8m. That will bring the total expenditure in this period to $269m, which is an increase in real terms. What this Government has done is ensure that it has a commitment. No-one is happy that there has been a slight reduction-a reduction of some $35m; but we all appreciate that the national road construction program is near completion so there is room for cutting back. There is room for just chipping away at some of that expenditure and putting it into other areas. And what is the Government doing? It is not just putting it back in the coffers. Instead, it is setting up a five-year plan for roads and, as well as that, it is designating a new category-national economic importance roads. I am sure those of us who represent country and rural areas, such as the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron), will be most pleased with this proposition because it means that roads in rural areas, such as the grain roads of central Queensland, the tourism roads of north Queensland and those very important economic roads, can now be dealt with. In the past, the plea came from local authorities, but the Government had to say that it was up to the States. It had to say that a deal was done over a three-year period; and the money was given to the States and they had to spend it within those particular categories-local roads, arterial roads and State and rural arterial roads. They could not just take the money out of one area and put it into these new arterial-type roads, but now they can. So the Government has addressed a fundamental problem in the road systems of Australia. It has ensured that we have an ongoing commitment on roads, a commitment that will go over five years. Yet again, no credit is given where credit is due.

Pensioners represent a very important area. I have stood up in this House on a number of occasions and raised the plight of many pensioners who faced provisional tax. I give credit to the Fraser Government, which in 1978 saw fit to lift the provisional tax threshold from $400 to $1,000 because, at that time, anyone who earned more than $400 from interest or dividends paid provisional tax. It did not matter who the person was. It could be the richest bank manager or corporate leader or a pensioner; and so the Fraser Government saw fit in that Budget to lift the tax free limit, and there has been a drag for a period during which it has not been shifted. But now this Government has taken action to ensure that the 255,000 people who face provisional tax in the next financial year will be protected. The Government has done more than that. It has also ensured that the rebate will be increased. Because of an increase in pensions all the time to make up for what was not done by the previous Liberal-National Party Government, we have seen a deterioration in the rebate value. It is now being shifted from $240 a year to $430.

TALK.START.PARA: —So it should.
—Of course it should, but the coalition did not do those things when it was in government. It froze pensions. It held them back.
—So did you.

—No. If the honourable member looks at the figures today, he will see that under the Liberal-National Party Government pensions were as low as 19 per cent of average weekly earnings. Today they are 25 per cent of average weekly earnings because the Labor Government has a commitment to the aged; we have a commitment to those on fixed incomes and those on low incomes. And so it is true right across the board. Primary industry will benefit from a massive $47m to be spent in the soil conservation programs over a three-year period-something the Liberal-National Party Government never did, something I hear the honourable member for Maranoa applauding because it will help the man on the land. Again, the man on the land will benefit from the income equalisation deposits. The Government realised there was a need for change in the system and, having been restructured, this scheme has been brought back and every rural producer will welcome it.

SPEECH.PARA: I move quickly to superannuation. Unfortunately fears were generated by many of the insurance companies and employers asking what would happen to the poor workers and saying that the Government was going to highly tax superannuation outcomes, especially lump sums. That has not happened. What has happened is a total reversal. Where before people paid 15 per cent tax on the first $55,000 and 30 per cent above that, there is now no tax on the first $60,000 and only 15 per cent tax above $60,000. This will be welcomed by employers, insurance companies and employees alike because now there is an incentive for the employee to get involved in superannuation schemes. There is an incentive for people to start planning for the future.

We face a dilemma, as we all appreciate: we have at the moment one elderly person for every five in the work force. Within 30 years it will be one elderly person for every two in the work force, and who will pay the taxes to provide those age benefits? There simply will not be enough people working in the marketplace. People should plan for their retirement and the superannuation scheme that the Government is now putting forward will help. It will not solve every problem. No-one expects a magic wand approach when we have economic difficulties, but it is a start. It is a philosophy that I believe will be adhered to and will be taken up.

In another area of important social consequence, it is the Liberals and the Nationals who have said that they want to do away with the first home owners scheme. This Government introduced it and has retained it. We now ensure that people with an income of up to $32,000 can still get some assistance to buy their first home. The assistance will be as much as $5,000. So in every area the Government has addressed problems that exist in our community, whether it be for companies, for farmers, for those on low incomes such as pensioners or for the family or the worker. Whilst I expect criticism from the Opposition I believe it is time credit was given. This Government has addressed the problems over a long period of time-over five years of innovative change-because this is the Government that has a strategy and a commitment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hewson Dr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In preparing for this week's mini-Budget, I happened to be reading the autobiography of Sir Arthur Fadden, who was in fact a previous Treasurer in this country, They Called Me Artie. He used a wonderful anecdote about Billy Hughes that I would like to share with the House. When preparing his horror Budget in 1951-52, Fadden used to lock himself in his room at the Hotel Canberra and have meals brought down so that, in his words:

SPEECH.PARA: I can avoid hosts of guests intent on showering me with good advice on how to save the nation.

Apparently, however, Billy Hughes and his wife, Dame Mary, did not take this injunction seriously and used to drop by every evening for dinner. On one particular occasion, Billy apparently put his hand on Fadden's shoulder in a gesture that Fadden said in the book he would never forget and he said:
Brother, you worry too much. Damn the Budget. Angels can't do more than their best. After all you can dress a harlot to look like an innocent bride.

It is funny how that anecdote came to mind in relation to this so-called Budget. I would not be prepared, of course, to suggest that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) is the harlot in that anecdote-that would be unparliamentary-but he is, of course, the `dresser' and he made a very diligent attempt and undertook in a very professional way the marketing of this fairly poor document to dress up his harlot as a bride. The truth is that this is no horror Budget. The challenge for us all is to strip back the clothes and see the extent to which the bride has been tampered with.

In the few minutes that I have tonight I thought I would make just a couple of points in relation to this mini-Budget in an attempt to do just that. The first relates to the very limited assessment by the Treasurer of the state of the economy in this mini-Budget. In fact, there are very few words at all on the economy, the nature of our current economic difficulties; there is no real sense of urgency that I believe the Treasurer should have in our current circumstances. The best way I can demonstrate the fact that this Treasurer is quite out of touch with the current state of our economy is to quote from one of his recent speeches. The same sentiment is echoed in this mini-Budget. The speech in question was made at the recent Premiers Conference. The Treasurer said at the Premiers Conference:

The easy thing for all of us today would be to take in the revenue benefit of the recovery in commodity prices and stronger economic activity and spend it. That is exactly the sort of short-sighted thing Australian Governments-State and Federal-have done in the past. But it is exactly what we must not do this time. We cannot afford to blow this terms of trade improvement on a splurge of imports. We must not slide back into the attitude of mind which assumes that our commodity export base will protect us from the need to change. We must press on with economic restructuring.

I ask honourable members not to let the rhetoric fool them. This is precisely what we have been doing for 12 or 14 months in this country. There is no point, in a statement such as the one made last night, in attempting to shut the stable door, because the horse has already bolted.

Commodity prices have trended up consistently since about mid-1986, in Australian dollar terms. Indeed, commodity prices have increased by about 51 per cent over that period. Our terms of trade have jumped by over 8 per cent in the last year, which, by historical standards, is a very rapid increase, in fact an extremely rapid improvement in the terms of trade. However, if we look at the Treasurer's statements in this House and in recent speeches we see that he has mentioned the `terms of trade' in this sense about 65 times in the last 18 months. On nearly all those occasions-indeed, all but three or four-he has referred to the significant deterioration in our terms of trade in 1984-85. He is still living in the past. He has not yet recognised the extent to which our terms of trade have improved in the last 12 to 15 months. Indeed, if we go to last night's mini-Budget we find the Treasurer saying:
. . . for the immediate future the full force of the Nation's fiscal resources must be devoted to keeping domestic demand in check and dealing with our external debt problem.
This task has been made all the more urgent by the recent evidence that demand has been running too strongly.

That is yet another indication that the Treasurer is out of touch. If we think about it, we should realise that about 12 months ago the Treasurer indeed had a choice. The choice was an implicit one, not an explicit one, and clearly he did not recognise it. When our terms of trade picked up in response to those rises in commodity prices, the Treasurer had a clear choice to take that improvement in the terms of trade solely in our balance of payments, so as to see as big and as significant an improvement in our balance of payments as possible, or to spend it-in terms of his statement to the Premiers Conference. He chose, indeed, to spend it.

In fact, rather than choosing to lag monetary policy, the easing of monetary policy, behind that improvement in our terms of trade, he accelerated the easing of monetary policy over the last 15 months. So he pushed down interest rates and stimulated aggregate demand. Of course, the direct result has been an acceleration in aggregate demand such that the economy is now considerably overheated. As a result, we have had a markedly smaller improvement in our balance of payments than would otherwise have been possible. The Treasurer likes to talk a lot about `economic miracles'. I suggest to the House that that fact, apart from anything else, will be the main reason why he will never reap an `economic miracle' during his political lifetime.

The second area on which I wish to comment, having suggested that the Treasurer has very little appreciation of the current state of our economic difficulties and, indeed, very little real sense of urgency about what needs to be done, is what he says in the Budget about expenditure restraint. For several Budgets in a row we have heard him talk about expenditure restraint. Indeed, he talks about being one of the most successful `restrainers' since Artie Fadden; but he has not, in this economic statement, as in earlier ones, achieved anywhere near the extent of expenditure restraint that he would have us believe.

Of course, if we look at some of the expenditure parameters in the economic statement we are inclined, at first blush, to say that he is on the right track. He talks about a $3 billion surplus in 1988-89. He talks about real outlays falling by 1 1/2 per cent. He talks about the percentage of Commonwealth outlays to gross domestic product falling to about 26 per cent or less. He talks about $1,350m worth of cuts. He promises further cuts in 1988-89. If we do not look too closely, if we do not take the clothes off the bride too quickly, we may be swayed by what he is saying. However, if we have a good look at what has gone on there we will see that there has indeed been very little expenditure restraint. For example, the $1,350m worth of cuts to which he referred are gross cuts. He has also increased his own expenditure by about $380m. Therefore, we are really looking at net cuts of only $982m; and of that, $870m is cuts imposed on the States. Indeed, the Treasurer's restraint of his own expenditure is minimal.

However, it is worse than that because if we really do peel back the clothes and have a good look at the nature of the harlot we find that, in fact, he has cooked the books. I gather that one of the Treasurer's favourite parlour games is the thimble and pea trick. He certainly has three thimbles, but he has no pea.

TALK.START.PARA: —You said that last year.

—That is right. I was right then and I am right again. The Treasurer definitely has cooked the books by changing the basis on which he has recorded certain transactions in this statement. In fact, he is reasonably open about the extent to which he has cooked the books.

SPEECH.PARA: Basically, he has done three things which I draw to the attention of the House. Firstly, there are certain primary industry charges and levies and light dues and Navigation Act receipts which were previously classified as offsets to outlays. Of course, now they are being classified as revenue. Secondly, discounts and premiums on treasury bonds, which have always been classified as financing transactions, have now been shifted to outlays. The effect of those two changes alone is to raise significantly the 1987-88 base expenditure estimate compared with those for 1988-89. Therefore, the Treasurer creates for himself, if you like, a nice neat cut in expenditure by that one particular change. Of course, over and above that, he perpetuates the illusion by moving at least one other major item `off Budget'. The Civil Aviation Authority has been shifted `off Budget' from 1 July this year. That will reduce outlays in 1988-89 by another $270m. The interesting thing is that, if we adjust for some of those changes, if we take those accounting changes and reverse them and put it back on the old basis, we get a feeling of how--

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbery.

—The honourable member has reminded me-a feeling of how rubbery those figures, indeed, are. Of course, the Treasurer's real expenditure decline of 1 1/2 per cent, as claimed in the document, becomes only half that amount, only a 0.7 or 0.8 per cent real expenditure decline. But if we also exclude from that the cuts imposed on the States-something which we should really do if, in fact, we want to get a realistic figure of Commonwealth expenditure restraint-we see that the Commonwealth's own expenditure actually goes up in real terms. This should not come as any surprise to honourable members because the Treasurer has over and over again, on the Goebbels principle, simply by repeating it, tried to create the illusion of expenditure restraint. That is the basis on which he claims to have brought about a balanced Budget and now, more recently, a Budget surplus.

SPEECH.PARA: However, the facts are very clear: he has done it all entirely by revenue. On his figures he will have picked up about $7.5 billion in additional revenue over expenditure. That is roughly equal to the amount to which the Budget deficit has moved, from the $4.5 billion when he came to office to his prospective surplus next year of $3 billion. Indeed, he has done it all by increasing taxation, mostly taxation by stealth, mostly through bracket creep. Unfortunately, the Treasurer has not yet been prepared to come clean with the Australian people and declare, legitimately, the little extent to which he has been able to restrain expenditure.

Just to summarise: what does all this say? The simple fact is that the Treasurer currently has a very difficult set of circumstances in Australia. The economy is over-heating. The world is moving to a period of much more difficult trading circumstances in which activity will flatten out and commodity prices will fall. We are in very real danger of what I call `the old Aussie crunch', sustaining our import demand against falling world activity and falling commodity prices.

In my view, there is a real risk of a major balance of payments crisis in the course of the next 12 months. On that basis this Treasurer's chickens will come home to roost. At that point he will have locked himself into a `soft' wages policy and a `soft' fiscal policy. So he will have to go back to relying on monetary policy. I suggest to the House that, in the course of the next 12 months, there will be sizeable hikes in interest rates as the Treasurer, as a last resort, resorts to a further tightening of monetary policy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Mr S.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a great pleasure to follow in the debate tonight an honourable member so learned in economics as the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson). However, I find a great deal of difficulty in following the logic of his argument in regard to a number of specific areas to which I would like to refer before he leaves. I shall come back to that shortly.

SPEECH.PARA: What was presented by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) last night was one of the most far-reaching and sweeping economic statements-a blueprint for the future of this economy-that we have seen for many years. I implore people in the community not just to take at face value some of the information that is being peddled to them, particularly by honourable members opposite, but to look at the underlying criteria behind the economic statement. Clearly it is a blueprint for future economic growth and for the development of the Australian economy to take us into the twenty-first century. It is designed to rid us of the shackles that have been imposed on Australia's economic development and growth over the last 20 or 30 years, many of which unfortunately were put in place by those sad remnants of the Country Party in this place and which were tolerated by the Liberals because of weak leadership in the past-weak leadership that was unwilling, unbending and not sustaining any changes that were necessary, particularly in tariff reductions.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have had five years!

—The honourable member for Adelaide sings out about five years. What did members opposite do when they had at least seven years under the former Prime Minister, Mr Malcolm Fraser, when the present Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) was in charge of the Treasury finances? It is quite easy to come into this place and say, `You have had five years'. Those opposite had seven years; what did they do about tariffs? Mr Deputy Speaker, you would know, because you were here during that time, that absolutely nothing was done for tariffs. This Government has taken the hard decisions in that respect, but it has done so in equity, with a sense of fairness, and is phasing in what has been proposed.

SPEECH.PARA: What about some of these other parts of the broad economic strategy? The honourable member for Wentworth talked about the Government having cooked the books. It is the same sort of line that gets fed up here. It used to be the line of the former shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton), when he was in the job. I recall the honourable member for Wentworth and some other honourable members on that side of the House last year when the Budget was delivered giving exactly the same speech, saying the books had been cooked. If anybody cooked the books, what did the Leader of the Opposition do in 1982 when he was the Treasurer of this country? He went to an election telling everybody, `No problems, folks. The deficit? No worries!' We came into government and immediately found a $10 billion deficit. Over five years we not only eliminated that, but a $3 billion surplus is in prospect through the economic statement delivered last night. And the Opposition is trying to tell us we have cooked the books!

I find it difficult to appreciate the logic of the argument that is often advanced by the so-called economic geniuses on the other side of the House. It just does not wash; it does not stand up in the light of day and is not sustained in thorough examination by those people who understand exactly what this country needs. What this country certainly needs is the economic policies that have been put forward by the Government at this point of time.

I am also concerned about the constant calls and echoes from that side of the House about cutting deeper. Members of the Opposition say that what we have to do to save this nation is to cut government expenditure. Honourable members on the other side of the House today heard the Treasurer's response to a question about further cuts, and the Treasurer said, `You tell us where there should be further cuts'. We said that last year-`tell us where there should be further cuts'. What are we supposed to do-get rid of the Department of Veterans' Affairs? That seems to be on the Opposition's policy agenda. What about the rest of those massive cuts which were talked about by the Business Council of Australia and which the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), the shadow Treasurer, said were not enough? He says, `Let's get into it and cut a bit more away'. When are we going to see some policies which clearly spell out where those opposite would cut and from what direction they believe they could still fund the tax cuts they talk about?

That leads us into a consideration of other areas; firstly, the tax cuts. We heard today the Leader of the Opposition respond to the Treasurer. I found it hard to believe, but he said, `Last year we said we would abolish the capital gains tax'-during the election campaign he said it would be thrown out the door-`but now we are not going to do that; we have reconsidered; we will keep it'. He has said that the Liberal Party of Australia would get rid of Labor's fringe benefits tax. Tonight he said, `We will get rid of Labor's fringe benefits tax but we will put in a Liberal fringe benefits tax instead'.

What happened to lock, stock and barrel? I know it sounds like a firm of solicitors but last year the Leader of the Opposition said that the Liberal Party would get rid of Labor's taxes lock, stock and barrel. All members of the Opposition used to call out in unison, `Lock, stock and barrel'. What happened tonight? Where were the cheers from the Opposition? All I saw was a lot of glum faces when that was mentioned tonight. Has the Opposition come around to believing that in that regard the Government was correct? I believe it must have.

A couple of very important parts of the statement handed down last night pertained to, firstly, the boost to the tourism industry and, secondly, the upgrading of the tax file numbers. I shall concentrate on those two points for the moment and then return to one or two other comments on the general views held by members of the Opposition. With regard to the boost to the tourism industry, clearly the Government has made the right decision by cutting the departure tax and at the same time eliminating the processing fee relating to immigration. I do not think anybody in this House who saw that in operation would agree that that was a fair and reasonable way to encourage tourism into this country. But a hallmark of this Government is that it is not afraid to face up to its responsibilities, and when a decision is taken that subsequently is shown to be incorrect and needs modification, the Government does something about it. I have said that before when I have spoken on taxation Bills. The Opposition says, `Why modify it? Why don't you think through the legislation?'. This Government does not mind doing that if it will lead to a fairer outcome. That is exactly what happened. I applaud the decision. I hope the boosts to the tourism industry in this country are extended and I look forward to seeing an immediate improvement in that area.

The other issue was the proposal to upgrade the tax file number system. It is interesting that only last week a committee of the Parliament, the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration--

TALK.START.PARA: —Who chairs that Committee?

—I happen to chair that Committee-handed down a report of the inquiry into a series of efficiency audits into the Australian Taxation Office. The Committee made a unanimous recommendation-I underline the word `unanimous' because that means both Liberal and National Party members on the Committee agreed to it-that there should be an upgraded tax file numbering system applied in the Australian Taxation Office. I was particularly pleased that that recommendation was included as part of last night's economic statement. I do not think one honourable member-there should not be in any case-believes people should not contribute their fair share, no more and certainly no less, to the Australian tax system because it pays for the services the Federal Governments must pay for.

SPEECH.PARA: In the inquiry the Committee conducted into a variety of taxation areas, evidence collected suggested that an upgraded tax file numbering system would be effective in combating tax evasion and avoidance. The Committee suggested that it be taken a step further but unfortunately the Government has not seen fit to do so at this stage. However, I will be monitoring the situation very closely; it was a great decision. I congratulate the honourable member for Wentworth because he also was a member of that Committee. I was sorry that he did not mention that in his contribution a little earlier.

In summary, I have to say that tonight's response by the Leader of the Opposition to the Treasurer's statement was one of the most limp-wristed, ineffectual approaches to policy I have heard. Not since his response to the Treasurer's Budget Speech last year can I recall such a poor response by the Leader of the Opposition. We are still waiting to hear the Liberal Party's announcement of its policies in a variety of areas. The Treasurer and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) have said they are willing to debate at length any of those policy areas, particularly taxation. We have yet to hear the policies. Last night this Government was prepared to make some magnificent decisions in terms of taxation policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where are the tax cuts?

—It foreshadowed personal tax cuts in the future-and they will be introduced-but it is interesting to note that members of the Opposition equate economic development with personal tax cuts. They should get their priorities right.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Before calling the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer), on this special occasion this evening I offer all my colleagues on both sides of the House best wishes for their much awaited move to the new House. I take this opportunity to thank the Clerks of the House for their support in the work that my colleagues and I do in the chair. I am sure that many people understand that the smooth workings of this chamber can be very much attributed to the work of the Clerks. In particular, I acknowledge Madam Speaker, Mrs Child, the Deputy Speaker, Mr Leo McLeay, and the very good advice and support from people such as the honourable member for Wide Bay, Mr Millar, the honourable member for Lyne, Mr Cowan, my colleague the honourable member for Banks, Mr Mountford, and other chairmen of committees. I am sure that all honourable members would share my view that they contribute to the smooth operation of the chamber.

INTERJECT.PARA: I also acknowledge the work of the Hansard staff, the attendants in the chamber and the Sergeant-at-Arms in supporting the work of this chamber, along with the Clerks, whose work I mentioned previously. I am sure that honourable members will join me in acknowledging the support of the attendants, who are always most cooperative no matter how late the hour, the Hansard staff, who are very accurate and diligent in their work, the Serjeant-at-Arms and the Clerks.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the ABC.
—And the ABC, which covers the proceedings very effectively and efficiently. We look forward to joining them as well in the new Parliament House.
—And the members of the public.
—We are all impressed at the diligence and concentration of the members of the public, even at twenty minutes to 11.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly endorse your remarks, Mr Deputy Speaker, and indicate that it is with some sorrow that I make my last speech in this building, having first come here as a tiny baby in my father's arms when he was a member of this Parliament after having been elected in 1949. Having listened to the rhetoric of the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin), I must say that it reminds me very much of Disraeli's famous statement of his political opponents that they were `inebriated by the exuberance of their own verbosity'. The honourable member for Macarthur, who was most certainly that, did not succeed in refuting any of the propositions put forward by this side of the House.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable members on this side are really saying that the challenge of this mini-Budget and the yardstick by which it must be measured is twofold. First, it must do something to reverse the tragic decline in living standards that we have had in this country over the past five years. We are such a potentially rich country and such a potentially successful country with all our natural resources. How can it be, while so many parts of the world have been booming in this period, that our people have suffered a decline in their living standards? The second thing that the mini-Budget must do is contribute to the urgently needed restructuring of the Australian economy. It is by those two yardsticks that we must judge the document presented by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) last night.

Let us look at the issue of living standards. What has the Government done to improve the living standards of ordinary men and women, and indeed children, in Australia? It has done, as many others before me have said, absolutely nothing. In fact, it could be described in a rather pejorative way as nothing more than a boardroom budget, because all the benefits of the Budget will go to the boardrooms of big companies, particularly through lower company tax. I do not oppose that, but none of the benefits go to the pockets of the ordinary men, women and children of this country. In that regard I would have thought that it was a gross inequity, an inequity that would cause the predecessors of members of the Australian Labor Party to turn in their graves. It is an inequity which is completely unacceptable to the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia.

Since 1983 we have seen in this country a decline in the living standards of the single income family with two children, which is a fairly usual sort of circumstance, of $42 a week. That is a shameful thing in a country which is so rich and so potentially successful. That is why so often members of this Party and the National Party have spoken of the `forgotten people'. It is why Menzies spoke of them in 1949, because the Chifley Government also forgot them. The Labor Government of today has forgotten the ordinary men and women of Australia even as it turns to the boardrooms and the executive rooms of the trade union movement.

We are told that the tax cuts will come one day. I have noticed how members of the Labor Party taunt us to tell them and the Australian public details of our tax cut proposals when they will not do the same thing. They say that there will be tax cuts one day, maybe, if the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) is prepared to agree with what the Government would like. But if the ACTU does not go in the right direction, that is it. By postponing the tax cuts which ordinary Australians deserve, the Government is saving $1,500m.

While the Government saves and pockets all this money, the community, the ordinary people of Australia, end up paying. During the next 12-month period their tax burden will increase by around 12 per cent above what it would have been if taxes had been fairly and reasonably indexed by this mini-Budget. That means, in terms of average earnings, about $13.60 a week is taken out of the pocket of the Australian wage earner. I am sure that the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous) would blush to hear that there is plenty for the boardrooms and plenty, no doubt, for the ACTU. But what about the average family in Australia-the people about whom honourable members opposite have never been genuinely concerned?

The tax burden on the income of the average Australian will increase over the next year from 24.2 per cent of income to 25.2 per cent. The Treasurer argues that we cannot have tax cuts now because that will create a balance of payments crisis. His logic is patently false. If we were to follow his argument through to its logical conclusion he would really be saying that our balance of payment crisis can be solved by increasing taxes. As a matter of fact, that seems to be what the Government has been doing. Since 1983 it has been progressively increasing the burden of taxation in Australia. It thinks that that will solve the balance of payments crisis, but the evidence is there for everybody to see: the balance of payments situation has got progressively worse, not better, throughout that period.

The second aspect of the Government's argument that we have to increase tax to solve our balance of payments crisis is that it has actually reduced company tax. Does that mean that it will exacerbate the balance of payments crisis or that, somehow or other, reducing company tax is immune from the whole argument? Mr Deputy Speaker, I know that you will agree with me that that does not make a great deal of sense.

Thirdly, it is wrong to say that, by reducing taxation, we will create a balance of payments crisis. If we reduce taxation and at the same time reduce government expenditure, that will not lead to an increase in overall domestic demand in the economy; it will redistribute wealth-that is a phrase that the honourable member for Calwell doubtless uses from time to time in his electorate-away from the bureaucracy, politicians and government and back into the pockets of ordinary people. They are the people whom I suspect that the Labor Party never really cared about, but they have certainly been forgotten if it ever did.

Let us consider whether this mini-Budget addresses the issue of structural change. First of all, does it reduce the size of government? Ninety per cent of the so-called reduction in spending in this mini-Budget has been borne by the States. The Commonwealth has made a paltry contribution yet again. So there is a certain falsity about the claims of the Treasurer and others on the other side of the House that they have done a magnificent job in reducing spending. They have not; they have just chopped off funding to the States.

Secondly, as the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson) pointed out, there is some shonky figuring. The honourable member for Macarthur never refuted this. He used a bit of rhetoric but he never refuted it. The fact is that in this mini-Budget the Government has increased the outlays for 1987-88-if one looks at page 26 of the document one will see how-by $974m. The Treasurer admits that. He says the Government will increase the outlays this year. What does that mean? That means that when we compare the overall outlays this year with next year's outlays a rabbit comes out of the hat and somehow we find a decline in outlays. But remember that the Government has increased the outlays for this year by nearly $1 billion in the first place to achieve that result. The simple proposition is that in presenting the Government's Budget last September the Treasurer claimed that outlays would decline by 2.4 per cent this financial year. Obviously, they will not do that if the Government adds another one billion dollars to outlays through the accounting practices of this mini-Budget.

Another aspect of the structural change in this mini-Budget is the tariff reform. I know that the honourable member for Calwell does not agree with this because I have listened to his speeches now for three years. He does not agree with what the Government has done, but I do. I think the Government has done the right thing. I am glad that it has reduced business taxes; I only wish that it had done more for ordinary people.

The third aspect of structural change is labour market reform. Labour market reform is fundamental to achieving proper structural adjustment in our economy. To achieve it there has to be a more flexible system of wage fixing. That is only commonsense. There have to be secret ballots so that ordinary workers decide whether there should be industrial disputation, not union bosses and leaders. Voluntary unionism has to be introduced. We on this side of the House are serious in our commitment to civil liberties, even if honourable members opposite are not.

The fourth aspect of structural change is privatisation. Why has the Labor Government strangled Qantas Airways Ltd, Australian Airlines and the Commonwealth Banking Corporation? They cannot raise any more money without borrowing enormously. If they borrow enormously and become highly geared and there is a downturn in their industries, those companies will be in dire difficulty. Privatisation, as the Treasurer, the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) know, is the only future for these companies, and they have ducked the decision for ideological reasons.

This mini-Budget is characterised by four features. Firstly, it has a few positives, which I have mentioned. Secondly, it is full of shonky accounting in order to achieve what the business community might perceive to be good outcomes. But if one sits down and reads the fine details one will see how the accounting is done. Thirdly, the Government has ducked nearly all the major structural change issues, and that needs to be debated much more fully in the community. The Labor Party, which always claims to represent the workers, the ordinary people, has, as usual, as it did with the Chifley Government and the Whitlam Government-we can go right back to John Christian Watson; it was doing it in those days as well-is never really interested in ordinary people. It turns its back on them, as it has done this time. A board room budget is fine, but what about ordinary Australians? There are no tax cuts for them. They have $13 a week more to pay next year. But there are plenty of tax cuts for the rich mates of the Prime Minister and the Treasurer-not a pretty story.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the few minutes left to me I would like to make one comment about the contribution of the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer). He is a young man and he has a hell of a lot to learn. He will be an old man before that group on the other side sits on the Government benches, if the performance of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) and his statements on the economy are anything to go by. Let me say one thing about the performance of the Leader of the Opposition. In a throwaway line he said, `These policies are not really the policies of the New Right'. Honourable members may have picked that up when he was making his speech. If these are not the policies of the New Right then he cannot even read, because his whole speech was nothing more than a document of the extreme New Right in this country. While the Opposition persists in putting this New Right nonsense before the Australian people, the Australian Labor Party will continue to govern. The Australian people are not interested in extremist nonsense of the kind which was peddled here tonight by the Leader of the Opposition.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I take a point of order under standing order 82 which prohibits tedious repetition in this place. I listened to the honourable member make this sort of tirade against the New Right only the other night in an equally irrelevant way. He is continuing to do so tonight.
—I know that the honourable member for Berowra has an excellent memory, but in terms of tonight's debate the honourable member for Calwell is in order.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, those kinds of irrelevant points of order are intended only to take up my time. Honourable members opposite do not want to hear what I have to say, so they try to interrupt what I am saying to the Australian people. Anyone who listened earlier to the speech of the Leader of the Opposition would have heard an extraordinary statement. There is a long list of assets to be sold off. There will not be anything left. Every government enterprise will be sold off. He had the nerve to say, `We're going to protect country people's telephone calls. We're going to sell Telecom, but we'll protect their telephone calls'. What rubbish!
—Mr Hawke wants to sell things; Mr Keating wants to sell them.

—Obviously the honourable member has not followed the debate in the Labor Party. If he had done so he would know that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has made a specific statement excluding Telecom Australia and all those other those enterprises from any kind of privatisation. Let us make it perfectly clear: wholesale privatisation is out. It is not the policy of the Labor Party and it is certainly not the policy which the Australian people will support.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Berowra (Dr Harry Edwards) insists that the proposals put forward by the Leader of the Opposition have nothing to do with the New Right. Of course they do. But the big difference between his proposals and those of the New Right's upfront spokesman is that the New Right is more honest. This week Andrew Hay said, `We want to cut welfare; we want to cut social security; we want to cut unemployment benefits; we want to cut education; we want to cut health'. What does the Leader of the Opposition say? After all of the cuts of the last few years, he says, `There haven't been enough cuts to programs'. He wants more cuts. The honourable member for Mayo and all of his other supporters have the impertinence to say that, after all of those cuts have been affected, people's standards of living will go up. What rubbish! What do they think provides people's standard of living? It is basic programs. If those programs are cut, obviously people's standards of living will be affected.

It is hypocritical nonsense for the Leader of the Opposition to say that he wants more and more cuts and that he will then try to offer tax cuts. It is not an honest approach of saying, `We won't have a surplus of $3 billion'. That would have been an honest approach. Instead, he says that he would have a surplus of $3 billion, offer tax cuts by making more cuts to Government spending and at the same time improve everyone's standards of living. If he is not Mandrake the magician, who is he? It is economic nonsense, and he knows that it is. The honourable member for Berowra knows that when one cuts programs, one cuts people's standards of living. The honourable member for Mayo knows this as well. If they are really honest in their claims that they want to help the average family, they should stop talking about all of these cuts that they will make and start formulating a decent policy. If they are not honest in their claims, they should not pretend to be the champions of the average person.

If average Australians believe that the Liberal Party of Australia supports the average family, they must believe that the devil is an angel. There is no question about the Liberal Party's stance. It stands for the policies of the New Right, for entrenched wealth. The honourable member for Mayo mentioned redistribution. It stands for redistribution in favour of the wealthy. The interruptions are not making an impact because the fact is that the honourable members opposite do not represent the ordinary people. The Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Mayo and others should not come in here with their hypocritical comments.

This mini-Budget has been an important historical event in terms of the positive measures that have been put into place to restructure the Australian economy, to create employment and to put into place a vast array of measures that will assist the building of Australia in the future. Opposition members do not like the fact that there has been no such comprehensive approach for many years in this country to tackle the economic problems which they refused to tackle. In August next year we will be putting into place further programs that will assist the Australian people. We will then be going to the polls ready to take the Opposition on and expose it for what it is.
Debate (on motion by Mr Miles) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: DEPARTURE TAX AMENDMENT BILL 1988[COGNATE BILLS:DEPARTURE TAX COLLECTIONAMENDMENT BILL 1988MIGRATION AMENDMENT BILL 1988]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 25 May, on motion by Mr Peter Morris:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that it has been agreed that there will be a cognate debate on the Departure Tax Amendment Bill 1988, the Departure Tax Collection Amendment Bill 1988 and the Migration Amendment Bill 1988. There being no objection, I shall allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —In 1984 the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) promised in the election campaign to `destroy for all time the myth that the ALP is the party of high taxation'. Following that announcement the Prime Minister and his Treasurer (Mr Keating) have successively increased the taxes paid by Australians. Senator Cook may have been more honest when he said in 1985:

SPEECH.PARA: The Labor Party is a high taxing party. It needs to be to carry out its reform. The question is how you levy that and who pays it.

Those statements were made by two key figures in the Australian Labor Party. Tonight we are debating the removal of what must be the most obnoxious tax this country has ever seen. The Australian Government decided to charge people a fee when they become Australian citizens and then levied a tax on those citizens when they wished to return to their own country. The arrival tax that the Departure Tax Amendment Bill dispenses with has in the short few months it has been in operation proved obnoxious and created great resistance and resentment not only amongst Australian citizens but also amongst visitors to this country.

There are three pieces of legislation before the House that we are debating cognately. The first, as I mentioned, removes the arrival tax of $10. The second, the Departure Tax Collection Amendment Bill, reduces the departure tax from $25 to $10. The reduction is not to take effect from the night of the mini-Budget but from 1 July this year. The Government will continue to make its charges to prove its point about how incapable it is of managing simple affairs such as people coming to and going from Australia. The Migration Amendment Bill changes the powers of officers under the Immigration Act.

I pay tribute tonight to the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp) for the crusade and campaign he has run against the arrival tax. He has worked hard and long on behalf of the tourist industry and on behalf of Australian citizens. He has consistently put to the Government the inequities of its proposals that were introduced in the last Budget and implemented on 1 January. By the end of January the airlines had found that 38 per cent of the travelling public had refused to pay the arrival tax. A total of 96,000 people had refused in one month to pay this terrible tax. There is a Budget loss in the process and it is interesting to go through the Hansard the Senate Estimates Committees and find that an officer of the Department, Mr McMahon, told the senators that the latest estimate that he could give on 14 April suggests that, compared to a Budget estimate of $8m, the likely outcome for the arrival tax was only going to be $7.4m. That is the scale of the loss of refusal, resentment and resistance by the travelling public. Then we find that instead of being a cost recovery process, as this matter was proclaimed to be when it was introduced, all funds raised from the arrival tax go directly to Consolidated Revenue. I will quote Mr McMahon from page D12 of Senate Estimates Committee D on 14 April. Senator Peter Baume asked:
Does the immigration fee, once collected, remain as part of the Department's budget?
Mr McMahon stated:
The immigration clearance fee goes straight into Consolidated Revenue.

So much for the cost recovery process that this was supposed to provide when it was introduced to cover the cost of issuing visas. It went straight off to the Treasury. I do not know whether there was going to be any reconciliation in the Budget. We will see whether the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs gets back the money it collected by an increase of that amount in its allocation. I would be very surprised if that were the case. There will be a notional allocation, but the Budget will not change beyond what was proposed and what is being considered at this point in Forward Estimates. There has been a Budget loss by this process of approximately $34.4m in the departure tax and a loss also to revenue from the arrival tax.

I believe that this Government will get that money in another way. I believe that the airlines will finish up by paying it. The Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Holding) nods in agreement. There will be an increase in cost to the travelling public because the airlines are going to have to pay these fees either by landing charges or by route costs. Some way or another the Government will recoup this money from the airlines. So the Australian travelling public will pay, but it will not be the obnoxious tax of Aussies paying to get back into their own country. That will be some relief anyway. I think that that was a completely dishonest approach by the Government. It is unfair and unheard of to have citizens charged for arriving back in their own country. I was surprised when the Government introduced it. The furore that this tax caused is best illustrated by statements from the Australian Tourism Industry Association Ltd. On 24 March, it stated:
Australia is experiencing millions of dollars in bad publicity due to the $5 Immigration Processing Fee being levied at international airports.

Australia is a favoured port for travellers. Mr Frank O'Dwyer, the committee chairman of the airlines group that had negotiated with the Government, has had great difficulty in getting the complicated wheels of government bureaucracy-not necessarily the Minister, but the bureaucracy-to understand the dreadful damage that this apparently simple thing was causing to the operation of the airlines. The airlines said, `We will do anything to cooperate with the Department in collecting this fee, but you have got to change the processes that you have taken'.

In the few minutes I have remaining I want to deal briefly with the other changes to the Migration Act concerning the powers of officers. To the Opposition they seem to be reasonable. There is no objection on our part. However, I do express some concern on the level of illegal immigration. I trust that the removal of these powers will not damage the detection and apprehension of illegal immigrants and that the powers of search, arrest and capacity to interview that officers of the Department have are not taken away from significant officers who, for human rights' sake, may have their capacity to apprehend reduced.

There is real concern out there in the community about the level of illegal immigrants in Australia. The Department now says that there are perhaps 75,000 in Australia-perhaps increasing at the rate of 14,000 a year. It is a very high level for a country such as Australia. The inability of departmental officers to apprehend more than 2,300 in a year-2,379 to be exact-is a matter of concern. Only a small percentage of those who stay on illegally are apprehended. That is a matter of real concern, and until this situation is dealt with and illegal immigration is prevented the support for a significant immigration flow will be weakened.

I understand the computer systems that will assist in the apprehension of illegal immigrants are not completely operative. As I understand it, that system would allow applications for visas to be entered on line to computers in Australia that will check people as they arrive and as they leave. According to departmental statements made before committees, as best as I can read between the lines, those systems are not fully operative. There has been talk about them for three or more years, but they are not working as they should be. This is urgent action that we believe the Government should take to allay the fears of the Australian community. We will not oppose any of these measures. We endorse the decision to remove that dreadful arrival tax; we endorse the decision to reduce the obnoxious departure tax to a reasonable level; and we do not oppose the other measures in the Bill. Again, I commend the honourable member for Gilmore for his work in this area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The airport arrival tax of $5, or the immigration clearance fee, as it is sometimes described, was introduced in 1987. Section 34a of the Migration Act of 1958 rendered passengers, except children under 12, liable to pay the $5 fee-and obliges the airlines to collect it. Furthermore, airlines are required to pay the fee to the Federal Government in respect of liable passengers, whether or not the airline operator has collected that amount for the passenger. The Minister for Transport and Communications Support (Mr Peter Morris) said in his second reading speech that the fee:

SPEECH.PARA: was modelled on the clearance fee operating in the United States of America, and required adult passengers on international flights seeking to enter Australia after 1 January 1988 to pay a fee for the services relating to their immigration clearance. The scheme provides for the fee to be collected, and paid to the Commonwealth, by the international airline operator who brought the passengers to Australia, whether or not the airline collected the fee.

Revenue collected from fees is estimated to be $8 1/2m for the period 1 January 1988 to 30 June 1988. This money will be used to offset the costs of immigration inspection at airports; costs relating to passengers refused entry; costs of facilities to detect fraudulent immigration documents; salaries and other costs of airport staff; costs of visa issue; maintenance of movement records and alert lists of undesirable entrants; and general administrative overheads.

Prior to the introduction of the fee, Australian taxpayers met the full cost of such clearances, and the costs for such services have been escalating dramatically with the ever-increasing numbers of people arriving in Australia. For example, 2.9 million passengers arrived in Australia in 1985-86; 3.3 million more passengers arrived in 1986-87. But the collection of the fee met with much resistance from the international airlines operating in the Australian market. Rather than cooperate with the Government in administering the fee charged, they endeavoured as much as possible to ensure that the collection of such charges was made unworkable. These international airlines were prepared to let the Australian taxpayer shell out more than $18m per annum to provide a service used exclusively by passenger arrivals from whom the international airlines profited handsomely.

From a balanced point of view, the international airlines completely ignored the great majority of Australians who either have no wish for or cannot afford overseas trips. The opposition of the international airlines was even more extraordinary in that this kind of service fee is not unique to Australia. For example, a similar charge is payable and collected by airlines flying passengers to the United States of America. The airlines heatedly suggested that the clearance fee had an adverse affect on tourism into Australia. The answer to that nonsense from the airlines is that passenger arrivals have continued to increase and, secondly, a foreign tourist paying hundreds, or perhaps thousands, of dollars for a flight ticket and carrying similar amounts in travellers cheques will not be deterred from visiting Australia because of the $5 airport arrival fee.

The International Air Transport Association demanded that the Australian Government remove its $5 airport arrival tax. It objected to the Australian Government charging international airlines 60 per cent of quarantine service costs which are designed to prevent foreign diseases, insects or plants being brought illegally into Australia. The President of the Australian Board of Airline Representatives, Mr Frank O'Dwyer, was incessant in his complaints concerning the $5 airport arrival tax. Quarantine, health, immigration and Customs concerns were not his. There was a campaign mounted through the Australian media protesting against the tax. Members of the Liberal and National parties scurried to the media complaining bitterly that the $5 airport arrival tax would spell the death of Australia's burgeoning tourist industry. Editorial after editorial, news release after news release, condemned the tax. The West Australian of 18 April 1988 urged as follows:

The Federal Government should admit that its $5 airport arrival fee was a mistake and scrap it. Although it was born out of the essentially sound user-pays philosophy, the $5 entrance fee was hastily introduced without proper regard for the inconvenience and disruption it would cause.
The problem is not so much with the amount-most airline passengers would have little difficulty finding the extra money-but that it exists at all.
The idea of paying a fee to re-enter one's own country is bad enough, but consider the impression it gives tourists-particularly in view of the poor state of most Australian Airports.
Even the Mercury, in its editorial of 19 April 1988, had this to say:

The Federal Minister for Tourism, Senator Graham Richardson, who appears to be as adept at measuring public feeling as he is at counting numbers in Caucus, yesterday said that the tax was bringing derision on this country from overseas visitors.
The Senator said the tax had not affected the numbers of visitors, only their perception of Australia. And in tourism perception can be worth millions.
If visitors perceive Australia to be pettily greedy then they will go home and tell their friends and neighbours. Word-of-mouth advertising of that nature can cost millions of dollars to counter.

The goodwill generated through Australian movies and international sporting events such as grand prix racing and the America's Cup can be dissipated in days. For what? The chance to gouge an extra $5 from an international visitor who has come to this country to spend hundreds, perhaps thousands of dollars.

Not 50 days had passed in 1988 when Senator Richardson announced in the Senate that the new $5 arrival tax `had had an effect on the tourist industry' and that he had `received complaints from airlines'. In late February this year the Federal Government agreed to review its $5 airport arrival tax. The imposition of the charge also generated a public furore in the airline and tourist industries. Not only did the furore come from genuine objectors to the charge but others seeking political advantage joined in the chorus of protest. One such individual, the Chairman of the Australian Tourism Industry Association, is reported to have said:

Putting charges on the arrival and departure of tourists is like singling out the performing export industries and then taxing them in a discriminatory manner so that their competitive edge is eroded.

Obviously the Government did not take these protests seriously. The Government saw through them for what they were-a political stunt. Honourable members will recall that it was on 24 October 1978 that the Liberal-National Party Government introduced a $10 departure tax. Later the Liberal-National Party Government doubled the departure tax to $20, yet there was not a squeak of protest from the Queensland Tourist and Travel Corporation or the Australian Tourism Industry Association. I am sure honourable members share my view that much of the protest against the arrival tax was politically motivated, as was industry silence when the Liberal-National Party Government introduced the departure tax.

Now, as a result of the amendments contained in this Bill the $5 airport arrival tax or immigration clearance fee is to be repealed with effect from 1 July 1988. The estimated loss of revenue to the Government or more accurately to the Australian taxpayer over the next three financial years brought about by these changes will be almost $50m. This revenue shortfall must be made up from other sources-and made up it must be. The Australian taxpayer demands no less. It is hard to fathom why the charge or fee was introduced in the first place. It should have been obvious that the charge would have been an irritant to the international visitors Australia is trying to welcome and that there had to be better ways of raising revenue. International airlines operating in the Australian market protested about the charge. They even mounted a High Court of Australia challenge as to the validity of the charge and their obligation to administer the collection of the charge. But the Federal Government has finally relented and the charge is to be abolished.

The abolition of the $5 arrival tax and the reduction in the rate of the departure tax from $20 to $10 has been welcomed by virtually every section of the tourist industry. Australia now has an annual turnover of $25 billion from the tourist industry, one-third of which eventually ends up in the pockets of Federal, State or local government. The abolition of the $5 arrival tax will not mean any difference to the perception I believe overseas visitors have of this country, but certainly the squeaky voices in the tourism industry, and particularly those motivated by political stunts, will have achieved their objective of burdening the Australian community with an additional $50m over the next three years.

Finally, the Bill contains provisions which enable the Minister to exclude certain officers and classes of officers from exercising specific powers-for example, the power to validly issue an entry permit to a person seeking entry to Australia. The Minister, in his second reading speech, referred to additional powers which can presently be exercised by even the most junior officers of the Department irrespective of their duties or responsibilities. Clearly this situation cannot be allowed to continue. It is essential that only officers authorised by the Minister should have the power, for example, validly to issue an entry permit to a person seeking entry to Australia or to arrest a person suspected of being a prohibited non-citizen or search aircraft or ships for stowaways or persons suspected of seeking to enter Australia illegally.

Mr Deputy Speaker, this may well be my last speech in this chamber. I would like to thank the staff of the Department of the House of Representatives for the courtesy extended to me at all times to enable me to discharge my duties on behalf of the people of the electorate of Herbert.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sharp Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) and the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay) for their restraint tonight in keeping their speeches down to 10 minutes each. Like other members, this will be the last occasion that I will speak in this old provisional Parliament House. But I can think of no more appropriate a note to go out on than to go out on speaking about the demise of the arrival tax. This is a victory for the Opposition which we have fought very hard on. It is one which, as a result of our efforts and the efforts of people throughout the industry, has seen the scrapping of one of the most ridiculous taxes that any government, not only in Australia but throughout the world, could have possibly conceived. We have championed the cause against the arrival tax. We have been assisted by people such as Mr Frank O'Dwyer from the Australian Board of Airline Representatives and Mr Peter O'Clery from the Australian Tourist Industry Association and from the broader tourist industry and airline industry, and indeed we have been most ably assisted by those passengers departing from our international airports throughout Australia this year. We have been assisted by those people purely and simply because this tax has been well recognised as being one of the most ill-conceived, poorly thought out and poorly designed taxes ever brought before the people of Australia. I will tell the House what a few Australian people thought of this arrival tax. I quote from an article in the Melbourne Herald of 22 February this year:

SPEECH.PARA: Australians among the passengers were especially blunt. `I think it stinks', said Mrs Helen Drews.
A leading figure in the tourist industry said in an article in the publication Inside Tourism of 25 January this year:
Industry critics of the tax include Thomas Cook Managing Director, John Massey, who said taxes on travel in Australia were now among the world's highest.
Visitors to Australia should go home without feeling ripped off by a savage tax unequalled anywhere in the world.
The Australian Tourism Industry Association said in March this year:
Our members advise that: The fee is such an irritant that visitors returning overseas are beginning to bad-mouth Australia.

That is what people felt about this tax. It is a very fair analysis of what people were saying about it generally and it is a very fair assessment of what it was doing to our tourist industry. It was doing immeasurable damage to an industry which has spent many years and a great deal of effort and money trying to build up a very good reputation around the world. As a result of that tax and the illogical nature of it, more than 200,000 people refused to pay it in its first few months of operation. A total of 200,000 people were prepared to break the law and suffer the consequences, purely and simply because they reckoned the tax was wrong. And wrong it was. If this Government was going about introducing charges in a proper way and was looking at this type of charge, the most logical thing to do would be to add the arrival tax to the departure tax and have one tax collected on one occasion so that it minimised the amount of bureaucracy and cost in collecting it. But, no. The logical things are impossible for this Government to do. This Government has to have two forms of taxes, collected in two ways, with two costs of collection and twice or even three times the problems associated with it.

As a result, the airline industries of Australia, which are lumped with the responsibility of collecting the tax, will probably have to fork out in excess of $4m from their own pockets in order to pay for the arrival taxes that were not paid by passengers arriving in this country. Indeed, that $4m may well be extended because many Australians and international visitors now know that this tax is to be axed as of the end of next month. As a result, the rate of refusal to pay it will increase quite substantially. If this Government had tried to look at the best interests of our airline industry, it would have said last night, `As of midnight last night the arrival tax ceased to operate'. But, no, it said, `At the end of the next month the arrival tax will cease to operate', thus sending a clear signal to everybody that they should not bother to pay it. As a result, the airline industry will be further out of pocket. That is one of the biggest mistakes that this Government has made in scrapping the legislation.

The legislation was doomed right from the outset. The whole philosophy behind it was wrong. Fancy placing a tax on Australians in order for them to return home! That philosophy is wrong. We are Australians and this is our country. We have a right to return to it and we do not have to pay a tax to get into it. What would happen if we refused to pay it? Would we be told, `Sorry, you can't come home till you pay.'? That is ridiculous, and all Australians saw it as such. The other ridiculous nature of the tax was that the Government refused to police it. Customs officers at our barriers were told to ignore completely whether a ticket had or had not an arrival tax stamp on it. They were told, if it did have an arrival tax stamp on it, not to negate that stamp and, consequently, people were able to use the stamp time and again if they were frequent travellers. It was an administrative nightmare. How on earth does one collect such a tax? The Government did not assist the airline industry at all in the manner in which the tax should be collected. It refused to assist in any way at all.
