SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sharp Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I was saying earlier, the arrival tax was one of the most ill-conceived and poorly thought-out taxes ever imposed on the people of Australia. It was one of the most difficult to administer. Indeed, it was described by the industry as an administrative nightmare. No-one in the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs had really thought out how this tax was supposed to work. I believe that the Department had not given it proper consideration. Indeed, the Government obviously had not known what it was going to do with the nearly $17m it had estimated would be raised through the imposition of the arrival tax.

SPEECH.PARA: It became very clear from questioning the various immigration Ministers overtime that there was no clear plan as to what they were going to do with the funds raised. For example, when Mr Young, the former Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, who has now fled this House for more lucrative pastures, first announced the introduction of the arrival tax he said that it would be used to pay for immigration services provided at airports. Later on, his successor, the present Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Holding), when asked in Question Time one day what the money would be used for, said it would be used for the purpose of upgrading airport facilities. Later on, in another Question Time in this House, as a result of a question asked by me, the same Minister said that the money would be used for the purchase of new technology to speed up passenger flow at our airports. It was quite obvious from the three separate statements on the proper purposes for the use of these funds raised by the new tax that nobody had a clear idea what was to be done with them. There were three quite separate and quite contradictory explanations of uses by the respective Ministers. Obviously, it had not been very well thought out.

The Government continually refused to offer advice to help the airline industry with the collection of the tax. As a result of that the airline industry has been left with a bill of more than $2m from the collection of the tax so far. It was so poorly thought out that no-one thought to charge sea passengers arriving in Australia who use the same immigration services as airline passengers. Thousands of sea passengers were coming in each month, but nobody involved in the drafting of the legislation or the planning of the Bill had decided that they should be charged for the same services that airline passengers were being charged for. Also no-one realised that about 90 per cent of all services that are provided at the barriers at our international airports are provided not by Immigration but rather by the Australian Customs Service. Customs officers stand at our barriers and check passports and immigration details as passengers come through. However, Immigration was the department collecting and receiving the benefits of the arrival tax, whilst Customs was being left out in the cold.

It is quite obvious that the excuse of using this tax as a means of paying for immigration services at our airports was not a just one at all. It was purely and simply a means of raising revenue for the general revenue purposes of this Government. Right from the outset there was no intention that the tax should be to cover the costs of immigration services at our airports. Another thing that the Government had not considered was that there are approximately 160,000 one-way passengers coming into our airports each year. Those 160,000 one-way passengers are called migrants. They come in and they do not go out. As the arrival tax was actually charged at the point of departure-rather an Irish way of doing things but the way that this Government chose to do it-all those 160,000 migrants did not get to pay the arrival tax. Obviously the airlines would have to make up the difference out of their own pockets, so the arrival tax was doing Australia's tourist reputation tremendous damage. That was well drawn out by people in the industry who were hearing views expressed by passengers travelling into and out of Australia. The honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay) in his comments tonight indicated some of the views he had picked up around the industry; people leaving the country were upset at having to pay this extra tax. One does not have to argue about the amount-that is not important; it is the principle that is important, and that is what was causing Australia's tourist industry to suffer so much damage.

It was not just the tourist industry that suffered damage. In the first few days of January the tax captured its first big fish in the form of the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett), who departed this land for an overseas trip somewhere, and in the process of departing forgot to pay his arrival tax. He, a Minister of the Cabinet, who would have been present at the time the Cabinet decided to impose this tax, would have been more aware of its presence than most other Australians, but he forgot to pay it. Although no doubt that was accidental on the part of the Minister, it highlighted the stupidity behind this tax and the fact that it was not going to work well. Ministers, people in the airline industry, travellers from around the world all had difficulty with it.

The industry was told by the Minister for Transport and Communications Support (Mr Peter Morris) when he announced the introduction of this tax that he had been in consultation with the industry and that the industry was quite excited about the thought of an arrival tax. When the tax was announced, it was news to the industry. Nobody in the industry had heard about it, and people were not excited about this new tax. The way the Government has treated the airlines, the tourist industry and international tourists coming into this country can only be described as cavalier. Australia's reputation as a tourist destination has been treated very poorly and it will suffer for a long time as international tourists return home giving the advice to other people, `Don't go to Australia; all they are interested in doing is ripping taxes from the travelling public'. It reflects the attitude of this Government towards tourism. The Government's attitude is, `Let's tax everything we can out of it; let's use those funds to put into the big pot for general revenue purposes'. It wants the money for other purposes. It highlights the fact that the Government is constantly out of touch with the will of the people.

The arrival tax was a disaster. It was designed by somebody who had no idea what he was doing and supported by somebody who had even less idea of what was going on in the tourist industry. I am pleased and proud that the Opposition was in the forefront of the attack against it and that as a result of our efforts and those of the industry, the airline operators and the tourists travelling into and out of this country we have been able to put the lid on one of the most ridiculous taxes this country has ever seen.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bill is a mini-Budget Bill designed to have local governments believe this Government is doing them a favour when that could not be further from the truth. The Federal Government is trying to dupe local government with referendum questions to constitutionally recognise local government. It is letting them think that the Labor Government has their best interests at heart. It is trying to do it all over again. In recent weeks the Labor Government has made three decisions regarding local government, all of which have not taken any major step in helping or benefiting local government. The first was the referendum question; a referendum that will cost Australian taxpayers $40m and will provide local government with no guarantees on the matters they require; that is, financial security, guarantees against dismissal and guarantees against amalgamation. The second was made last night with a $30m cut to road funding as brought down in the May economic statement.

Although the amendment is basically technical, if one were to believe the second reading speech of the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Holding), one would believe the Government was giving local government some great extra bonus. The purpose of the Bill is to amend the Local Government (Financial Assistance) Act 1986 to allow the Commonwealth Government financial assistance to local government to stay in line with previous years because the formula was changed at the Premiers Conference.

SPEECH.PARA: The Federal Government accepted the report of the Self National Inquiry into Local Government Finance in 1985 which said that local government should be treated on the same basis as State governments with regard to general purpose funds but it did not implement this system right away. In 1986 the Government made the guarantee that, in real terms, funding would be maintained. This is the first year that local government will be treated as equal with the States in general purpose funds. The Commonwealth defined general purpose funds in section 6 (5) (a) of the 1986 Act as including financial assistance grants, general purpose grants and identified health grants. This same formula was to be used to determine funding for the States as well as local government. However, the Premiers Conference changed the whole pattern for the States by lumping identified health grants with other minor health grants such as Medicare compensation grants and re-naming them hospital grants. In other words, the identified health grants disappeared in name only. This would have changed local government funding under the formula.

As the paper shows, the funds allocated to the States and the Territories for identified health funds for 1988-89 in the Estimates are to be nil. That document which was prepared in connection with the last Budget showed that up to 1987-88 the identified health grants were $1,782m whereas they have been eliminated in 1988-89. The Act was changed to recognise that no funds were being received under the identified health grants, as I just mentioned. The amendment is just compensating local government for the loss of this third category. It is not doing local government any particular favour, it is just amending the situation that it created; it is just like the referendum in that it is not really giving local government anything.

Furthermore, the Minister's second reading speech is misleading. It implies that the Government is actually increasing the amount of funding for local government. Instead, as I mentioned before, it is making an adjustment. However, if one looks at the funding figures in real terms, one will note that in actual fact there has been a loss of funding of about $17m for 1988-89, which is a drop of about 3 per cent. TALK.START.PARA: —As I have mentioned, the table shows that in real terms local authorities around Australia are receiving a smaller percentage of personal income tax. This is in spite of a promise made by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), going into the 1983 election, that his Government would guarantee real increases in terms of inflation rates. Of course, in 1983-84 and again in 1984-85, in spite of the efforts of the Minister of the day, there was a loss of $27m to local government because that promise with regard to inflation was not kept.

SPEECH.PARA: This is also an opportunity to draw attention to what I said earlier: the complaints that I have been receiving from local councils in my area over the past six months have been consistent. There have been complaints about a drop in the road funding which flows through from the Federal Government to local government. In fact, in my State of Queensland there have been massive conferences by all authorities, including councils, road construction authorities, the Royal Automobile Club of Queensland and any other interested parties. They have all been very alert to the fact that in the past five years under Labor there has been a loss of $300m in real terms in Federal Government road funding. Of course, this has flowed down. I have also received complaints about the reduction in the general purpose grants and particularly the way that they have been redistributed on a per capita basis eventually away from where they are needed. In fact, the Government is tying conditions, which did not previously apply, to the grants. They are the types of complaints that I have been getting. In all of that time, I have not received one complaint about the fact that local government is not being constitutionally recognised; and I have asked my colleagues what their experience has been in this regard. So what we see in this referendum proposal is a smokescreen. This was properly described--

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a sop.

—It is a sop. It was properly described by the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay) in Caucus, where he said that the Federal Hawke Labor Government is in bad odour with local government because of its attitude towards road funding. What happened to the honourable member? He got rolled and the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) took him to task for what he did. He now has to show himself in this House-although he is not showing himself at present and I do not blame him for not doing so. Of course, his seat of Herbert also houses the Minister for Local Government (Senator Reynolds), and she has to take blame for this too.

SPEECH.PARA: I just want to place on record what the conservatives did for local government when they were in office. It was that Government that first gave to local government a fixed funding arrangement through personal income tax sharing. That Government also provided for representation of local government to the States Grants Commission and the Australian Council of Local Government Associations. My good colleague the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt) was responsible for the bicentennial levy of 2c per litre, which has now been indexed--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is the only injection of good blood.

—That is right. That indexed amount is no longer going to roads. The Liberal and National parties also provided an extensive submission to the Self National Inquiry into Local Government Finance, and, as I mentioned earlier, we set up the Advisory Council for Inter-government Relations.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to contrast this with the Labor record. This Government disbanded the Advisory Council for Inter-government Relations in 1986. As I mentioned earlier, it pegged back the 2 per cent of personal income tax to a figure of 1.65 per cent in 1988-89 terms. While the Labor Government indexed the bicentennial road levy introduced by the honourable member for Gwydir, it has reduced road funding by $300m, or 25 per cent, over the last three years. It set up the Constitutional Commission at a cost of $6m and ran a referendum costing $40m at a time when it still did not have funds to put into local roads and the road plan. What hypocrisy!

TALK.START.PARA: —What an outrage!

—What an outrage. We can hardly bear to think about it. The local government provisions in the referendum do not include the Australian Territories. The Federal Government is also currently proposing to form Aboriginal compacts and councils and, under the terms of that referendum, a scheme for local government could well be included. The Labor Government also introduced quarterly payments of grants, again reducing the funding to local government. So it is hypocrisy for this Government to provide this sop and this smokescreen when it is in real trouble. Honourable members opposite should not think that, over the recess, we will not be telling every local council, every authority and every person who is interested in this matter exactly the way in which this Government is treating them and, in particular, the way this Government treated them last night. The Opposition is not opposing the legislation.

DEBATE.TITLE: PRIMARY INDUSTRIES (RECOVERY OF LEVY COLLECTION EXPENSES) BILL 1988[COGNATE BILL:FERTILISERS SUBSIDY AMENDMENT BILL 1988]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 25 May, on motion by Mr Barry Jones:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that it is the wish of the House to debate the Primary Industries (Recovery of Levy Collection Expenses) Bill concurrently with the Fertilisers Subsidy Amendment Bill. If there is no objection, the Chair will allow that course to be followed.

DEBATE.TITLE: PRIMARY INDUSTRIES (RECOVERY OF LEVY COLLECTION EXPENSES) BILL 1988

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: —At this absurd hour and subject to this restrictive guillotine, we have the Primary Industries (Recovery of Levy Collection Expenses) Bill and the Fertilisers Subsidy Amendment Bill to debate. When this Parliament's agenda was set we were to be sitting next week. The sensible situation would have been for this Parliament to sit next week so that there could be adequate debate not only for these Bills but for all the other Bills which are imposing increasing hardship on the country people of Australia, and to get the message through and to have questions answered here on the confusion, the contradictions and the imposts that are being put on those people.

SPEECH.PARA: The Fertiliser Subsidy Amendment Bill terminates the phosphatic and nitrogenous fertiliser bounties from 1 July with a saving to the Government of $50m. It ends quite a long period of parliamentary association and legislation, particularly with phosphatic bounties, which commenced in 1931. The nitrogen bounty commenced in 1966 and for most of that time there has been some form of bounty assistance. It was temporarily abolished by the Whitlam Labor Government in 1975. In that period Mr Whitlam went to Gippsland and said to the farmers of Gippsland and Australia, `You have never had it so good'.

TALK.START.PARA: —And we have never forgiven him.

—He was never forgiven. The termination of the fertiliser bounty was a symbolic feature in the country revolt against the Labor Government in the 1975 election. It was symbolic of the fact that the Labor Government had turned its back on the country people of Australia.
—Gippsland survived despite him.

—Gippsland is surviving well with its present member. If honourable members look at the symbolic situation concerning Labor turning its back once again on the country people of Australia, they will see the shameful situation of income equalisation deposits, which are so necessary for self-insurance by rural people, being delayed unnecessarily for 12 months until 1989 instead of commencing from 1 July 1988.
—It is deliberate.

—It is a deliberate delay. That is symbolic-as with the fertiliser bounty in 1975-of the way country people feel about this Government. Since January 1986 the bounty has been paid only on locally produced fertiliser. Special compensation payments have been made to importers to offset dumping duties on imported fertiliser. The situation at that time raised the question of actually who is helped by the bounty. Is it the farmers of Australia or is it the local fertiliser manufacturers?

SPEECH.PARA: 26 and 27 May 1988 REPRESENTATIVES
REPRESENTATIVES 26 and 27 May 1988
26 and 27 May 1988 REPRESENTATIVES

The Opposition parties will not oppose this legislation. It is Budget legislation. Country people recognise that all sectors of our society must share in reduced government expenditure. There have been distortions in the purpose and coverage of the bounty since the new arrangements in 1986. It is of declining value. It is $13 out of a cost per tonne of $130 to $140-10 per cent or less. I can remember in my younger days as a farmer when the percentage was several times higher than it is now. The continuation of the bounty nowadays creates a negative image for rural people with other sectors of our society because it is seen by those people, incorrectly and unfortunately, as somehow or other part of a massive subsidy arrangement for the farmers of this country when in reality the degree of assistance for agriculture is about half that of the manufacturing sector.

So it was in this situation earlier this year that the National Farmers Federation (NFF), through its President, Mr Ian McLachlan, proposed a trade-off with this Government. Ian McLachlan, in his final speech to the National Farmers Federation conference here in Canberra on 18 May-only a week or so ago-stated that part of this trade-off was as follows:

. . . we said that all that aside, on an all or nothing basis, as a special arrangement across the board, we were prepared to give up the superphosphate bounty as long as we could buy fertiliser at world prices, and as long as the tariffs were removed from parts for agricultural machinery not produced in Australia.

That is what Mr McLachlan said, only a week ago, reiterating what the NFF genuinely considered was a trade-off in return for the termination of that bounty. I now quote from the speech of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) in this House last night after the presentation of the May statement. He said:
. . . the Government is disposed to grant duty free entry on agricultural and mining equipment and parts not made in Australia.
I make this point: the Government is `disposed'; it has not made a decision; it is not at this stage keeping its part of that deal.

26 and 27 May 1988 REPRESENTATIVES

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope the farmers are disposed to give him a good kick.

—Yes, to dispose of him, as a part of it. So the Government is on trial with the farming community of Australia. Its credibility is very much at stake at present. The point in particular is that the farmers of Australia are watching in relation to this situation. The Government will make its decision following an Industries Assistance Commission inquiry, but the farmers are taking the Minister at his word, believing there will be and requiring duty free by-law admission of any agricultural machinery parts not made in Australia. I am not saying `not capable of being made in Australia' or `not where someone else intends to make those parts in Australia', but `not made in Australia'. I want to make that important distinction. I can give honourable members an example of this: too often in the past by-law admission has been refused because somebody has indicated that he has an ability or an intention to manufacture something.
—Sometimes never.

—Yes, sometimes never-and the tariff remains. I give a specific example-agricultural lasers, which for years we fought to get by-law admission for so we could get on with the job of improving the salinity situation in the Murray Valley. Because of one person who kept on claiming he was going to make an agricultural laser there was an unnecessary cost to people for years. I want to make it clear that the farming community will not tolerate that sort of situation with agricultural machinery parts in relation to the deal that it believes it has made with this Government. So let the Government be warned. Not only does the by-law admission come in but it comes in completely for machinery parts not made in Australia-no ifs or buts-and capable of being or intended to be made in Australia.

The second part of the deal was to allow the Australian farmer to buy fertiliser at world prices. The National Farmers Federation is concerned, as are the coalition parties, that because Australian farmers have to compete at world prices in exporting and keeping this country viable they are entitled to purchase their fertiliser at world prices. This means that timing will be critical for the Government with the section 96 grants it has been making, compensation measures, and the removal of anti-dumping duties

Unless this happens there will not be genuine access at world prices to fertiliser for use by Australian farmers. We know that world prices for fertilisers have risen. They were tipped to rise in Australia, and they have now firmed. Conversely the amount of phosphate rock that we get from that tied situation existing with Christmas Island is declining, and the very high cost of the shipping service is declining as a part of the final cost of fertiliser in Australia. The shipping arrangements are better now than they were several years ago. But the only way to make sure that Australian farmers are able to compete and have access is to allow fertiliser to be freely imported, or grant the ability to import, so that there is this access to fertiliser at world prices. After all it was only last night that the Government showed how brutal it can be in requiring world efficiency in the citrus industry, the sugar industry, the dried vine fruits industry and the dairy industry. The viability of all regional and coastal Queensland, with its sugar industry, has been threatened. The very least the Government can do is to allow some access to fertilisers.

The second Bill, the Primary Industries (Recovery of Levy Expenses) Bill 1988, enables the Commonwealth to recover from agricultural industries the cost of collecting and disbursing funds raised through industry levies and charges. The Government will raise $1.93m out of a total of $95.7m collected, or 2.2 per cent of the collection. This is petty and it is pathetic. The Government will do anything and everything to recover everything possible from the farm sector. It will extract anything at all that it can get its hands on.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't they leave it to compete with subsidised farmers overseas?

—The honourable member is right. It is part of the $100m in extra charges and taxes that this Government imposed last night on the rural sector of Australia. What did it do to the other sectors of Australia? Nothing like it, even although agriculture already has less assistance and has to compete more in the world.

SPEECH.PARA: I would be interested to hear of an equivalent government cost recovery collection arrangement in another sector of our society, such as the Public Service. I would be very interested to hear whether the same degree of cost recovery, of chasing every last dollar, goes on in other sectors. I believe this action is particularly petty because the rural sector of this country makes a greater commitment to research than any other sector of our society. That is one of the reasons why it is more efficient. Even when farmers' average income was one-third of average weekly earnings of this country they still made a contribution to research and promotion. There is nothing like this in the manufacturing industry.

Some years ago I was shadow Minister for health. The Labor Government cut medical research grants. That was poor of it. I talked to the doctors of this country and suggested to them, `Why don't you do the same as the farmers of this country and put up some of your own money?'. That was a little bit too much for the doctors, whose incomes are far higher than those of farmers, to accept.

I go further and mention the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO). Look at what this Government is doing with rural research funds through CSIRO. It is diverting the money from rural research and requiring a higher percentage of farmer provided finances as a part of total research. This is a good example of this Government hitting that sector, a sector that has done more to help itself through its commitment to research than any other sector. Once again, because this is a Budget Bill, the Opposition coalition will not be opposing it, but I think it is petty and I think it is pathetic.

TALK.START.PARA: —These Bills, the Primary Industries (Recovery of Levy Collection Expenses) Bill and the Fertilisers Subsidy Amendment Bill, are made easier by the emergence over the past few years of a different type of farm leadership in Australia, and Ian McLachlan is someone I have had differences with on a number of occasions over the past few years, particularly at Cooma last year when I criticised his call for cuts in road funding by $100m. I am pleased to say that in the recent Budget the Government did not accept that sort of advice and in fact funding to local roads has not been reduced at all in real terms. What Mr McLachlan did do was take the farming industries out of the realm of politics, particularly the long association they had had with the National Party of Australia. Gone are the days of the McEwen influence, and that was referred to earlier today. Assistance to agriculture by the Federal Government was approximately 16 per cent for 1986-87, compared with 19 per cent to manufacturing. I appreciate that there is quite a good deal of assistance to dairying. The extraordinary ability of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) to cooperate with the dairy industry has meant that a lot of difficulties in a number of States, particularly New South Wales and Victoria, have so far been overcome to the extent that the industry is adapting, and I believe will adapt so that it does not receive the same level of protection, just as will the citrus and vine industries. Primary industry will soon be able to say to other industries: `Do as we do'. It is getting to that stage now. I believe that by 1992-93 the assistance to primary industry will have dropped to approximately 11 per cent from the present 16 per cent.

One of the features of the Bills we are discussing removes the fertiliser subsidy. That was so difficult to do in the days of the Whitlam Government, but there has been a change of attitude by farming industries, and the fertiliser subsidy has been removed with much less complaint than at that time. This is partly due to the negotiating skills of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, and partly due to the fact that the National Farmers Federation is sincere in its desire to see Australian markets freed from protection. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 8 October 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: What action will be taken to ensure the long term safety and viability of the Commonwealth-owned East Hills pedestrian footbridge crossing the Georges River and linking the Division of Hughes with the Division of Banks.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The bridge was originally constructed in 1950 by the Commonwealth to provide access across the river for the local Naval establishment and the East Hills Migrant Hostel. In 1976 the Hostel closed and at that time responsibility for repair of the bridge was picked up by the Department of Defence.
Although the bridge was constructed by the Commonwealth I understand the question of ownership is a matter of conjecture, given that it is constructed on State land.

In view of Defence's historical involvement with the bridge and the fact that it does not require consideration under the Lands Acquisition Act, I wrote to the Minister for Defence as the appropriate action Minister to pursue the future of the footbridge. Defence has agreed to fund repairs to the bridge and through my Department to negotiate with State and Local Government Authorities on ongoing management and future responsibility for repairs and maintenance.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 25 November 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What items of merchandise are advertised on the ABC and sold through various outlets.
(2) How many employees are involved in producing and selling the items.
(3) What is the (a) gross and (b) net income from the sale of these items.
(4) Which items return a profit and approximately what is the profit expressed as a percentage.
(5) What costs are involved in selling through non-ABC owned outlets.
(6) What is the average weekly (a) number and (b) length of time, of merchandising commercials (i) telecast on ABC television and (ii) broadcast on ABC radio.
(7) What would be the approximate cost of this advertising if commercial advertising rates were charged.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport and Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question, based, in part, on information provided by the ABC:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Section 29 of the ABC Act 1983 provides that the Corporation may, in such manner as the Board thinks fit, make, promote, circulate and distribute any article or thing bearing a mark that is associated with any programs, concert or entertainment of the Corporation. Consequently, the Marketing Division is given access to broadcasting time on ABC Radio and Television to promote books, records, tapes, compact discs, videos, spoken-word cassettes, toys, clothing and posters.

This merchandise comes from two sources: it is either produced by ABC Marketing on behalf of the ABC or purchased from other suppliers who have the Australian ancillary rights to program-related products broadcast on the ABC.
The retailing of ABC products is through the ten ABC Shops in Australia (one in each capital city, one in Newcastle and one in Parramatta).
In addition, the ABC, through its distributors, has products available for sale in all major book, music and video retail outlets.

(2) ABC Marketing employs 88 people-25 employees are directly involved in producing and selling merchandise while the ten retail outlets employ 18 full-time shop staff plus casual staff when key selling periods so dictate.
(3) (a) The gross income from the sale of ABC merchandise outlined in (1) above for the year ending 30 June 1987 was $8.97m;
(b) The net income for these items for the year ending 30 June 1987 was $3.72m.
(4) All products marketed by the ABC Marketing Division are designed to be profitable, at one level or another. All items sold return a profit at the gross level.

ABC Marketing is charged by the Board of the Corporation with improving margins, reducing costs of sales and the provision of an overall profit. The level of net profitability achieved by the Division ranges between 45 and 48%.
(5) Products are sold through non-ABC owned outlets in two ways:

ABC books, records, cassettes and video products are distributed by external distributors. ABC books are sold to the distributor at a competitive market trade discount and no further costs are involved. ABC records and video products are manufactured externally and products are purchased by the ABC Shops from the manufacturer in the same manner as any other retailer.

ABC products are sold by Mail Order. This is carried out by an outside fulfilment house. The main costs involved with this activity are an appropriate fee to the fulfilment house; plus the costs of the catalogues and the telephones to service this activity.

(6) The average weekly number of ABC Marketing promotions on ABC Television is 30 in an off-peak period and 4 in a prime-time slot. As far as ABC Radio is concerned, promotional messages for ABC Marketing products amount to 25 per week on Radio National and 50 per week on the Radio Metropolitan capital city network.
The average length of promotion on ABC Radio and ABC Television is 30 seconds.

(7) Based on 1987 commercial prices (employing the capital city network) it is estimated that ABC Marketing receives the equivalent of $30,000 worth of Television time per week. The equivalent of $10,000 worth of Radio time per week is received from ABC networks.

It must be understood, however, that ABC Marketing does not only utilise the promotional facilities of its broadcast networks. A considerable amount of money is spent in a traditional commercial promotional arena. As an example: the entire ABC Mail Order program embraces direct marketing and telephone marketing costs which are bought at traditional commercial rates.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 10 December 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Further to his statement to the House concerning Cambodia (Hansard, 7 December 1983, page 3404), what progress has been made since then towards a resolution of tensions posed by the Cambodian conflict;
(2) What specific initiatives has Australia made towards this process of resolution, and what results have followed from those initiatives;
(3) What are the present goals and priorities now in Australian policy towards the conflict and what further role can Australia play.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) During the past four or five years several proposals and counter-proposals have been put forward concerning ways to achieve a peaceful resolution of the Kampuchean issue. Unfortunately, there has been little real progress towards settlement negotiations.

Australia has been encouraged by Prince Sihanouk's recent efforts to achieve a peaceful settlement, notably his separate talks with the Prime Minister in the PRK regime, Mr Hun Sen, in December 1987 and January 1988, and with Khmer Rouge leader Mr Khieu Samphan in February. Prince Sihanouk has made it clear, however, that a peaceful settlement will only be achieved if, in addition to Vietnam, the other major international parties with an interest in the dispute-China, the Soviet Union and Thailand-feel that their national interests are protected.

Australia has also welcomed the efforts of the previous Indonesian Foreign Minister, Dr Mochtar Kusumaatmadja, to promote dialogue on the issue. On 29 July 1987 Dr Mochtar, who was the designated ASEAN interlocutor with Vietnam on Kampuchea, signed a joint press release with the Vietnamese Foreign Minister, Mr Nguyen Co Thach, proposing talks between the four Khmer factions, followed by a wider meeting bringing in other concerned countries. Prince Sihanouk recently affirmed his support for this proposal. The new Indonesian Foreign Minister, Mr Ali Alatas, seems keen to continue this initiative.

(2) Australia has tried to assist where possible in facilitating a peaceful settlement in Kampuchea. Australia has not sought a central role, but has sought to stimulate and support the efforts of those more directly involved to establish dialogue.

Australia has been able to contribute in this way because of our long-standing friendship with the ASEAN countries, our good relations with China, our ability to talk frankly and productively to the Soviet Union and our relationship with Vietnam.

After the tripartite resistance body, the Coalition Government of Democratic Kampuchea (CGDK), issued an 8-point plan aimed at producing settlement negotiations in March 1986, I wrote to the Indonesian Foreign Minister Dr Mochtar Kusumaatmadja, Vietnamese Foreign Minister Mr Nguyen Co Thatch and Prince Sihanouk suggesting that there were positive elements within the 8-point plan that could be built upon. In particular, I said that the question of the status of the Heng Samrin group (PRK) and the Khmer Rouge might be a suitable issue to address, thereby conveying Australia's interest in encouraging dialogue on matters of substance.

As mentioned above, I have also corresponded with others about conditions for a peaceful settlement of the Kampuchea question. I have also put forward several specific initiatives. At the ASEAN Post Ministerial Meeting in Jakarta in July 1984 I suggested a meeting between the ASEAN countries on one side and Vietnam and Laos on the other without preconditions. I offer Canberra as a venue. Although the proposal was not taken further at the time, it has remained on the table with a number of other proposals for meetings of the principal parties.

In the view of a number of countries, including Australia, a major obstacle to progress has been the continued presence of the Khmer Rouge within the Coalition Government of Democratic Kampuchea. While Australia accepts that any settlement will have to take into account the Khmer Rouge rank and file, we are firmly of the view that such a settlement must also include arrangements to prevent the return to power of the murderous Pol Pot group.

With this in mind, I raised the question of establishing a tribunal to determine the culpability of the Pol Pot leadership at the 1986 and 1987 ASEAN Post Ministerial meetings. While some interest has been shown in the proposal, it has not, to date, attached the necessary degree of international support to allow it to go ahead. The process involved in exploring this issue has, however, proved most useful in clarifying the thinking of a number of the principal parties towards the Khmer Rouge. In particular it has enabled the Vietnamese (and the PRK) to identify for the first time Khmer Rouge leaders who in their view would be acceptable in future negotiations.

In addition, my Department is funding a series of academic seminars on conflict resolution in Kampuchea hosted by Griffith University. The first seminar was held in June/July 1986 and the second is scheduled for May 1988.

(3) Australian policy on Kampuchea remains as set out in my statement to the House on 7 December 1983. Australia shares the principles of the ASEAN countries on the Kampuchea issue and has each year voted in favour of the ASEAN resolution on Kampuchea at the United Nations General Assembly. Like the ASEAN countries, Australia continues to deplore and protest against the invasion of Kampuchea by Vietnamese troops. Australia hopes that an eventual resolution of the problem will see self-determination for the Kampuchean people; the safe return of displaced Kampucheans to their homeland; and the withdrawal of Vietnamese forces from Kampuchea, matched by arrangements to prevent the return to power of the Pol Pot group. Any solution to the Kampuchean issue will also need to satisfy the legitimate security concerns of Vietnam, Thailand and other regional countries.

Australia recognises that substantive negotiations and major initiatives are a matter for the principal parties. What we have done and will continue to do is to encourage movement among those parties as opportunities arise.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 10 December 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) In view of the weight given to Professor H. Hughes' article about the International Fund for Agricultural Development (IFAD), and subsequent funding decisions, will he present to the House the advice from the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau concerning Australia's support of IFAD post 1992 and its special program for sub-Saharan Africa; if not, will he present the assessment on which Professor Helen Hughes based her advice.
(2) What advice had he received, other than the views of Professor Hughes', from his Department or from any other source in support of, or in opposition to, his decision to terminate IFAD funding.
(3) Will he present the reasons for Australia not supporting IFAD's special program for sub-Saharan Africa.

(4) Will he initiate a review of the funding decisions announced, so that Australia's attitudes may be based on current information about IFAD's effectiveness, including the recent statement by the US President that IFAD offers a brighter future around the Globe and new evidence of US support for IFAD's programs.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's questions is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Professor Hughes was referred to as a convenient and authoritative public source. If the Honourable Member wishes to discuss Professor Hughes' views further I would suggest he make contact direct with her.

(2) An IFI Review was prepared internally by AIDAB as a Cabinet-in-Confidence document. It is not therefore available for public distribution. I also received representations in support of IFAD from individuals and groups with a particular interest in the Fund. I understand that a group called ``Results'' has been particularly active in lobbying on IFAD's behalf.

(3) The Government considers the International Development Association (IDA) as the major multilateral channel through which Australia gives assistance to countries in sub-Saharan Africa. Australia will be contributing $A335 million to IDA's $US12.4 billion eighth replenishment. Donor countries have agreed that between 45 and 50 per cent of IDA-8 resources will be directed towards countries in sub-Saharan Africa. This means that, in effect, Australia will be supporting IDA commitments to Africa of approximately $A50 million per annum over the next three years.

Furthermore, Australia is providing a new package of assistance totalling $100 million over three years for the nine member countries of the Southern Africa Development Co-ordination Conference (SADCC)-Angola, Botswana, Lesotho, Malawi, Mozambique, Swaziland, Tanzania, Zambia and Zimbabwe; $15 million is programmed for disbursement this financial year. This program represents the largest percentage increase in funds for any region in the Australian aid program. The broad focus of the program is the promotion of food security in the region and a reduction of the SADCC states' dependence on South Africa.
(4) The decision to make no further contribution to IFAD was not taken lightly and the Government is not at this stage planning to review the decision.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 22 February 1988:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 22 February 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Which aims and objectives of the Organisation of African Unity does the Government support.
(2) Is he able to say which countries are members of this organisation.
(3) Is he able to say which of these countries are ruled by one-party systems and which countries are not.
(4) Is he able to say which of these countries presently have democratic elections.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The aims of the Organisation of African Unity are set out in its charter which was adopted when the Organisation was set up in 1963. Article 2 of the charter contains the following purposes:
(a) To promote the unity and solidarity of the African states
(b) To coordinate and intensify their cooperation and efforts to achieve a better life for the peoples of Africa
(c) To defend their sovereignty, their territorial integrity and independence
(d) To eradicate all forms of colonialism from Africa, and
(e) To promote international cooperation, having due regard to the charter of the United Nations and the Universal Declaration of Human rights
In order to achieve its purposes the OAU charter provides that ``the member states shall coordinate and harmonise their general policies, especially in the following fields:
(b) Economic cooperation, including transport and communications
These aims and means are shared by all the members of the Organisation and Australia supports their achievement.

(2) The following countries are members of the OAU: Algeria, Angola, Benin, Botswana, Burkina Faso, Burundi, Cameroon, Cape Verde, Central African Republic, Chad, Comoros, Congo, Djibouti, Egypt, Equatorial Guinea, Ethiopia, Gabon, The Gambia, Ghana, Guinea, Guinea-Bissau, Ivory Coast, Kenya, Lesotho, Liberia, Libya, Madagascar, Malawi, Mali, Mauritania, Mauritius, Mozambique, Niger, Nigeria, Rwanda, Sao Tome and Principe, Senegal, Seychelles, Sierra Leone, Somalia, Sudan, Swaziland, Tanzania, Togo, Tunisia, Uganda, Zaire, Zambia, Zimbabwe.

Note: The Western Sahara was admitted to the OAU in February 1982 but its membership is disputed by Morocco and some other states. Australia does not recognise the independent state of the Western Sahara (the so-called Sahrawi Arab Democratic Republic). Morocco withdrew from OAU membership as a consequence of the admission of the ``SADR''.

(3) The majority of African countries feature a one-party system of government. Some others maintain a multi-party system of government while a number of African states have military governments. The Honourable Member can find details in several reference books in the Parliamentary Library. Good starting points for this research are ``Africa-South of the Sahara'' and ``The Middle East and North Africa'', both of which are published on a yearly basis.

(4) See my answer to 3. The question of whether or not elections are democratic requires value judgments. For example, a number of countries with one-party systems feature regular elections in which numbers of sitting members lose their seats. Others offer less freedom of choice. There is, therefore, a range of variation and it is not possible to be categoric on which countries have democratic elections.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs, upon notice, on 24 February 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What are the arrangements for itinerant workers and other Australians who change residence regularly to enrol to vote and when were these arrangements implemented.
(2) How many persons sought this type of enrolment for the 1987 general election.
(3) What arrangements are undertaken to ensure that there is no dual enrolment and that this enrolment is not manipulated for political purposes.
(4) Did the Australian Electoral Commission undertake a reconciliation of itinerant enrolment with the record of actual votes cast; if so, what was the result of this reconciliation.
(5) How is the electoral division of enrolment determined and how is this substantiated.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Home Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1), (3) and (5) The Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 was amended by the Commonwealth Legislation Amendment Act 1983 to provide, under section 96, for the enrolment of itinerant electors, that is, persons who are in Australia but do not reside in any subdivision and are by reason of that fact alone not entitled to have their names on the Roll for any subdivision. Such persons can apply to have their names enrolled for the subdivision in that State (a) where their next of kin is enrolled; (b) where they last had an entitlement to be enrolled; (c) the subdivision in which they were born; or (d) the subdivision with which they have the closest connection. Where an application is received by a Divisional Office, the staff check whether there is already a person on an electoral roll in the State with the same name and date of birth as the applicant. The application form (with a recommendation) is forwarded to the Australian Electoral Officer for his decision. A computer check is made of the electoral roll to ensure that the enrolment is not being duplicated.

(2) and (4) In the period from 1 December 1984 (the date of the previous general election) to 12 June 1987 (the close of rolls for the 1987 election) 1,300 persons sought itinerant enrolment. A total of 1,261 applications were granted. On a State-by-State basis, the figures were as follows:

After a general election the DRO checks the Non-Voters List against the Register of Itinerant Electors. Those itinerant electors who fail to vote lose their entitlement to be treated as itinerant electors. A total of 962 itinerant electors (out of 1,261) voted for the 1987 election.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Philippines: Allegations of Diversion of Funds to the CPP/NPA

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 25 February 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will he initiate an inquiry by our security services to determine whether any money raised from the public by Australian overseas aid agencies for welfare purposes has been diverted to assist the activities of the Communist New Peoples' Army in view of the address given by the Catholic Archbishop of Manila, Cardinal Sin, on 4 February 1988 to the Foreign Correspondents Association of the Philippines, in which the Archbishop said that money given to the Catholic Church's welfare agency could not be controlled by the bishops and was believed often to be diverted to aid and develop the Communist New Peoples' Army, rather than to help Filipino families living in poverty.
(2) Will he undertake to make public the findings of such an inquiry.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The Government is aware of claims, including those of Cardinal Sin, that funds provided by West European and Australian overseas aid organisations have in some cases been diverted to the Communist Party of the Philippines (CPP) and its military wing, the New People's Army (NPA).

The Government is naturally concerned by these claims as the violent activity pursued by the CPP/NPA against the democratically elected government of the Philippines is opposed by the Australian Government and it is contrary to Australian values. The Australian International Development Assistance Bureau (AIDAB) has mechanisms in place to assess carefully all NGO projects funded by the Government. These mechanisms are considered to be appropriate and effective.

The issue of any illicit diversion of funds by Philippine organisations to the CPP/NPA is a matter for the Philippine authorities. The Philippines Government is reported to have asked some foreign governments for assistance in investigating similar allegations made late last year. No request has been made of Australia nor has any evidence been provided which would substantiate the claims that have been made. The question of a possible inquiry by Australian security services therefore does not arise.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 15 March 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many senior officers of the ABC work in the Corporate Division referred to in the 1986-87 ABC Annual Report.
(2) Has this figure increased since 1978: if so, by how much.
(3) What sum did the ABC spend on salaries and contract expenses for ``star'' performers, including Mike Walsh, since 1983.
(4) How many persons has the ABC employed on short-term contracts since 1983.
(5) What is the cost to the ABC in salaries and other expenses of those employed on short-term contracts.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport and Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question, based, in part, on information provided by the ABC:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The ABC's Senior Executive Service is defined differently from that of the Australian Public Service. The ABC includes all those officers whose classification corresponds to APS class 10 and above, whereas the Public Service classes Level 1 and above as members of the Senior Executive Service.

There are 58 senior officers in the Corporate Division of the ABC. This Division includes Corporate Management which has responsibility for the entire ABC, as well as Human Resources, Finance, Corporate Relations, Corporate Policy and Planning, Legal and Administrative Services, Management Information Systems, Internal Audit, Overseas Offices and Territory Management. In addition to their Corporation-wide responsibilities, these officers are responsible for approximately 750 staff and expenditure of approximately $65 million.

(2) Yes. By 19, particularly in Finance, where the ABC has been improving its financial systems; Management Information Systems, where there has been a major expansion in computer services since 1978; and in Legal, where the additional professional expertise is justified by less reliance upon outside counsel.

(3) ``Star'' performers is not a definable employment category within the ABC. Whether engaged as artists or as staff, the ABC has never needed to distinguish in its overall expenditure between ``star performers'' and ``others''. An aggregate costing for top performers alone is not available. Typically salaries for top performers range from that for a lead actor $966.15 per week, reporter commentator $80,000 per annum, comedy actors in major series $4,500 per episode.

The Mike Walsh Show shown on ABC-TV in 1987 was a co-production between ABC TV and Hayden Productions Pty Ltd. The contract required Hayden Productions to provide the services of Mike Walsh and six production staff. The remuneration of Mike Walsh and staff was not the ABC's responsibility and this information is not available.

(4) While it is not possible to provide an historical analysis of short term contract employment since 1983 because such records have not been maintained, it is possible to provide a current breakdown. At present, the ABC has 514 contract employees. In addition, there are 530 fixed-term temporary employees and, approximately 218 casual employees. The first group is employed by a contract drawn up by the ABC's Legal Department, the second group is employed by a staff engagement approved by the appropriate delegate, and the third group are employed strictly on an as-needed basis.

(5) The ABC has never needed a system to distinguish between the salaries and expenses payable to full-time staff employed on a contract basis and those payable to permanent officers. The fact that the composition of staff employed on short-term contracts changes continually makes any manual calculation impracticable. Costing and justification for short-term engagements is done on an individual departmental basis within an overall policy of keeping this form of employment to a minimum.
Totals are kept for expenditure on artists and casual staff: for the 86/87 financial year the amounts were $15.235 million and $5.614 million respectively.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Trade Negotiations, upon notice, on 15 March 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What are the goals of the Cairns Group of countries.
(2) Which countries are members of the Cairns Group.
(3) What progress has been made so far by the Group.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The broad goals of the Cairns Group, as expressed at its inaugural meeting, are the reform and liberalisation of world agricultural trade. The Group agreed to pursue its goals through the Uruguay Round of multilateral trade negotiations and through other appropriate international fora.

The Group's goals are elaborated in a joint proposal that was announced by Prime Minister Hawke and tabled in the Negotiating Group on Agriculture of the Uruguay Round in October 1987. The proposal seeks a long-term framework wherein all access barriers and subsidies affecting trade are eliminated, apart from defined exceptions, and which is underpinned by strengthened GATT rules and disciplines. This would be achieved by means of a reform program involving the systematic reduction of agricultural support levels and access barriers. The proposal also seeks agreement to early relief measures to ease the severe distortions affecting agricultural trade.

(2) The members of the Cairns Group are: Argentina, Australia, Brazil, Canada, Chile, Colombia, Fiji, Hungary, Indonesia, Malaysia, Philippines, New Zealand, Thailand and Uruguay. (With the exception of Fiji, all are GATT members).

(3) The Cairns Group has become a recognised effective coalition on agricultural issues in international negotiations including especially the GATT Uruguay Round. It worked successfully to ensure that an acceptable negotiating program for agriculture focusing on both access and subsidy issues was adopted. It has also been instrumental in influencing attitudes to the agricultural reform process reflected in the outcomes of last year's OECD Ministerial Meeting and the Venice Economic Summit. The Group's subsequent negotiating proposal in the Uruguay Round for reforming agricultural trade has been widely recognised as a comprehensive contribution which is central to that negotiating process. By maintaining cohesion and unity of purpose, the Cairns Group has come to be regarded as an important and effective influence-a third force-in the negotiations alongside the United States and the European Economic Community. No individual Group member could have achieved such prominence and impact. The diverse nature of the Group has served to strengthen its impact.

The Group is seeking to maintain the momentum of the Uruguay Round negotiations. An important opportunity to consolidate and accelerate the negotiating process will be presented by the proposed Mid-Term Ministerial Review of the Uruguay Round, to be held in Montreal in December.

At the recent Cairns Group Ministerial meeting at Bariloche, Argentina, which I chaired, the Group agreed on a negotiating strategy designed to extract firm commitments to the elements of a long-term framework for agricultural reform and for immediate implementation of measures-a downpayment-to set that process firmly on track. There are formidable obstacles to be overcome but the Cairns Group will be making every possible effort in Geneva and elsewhere to achieve an international trade environment for agriculture free of subsidy distortions and access restrictions.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Trade Negotiations Committee of the Uruguay Round

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Trade Negotiations, upon notice, on 15 March 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the Trade Negotiations Committee of the Uruguay Round of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.
(2) What is the status of the Committee in relation to GATT.
(3) What is the significance of the agreement to hold an end of year meeting of the Trade Negotiations Committee in Montreal in December.
(4) What do Committee members expect to achieve at the meeting.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Trade Negotiations Committee was established by Trade Ministers at Punta del Este, Uruguay, in September 1986, to oversee the Uruguay Round of multilateral trade negotiations. The Committee, which can meet at Ministerial or official level, is the co-ordinating body for the negotiations and has authority over all subsidiary negotiating bodies.

(2) The Committee has no status within the existing legal framework of the GATT. However, the Committee is the supreme co-ordinating body for the Uruguay Round which is being conducted under the auspices of the GATT. At official level, it is chaired by the Director-General of the GATT. It was established by Ministers meeting on the occasion of a Special Session of Contracting Parties of the GATT and is comprised of the 96 members of the GATT and some 10 countries which are not GATT contracting parties. As the supreme co-ordinating body for the negotiations, it oversees negotiations on trade in goods, which take place within the current legal framework of the GATT, and trade in services, which because they are not presently covered by the GATT legal framework, take place separately but in parallel with the negotiations on trade in goods.

(3) The decision to hold a Ministerial level meeting of the Trade Negotiations Committee in Montreal in December is significant for a number of reasons. Firstly, it reflects the degree of urgency which the Uruguay Round participants attach to finding solutions to the problems in the world trading environment. Second, it emphasises the need for and importance of maintaining the momentum of the negotiations. Third, it affords Ministers the opportunity to review progress at the mid-point of the Uruguay Round and to restore its political impetus.

(4) The expectation of most Uruguay Round participants is that the meeting in Montreal will maintain momentum and renew the political commitment to negotiations on all elements in the Punta del Este Declaration. Where appropriate, the meeting would also provide an opportunity to endorse any interim agreements which might have emerged from the negotiations. The extent to which such a package will include substantive reforms is dependent on progress in negotiations this year. For its part, Australia will be looking to the meeting to translate the positive trade reform rhetoric of the past eighteen months into practical reform measures, for example, in the areas of agriculture, services, market access barriers and the GATT institutions. While an interim reform package for agriculture remains a priority, progress in a number of other areas of the negotiations suggests that agreement on a broad range of reforms is possible provided that participants continue for the remainder of 1988 to engage fully in the negotiating process.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Trade Negotiations, upon notice, on 15 March 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What progress has been made to date in the Uruguay round of the Gatt multilateral trade negotiations.
(2) What progress has been made in areas of benefit to (a) Australia and (b)Third World countries.
(3) What attention has been given in the negotiation groups to the issue of special and differential treatment for Third World countries which was mandated by the Punta del Este Declaration.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Good progress was achieved in the first year of the Uruguay Round, compared to the Tokyo Round. There have been few delays over preliminaries despite the much greater complexity of negotiations on issues such as intellectual property rights, the functioning of the GATT, agriculture and services trade. Concrete proposals are ``on the table'' in a majority of negotiating groups. In major areas of interest to Australia, such as agriculture and services, proposals indicate a preparedness by participating countries to contemplate change. However, some negotiating groups have yet to address the substance of the more fundamental issues confronting them.

Despite efforts by many countries to identify areas where interim agreements may be reached in the December 1988 Mid-Term Review, a very difficult period of negotiations lies ahead. This is particularly so in regard to world agricultural reform. At the recent informal meeting of Trade Ministers at Lake Constance (20-22 March 1988), the latest in a series of Round-related informal consultations, public statements made by the major players gave little, if any, confidence of any resolution of the problems of protection in world agricultural trade by the time of the Mid-Term Review.

(2) (a) Australia's interests in such key issues as agriculture, market access, subsidies, services, intellectual property rights, dispute settlement, safeguards and the functioning of the GATT system have already been well established in the Uruguay Round negotiations. The breadth and scope of our interests in the negotiations, which extend well beyond Australia's traditional orientation towards agriculture, was a point clearly conveyed to GATT members by the Prime Minister in Geneva in October 1987. That being said, progress in reducing agriculture protection is, of course, a priority goal for Australia.

Generally, while the discussion on achieving fairer international trading conditions has moved in the right direction over the last twelve months, this has yet to be translated into concrete results in the Round. The meeting at Lake Constance, for example, evidenced a reluctance on the part of some of the major players in the Round to take early decisions on issues such as agriculture, non-tariff measures, trade in services and natural resource-based products.

(2) (b) The Cairns Group of Fair Traders in Agriculture is perhaps the most visible proof of the common aims shared by Australia with Third World countries in relation to the Uruguay Round negotiations. Currently ``on the table'' in the negotiations, for example, is a Cairns Group proposal whose fundamental aim is to provide the means to achieve fully liberalised trade in agriculture, to eliminate distortive agricultural policies and to bind the necessary undertakings under strengthened GATT rules and disciplines. In addition, issues of interest to Australia, such as natural resource-based products and market access for tropical products, are also big issues for a significant number of developing countries. So far in the negotiations, little progress has been made in the area of natural resource-based products. Tropical products, however, have been given priority in the Uruguay Declaration which launched the Round. Consequently, there is a generally favourable disposition by key participants in the Round to move quickly to substantive decisions in this area.

(3) Some but not all developing countries are preoccupied with ensuring that the issue of special and differential treatment is addressed in a number of negotiating groups, such as safeguards, agriculture, dispute settlement, etc. Other developing countries have realised that until firm and defensible rules are set in place, it is premature to consider to what extent developing countries need to have special and differential treatment. As negotiations are still under way and largely in the early stages, there has been no conclusive discussion on the issue.

However, the principle of differential and more favourable treatment for developing countries applies to all elements of the Cairns Group proposal to the Uruguay Round Negotiating Group on Agriculture, including early relief measures. These elements include certain support measures in relation to domestic economic programmes to promote economic and social development, which are not explicitly linked to export purposes.

Also, recognising the importance of tropical products for developing countries, the Punta del Este Declaration provided that negotiations in this sector be given special attention, including the achievement of early agreements. The Australian negotiating proposal, to be tabled in full at the next meeting of the Negotiating Group in April, is intended to highlight market access problems which need to be resolved. It does not specifically address special and differential treatment for developing countries, since our approach is that negotiations should be between importers and exporters of tropical products, irrespective of whether a country is industrial or developing. It is our view that such an approach would offer the best prospect of achieving secure and improved market access.
It should be noted that Australia is the only developed country to accord, automatically and without exception, a margin of preference to all developing countries across its whole tariff.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 16 March 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is he able to say whether the Prime Minister signed letters to be sent out to families regarding the Family Allowance Supplement (FAS); if so, (a) how many letters were sent, (b) to whom were they sent, (c) what amount did the (i) printing and (ii) postage of these letters cost and (d) were there any other associated costs.
(2) If there were other costs, what (a) was their nature and (b) sum was incurred on each item.
(3) Was it originally intended that (a) regional managers or (b) other persons would sign the letters; if so, which other persons.
(4) Were these letters (a) signed and prepared for despatch and (b) recalled; if so, what happened to them.
(5) If the letters were recalled, (a) who made the decision, (b) (i) when and (ii) why was the decision made and (c) is the decision regretted.
(6) Was the FAS reduced to pay for the money wasted by recalling the letters; if so, how many families are still below the poverty line because of this action.
(7) Will anyone (a) resign or (b) be dismissed over the decision to recall the original letters; if not, why not; if so, who.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (5) Letters over the Prime Minister's signature about the Family Allowance Supplement (FAS) were sent to all families on the Family Allowance register in December 1987 and March 1988. The first batch went to 322,000 families with three or more children, not in receipt of a pension, benefit or FAS. The second batch went to about 1.35 million families with one or two children, not receiving a pension, benefit or FAS. Costs associated with the first mailout were $92,897 made up as follows:
Costs associated with the second mailout were $310,604 made up as follows:
The letters were printed on the Department's laser printers.

For the first mailout letters were initially printed with ``Regional Manager'' as the sender. I decided to review the proposed approach to the mailout against the background of the overall FAS publicity and information strategy. Given the Government's commitment to obtaining the highest possible take up of FAS, it was decided that the letters would have greater impact if they were sent over the laser printed image of the Prime Minister's signature, rather than as ordinary Departmental correspondence.
This approach proved to be very successful and was followed up by the second similar mailout in March 1988. Again there was a very successful response.
The cost of letters printed before the change in strategy was $9,843 made up as follows:
The change of approach certainly is not regretted. It has proved to be very successful and cost effective reducing the need for expensive broad media advertising.

(6) This question shows a lack of understanding of the appropriations process. FAS is paid from appropriations separate from those of the Department's administrative expenditures. In any event the cost of $9,843 compares with current expenditure of approximately $14 million per FAS payday.
(7) These issues do not arise. The project was extremely successful and cost effective.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs, upon notice, on 20 April 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Under what circumstances can an elector have his or her address recorded on the electoral roll as a postal address, in particular a postal office box, rather than his or her residential address.

(2) When habitation reviews are undertaken, what arrangements are made to check the residential qualifications of those persons who record a postal address, in particular a post office box number, on the electoral roll.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Home Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There are no circumstances under which an elector can have his or her address recorded on the electoral roll as a postal address unless that address is also his or her residential address.
For the purposes of contacting an elector by post, provision is made to separately record a postal address.

(2) When habitation reviews are undertaken, the review officer is supplied with a list of all electors in all habitations in the area under review. Those electors who have supplied postal addresses which are different to their residential addresses are included on this list for their residential addresses and a physical check is made at their residences.
A postal address of an elector is for postal purposes only.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Community Services and Health, upon notice, on 21 April 1988:

These are located in the following areas, and serve a designated catchment area surrounding the unit's location or, in the case of specialist units, they provide services to clients from the overall population in co-operation with other regional units and community resources:

(b) The following facilities have client accommodation in the adjacent area:

(9) The established regional network of the CRS means that clients are now able to use CRS facilities close to their home rather than travelling to major metropolitan centres. Many of the new regional units which replaced the centres were particularly well placed, geographically, to take on the former clients of the major centres when they closed.
